original: We propose and analyse a smoothing-free version of the "Petrov-Galerkin" method for the Helmholtz problem with a large  for a numerical simulation of the radiation and wave field. As trial functions, we use standard, continuous, positive, Q1-finite elements at a coarse discretization scale $H$, while the test functions are based on the solutions of local problems at a finer discretization scale $h$. The support of the test functions is then given as a function of the  dimension, the size of which depends on a certain oversampling factor. $m$ cdot $log(kappa)$ and $h$ is sufficiently small, the method is stable and quasi-optimal in the regime where $H$ is proportional to $kappa-1$. In a homogeneous medium (or, more generally, periodic), the fine-scale test functions depend only on the local mesh structure, and therefore the numerical cost of the test functions can be drastically reduced on structured meshes. We give numerical experiments in two and three dimensions.

As already mentioned, region-based methods have proven useful for improving the segmentation accuracy of neuronal structures in EM images. Most of these methods rely on a scoring function to determine the merging of regions. These scoring functions are usually learned by supervised learning with large amounts of ground-truth data, which are expensive to obtain. We propose a semi-supervised learning approach that reduces this need. By using a tree-based structure for region merging, we develop a differentiable unsupervised loss that forces the learned function to make consistent predictions. We then propose a Bayesian model that combines the supervised and unsupervised information for probabilistic learning. Experimental results on three EM image data sets show that, with only a small subset of the ground-truth data, 3-7% of the total amount, our method can achieve performance very close to the best fully supervised method using the full ground truth.

In this paper we propose a new class of dynamic mixture models (DAMMs) which can sequentially adapt the mixture components and the mixture composition based on information coming from the data. The information-driven nature of the proposed class of models allows us to calculate exactly the full likelihood and to avoid simulation schemes. Extensive Monte-Carlo experiments show that the new proposed model accurately represents the more complex Stochastic Dynamic Mixture Model, which was proposed in the literature. It also demonstrates that the new model can be used to accurately approximate the Stochastic Dynamic Mixture Model, which was introduced in the last issue of the work, and other similar models. The properties of the new proposed class of models are discussed throughout the paper. We also report on an application to financial econometrics.

Deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been shown to perform very well on a variety of tasks, including tasks related to driving, such as image segmentation and object recognition. However, the training of these networks requires large amounts of data and a long time to converge. In this paper, we first examine the design principles of end-to-end driving networks by presenting three small and inexpensive end-to-end neural network models that generate driving control signals directly from input images. In contrast to previous work that mainly focuses on image processing, our network is designed with a novel approach to the driving task, using a very small number of cheap layers and low-cost deep convolutional neural networks to tackle a complex end-to-end regression task that predicts both the yaw rate and the accel rate. In addition, we design layers that are optimized for classification so that the network can implicitly learn image semantics. We show that the resulting networks are trained three times faster than the most recent comparable end-to-end driving network and 500 times faster than the AlexNet variants and are still more accurate and more robust to overfitting.

We present sound and complete behaviour bisimilarities for a variant of Dybvig et al.’s calculus of multi-prompted delimited control with dynamic prompt generation. The derivation of our new principles generalizes and extends existing methods for establishing program equivalence in calculi with a single-prompted delimited control. The core of the theory that we develop is presented in the framework of Madiot et al., which allows the smooth integration and composition of bisimulation methods up to now. We further generalize this framework to allow us to express bisimulations on evaluation environments, enabling equivalence proofs for evaluation contexts representing continuations. This change leads to a new and powerful technique for bisimulation proofs in the presence of control operators.

Stochastic ADMM is a popular solution for large-scale learning problems. Stochastic ADMM is to reduce the per-iteration complexity, which is more suitable for big data problems. More recently, in order to speed up the convergence of ADMM, it has been combined with various variance-reduction methods, such as SAG-ADMM and SVRG-ADMM. These methods still have some weaknesses in terms of convergence speed, and their convergence speed with the smoothing constant is not very good. In this paper, we propose a fast stochastic ADMM with variance reduction, which is much faster than existing ADMM, and theoretically prove its convergence speed, which is a theoretical guarantee of the smoothing constant. We also verified its effectiveness and compared it with other common methods.

“Markov random fields are a common modeling technique for a variety of pattern recognition and reconstruction problems in robotics and vision. Unfortunately, inference in MRFs is usually intractable, and related work generally resorts to approximation methods. Among these, semidefinite programming relaxations have proven accurate, but scale poorly and are typically too slow for practical applications. We present two contributions: the first is to use a dual-ascent method to speed up the solution of standard SDP relaxations by utilizing the geometric structure of the problem. This method, known as the Dual Ascent Riemannian Staircase, can solve large instances in seconds. The second contribution is to develop a second, faster method based on a new relaxation of the problem, which requires only a linear addition to solve. It is combined with a fast, scalable solver based on smooth Riemannian optimization. We show that this method, known as Fast Unconstrained Semidefinite Escalator, can solve large instances in milliseconds. Unlike local MRF solvers such as belief propagation, our methods require no initial guessing. Moreover, we take advantage of recent results in convexity to ensure that each solution is approximately sub-optimal. We test these methods on multiclass image segmentation problems. Extensive experiments demonstrate that (i) FUSES and DARS produce near-optimal solutions with an objective  within 0.1% of the optimal, (ii) FUSES is more than two orders of magnitude faster than DARS, but with similar accuracy, and (iii) FUSES outperforms local solvers while achieving the same approximate quality.

We show a general class of unbounded operators in Banach spaces whose local spectral radius can be determined at certain points. For such operators we show that the local spectral radius is analogous to that for a globally defined bounded operator on a Banach space with the single-valued extension property. In practice, an operator of the above class appears as the (extension of) a differential operator which, roughly speaking, can be diagonalized on its domain of smooth test functions by a discrete transformation, and where the said transformation establishes an isomorphism between the space of the differential operator in its own topology and a sequence space. We present examples of such (extended) operators (differential operators with constant coefficients on the d-th tori, Jacobi operators, Hermite operators, Laguerre operators) and we indicate further prospects.

A recent study has shown that when the attention mechanism is used in image recognition, the edges of the foreground, that is, the parts of the image representing the healthy tissue, are disproportionately classified as background, resulting in a high false-negative error rate. To combat this high false-negative error rate, we introduce a novel attention mechanism called Pay Attention to Mistakes. The proposed mechanism has two complementary implementations: (a) “explicit” attention focusing on a larger Efficient Receptive Field on the foreground; (b) “implicit” attention focusing on the false positives, by focusing on a smaller Efficient Receptive Field on the background. We tested the proposed mechanism on three tasks: (a) the prediction of the densely spaced vehicle in the Cityscapes dataset; (b) the enhancement of the tumor core in the multi-modal MR images used for BRATS-X; and (c) the segmentation of the stroke lesions using ultrasonic images at ISLES-NaNaN. Our results were compared with state-of-the-art attention mechanisms in medical images, such as self-attention, spatial attention, and spatial channel-mixed attention. For all three tasks, our models outperformed the baseline models in terms of IoU and/or HD. For example, in the second task, the “explicit” implementation of our mechanism reduced the HD of the best baseline by more than 26%, while improving the IoU by more than 3%. Our proposed attention mechanism will benefit a variety of medical and vision tasks that suffer from over-detection of the background.

3D image segmentation plays an important role in biomedical image analysis. Many 2D and 3D deep learning models have been reported to achieve state-of-the-art results in the segmentation of 3D biomedical images. However, both 2D and 3D models have their own advantages and disadvantages, and by combining them together, one may be able to get more accurate results. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning framework for 3D biomedical image segmentation that combines the merits of 2D and 3D models. First, we design a meta-learner that learns to improve the results of 2D and 3D models by using a fully convolutional network, and then we propose a new training method to minimize the overfitting of our advanced meta-learner, using the results of 2D and 3D models as the "ground truth" of the meta-learner. Our new method does not rely on hand-annotated data, and it can be used to train the model with a large amount of unlabeled data. The results of experiments on two public data sets (the HVSMR 2016 Challenge and the mouse piriform cortex) show that our method can achieve good performance in fully supervised, semi-supervised and unsupervised learning modes, and it can outperform the state-of-the-art methods.

A FAACUSATION ON THE FACADE OF A CITY IMAGE, taken from a DUCT, involves several peculiar difficulties in contrast to a FAACUTE OF AN IMAGE FROM A PHOTO. A FAACUTE OF AN IMAGE FROM A CITY STREET, is the most difficult of problems. A FAACUTE OF A STREET is a mosaic of the two: the two elements are highly corroborative and varied in their characteristics. In this paper we propose three distinct ANN architectures of varying complexity, which are intended to achieve multi-label semantic segmentation of facade images by exploiting their peculiar properties. We propose a MULTIFACSEGNET, a low-rank ANN architecture for extracting rectangular elements, and a COMPATIBILITY ANN which seeks simultaneously the segmentation of the various elements of the facade. Our results on a well-known dataset demonstrate significant improvements over the state of the art for a variety of elements on the facade, including an accuracy of 0.97 on windows, the most important architectural element.

Given a commutative ring A, a “formal A-module” is a formal group equipped with the action of A. There is a classification ring of the formal A-modules. The article proves structural results on the classifying ring and on the moduli stack of the formal A-modules. A result is proved that, given a certain generator of the group H1_fl (M_fm_Z), which also generates, through the Adams–Novikoff sequence, the first stable homotopy group of the spheres, we obtain the generator of the formal A-module H1_fl (M_fm_A_2-buds; ) for any torsion-free Noetherian commutative ring A, for any torsion-free commutative ring A. We prove that the order of the formal A-modules H1_1_fl(M_fm_A_2-buds; ) and H2_fl (M_fm_A_2_buds) is 2N_1 where N_1 is the leading coefficient in the leading local zeta function of A. The cohomology of the formal A-modules is closely related to the symplectic structure on commutative rings studied in commutative algebra. In particular, the homology of the largest ideal of A which is in the kernel of any homomorphism of commutative rings is given by H0_fl (M_fm_A_2-buds; ). H0_fl (M_fm_A_2-buds; ) is zero only if A is a ring in which the symplectic structure on this ideal is zero.

For several decades now, random fields have been of considerable interest for purposes of inference, especially in image processing. The local nodal interactions which are usually employed in these models are, however, subject to the short-term boundary bias problem, which is largely corrected by the addition of long-range nodal interactions. The problem of tractability becomes very important when long-range nodal interactions are incorporated, particularly when large numbers of long-range nodal interactions are modeled, as in fully-connected random fields. In this paper, we introduce a generalized random field framework, based on the concept of the Stochastic Clique, which provides a stochastically constructed sparse representation of the random field, enabling efficient inference with fully-connected random fields without any restrictions on the potential function which may be used. We discuss and evaluate several implementations of the proposed framework with graph cuts, and experimental results show that the proposed framework is able to provide efficient structured inference in fully-connected random fields, with excellent results for the task of image segmentation, compared to existing fully-connected and principled deep random-field frameworks.

This regression is of great interest in the modelling of spatial point processes in ecology and public health, for example, to determine whether the geographical or geographically defined environment is a significant modifier of the spatial associations between events and the outcomes. If we extend these regressions to clustering, then the likelihood-based inference becomes difficult to compute because of the complexity of the likelihood and its score function. It is therefore interesting to consider estimation procedures based on simpler likelihoods. We derive an estimation procedure for the class of first-order estimating functions. The estimation procedure depends on the solution of a Fredholm integral equation, which in practice is solved by numerical integration. The approximate solution is equivalent to a quasi-likelihood for spatially defined, binomial data, and hence the term quasi-likelihood is used to denote our approach of using the optimal estimating function. We show by simulation and an example with data that the quasi-likelihood-based method for spatial point processes is statistically and computationally efficient.

The gauge formalism in teleparallel gravity is an interesting tool to describe interactions in the context of an anholonomic-observed tetrad. The algebra of the perturbed space-time with the Weitzenbock connection may be compared to a local complexification of the SU(4) Yang-Mills theory, which we call hypercolor or simply color. The formulation of the hypercolor dynamics is accomplished by a translational gauge, as in teleparallel gravity. This work, in particular, is concerned with the perturbation of a decomposition of a metric related to the Wilson line and the Kaluza-Klein metric, which gives a version of four-dimensional electrodynamics. The coordinates of space-time are now matrices representing elements of the SU(4) Lie algebra. To make the formulation of a colored gravity consistent with the Lorentz force and Maxwell equations, it is enough to place the energy potentials with zero potential at the event horizon, instead of the usual zero potential at infinity. The framework of colored gravity provides an abelian limit of standard electromagnetism.

Clustering is an important tool in data mining and has been widely used in many applications. In this paper, an extension of the Fuzzy C-Means clustering is proposed. Instead of the single membership value used in the original Fuzzy C-Means clustering, a multi-dimensional membership vector of each point is used instead of the traditional membership value. Each membership value of a point is obtained by considering each feature of the point and calculating the membership value for each feature. Moreover, an initial cluster center search method that closely converges to the real cluster center is proposed. This method is evaluated by analyzing two standard data sets. In addition, the effect of the proposed method is examined by comparing the image segmentation problem with the Fuzzy C-Means clustering.

This paper proposes a deep learning-based method for ranking response surfaces with application to financial mathematics. The underlying problem of ranking response surfaces is to efficiently determine the corresponding index to the minimal response in a continuous input space $mathcal X  MathBb$. By treating the points in the space of X as pixels and the corresponding response indices as labels, we can reformulate the problem as a classification problem in image segmentation, wherein an image is divided into a number of distinct regions, each of which has its own label. This provides an alternative way to solve the problem, as opposed to the sequential method that we used in our previous work (Hu R. and Ludkovski M., Journal of Uncertainty Quantification 5 (2017) 212–239). The approach is scalable and parallel, and since the solution is not subject to any model-free assumption about the form of the response surface, it is model-free. Finally, it allows us to apply a wide class of deep learning models for image segmentation, such as U-Net, Seg-Net and DeconvNet, which have been shown to be highly accurate in this field. We systematically study the dependence of deep learning on the input data generated by uniform grids and sequential sampling, and we observe that deep learning is relatively insensitive to the noise and the location (near or far from the boundary) of the training data. We show by a few examples, both synthetic and real-world, that this method is efficient and accurate.

We present observations of the high-intensity HeI 10830 line in 45 low-metal HII regions. We combine these NIR observations with optical spectroscopic measurements in order to determine the primordial He abundance. The HeI 10830 line, whose intensity is very sensitive to the density of the HII regions, greatly improves the determination of the physical conditions of the He+ zone. It results in a tighter regression Y — O/H than all previous studies. From these data, we have selected a sample of 28 HII regions with  > 150 A, O-2+/O  0.8, and He abundances determined to better than  3% accuracy. Using this sample, we derive a primordial He abundance Yp = 0.2551 +/- 0.0002 with respect to the sun. The derived Yp value is higher than that predicted by the standard big bang nucleosynthesis (SBBN) model. With our Yp, and D/H = (2.53) +/- 0.0004, we found that the best fit for these abundances is with a baryon density Omega b h2 — 0.02400 +/- 0.00008 at 68%, 0.02800 +/- 0.0002 at 95.4 %, 0.06400 +/- 0.0007 at 95.4 %, and a total number of effective neutrinos Neff = 3.58 +/- 0.24 (at 68% and 95%). At the 99% level, we find that the effective number of neutrino species is not exactly equal to one. This may suggest that there are additional species of neutrino.

Let A be a finitely generated integral domain in Z with characteristic 0. We study the Thue equation F(x,y)=b and hyperelliptic and superelliptic equations f(x)=bym, where F and f are coefficients of A, b is a non-zero element of A and m is an even positive integer. In our results we find an explicit upper bound on the size of x and y by the appropriate representations of A, F, f, b. Also we generalize a result of Schinzel and Tijdeman that there exists a constant C such that there exists no solution of f(x,y)=bym in A for which y is not 0 or a non-zero primitive root of unity if m>C. In our proofs we use effective results on the Thue equation, hyperelliptic and superelliptic equations over number fields and function fields, some results of effective commutative algebra and a commutative law.

Efficiency and ease in the segmentation of images and volumes is of practical importance. The segmentation problems that have inspired our method come from microscopy, a tool widely used in material science, medicine, and biology. We formulate image segmentation as a probabilistic pixel classification problem, and we use segmentation as a step towards characterizing the content of the image. Our method allows the operator to define the structure of interest by marking some of the pixels in the image. Because of the immediate feedback, the operator can place new marks in the image strategically, depending on the current classification results. Our method requires the construction of a graphical representation of the image content, which is built during initialization, unsupervisedly, and is based on clustering image features. As our method combines a limited amount of operator-marked data with clustering information obtained from the unmarked parts of the image, it falls within the general framework of semisupervised learning. We show that such a semisupervised strategy can be a very efficient one for image classification.

We present a method to deal with the ill-posed scales of the model in the context of the ensemble-transform Kalman filter (ETKF). It extends to this class of algorithms the deterministic model error formulation that has recently been developed for the extended Kalman filter. The necessary model uncertainty for the update of the state of the system is estimated from the increments of the reanalysis. Two different versions of the method are described: a time-constant model error treatment where the model error statistical description is held constant in time, and a time-varying treatment where the assumed model error statistical distribution is sampled at each reanalysis. We compare both methods with the standard method of dealing with the model error through the standard scheme of calibration and model error inflation, and illustrate our results with numerical simulations on a nonlinear system with chaotic behavior. The results show that the skill of the filter is greatly improved by the model error formulation, and that both methods require far less adjustment than the standard scheme. The proposed approach is simple to implement within an existing structure based on an ensemble. The general usefulness of the proposed method in the context of square-root filters such as the ETKF is also discussed.

GETTING A CONNECTION MAP FROM A TRANSMISSION-ELECTRON MICROSCOPIED IMAGE OF THE NEURAL CORTEX, TO DO SO, INVOLVES IDENTIFICATION OF NERVE CELLS AND CERTIFICATION OF INTERNECTIONS BETWEEN THEM. GETTING THEM BY HAND IS A VERY TIME CONSUMING PROCESS, AND IN ORDER TO MITIGATE THE DELAYED TIME, TO DO BYOUgD’S APPENDIX THERE HAVE BEEN COMMUNICATED. This disparity may be partly accounted for by several factors: obtaining neuronal shapes is an essential first step in obtaining a connectome, tracing is much more time consuming than annotating synapses, and neuronal contact areas may be used as a proxy for synaptic contact areas to determine connections. Also, in recent research, the contact area alone has been found not to be a reliable predictor of the synaptic contact. And as the methods for obtaining neuronal shapes have improved, the time for annotating synapses has become an increasingly significant portion of the total time for the reconstruction. This disparity is bound to increase further as neuronal shape reconstruction methods become better, thus limiting the possible speed up of the process. In this study, we have addressed this problem by developing an automatic method for obtaining both pre- and post-synaptic structures. The pre-synaptic structures are obtained using a deep and wide recursive neural network, and the post-synaptic structures are obtained using a neural network, with features based on the local neuronal shape. This method requires very little supervised training and takes advantage of recent advances in image segmentation. We introduce novel metrics to evaluate the performance of our system, and show that complete automatic prediction may provide an adequate account of most connections.

With probabilistic databases, query evaluation is generally intractable (#P-hard). Existing dichotomies have identified tractable queries, and associated them with tractable lineages. In our previous work, using a different tool, we have shown that query evaluation is linear time on probabilistic data bases for arbitrary monadic second-order queries, if we bound the treewidth of the instance. In this paper, we study restrictions and extensions of this result. First, we show that for probabilistic queries, the scope of monadic second-order tractability does not extend beyond bounded treewidth: even for queries of second order, there exist instances of graphs with unbounded treewidth that are intractable. This dichotomy relies on recent polynomial-time bounds on the extraction of planar minors, and also implies lower bounds in the non-probabilistic setting, for the evaluation of queries and the counting of matchings in the families of subinstance-closed families. Second, we show that our tractability result can be explained in terms of lineages: the lineage of MSO queries on bounded-treewidth instances consists of bounded-treewidth circuits, polynomial-size OBDDs, and linear-size d-DNNFs. Moreover, we strengthen the dichotomy for lineages, and show that for UCQs with disjunctions, the unbounded-treewidth query consists of an OBDD that is super-polynomial, and characterize them. Finally, we explain the tractability of safe queries by considering a set of instances with bounded treewidth.

This paper presents a new method for image segmentation, which combines the advantages of both conditional random fields and decision trees. In general, the potential function in the literature is defined by a linear combination of some predefined parametric models, and methods such as structured support vector machines (SVM) are used to learn these linear coefficients. Here we propose a new formulation for the potential function, which represents the unary and pairwise potentials as non-parametric forests, and then learn the ensemble and the trees as a single optimization problem in the framework of a large margin. This approach enables non-linear learning of both the unary and pairwise potential functions in the random field. Furthermore, we use the decision trees to represent the discrimination of each object in the image. Because of the rich structure and flexibility of decision trees, our method is powerful in representing complex data dependencies and class associations. The resulting large-scale convex problem is extremely difficult to solve because it has exponentially many independent and dependent variables. We show that this difficult problem can be efficiently solved by combining the column generation method with the plane cutting method. Experimental results on the one-class (Graz-02, Weizmann horse, Oxford flower) and two-class (MSRC-2, Pascal-Voc) datasets show the effectiveness of the learned non-linear, non-parametric potential functions.

The segmentation of two-valued images of porous media is a crucial step towards a deeper understanding of the factors governing the biogeochemical processes at a microscopic scale. In recent years, a large amount of research has been carried out, mainly on the basis of primitive methods based on the use of either a global or local threshold that is well known for its limitations in the image segmentation. Moreover, the lack of a unified and quantifiable standard limits the ability to evaluate existing methods. This paper addresses both problems. Firstly, based on a method of automatic segmentation developed for natural images, a method is proposed for the automatic segmentation of porous media images, named 3D Quantum Cuts (QCuts-3D), and based on the current state-of-the-art spectral clustering technique. Secondly, a data set of 68 images of porous media with various solid geometries and with a ground truth of phase in each voxel is prepared and made publicly available. We test the proposed method against other current state-of-the-art methods on this data set and find that the method is robust to variations in the composition of porous media.

But to train a DNN requires a large amount of annotated data, which is costly and time-consuming for medical image segmentation tasks. This paper presents a new, error-aware semi-supervised framework for the segmentation of the left atrium from three-dimensional MR images. Our framework can make full use of the unlabeled data, promoting consistency of the prediction for the same input under different perturbations. The framework consists of a student model and a teacher model, the student model learns from the teacher model by minimizing the total loss, including the loss of the training error, the overall loss, and the consistency loss. We propose a novel error-aware learning framework to help the student model learn from the meaningful and reliable labeled targets, by taking advantage of the available error information. Experiments show that the performance of the student model is greatly improved by the use of unlabeled data. Compared with the results of semi-supervised learning methods, our method outperforms them.

The task of polarimetric SAR image segmentation is currently of great importance for remote sensing applications. Nevertheless, it is a difficult task for two main reasons: Firstly, due to the high cost of the classification, it is difficult to obtain a large number of examples. Secondly, the required background information is not available in the image. Moreover, the speckle noise in the SAR images, which is inherent in the SAR image acquisition process, has a significant influence on the quality of the segmentation. In this paper, a context-aware semantic polarimetric SAR image segmentation method is proposed. The new channel-compatible feature set is used as the input to the three-dimensional discrete wavelet transform (D3) method to extract multi-scale features that are robust to speckle noise. Finally, a Markov random field is used to ensure the smoothness of the segmentation labels. The proposed method for the first time takes full advantage of the available background information to ensure accurate and smooth classification. To test the effectiveness of the proposed method, extensive experiments are carried out on three real polarimetric SAR images from the ALOS-2, ALOS and ALOS-2 Apertures, and the results show that the proposed method achieves excellent classification accuracy and spatial consistency with a small number of classified samples.

We consider weak convergence theorems of the quantum walk (DTQW) whose paths are based on intervals. We show that continuous-time quantum walk (CTQW) and discrete-time random walk (DTRW) can be expressed in the form of DTQW for certain limits. We first generalize our previous study [2 Physics Letters A 40 (5) p. 81-82, 1994] to general walks with variable step length. Further, we develop a new result on the DTQW with position measurements. We show that the step length has a unique probability distribution with probability p, where n is the final time and p is the time-step probability. Also, we give the continuous-time analog of the DTQW. Second, we introduce a new class of DTQW for which the absolute value of the diagonal of the quantum coin is proportional to a power of the inverse final time. In addition, we prove weak convergence theorems for this DTQW. This DTQW is named final-time dependent DTQW. We prove the weak convergence theorem for this DTQW which has a number of interesting properties. Third, we consider the final-time dependent DTQW with periodic position measurements. This weak convergence theorem shows a phase diagram which can be used to find the relation between the continuous-time and discrete-time random walk for sufficiently long times.

It has become one of the main lines of research. Medical image segmentation is often needed for the diagnosis of diseases in clinical evaluation. However, the images used in medical diagnosis are not smooth, and the results of the image segmentation method cannot be obtained. The first thing to do is to pre-process it. In order to get the most suitable method for medical image segmentation, we propose a two-stage segmentation method. The first step is to automatically generate a binary image using mathematical morphology, and the second step is to generate a 2D boundary using a convolution kernel. The boundary of the image is used as a mask image for the second step, and the GrabCut method is applied to the original image, and the image is efficiently segmented. The result can be further improved by using a graphical user interface. The results of the experiment show that the proposed method is accurate and that satisfactory results can be obtained with minimal interaction with the human brain in both medical and natural images.

Over the past few years, the community of computer vision has made a huge leap in semantic image segmentation, a pixel-wise classification task that is critical for dense scene understanding and which is already widely used in many real-world applications such as unmanned cars or medical image diagnosis. Recent models are now able to reach previously unimaginable performance numbers, such as 89% mean iou on Pascal VOC and 83% on Cityscapes, and although the performance measured by iou and other metrics provides a general view of performance, we are now going to develop other meaningful and important for the applications characteristics such as answering the questions “how accurate is the model at recognizing small objects in the general scene?” and “what causes the model to make an error?” Besides establishing a methodology that covers the performance of a single model from different perspectives, we will also show several extensions that are likely to be useful in further improving the current best result in semantic image segmentation.

We prove lower bounds on the energy of point particles in the Gaussian core model. For the potential with e-t  -alpha with 0  alpha  4 pi  e, we prove that for a density $rho$ on the sphere with radius $n$ and potential $t$  e-t -alpha t$ with 0  alpha  4 pi  e$, there is no point configuration in a sphere of radius $R$ with density $rho$ and -a -a (fixed) less than the expected value of energy $rho (pi  alpha) n  2$ as $n to infty$, with the alpha and the rho fixed. The proof is based on the solution of a certain interpolation problem similar to the one from the Beurling-Selberg problem. On the other hand, we prove that the upper bound for the energy is not asymptotically sharp when $alpha geq pi e$. As a consequence of our results, we obtain a bound on the energy under the inverse power law, $t to t n + s$, with $s > 0$, and these bounds are sharp up to a constant factor as $n to infinity$, with $s$ fixed.

Deep learning methods have a difficult generalization problem in the deployment of practical applications. For this reason, we propose a method for generalization, which is to learn a universal representation of the data from multiple source domains, and to improve the generalization of the network to the unseen domains. This paper first analyzes the generalization capability of neural networks by combining multiple consistency metrics and tries to determine which metrics are the most synergistic. Finally, we present a novel hierarchical consistency framework for generalization, which combines extrinsic consistency and intrinsic consistency. In particular, we enforce consistency by utilizing the knowledge of multiple source domains., and also use a Fourier-based amplitude Gaussian-mixing method to improve consistency. intrinsically, we enforce consistency between the same instance of data by using dual task formulations. The proposed HCDG framework is evaluated on two medical image segmentation tasks, namely the optic disc segmentation on fundus images and the prostate MR segmentation. Extensive experiments have proven the effectiveness and applicability of the HCDG framework. The source code will be available upon acceptance.

This paper deals with the problem of real-time semantic segmentation of high-definition images using a hybrid GPU/CPU architecture. We propose an Efficient Video Segmentation (EVS) pipeline which combines: (i) on the CPU, a very fast optical flow method which exploits the temporal aspect of the image and propagates the semantic information from one frame to the next. This process is done in parallel with the GPU. (ii) on the GPU, two convolutional neural networks: a main network for predicting dense semantic labels from scratch, and a refinement network which improves the predictions of the previous frame with the help of a fast inconsistency attention mechanism (IAM). This mechanism identifies regions that cannot be propagated with certainty. We recommend several operating points depending on the required frame rate and accuracy. Our EVS pipeline achieves accuracy levels comparable to those obtained with the most accurate real-time methods for semantic image segmentation (more than 60% IoU) while providing much higher frame rates. The operating points that we propose range from 80 to 1000 fps on a single GPU and CPU.

In our last [Sh:300a] we have only a thinly stable situation, and it seemed that we could not proceed further. We wish to develop a theory of models of $T$, which should be a complete theory in $mathbb L theta, theta tau$, provided that $theta$ is a compact cardinal. In treating ultrapowers (and ultraproducts) we restrict ourselves to $D$ a $theta$-complete ultrafilter on $I$, probably regular. Our basic theorems hold, but can we generalize the axioms of model theory, especially stability, and in particular generalize [Shc:2c, ch. 6]? We prove that we can characterize the models of $T$ which are minimal by Keisler order, i.e. where $D:D$ is a regular ultrafifer on $$ and where $M : T  M lambda r D$ is the saturated $$. We also manage to connect our study with the logic $mathbb L theta, theta tau$ introduced in [Sh:797]: two models are $mathbb L theta, theta tau$-equivalent if, for any $omega$-series of $theta$-complete ultrafinites, the iterated ultrapowers of the two models are equivalent.

With the development of Internet technology, social network and other related fields, user authentication has become an increasingly important method of protecting the data of the users. Password identification is one of the widely used methods of identifying legitimate users and preventing unauthorized users from accessing the system. There have been many password decryption methods in the past few years, and people have been designing a series of password cracking countermeasures. But I find that there is not much survey research on password cracking. This article is mainly to give a brief introduction to the methods of password decryption, the important techniques of password decryption, and the password protection countermeasures that are generally used in two stages: one is the password design (such as: password education, the use of tokens, the generation of passwords by the computer), the other is the after-design (such as: the use of mobile phones, the installation of the network. When you enter a password, it will immediately prompt you to enter a password, which can be used as a reminder. The implementation of access control). The main purpose of this paper is to provide basic knowledge for neophyte information security engineers and the general public, and to promote the development of this field. The keywords are: password decryption, password cracking, cryptanalysis, countermeasures.

On the other hand, advances in generative models and adversarial training have resulted in the growing image-to-image (I2I) translation literature. The current I2I methods require images from both domains, which are either paired (supervised) or unpaired (unsupervised). In practice, it is often very expensive and cumbersome to obtain the paired data. However, the unpaired I2I methods are still more widely used although they are less accurate. In this paper, we seek to bridge the gap between the supervised and unsupervised I2I methods with the application of semantic image segmentation. The I2I method is based on two key methods, pix2pix and CycleGAN. We introduce a method for selecting a small number of pairs to improve the performance of the supervised and unsupervised I2I translation methods, and we further improve the accuracy by including the (selected) paired samples and the unpaired samples together in the training. Our experiments show that an extremely weakly supervised I2I translation solution with only one paired training sample can achieve the same performance as the unsupervised CycleGAN model, which is much better than the supervised pix2pix model that was trained on thousands of paired images.

Meanshift is a popular mode-seeking clustering algorithm widely used in machine learning. However, it is well known that it is too slow, as the time required per iteration is quadratic. In this paper, we propose Meanshift++, a very fast mode-seeking clustering based on Meanshift, which uses a grid-based approach to accelerate the meanshift step by replacing the expensive neighbors search with the weighted mean of the neighboring cells. In addition, we prove the theoretical properties of the meanshift++ method. The time required is linear in the number of points and only exponential in the dimension, which makes it suitable for applications with low dimensions, such as image segmentation and object tracking. Our experiments show that Meanshift++ is at least 10,000 times faster than Meanshift, with similar clustering results on some benchmark data sets and similar image segmentation results on some data sets. Finally, we show that Meanshift++ has a good performance on object tracking.

Active contour models (ACM) have been widely used in computer vision and image processing. Recent studies have combined active contours with convolutional neural networks to replace the hand-designed energy function, in order to overcome the limitations of ACM, which rely on the parameterization of the energy function and initialization. However, these studies have not dealt with initialization, which is the main problem in the study. In addition to manual initialization, the initialization method is sensitive to the starting point and fails to accurately delimit the boundary. We propose a completely automatic image segmentation method to overcome the initialization problem, inadequate input range and insufficient border accuracy, as well as the energy function design problem. We use two convolutional neural networks to train active contour weights, obtain ground truth, distance transform, and initialization circle. The distance transform is a field in which each pixel in the image is mapped to the boundary of the nearest distance, and the energy is a function of the distance map. We test the method on four public image datasets: two buildings of Vaihingen and Bing Hut, and two breast images of INBreast and DDSM-BCRP. The test results show that our method outperforms previous research by 0.59 and 2.39 in the mean IoU, 7.38 and 8.62 in Boundary F-score in Vaihingen and Bing Hut, respectively. On the INBreast and DDSM-BCRP, the Dice similarity coefficients are 94.23 and 91.89. This shows that our method is comparable to the existing framework.

To meet the development of systems that are parallel and distributed, the active object model offers a high-level abstraction for the coding of concurrent operations. There already exist a large number of frameworks for active objects, aimed at a wide range of applications, such as modeling, verification, efficient execution. Among these frameworks, however, few are concerned with the parallel execution of active objects. Introduced into active objects, a parallelism that is carefully controlled allows some of their limitations to be overcome. We present here a framework of the multi-active object programming model, illustrated by ProActive, a library for Java which makes multi-active objects available, and MultiASP, a language for formalizing developments of this kind. We then show how to compile a language for active objects with cooperative threads into a language for multi-active objects. Finally, this paper also presents several use cases and the means of development, demonstrating the practical utility of our language. The formalization of our work gives the programmer a guarantee of the behaviour of the model of multi-active objects and of the compiler.

The search for the zero-neutrino double beta decay (onubetabeta) requires extremely low background and a thorough knowledge of their origins and their effect on the rate in the region of the parameter space, which is sensitive to onubetabeta. Here we report a study of beta and gamma background in the EXO-200 0nubeta experiment. We want to understand more precisely the place and the power of particular background sources and compare the results to radioactivity measurements made before and during the construction of the experiment. Finally, we discuss the significance of the study for EXO-200 and the future nEXO experiment, which will be a one-ton experiment.

FSS has many uses in medical image processing. Most of the existing FSS methods rely on an abundance of annotated semantic classes for training, which is difficult for medical images because of the lack of such annotations. Besides, there is a bias-free mechanism that is sensitive to training loss, which combines localized averaged filters and prototypes with the method of pseudo-labelling super-pixels. This paper presents a new self-supervised framework for medical images that completely eliminates the need for annotations during training and generates super-pixels based on pseudo-labels to be used as supervision; (2) an adaptive local pooling mechanism to overcome the problem of foreground-background imbalance in medical image segmentation; (3) three different medical image segmentation tasks are compared, including the segmentation of the gastrointestinal organs in a X-ray, the segmentation of the heart in a magnetic resonance tomography (MR) image and the segmentation of abdominal organs using CT. The performance of the proposed method was compared with that of conventional FSS methods which use annotated images for training.

The need for sign language is radically increasing especially among the deaf. Few research groups are working on automatic recognition of signs from videos, hand-painted gloves and the like. However, their approach requires proper data segmentation for both the training data and the data to be recognized. The recognition of sign language is very difficult because of the diversity of hand shapes and hand movements. This paper proposes a combination of image segmentation and restoring hand shape using topological derivatives for high recognition accuracy. Here, the quality of the resulting hand shape is compared subjectively and objectively. The experiment results show that the extra restoration before the image segmentation process is significantly improved the accuracy of hand detection and that the discrete derivatives give high discrimination between different static hand positions as well as between hand positions and background. This research is expected to contribute to the implementation of automatic sign language recognition systems, which are mainly for welfare purposes.

We propose a method of active learning of image and three-dimensional image volumes, which makes use of the geometrical information to speed up and simplify the annotation process. Our method combines geometric smoothness with other uncertainties to estimate the most informative voxels, which are the most instructive, and should be annotated next. In multiclass cases, we also introduce two new criteria of uncertainty. In three dimensions, we use the resulting uncertainty to select voxels that are on a planar patch, which is much more convenient for the end-user than a randomly selected voxel distribution in a volume. The planar patch is found by a branch and bound algorithm, which finds a plane in a three-dimensional volume, on which the most instructive voxels are. We have tested our approach on images of EM and MR volumes, as well as on regular images of horses and faces. Thanks to the geometrical uncertainty, we have obtained a significant increase in performance over previous approaches.

Characterizing the malignant areas in the three-dimensional magnetic resonance images is a crucial operation in the radiotherapy of cancer, which requires the fine contours of the tumor to be carefully outlined at the cost of labor, time and repeatability. While the deep learning-based methods are good bases for the task of 3D image segmentation, the patch is restricted in the restricted field and the segmentation performance is degraded. In addition, determining the region of interest from large whole-volume 3D images brings many benefits in terms of speed, accuracy and false positives. Unlike sliding window or non-joint localization-segmentation models, we propose a novel multi-task framework: the 3D Region-Aware U-Net (the 3D R-U-Net), which combines the tasks of region-of-interest localization and inside-out region-of-interest segmentation with the same underlying convolutional neural network. Encoding, using the area-representation proposals from the encoder, we can build a multi-scale inside-out region-preserving decoder for the digitized object. The applied volume and effective resolution are enlarged. To train the model effectively, we designed a Dice-like loss function for the global-to-local multi-task learning method. In addition, we use the advantage of performance to develop a hybrid framework that combines the functions of the different resolutions of the convolutional neural networks. The model's performance on 64 cancerous cases with a four-fold cross-validation showed significant advantages over existing methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency. In addition, the proposed method has a great potential to be extended to other 3D object segmentation tasks from medical images due to its inherent generalizability. The model is publicly available.

Multi-atlas segmentation (MAS), as introduced and popularized by the pioneering work of Rohlfing, Brandt, Menzel and Maurer Jr. (2004), Klein, Mensh, Ghosh, Tourville and Hirsch (2005), and Heckemann, Hajnal, Aljabar, Rueckert and Hammers (2006), is a multi-atlas approach to image segmentation that is one of the most widely used and successful methods in biomedical image processing. By taking advantage of a set of anatomical images (e.g., annotated by an expert), MAS is able to cope with anatomical variety, thus allowing better segmentation, but this flexibility has the disadvantage of high computational cost. Recent advances in both computer hardware and image processing software have addressed this challenge and have enabled a large-scale implementation of MAS. Today, MAS is a sophisticated and increasingly well-developed approach encompassing sophisticated and powerful methods that draw on the ideas of machine learning, probabilistic modeling, optimization, and computer vision, among others. This paper presents a survey of MAS methods and their application to a variety of biomedical problems. Our goals are threefold: First, we want to provide an account of how MAS was originally conceived, how it developed, and how it is compared to other methods. Second, we want to give a detailed account of the research activity in MAS over the past decade (2003–2014), including both methodological developments and application-oriented approaches. Third, we want to give our own view of the future of MAS, which we believe will continue to be one of the dominant methods in the biomedical image processing field.

An important task of image segmentation is the learning of dense prediction models so that they can produce accurate generalizations at difficult pixel locations. A typical group of such difficult pixel locations are boundaries between instances. Many studies have proposed to devote special attention to learning boundaries. Such strategies include using neural networks with the additional task of boundary prediction and boosting the importance of boundary pixel predictions in the loss function. Such strategies require a priori knowledge of where attention should be directed and how to encode it in the model. The difficulty is that there may be many other groups of difficult pixels, and to select and encode the appropriate attention for each group of pixels by hand would not scale. To provide a more general and scalable solution, we propose a new attention model based on boosting. AttentionBoost builds a multi-stage network and a new loss adjustment mechanism to let the dense prediction model learn what to pay attention to in each stage, based on data without requiring any a priori knowledge of what to pay attention to. The mechanism adapts the attention of each stage to the error of the previous stage by adjusting the weight of each pixel in the loss according to how well the previous stage did on that pixel. This mechanism enables AttentionBoost to learn different attentions for different pixels in each stage, depending on how difficult they are to learn, and multiple attentions for the same pixel in different stages, depending on how confident each stage is of its prediction for that pixel. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AttentionBoost using the example of predicting glands from radiographs.

By making a cut-out of a line pattern in a picture, a basic step is performed in various applications, such as detecting blood vessels in radiological images, the contouring of rivers and roads in aerial photographs, the detecting of cracks in walls and pavements, and so on. In this paper, we introduce trainable B-COSFIRE filters which are a model of the functions of some of the neurons of the primary visual cortex. These filters are tunable, since they are automatically re-tuned, given a particular example of a desired image. They can be made to detect any kind of a line structure (e.g. lines, corners, intersections, etc.), and so they are useful in automatic learning of an image representation. We have made experiments on two kinds of images, a data set of network lines from INRIA and a set of fundus images called IOSTAR. The results show the stability of the proposed method and its effectiveness in detecting line structures in various kinds of images.

Despite the recent considerable advances in image super-resolution (ISR), its performance has so far been evaluated only perceptually. Consequently, it is still unclear whether ISR can be useful for other visual tasks. In this paper, we report the first comprehensive study and analysis of the usefulness of ISR for other visual applications. In particular, six ISR methods are evaluated for four common visual tasks: edge detection, semantic image segmentation, digit recognition, and scene recognition. Our experiments show that the input images for these tasks can be improved when the inputs are low-resolution. We also study the correlation between four commonly used perceptual metrics—namely, PSNR, SSIM, IFC, and NQM—and usefulness for the tasks. Experiments show that, in general, they have good correlations, but that the perceptual metrics are still not sufficiently accurate to be a good proxy for the usefulness. It is hoped that this work will encourage the community to evaluate ISR methods on real-world applications and to adopt ISR as a pre-processing step for other visual tasks when the input images are low-resolution.

Post-DAE, a method of post-processing based on denoising autoencoders (DAE), has been developed to improve the anatomical plausibility of arbitrary biomedical image segmentation. Some of the most popular segmentation methods (e.g. based on convolutional neural networks and random forest classifiers) have been shown to benefit from the addition of post-processing steps, which ensure that the masks produced meet the expected spatial continuity constraints. These methods work under the assumption that neighbouring pixels with similar appearance should belong to the same class. This assumption, while correct in general, is too basic to be easily incorporated into the methods used. The aim of Post-DAE is to exploit the latest developments in manifold learning via denoising autoencoders. The first step is to learn a compact, non-linear embedding that represents the space of anatomically plausible images. Then, given a mask obtained by an arbitrary method, we project it onto the learned manifold to produce an anatomically plausible mask. The method is trained on the unpaired masks, which makes it independent of the modality and intensity of the images. We have conducted experiments on a multi-class, binary, and spectral decomposition of chest X-rays and cardiac magnetic resonance images. We show how masks with errors and noise can be improved by Post-DAE. Without a significant increase in the computational complexity, the method restores the data from which it is derived to a space where errors are not made.

Fingerprint recognition plays an important role in many commercial applications and is used every day by millions of people, for example to unlock a mobile phone. Fingerprint image segmentation is usually the first processing step of most fingerprint recognition algorithms and consists of dividing an image into a foreground, where the region of interest is located, and a background. There are two types of errors that can occur during this step and that both have a negative effect on recognition performance: the true foreground may be labeled as background, which can lead to the loss of some of the features, such as minutiae, or conversely, the true background may be labeled as foreground, which can lead to the introduction of spurious features. The contribution of this paper is threefold: First, we propose a new method for determining the foreground by using a directional Butterworth Butterworth filter, interlaced with a soft threshold. Finally, we provide 10560 ground truth segments that are marked by hand as an evaluation basis. Second, we perform a detailed comparison between the performance of our FDB method and four of the most frequently cited methods for fingerprint image segmentation, and show that the performance of the FDB method is clearly superior to the performance of the four most widely used methods. The ground truth data as well as the implementation of the FDB method are available.

‘The story is set in London in 1865, and involves Charles Lenox, a gentleman of independent means, who enjoys the odd murder-suddenly solved as a pleasant pastime. He is normally, though, content to spend cold winter days in his library with a book and a cup of tea. This time, however, his lifelong friend Lady Jane Grey, who has been known to him all his life, asks him to lend her a hand. Prudence Smith, her former maid, has been found dead of a supposed suicide. But Lenox immediately suspects murder, and more particularly, murder with a rare and fatal poison. She lived and worked in the household of George Barnard, a house with many suspects. Although she had broken more than one heart, a motive for her death is elusive. When yet another body is found at one of the most fashionable balls of the season, Lenox finds himself obliged to unpick the complicated web of loyalties and animosities that surrounds the mansion of George Barnard. He receives help in his task from his trusty valet, Graham, and his friend, Dr Thomas McConnell. Throughout the story, the efforts of Inspector James Exeter, of Scotland Yard, are in turn helped and hindered by the presence or absence of Lenox, whose assistance is needed, but who needs to appear to be in complete control of the investigation. There are also sub-plots, among which the reader learns of the growing intimacy between Lenox and Lady Grey, and the strain in the marriage of McConnell and Lady Victoria Phillips – all three being recurring characters in previous novels by Charles Finch.

His father’s suicide, when he was a child, occurred on Christmas Eve. It was a fact that his father was then struggling against the Mafia to establish his own undertaker’s business. The Mafia sent a friend to deliver a letter to him on Christmas Eve, and on reading it he went and shot himself. The letter was never found, and no one but the Don, Salvatore Biganti, knows what it contained. On hearing the shot, he had rushed to his father’s side, and saw his father on the floor bleeding from his temples. He knelt in the blood and tried in vain to stop the bleeding. Then the whole thing passed from his mind and he suffered from terrible nightmares. His mother soon afterwards died in a hospital upstate of a nervous breakdown. His aunt in Conn. brought him up and after twenty years he decided to return to New York and take up the profession of undertaker. His psychologist friend at school advised him to get the truth before his psychedelic demons completely enslaved him. The secret of death led him into a labyrinth of lies, greed and evil, and he became caught up in an intricate spider’s web of organized crime, secret cults and unspeakable atrocities. He writhed in torment, unable to cope with the knowledge. The known is worse than the unknown, and he was swept down into a hell of devils and new nightmares.

Gracie knew when a bad thing was going to happen, and sometimes even when it had already happened. She begged her mother not to go on a trip where she met her death when her automobile was struck by an orange truck. And now that she was living in Washington with her Aunt Shay, she had visions of her best friend, Miss Emily. Gracie would rather her psychic powers were not there at all, but when Miss Emily went missing, she had to depend on them to find her friend. The trouble with Gracie’s visions was that she did not know what she was seeing. Sometimes she saw the past, sometimes the present, and sometimes she completely misinterpreted what she had seen. In the hope of finding her friend, Gracie, aided by her cousin Diego, followed the directions of her visions. After a few false starts, she finally caught up with Miss Emily’s abductor and was herself captured. Imprisoned in a dark and sinister house, Gracie began to see visions of the captor’s childhood, the gloomy childhood of the man and his kinsmen. He was a madman who regretted not being able to cure his sick sister Nell. The man had set fire to the house to burn Nell to death, but the rage of his father, who had just lost his beloved wife, had burned all his siblings to death as well. The disillusioned madman now intended to put an end to his existence and was plotting to die with his family.

The book opens with the most amazing extravagances, with Renee and Maxime, asleep in a tuileverrière, emerging very slowly from a Parisian park (the Bois de Boulogne) and locked up in the congestion of the public. It is thus made quite clear from the first lines that these characters are of the greatest riches, which, when they arrive at home, will be dressed for hours by their servants, before presiding over a banquet to which the most opulent people in Paris will come. This scene seems to be very remote from the end of the first novel, but at the beginning of the second, we are told that this opulent scene is dated more than fourteen years later. The story then resumes, practically in the minutes, from the end of the first novel. We had seen in La Fortune that Eugène Rougon, made a man of the most powerful politics in Paris, brought his little brother Aristide, a journalist of no talent, of a comic character, incapable of deciding the imperial question in a comic way, thus left out of the rewards; and that he had followed him to Paris to appropriate the wealth and the power which he believes to be his. Eugene promises him these things, on condition that he keeps out of his way, and that he changes his name, in order to avoid the bad news of the scandals that might have sullied the reputation of Eugene. Aristide took the name of Saccard, and Eugène found him a job in the district, a very modest job. Saccard, no longer having a bad taste for his job, sees that he is able to know in advance the houses and the buildings which will be demolished to make room for the big new boulevards of Paris. Knowing that the owners of the houses demolished by the municipality receive rich indemnities, he gets money from usurers to buy them before their situation becomes public, and to make great profits by their sale. But he has not the means to do this at first, and his wife, in the next room, is dying of a fatal illness. Saccard, however, takes the opportunity, in a scene of sublime callousness, to marry the rich young woman, Renée, who is pregnant, and whose parents, to avoid a scandal, offer a dowry to the man who will marry her and make her his child. Saccard accepts, and his career of speculation begins. Her husband carries her off to Plassans, and sends his son Maxime to school in Paris, where we meet him when he has just come out of college and meets his new wife, only a few years older than himself. The flashback finished, the novel is placed in the background of the opulent house of Saccard, of his prodigality, of his luxuries, in the midst of a game of lust and politics. Renée and Maxime fall in love, which Saccard suspects, and seems to tolerate, perhaps because of the contract of commercial marriage that he had made with Renée. However, the house of Renée, the family estate, would be worth millions, and Renée refuses to sell it. The novel continues, the tension increases, and ends with a sequence of bitter reflections by Zola on the hypocrisy and immorality of the new rich. At the time of the publication of the Curé, he was a poor journalist, who had never seen such scenes. Ample notes, preserved in volumes, were taken on architecture, on fashion, on garden design, on greenhouse plants (a seduction takes place in Saccard's greenhouse), on cars, on carriages, on liveries. Then he brought his notes to the printing press, and many people praised the realism of his novel. In 1966, Jean Cau made an adaptation in contemporary Paris with Jane Fonda, Michel Piccoli and Peter McEnery. It was released in English as the End of the Game.

The principal character is Beverley, who remembers his childhood days with his brother Felix and his cousins Félicité, Cecile, Dan, Sara Stanhope, and Peter, the hired man, and his friend Sara Ray. They spent a great deal of time in their orchard and had many adventures. We see the children grow up; we see especially Sara Stanhope move away from the golden highway of childhood. We see the beginning of the chemistry between Peter and Félicité, we even see a little bit of that between Beverley and Sara Stanhope, but it is not very important. During the whole of the story it is intimated that Beverley's cousin Cecile is consumptive. In the end the story tells us that she has never left the golden highway. She also tells us that Peter and Félicité are married. The story ends when Sara's father comes to take her away to educate her. Their little band is never complete again.

Anna is elated when her parents tell her they are going to have a baby. She thinks this is her chance to show that she’s grown up and can manage her own household. But the birth of Ben is overshadowed by the fact that he has hydrocephalus. Anna initially finds it hard to cope with this new situation, but she really loves Ben and tries her best to care for him. At school she has trouble telling her classmates what’s wrong with her brother, because she’s afraid they won’t understand and she doesn’t want to have them pity her. But as soon as he meets Anna’s schoolfriend Miranda, word of his being handicapped spreads quickly to all of Anna’s classmates. Anna at first becomes angry, but then she begins to weep and her classmates feel sorry for her. Then she tells them how nice Ben is and they all like him. The book mainly concerns the difficulty of Anna and her family in coping with Ben’s disability and then in coming to terms with his loss and in trying to go on with their lives.

Crystal, the only daughter of the exiled old royalist, the Count of Cambray, is to be betrothed to Victor de Marmont (secretly a fervent Bonapartist). And when the Englishman who loves Crystal and who questions Victor de Marmont, he replies that he has never deceived the Count, but that the Count had taken his political ideas for granted. Crystal, however, had a third admirer, Maurice de St-Genis, who, through the misfortune of his position, and his unsteady conduct, which her father regarded as a bad knout, deprived him of the right to her hand. But at the moment of the betrothal, Maurice derives the most bitter revenge on his rival. As soon as the assembly of the party was about to take place, there was a commotion in the corridor; Maurice de St-Genis stepped in, with his rough clothes and his muddy boots, which contrasted with the immaculate costumes of the Count’s guests. Beside himself with rage, and brandishing his cane, he cried that he had only come to avert the horrible catastrophe which threatened the Count and his family. At these ominous words, the Count turns pale, and asks what disaster can be more serious than twenty years of exile? “An alliance with a traitor, M. le Comte,” he replies. St-Genis then accuses his rival of having nailed Napoleon’s Proclamation to the walls of Grenoble; but instead of repudiating the charge, de Marmont takes a copy of the Proclamation from his pocket, and waving it about, cries, “Vive l’Empereur!” And although the abrupt rupture of the betrothal does not cause the ruin of Crystal’s heart, it is not St-Genis who gains her love, for it is the English merchant, Clyffurde, who, through his perseverance, eventually overcomes the prejudices of the old French count. Having promised never to buy nor sell gloves again, and to try and live like a gentleman, Clyffurde, laughing, asks Crystal’s aunt, “Do you think he will consent?”

Duff Pringle, a new recruit in the high-tech industry, has just driven across the country for a job in the Valley, California. His old Ford Escort has not gone a hundred miles from his front door before it broke down. He calls a towing company to pick him up and when they reach the garage it takes three or four days to get it fixed. He only has two weeks to get to California. While waiting at a motel he finds a note asking for a driver to take a car to St Louis. Duff emails him, saying he’ll stay in the same motel, and the mechanic sends him the car. Then Duff finds Stu, a fellow waiting in the car park who’s trying to get to California and wants to come with him. Duff is prepared to take him, in spite of Stu’s looks and behavior. They drive the car, a 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air, to St Louis to be delivered to Rosalie Hopgood, a businesswoman. A number of other people get involved in the story, such as Bonnie, an aspiring singer whose mother is a professional cheat (she’s a swindler, a major swindler who’s been sued for a lot of money and is on the run); two gangsters who are after a trunk full of money; and Moony, a terrier with a fear of cars.

The Golden Notebook is a work of fiction by Anna Wulf, about her four notebooks, in which she records her life, and how she tries to gather them into a fifth, golden notebook. The Golden Notebook is composed of a fictional story about the lives of two women and their children, ex-husbands and lovers - under the title “Free Women” - interspersed with passages from Anna's four notebooks, coloured black (about her experiences in Southern Rhodesia before and during World War II, which inspired her novel), red (about her membership in the communist party), yellow (about the novel that Anna is now writing about the painful end of her love affair), and blue (her diary, where she records her thoughts, dreams and emotions). Every notebook is referred to four times, between which there are scenes from “Free Women”, so that a haphazard and non-chronological story develops. This post-modernistic form, with its spaces for ‘play’ for the characters and the reader, was one of the book's main features. But the serious themes in the novel were more important to the author.

Summer 1944 in New York City. Although she has a successful psychiatric practice on Park Avenue, Dr. Charlotte Manning—young, beautiful, blond, and wealthy—is never satisfied. To increase her income, she takes in a criminal gang—a “consortium”—that is both a vice and a drug house. The brains of the operation is Hal Kines, who has had a plastic surgeon’s touch, which makes him look much younger than he is, and who thus attracts young women who he turns into whores. Manning herself specializes in treating the rich and genteel—people who would rather not have their addiction become public knowledge. Instead of helping them to get over their addictions in her private, exclusive clinic, she makes them more dependent on drugs—mostly heroin—and on herself, who provides them with the drug herself. Manning, who on the surface maintains her respectability as a world-renowned psychiatrist, falls in love with Myrna Devlin, a young girl who had become a junkie and whose suicide attempt he prevented, and brings her to Dr. Manning’s clinic for “treatment.” After she has been cured, she and Jack get engaged, and the Mannings keep in touch with them. He has long been suspicious of the ways of Dr. Manning and decides to go into the matter himself, in private, secretly. When he finds out that Hal Kines, a former college student whom she knew through her clinic and who had become a friend, is actually a criminal, he is forced to have an impromptu conversation with her about it and informs her of it. At a party given by Mr. Williams in his apartment, Dr. Manning sees some old yearbooks whose photographs, if made public, would expose Kines’s duplicity. In the course of the evening she goes home, but that same night, after her maid has gone to bed, she comes back to his apartment and shoots him in the stomach with a silenced pistol. She enjoys watching his agonizing death and takes the yearbooks with her. No one at the party has an absolutely reliable alibi for being in the apartment at the time of the murder, but neither Pat Chambers, the police inspector, nor Mike Hammer, a friend and fellow-investigator, can find a motive for the murder. Throughout the book, as one after another of the immediate suspects is eliminated (“If this keeps up, there’ll be no one left”), Hammer occasionally wonders if the murderer might not have been a “foreigner”—someone unknown to the group of people who had been at Mr. Williams’s party, perhaps one of the people whom he, Mr. Williams, had been investigating in his capacity as an agent of an insurance company. The police are soon forced to reject this idea, however. After examining the body (“I felt as if I wanted to cry for the first time in my life”), Mike Hammer vows to himself that he will find the murderer and will have him executed. He will not allow the justice system of the United States to touch the case. He knows that if he did, a clever lawyer would get him off, and the murderer would get away with his crime. So he will be the jury himself, and the judge himself. During their separate investigations Hammer and Chambers are, however, very close, and they constantly exchange information. Nevertheless, each of them hopes that he will be the one who will find the murderer first. The first suspects are Esther and Mary Bellemy, beautiful twin sisters living in a rented apartment in New York City. Both are well to do and live on a large country estate. Neither is married, and both are blatantly looking for a husband. He finds out, through personal experience, that Mary is a nymphomaniac. Esther, whom he never touches, is also not a virgin, but she is much more reserved than her sister, with whom he has relations on two different occasions. He also suspects George Kalekoi, who had been a crook—a bootlegger—but has apparently straightened out and is now Hal Kinze’s paternal friend, supporting him, paying his rent, and helping him with his tuition. , the “scion,” is the head of an organized crime syndicate dealing in drugs and prostitution. (In actual fact, it is the other way around. Hal Kines, the “scion,” and the brains of the outfit, has a document proving that George Kalekoi is a murderer.) The very sophisticated and complicated way in which he gets women for his gang is understandable only in the morally repressed society of the late 1940s. He passes himself off as a student named John Hanson, attending some college or other in a remote area—maybe in the midwest—pretends to fall in love with a female student, gets her pregnant, and forces her to have an abortion. Then he takes her to the university hospital and, in the midst of her suffering, has her sent home from college, shunned by the rest of the students, her family, and, more than likely, even by her friends. Then he has a car waiting, picks up the desperate young woman, and drives her to one of his “work houses” in New York City, from which there is no escape. To the outsider, such a girl seems the perfect nymph. Besides Mary, whom he knows through a friend, he falls in love with a fellow student, Charlotte Manning, who, to the best of his knowledge, had no motive for killing John Williams. And, sure enough, she soon confides her love for him, while he declares that he has never been in love before. Soon they are talking about getting married. It is only when she undresses at the end that he finds out that she is a real blonde. For the next five murders, after her first, she must hide her tracks and eliminate anyone who might expose her, and as M. HAMMER puts it, she is remarkably fortunate. There is also Myrna Devlin, a former “freak,” who, as it turns out, has no role at all except that of a victim. At the end of the book, when she is in the coatroom upstairs, trying on a fur coat, she finds a packet of heroin in it. Then Charlotte Manning shoots her, too. It takes Hammer and Chambers a long time to figure it all out. After Mary, Charlotte keeps on killing anyone who might be dangerous to her. All this takes place through Hammer’s eyes, and for a long time he is completely unaware of the facts (“I hope you catch him,” she says, sincerely).
