He has been sent to Chiapas, Mexico, to report on the massacre of the indigenous population there by landlords working for capitalist corporations. But NewsReal, because of a deal struck with the Mexican government, does not transmit the programme, and he decides to retire from his job. He meets Margaret Mayfield, a rebel Zapatista, and they fall in love and decide to fight the capitalist elite. St. John and Mayfield decide to join an expedition sent by the corporations ‘Intrepid Explorers’, to find a strong band of Zapatistas to join. There they meet an individual who claims to be Subcomandante Marcos, the first revolutionary to take part in cyber-revolutions, and who proposes to St. John and Mayfield that they should place all the victims of the massacres killed by the capitalists with virtual interfaces so that the whole world can share in their suffering by assuming all the senses of the person so affected. As for Margaret Mayfield, she goes on her mission with Webster Webfoot, a former star of the Internet, but who, after his fall, has tried to avoid using his virtual interface whenever he can. She learns from NewsReal that Santee is dead and that the funeral is to take place tomorrow, and that Santee is not dead but has been killed. She leaves Webster some money for travel and goes off with Zack Hayman, a hotel-keeper who appears to have inside knowledge of the conspirators. Webster’s virtual girlfriend, Starchilde, or ‘Starr’ for short, learns from her work on a space station that there is oil on Mars and that this means that there was at one time biological life on Mars and that the rebels from Chiapas are being shipped to Mars to mine it. Back on earth, Zack, the hotel-keeper, discovers that the rebels are being sent to Mars partly so that the rich can take the land they occupied without resistance. Santee and Margaret believed they were installing virtual interfaces on the victims so that they could be made to suffer in solidarity with the victims outside Mexico. But in fact the virtual operatives were deceiving the rebels into thinking that they were receiving messages from Santee while they were in fact being deceived into going to Mars as slaves. On the ship going to Mars Starr learns that the rebels are going there to live for a while and to scout the place for any chemical or biological hazards. Starr then shows the rebels the whole of the Internet and she herself becomes convinced of the tyranny of the capitalists. Then Starr gives the rebels the virtual means to take over the ship and the Zapatistas, with the help of Alice Irene, take control of it and offer the revolutionaries the choice between staying on earth or going to Mars, but as an enlightened society and not as slaves. Santee St John and Margaret Mayfield opt for staying on earth, but the other main characters choose to go to Mars.

Then Arkaan is abducted by the Order of Chaos, which seeks to weaken the Legion by destroying his existence. Isabel, possessed of his mother’s love, is determined to save him, but to do so she must defy Lorian’s orders, risk her life, and venture into the Underworld itself. With her companions Ethan and her brother Matt, she undertakes the task. On the way they meet a new friend, John Wren, and save Ethan’s sister, who was murdered when he was a child. She is now a ghost (a wren is a bird-like creature, but with some of the features of a human being). In rescuing Arkaan, they are joined by Dillon, who had been a spy for the Order of Chaos but has now turned to the good side. Arkaan and Isabel realize their love for each other, and together, opening a rift, they rescue themselves and their loved ones. When they return, Lorian summons Isabel to the tribunal, where Arkaan intercedes on her behalf and learns that Lorian is his father. He forgives her and, in a final act of kindness, gives her the power to cease aging, so that she can be with Arkaan forever.

The story is told by the two young girls, Mary, twelve years old, and Jean, ten years old, who are travelling alone to join their father in Australia. In the days when they were still at home they were in the habit of 'borrowing' babies from the neighbours. But the ship is wrecked in a storm, and the two young girls are left alone in a lifeboat with four babies, all under two years of age, all of them belonging to other passengers. The boat drifts to a tropical island, where they have to learn to survive, like Robinson Crusoe, building shelters, and collecting food from the jungle. They succeed admirably, the children grow up and develop into healthy youngsters, and they take a baby monkey to their home and train it together with the children. At a later stage of the book the reader encounters a Friday, a mysterious, stern, and primitive man who lives alone on the island, and dislikes children. But he soon makes friends with the children and they all enjoy his companionship and his useful craftsmanship. At last the young girls are rescued from the island on Christmas Day, and the babies are returned to their parents.

The first part of the book covers the seventeen years after Karen’s coma. Richard must face the loss of his wife and the birth of his daughter, Megan, from the sexual relations of the past which were inevitable between them, in the hour of Karen’s coma. Pamela becomes a model and Hamilton a demolisher, but none of the friends’ lives turn out as they expected. Broken and shattered, they go back to their old home suburb, to regain what they have lost, until one day, almost twenty years after she fell asleep, Karen wakes up. The book is divided into three parts. The first part is narrated by Jared, the ghost of a friend of the main characters, who died young of leukaemia. The rest of the first part is told in the first person by Richard and covers the next seventeen years. The second part of the book, which is not narrated, covers Karen’s return to the world. It explains where she has been all those years, and the reality she had hoped to avoid. Then suddenly the world ends. This part is told in the third person, with insights into the thoughts of all the characters. The last part of the book describes the world after all the people except these seven, have fallen asleep and not woken up. This part is again narrated by Jared. The characters have to face the world ending, as predicted by Karen while she was in her coma.

On the very day that Tallis Keeton disappeared in the woods, her father James Keeton entered the woods to find her. He remained there for only four days, but outside it was the fourth year. When he reappeared, he was carrying the mask of the Moon-Dream, which he had taken from her and he was put in a lunatic asylum. James Keeton has many weird experiences in which he seems to communicate with his daughter through the mask. Alexis Bradeley, a young companion of the missing child, who is the only one who can reassure James, keeps him company. One day in the asylum, Richard Bradley sees James Keeton collapse and die. At the same time, his son Alexis is injured by a dreadful force and his mind is affected. He is sent to the same asylum as his father. He escapes from the asylum and his bones are found afterwards in a state of great decomposition. In the course of six years, the author learns that the young man is still alive in the wood. His father, Richard Bradeley, joins a scientific expedition which enters the wood to find him. He falls in love with a young Native American woman, a girl of the Silverlocks. In the forest of Ryhope, the customs of the North American Indians are introduced, and also the myths of Jack (i.e. of the Bean-Stalk), of the Tower of Babel, and of Jason and the Argonauts, which are of foreign origin, in an extraordinary manner.

The film The Aviator by Martin Scorsese is going to win the Academy, according to the opinion of the leading film critics of Britain. Several of them think, however, that the best director will be Clint Eastwood, and most critics predict that the actors Ray and Million dollar Baby will be the best. The jury consists of experts and critics from the leading British film magazines, and the panelists also revealed which of the nominated films they personally wish to win. They all expect The Aviator to win in the best film category, but many think that it will be a close competition between Scorsese's film about the life of the aviator and the film by Clint Eastwood, a boxer. The other nominated films are the wine comedy Sideways, the factual drama Finding Neverland and the biopic of Ray Charles. "The Aviator will probably win, but my personal choice is Sideways," said the Observer critic Philip French. "Sideways should win, but it's out of the question," said Total Film's Jamie Graham, an opinion shared by Film 2005 host Jonathan Ross. "The pattern for the Oscars is The Aviator, but I liked Million dollar Baby better," said Tim Dams, the news editor of the film magazine Screen International. Five out of eight of the critics named Scorsese as the best director, while three, Mr. Dams, Charles Gant of Heat magazine and Empire's Angie Errigo, voted for Eastwood. Alexander Payne for Sideways, Taylor Hackford for Ray and Mike Leigh for the period drama Vera Drake were considered to be outsiders in this category. "I thought for sure Scorsese would get it just because he's Scorsese," Errigo told the BBC news site. "But I think Eastwood has a chance. " The actor who portrays Ray Charles, Ronny Foxx, has already won at the Golden Globes, BAFTA and the Screen Actors Guild awards. Mr. Dams thinks this makes him the definite favorite to be named the best actor at the Academy. "It would be a major surprise if he didn't win," he said. He's "bettor's insurance." "If Paul Giamatti had been nominated for Sideways, it would have been a different ball game," said Jamie Graham of Total Film. But Foxx will and should win. " in the best actress category, he was also nominated for Kate Winslet. The winner is probably the Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, of which Jonathan Ross is very fond, but The Times critic Charles Gant, however, sees the BAFTA award as "unimportant". It would be nice to see Imelda Staunton win, but her chances are not so great, he said, expecting to see another Oscar for Hilary Swank. "I think Swank will win," said Philip French. "Imelda has got as far as she can go with this role." He also likes Imelda Staunton, but he also predicts Swank. "Everything can turn on a single vote and go the other way," he told the BBC news site. The British believe that the vote is not influenced by the reputation of a director or a film. " The Americans are quite a different story, they have to look at the script and see how they have to work to get the job done. The readers of BBC radio 5's site have also been asked which movie they would like to have won an Oscar without having won one. The radio audience voted in favor of the Shawshank Redemption, the 1994 film by Frank Darabont, which received 51 percent of the votes from the web and 68 percent of the votes by text message. The next two films, Citizen Kane and A Matter of Life and Death, were voted for almost equally. The British will be able to see the awards on Sky 1 at 01:00 on Monday morning. Tim Dams, Screen International: The film: The Aviator; the director: Clint Eastwood; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Angie Errigo, Empire: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Philip French, the Observer: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Charles Gant, the Times: The film: The Aviator; the director: Clint Eastwood; the actor: James Ihe Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. James Gray, the Guardian: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Dan Gaydos, Variety: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. In The Times, editor-in-chief Wendy Ide writes: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Jonh Ross, movie 2005: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: James Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Tim Dams, Screen International: The film: Million-Dollar Baby; the director: Clint Eastwood; the actor: Jamie Foxx; the actress: Hilary Swank. Angie Errigo, Empire: The film: The Aviator; the director: Martin Scorsese; the actor: James Foxx; the actress: - - - - Charles Gant, Heat: The film: Frankie and Alice; the director: Mike Leigh; the actor: James Foxx; the actress: Imelda Swank. Dan Gaydos, Variety: The film: Million-Dollar Baby; the director: Clint Eastwood; the actor: Don Cheadle; the actress: Imelda Swank. Jamie Graham, Total Film: The film: Sideways; the director: Alexander Payne; the actor: Don Cheadle; the actress: Imelda Swank. Wendy Ide, the Times: The film: Sideways; the director: Alexander Payne; the actor: Don Cheadle; the actress: Imelda Swank. Jonh Ross, movie 2005: The film: Sideways; the director: Clint Eastwood; the actor: James Foxx; the actress: Kate Winslet.

The authorities of Coahuila, in the state of Coahuila, have announced that they will confiscate lands owned by a British company, part of the Vestey Group, in the framework of the agrarian reform undertaken by the government of Hugo Chávez. This follows the establishment, by the president of the Republic, of a special commission to supervise the operation of the so-called “latifundios” (large properties), which according to the government are only left idle. The Vestey Group has declared that it has not been notified of the intended confiscation. The company, whose subsidiary Agroflora has thirteen farms in the country, has affirmed that it has complied with the Venezuelan laws. The judicial authorities in the south of the country, where Agroflora owns a ranch, have set their sights on El Charco, a cattle ranch. According to Reuters, they intend to confiscate an area of 5,200 acres out of the 32,000 that the ranch covers. The authorities affirm that Agroflora does not have valid title to the land in question. They also allege that certain parcels of the ranch are not being used for any agricultural activity. The State Attorney Alexis Ortiz declared to Reuters that there was a difference between the legal boundaries of the property and the boundaries as laid down by custom. “The result is that the government is putting it out of use.” According to the controversial reforms of 2001, the government has the right to take over private property that is declared idle or where the ownership cannot be traced back to the nineteenth century. The law has been criticized as infringing private property rights. The Vestey Group has affirmed that it has owned the property since 1920 and that it is working in full compliance with the authorities. But it added that it was “very confident” that the documents it has produced will demonstrate that it has valid title to the property. The company affirmed that the ranch, which employs 300 workers, produces meat solely for the domestic market. In a recent report, the government declared that it had found more than 500 “latifundios” that were not producing any income, and that it was still considering 40,000 more. It also stated that any owner who had a valid title to their property and whose property was in production had nothing to fear. It has also affirmed that it will take into consideration the land for use as a reserve for a new generation. Under President Chavez, the government has steadily expanded its role in the economy. Recently, it has said that it would examine all mining contracts in order to determine whether they are bringing sufficient benefits to the state.

Daniela Hantuchová moved into the quarter-finals of the Dubai Open by defeating Elena Likhotsev 7-5, 6-4 and will now face Serena Williams. The Australian Open champion came through a setback in the first game to beat Elena Bovina 1-6, 6-1, 6-4. Davenport beat China's Jie Zheng 6-2, 7-5, while Myskina, the French Open champion, retired due to an injury to her opponent, Marion Bartoli. The American will now face another former Wimbledon champion, the Spanish Conchita Martnez, who beat the seventh-seeded Frenchwoman Nathalie Dechy 6-2, 6-2. In the other quarter-final, Sania Mirza from India will face Serbia's Jelena Jankovic, who won her third-round match on Tuesday. Davenport sees a lot of room for improvement before her encounter with Martnez: "I started well and I finished well, but I played a bit in the middle," she said. Serena Williams was also not satisfied. "I don't know what I did there," she said. All my shots went away. But the more optimistic Hantuchová is in a better mood before her encounter with the younger Williams sister, who received a first-round bye. "It's a difficult court. It's fast, and you don't know if you can handle it. "

Andre Agassi fought inconsistency and reached the fourth round of the Australian Open, beating Taylor Dent. The 34-year-old American, eighth in the rankings, started badly, losing the first set and missing two chances to win the next set. Then he was able to take the lead, but his service lapsed again and the two players exchanged breaks. But Agassi came back, won the tiebreaker, and then finished it off in three straight sets, 7-5, 5-7, 7-6 (11), 6-1. Fourth-ranked Ivan Lendl escaped an injury scare when he beat the Croat Mario Ancic 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4. In the third game of the fourth set, Ancic twisted his right ankle and immediately asked for medical attention. But he was able to return to the court and finished off the victory in two hours and forty-five minutes. Ancic, a Wimbledon semi-finalist in 2004, looked to be a tough challenge for the top-ranked Safin, winning the second set, but Safin came up with a new game plan and knocked off the Croat. Safin said he had been trying to control his temper in this tournament. Safin slapped himself on the head a few times during a second-set outburst, but he stayed pretty cool in the rest of the match. “I’m trying to keep my cool because if you lose your cool against a player like Ancic, it’s difficult to come back. The Russian said he wasn’t worried about the ankle injury. “I’ve had a lot of trouble with that ankle in the past, so I think I’ll be fine.” The Russian’s path to the fourth round was eased when Jarkko Nieminen retired because of injury. The defending champion was leading 6-3, 5-2 when the Finn, who had won the first set, retired. In this match the world number one had been somewhat inconsistent, hitting 19 unforced errors to 19 winners. He will next face the Cypriot Marin Cilic, who defeated Tommy Robredo 7-6 (13), 6-4, 6-1. (Ancic is ranked 94th.) Sixth-ranked Roger Federer, whose winning streak reached an amazing 24, said he felt some added pressure after he had won twenty-four consecutive matches. “I felt this would be a tough match. I had a poor start, but I came back. I always want to play better, but I think I did pretty well.” However, the sixth-ranked Swiss, who lost to Dominik Hrbaty 7-6 (13), 6-7 (11), 6-7 (5), 6-7 (3), 6-1, 6-3, was out of the tournament after four hours and twenty-one minutes. After exchanging sixteen breaks, Hrbaty moved ahead 3-2 in the eighth game of the final set. He will face the Czech Radek Stepanek, who beat American Kevin Kim 3-6, 6-2, 6-7 (11), 6-2, 6-2, 6-2.

UK aid to the Asian disaster victims will not divert resources from Africa, Prime Minister Tony Blair has promised. Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost program, he said that the money for the Asian disaster would not "clash" with the money the United Kingdom wanted to spend on Africa. When asked if he had not lost faith in God in the disaster, he said: I haven't lost my faith in anything. He added that he would give new figures to the House of Commons on Monday about British casualties in the disaster. Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said on Friday that about 440 Britons had been killed or were missing, and he said that the figures had not changed much since then, and that this must be a sign that the figures are starting to drop. But we can't be sure. It's a hugely difficult task to get accurate figures. Every country is struggling with it. The original £50 million set aside by the Department for International Development is now largely allocated. But until the World Bank has finished its evaluation, the precise amount of aid cannot be determined, he said. In the next few weeks, it will be clearer what the reconstruction costs will be. But Africa, where every month a "tsunami of preventable deaths" is reported in poverty, conflict and disease, will not be forgotten. As Britain prepares to take over the G8 presidency, the African agenda has taken on a greater significance, he said. Now for the first time, a plan has been devised that not only covers debt and development, but also the governance of African countries and conflict resolution. A lot of the problems in Africa are due to conflict, and these too are preventable if the right conditions are in place.

Despite the recent slump in the housing market, the mortgage and house building industries remain buoyant, according to bankers, and to George Wimpey, the housebuilder. The mortgage bank, Bradford & Bingley, which specializes in letting, expects the business to continue to expand at a much faster rate than the mortgage market in general. Profits rose by 6 percent, to £28m. Wimpey's profits rose by 19 per cent, to £457m, and orders for new houses were more plentiful than anticipated. Recent reports on the state of the housing market show that the recent years of phenomenal growth are over, and the popularity of buy-to-let mortgages, which played such a large part in the recent boom, is falling. However, Bingley, which has a 22 per cent share of the UK letting market, says that though the rate of growth is falling, it is still "significantly higher than the overall mortgage market". In its overall assessment of the market, the bank says that "housing market fundamentals remain strong". Interest rates and unemployment are likely to stay at their current low level, and real household incomes will rise; “over the medium term, demand for new homes is likely to continue to outstrip supply.” However, despite the upbeat comments, Bingley shares were down by 4 per cent at 325p in the morning, as investors fretted over future growth. Wimpey's profits exceeded expectations, with a strong performance in the US offsetting a slowdown in the UK. Wimpey said that the UK market was “challenging” in the last year. The market slowed down towards the end of the summer, and did not recover during the autumn. However, the first seven weeks of the year have been encouraging, and inquiries and reservations have been “above the top end of our expectations.” Wimpey shares were up 6 per cent, in the morning, at 458.5p.

The government’s concessions on a bill criticised for allegedly opening the door to euthanasia “by the back door” were not a “ploy”, the Lord Chancellor has claimed. In the Commons on Tuesday ministers were accused of panicking and offering last-minute concessions on the Mental Capacity Bill. He said the changes provided a solution to a very difficult issue, but some MPs have said they still don’t know. The bill would allow people to give another person power of attorney to make decisions for them if they become too ill to do so for themselves. Ministers have insisted this would not change the law on euthanasia and that the new safeguards would protect people. However, critics have said it could allow people to be killed by having their treatment stopped, including food and water. Tony Blair said he would do everything to meet concerns about the bill. But changes to the bill must not undermine the ruling that a court can order doctors to stop feeding and hydration from a man in a coma. He said he did not want to end up with a situation where doctors or hospital consultants were confused about the law, and where they might face criminal proceedings when no reasonable person would want that to happen. On Tuesday the government saw off a backbench rebellion against the bill by 297 votes to 203. But the revolt was quelled partly because of news that the Catholic Archbishop of Cardiff had secured a promise from the Lord Chancellor to strengthen the safeguards. Then, as the vote loomed, MPs bombarded the minister for constitutional affairs, David Lammy, with demands that he read out the letter, saying they had not been told of the changes. It took five minutes before the crucial vote to do so, provoking accusations of a shambles. The deputy speaker later said the issue had not been handled well. Lord Falconer said there would be further changes when the bill goes to the House of Lords. He told the BBC: “We have committed ourselves to put into the bill a provision that says nothing in the bill authorises any decision where the motive of the person giving that decision is to end life, but merely to end suffering.” He denied the changes were a “political manoeuvre” prompted by the rebellion. The debate was “hardening” as the bill went through Parliament, but the outcome was a “sensible solution”. “These issues are not easy to resolve,” he said. The BBC’s political editor, Andrew Marr, said Mr Lammy was “up to his neck in quicksand” after his performance. But Lord Falconer said his minister had done “an excellent job”. But former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith, who is one of the most prominent opponents of the bill, said it was a “charade” and that the safeguards promised were “vague”.

In January manufacturing grew at its slowest pace for one and a half years, according to a survey. The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said its purchasing managers' index fell to 51.80 from a revised 53.50 in December. However, although it fell below the expected 53.7, the number remained above 50, which means the sector is still expanding. The institute said the strong pound had harmed exports, and the rising cost of oil and metals weighed on business. Rising costs and slowing demand meant factory managers were reluctant to recruit, which meant that the employment index fell to 48.3 for the second month in a row, its lowest level since June 2003. The survey is more upbeat than official figures, which show manufacturing is in contraction. However, economists said the data suggested the manufacturing recovery was losing momentum. “The UK is in a two-speed economy again,” said economist Lena Komileva at Prebon Yamane. “There is weakness in manufacturing, which would be a worry for the Bank of England.”

An American stewardess who was suspended for "inappropriate" pictures on her weblog says she's been fired. The stewardess, Ellen Simonetti, who called herself the Queen of the Skies, kept a semi-fictitious account of her life in the air. She was suspended from her job with the company in September. In a statement, she announced that she would sue the company for "unfair termination." On Wednesday, a spokesman for Delta confirmed that the stewardess was no longer an employee. The company has repeatedly refused to comment on what it has called "internal personnel matters." The spokesman said that there were "very clear rules" about unauthorized use of Delta's trademarks and uniforms. On her weblog, Simonetti said she was fired on November 1. On the company's behalf, she wrote, "As a result of my suspension and subsequent termination for no reason, I have filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission." She also said she had hired a Texas law firm to sue for a "violation of my civil rights, defamation, and lost wages." In a telephone interview with the BBC News Web site, Simonetti said she had been suspended without any explanation or warning. The Queen of the Skies has received support and advice from the worldwide weblog community since news of her suspension first appeared on the BBC News Web site and other news services. The story has highlighted a growing concern among the weblog community about possible conflicts of interest, conflicts of interest, employment laws, and free speech on personal websites. Simonetti began her weblog in January as a way of dealing with the death of her mother. The Queen of the Skies, as a fictional character, developed over the months. In her posts, she gave fictitious names to cities and companies to protect her identity, but she also included images of herself in her uniform. Of ten images, only one showed her Delta "wings." Simonetti said she never intended to harm the company and did not understand how she could harm it. Legal experts in the US said they thought that Delta was afraid that the posts, although not specifically about the company, would be associated with it, because of the images. Delta is currently under great pressure from rising fuel costs and the high level of competition. It has announced plans to cut between 6,500 and 7,000 jobs and reduce costs by $ 3.1 billion. Analysts have recently warned that the company might be forced to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. This week, the pilots voted for a $ 1 billion cost-cutting plan that would probably prevent the bankruptcy of the company. The pilots were to accept a pay cut of 32 percent and were given the right to buy 30 million shares of the company, the union said. Also on Monday, Delta said it had reached an agreement to delay about $ 134 million in debt until 2007. The company said it also agreed to a loan of up to $ 600 million from American Express.

Microsoft is entering the world of search for documents, e-mails and other files on the hard drive. The test program is available for Windows XP and Windows 2000 only. Search engine Google introduced a desktop search in October, while a similar product from Yahoo will come out in January. The Microsoft program can be used as a toolbar on the Windows desktop, the Internet Explorer browser and within the Outlook e-mail program. The world's largest software maker is entering a battlefield where many other companies are already active. Google already has a desktop tool, while in January a desktop search is also planned at Yahoo, while AOL also offers a search in the first quarter of next year. Smaller companies such as Blinkx, Copernic, X1 and X-friend also offer tools to search the increasing amount of data stored on home and office computers. Apple is also planning to offer a similar search program for its Macs, called Spotlight, which is included in the Macintosh Tiger operating system.

A thousand slaves were accepted as security for loans by two banks which became a part of J. P. Morgan and Company. The admission is contained in a memorandum addressed to the staff of the company, and is made under the pretext that the company was making inquiries into its connections with slavery in order to comply with a law passed in Chicago. The two lending banks were the Canal Bank and the Citizens’ Bank. They are now closed, but they formed a part of the Bank One which J. P. Morgan bought last year. Between 1831 and 1865, a total of 13,500 slaves were pledged as security for loans. As a result of defaults, the two banks acquired 1,250 slaves themselves. We know that slavery existed in the United States, but it is quite different to see how our history and the institution of slavery were entangled together,” the letter signed by William Chase, the president of J. P. Morgan and James B. Dimon, the chief executive, begins. Slavery was unfortunately a part of American life, but this is no excuse. We apologize to the African American community, especially to the descendants of slaves, and to the rest of the American public for the part which the Canal Bank and the Citizens’ Bank played in the epochs of the slave trade. The times of slavery are a tragic epoch in the history of the United States and in the history of our company. The letter announces that J. P. Morgan will establish a scholarship fund of $ 5 million for students in Louisiana, where the events took place. The company declares that it is a different company today than the Canal Bank and the Citizens’ Bank in the nineteenth century.

The plot of an international best seller that thousands of people will probably be given as a Christmas gift, is a laughing matter, a priest says. The Da Vinci Code, which says that Jesus Christ was not crucified, but had married Mary Magdalene and had died of a natural death, says the Church later covered up this fact. The book has been sold around the world over seven million times. The Bishop of Durham, the Rt Rev Dr Tom Wright, said the book was a great thriller, but a bad history. Dan Brown's conspiracy theory may have been a treat for the reader, but he was disappointed in the lack of evidence to back it up. In his Christmas message, published in the Northern Echo, he said: “Conspiracy theories are always fun – fun to think up, fun to read and fun to ponder. But anyone who knows anything about the history of the first century will find the underlying substance of this work a laughable matter.” A large amount of credible evidence proves that the biblical story of Jesus is true, the bishop said. The evidence for Jesus and the origins of Christianity is very good, he said. There are a hundred times more early copies of the New Testament books than for the main classical writers, such as Cicero, Virgil and Tacitus. Historical research shows that they build a consistent and credible picture of Jesus, with all sorts of details that fit the time he lived in, and which do not fit into the world of later legends. The Da Vinci Code has become a publishing phenomenon, topping the UK and US best-seller lists for the past two years. It has been translated into 42 languages, and has spawned a whole industry of guides to reading the book, debunking and refuting it. It has been made into a film with Tom Hanks in the leading role.

The Premiership’s Newcastle United will travel to Ryman League leaders Yeading in the third round. The meeting is a potentially lucrative one for Yeading, who knocked out Slough in the second round. Conference South side Exeter City, who disposed of Doncaster on Saturday, are drawn to Old Trafford to meet holders, Manchester United, in January. Arsenal are at home to Stoke and Chelsea are at Scunthorpe. The only other non-league side still in the hat is Hinckley United, who drew goalless with Brentford at the weekend, and if they can win their replay at Griffin Park they will play Luton Town in the third round. In the FA Cup, a number of premiership sides are drawn away to second division sides on the weekend of 8th and 9th January. Everton, third in the table, are away to Plymouth, Liverpool travel to Burnley, Crystal Palace have Sunderland, Fulham face FA Cup semi-finalists, Watford, Bolton face Ipswich, and Aston Villa will entertain Sheffield United. And of the teams that are battling for survival, Norwich, Blackburn and West Brom, will be away to West Ham, Cardiff and Preston. Having already beaten them in the Carling Cup, Southampton have to travel to Northampton. Tottenham have been drawn away to Brighton.

Employment conditions will be raised from the end of this year; from now on, employers will not be able to force workers to retire before they reach the age of sixty-five, without giving reasons. The government has now announced that from the beginning of the coming year, companies will no longer be allowed to impose arbitrary retirement ages. New European age discrimination regulations are introduced, and a compulsory retirement age of sixty-five will be established. Workers will be able to ask for an extension of this retirement age, but the company has the right to refuse. Trade and industry minister Patricia Hewitt says that people will not be forced to work longer than they want to, as the regulation age is not a statutory retirement age. She says that as long as the worker is capable of doing his job, the employer is free to keep him. Under the age discrimination proposals from the Ministry of Trade and Industry last year, workers were allowed to continue to work until the age of seventy, if they wished, and companies opposed this proposal because it would have been too expensive and complicated. Now, however, the British Chamber of Commerce is welcome the new proposal. "This move is a move in the right direction," it says. "It gives companies the right to decide when an employment relationship ends, while giving workers the flexibility to ask to stay on after the age of sixty-five." But Age Concern says imposing a retirement age of sixty-five is "cowardly" and "totally reversed". "It completely belies the government's alleged commitment to abolishing ageism and will now seriously undermine the incoming age-discrimination law," says director-general of Age Concern England, Mr. Lishman. "It is certain that older people will challenge this decision under European law." The government says the decision will not affect the age at which people receive their pensions.

Music distribution sites have proven popular not only among young people, who have come to expect free music, but also among savvy advertisers, who are looking for a captive audience. The debate about the legality of music distribution sites continues to rage, as the music industry continues to threaten to close them down forever. In the meantime, the millions of consumers are both a dream come true for the advertiser and a nightmare for the brand. Paul Myers, chief executive of Wippit, a peer-to-peer music distribution service, believes that it’s time for brands to stop breathing the same oxygen as sites that facilitate piracy. “You may be surprised to know that, as of today, the most popular music distribution site, eDonkey, is still advertising a number of large companies that support the theft of copyrighted music with real cash: the Nat West, the BT Group, O2, NTL and even Renault,” he wrote in an open letter to the British Phonographic Industry, urging people to follow his lead and stop using any brand that is associated with eDonkey. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) also has a bone to pick with established brands that choose to associate themselves with sites that facilitate piracy. “These networks such as eDonkey, Kazaa and Grokster facilitate the illegal sharing of music and the BPI strongly believes that any reputable company should carefully consider the support they give to these sites through their advertising budgets,” the BPI said in a statement. “Millions of pounds are stolen every year from the music industry by those who pirate it and we are sure that those companies advertising on these services would not tolerate such theft in their own businesses,” the BPI added. But the situation for brands is far more complicated, says Mark Mulligan, an analyst with Jupiter Research. “This has been an issue since the early days of Napster,” he told BBC News. “In reality, millions of people who are constantly connected to the sites are very attractive for the advertiser. “It’s probably cheaper to advertise there than on other, more respectable sites, and the audience is perfect,” he added. “If you can put the legal issues aside, it’s a pretty attractive opportunity to reach a large audience.” Some of the companies contacted by the BBC News website deny that they have any knowledge of the sites on which their adverts are appearing. Onetel, which is advertising on eDonkey, has the following to say. “We have investigated this matter and we believe that one of our affiliate partners has placed this advert without our knowledge. We do not have a policy of advertising on peer-to-peer networks and we have asked them to remove it immediately,” a spokeswoman for the company told BBC News. A spokesman for NTL, which is also advertising on eDonkey, blames its advertising agency for a lack of knowledge of the sites on which its adverts appear. “We have given our agency strict instructions that our adverts should not appear on these types of sites,” he said. But Mark Mulligan isn’t convinced. This might be excusable for less well-known companies, but not for well-known brands. “I would be surprised if they were unable to prevent this from happening,” he added. At the moment eDonkey is benefiting from some very well-known names advertising on its network. Sam Yagan, its chief executive, says that some of the world’s biggest brands are using eDonkey. “Senator John Kerry and President George W Bush have used eDonkey as a platform to reach the world’s largest audience.” “Peer-to-peer clients offer the world’s biggest brands a unique opportunity to engage with their customers in the most comfortable place for them: on their desktops while they’re consuming their favorite digital media,” he added.

Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou were to learn on Wednesday whether they were to be banned for missing drug-testing during the London Olympic Games. The IAAF Council held a telephonic conference on Tuesday to make its decision. The two olympians pulled out of the Olympic team after they failed to show up for the test, claiming to have been injured in a motorbike accident. In Greece, the two athletes and their former coach Christos Tzekos are facing charges for deliberately missing the tests and for staging an accident. They are awaiting the date of their trial. The IAAF, after examining all the evidence, will rule on the athletes’ future in athletics. The Greek Athletics Association will be notified of any disciplinary action, and the two sprinters can appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both athletes had sent written statements to the IAAF, which had taken these into account. The IAAF had earlier issued a formal warning to the sprinters and their coach Tzekos after they were found to be training in Qatar, not Crete, as they had reported. Despite this, they both then failed to appear for tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago, and also failed to show up in Athens after flying home early. The pair resigned just before the Olympic Tests were to begin. In the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, Kenteris won gold in the 200 metres, and Thanou silver.

Jason Gardener battled hard to win the men’s 60 metres title at the Norwich Union British Trials and AAA Championships at Ipswich. The world 60m champion, in his element at a standing start, just got the better of his rivals, Mark Findlay and Darren Chin, who both set personal bests. “It was a close race,” admitted Gardener. “I stumbled at the start but I think my experience just told. I still feel there’s more to come and I believe I can run faster.” Gardener’s performance in the Sheffield semi-finals might have been influenced by the news that his European record had been beaten by the Frenchman, Ronan Pognon, who is a threat to Gardener’s European title in the short term. Victory went to the favourite, Anita Whelahan, who ran an outstanding race to win the women’s 60 metres in 7.27 seconds. “You will see me in Madrid and I feel I have more to give,” said the 22-year-old. Joice Maduaka had withdrawn from the final because of a chest infection. The former champion, Gail Emms, again broke the British record in the women’s 60 metres hurdles. The 25-year-old, who had set the record twice in seven days, clocked 7.96 seconds to beat Diane Allgrove, who ran a personal best of 8.15 seconds. Emms was in tears as she told BBC Sport: “I’m so pleased, all these years of running and now people are starting to notice me.” Her time also qualified her for the European Championships. In the men’s 800 metres in Sheffield the defending champion, Mark McIlroy, went off in the lead and never looked back to win in 1 minute 47.96 seconds. He had qualified for the European Championships along with the Welshman, James Watkins, who clocked a personal best of 1 minute 48.32 seconds. In the women’s event the European standard was not met, as she came home in 2 minutes 4.45 seconds. The Olympic bronze medallist rounded off a good weekend by running two more personal bests in Sheffield. The 28-year-old cleared 1.80 metres in the high jump and ran in the heats of the 60 metres hurdles in 8.47 seconds. “I am surprised by my performance and I think I’m beginning to enjoy the pressure, but it’s not the end of the world if I don’t do well in Madrid.” The Manchester pole vaulter, Tom Solesbury, marked his return to the sport with victory after serving a two-year ban for using anabolic steroids. In the men’s triple jump he also set a new standard in the event. He jumped 17.30 metres on his last jump—the longest jump so far this year. “I really had no idea,” he said. “I’ve never jumped indoors before and I just wanted to make sure I made the qualifying mark.” he added. “But this isn’t a bad start and hopefully I can come back from Madrid with a gold medal.” In the long jump the two European long jump champions, Thomas Barr and Anita Wijnants, resumed their rivalry, with Barr achieving the qualifying mark and Wijnants jumping a lifetime best of 7.55 metres. The British champion, Eamon Morgan, had a first jump of 7.96 metres, the longest jump by any woman in the field, but he retired after the first jump with a sore heel. Olympic medallist Chris Tomlinson, also injured his heel and pulled out after the first jump. “I’ve been told by my doctor not to jump and I’m glad to have got through today.” The Loughborough-trained Kelly Sothcott, now in the women’s 400 metres, overtook the leader Catherine Murphy in the final hundred metres to win her first British indoor title. The 21-year-old clocked a personal best of 53.45 seconds, beating Catherine Murphy, who has already achieved the qualifying time. The 18-year-old Sudanese, Rabah Yusuf, who is applying for British citizenship, was third. In the women’s high jump, Libby Wells, with a best of 1.90 metres, achieved the qualifying mark and won the title. In the men’s 3,000 metres, the reigning champion, Steve Ovett, produced a personal best of seven minutes 56.86 seconds to retain his title and beat the qualifying mark for the European indoors. It was the first time at the British Championships for over ten years that the eight-minute barrier had been broken. In the absence of Kelly Holmes, Sarah Law won the women’s 1,500 metres title. The time, four minutes 19.11 seconds, was outside the qualifying mark, but Nicola Ovens had already pulled out of the race. The men’s race was won by Tony Stirland, who held off a strong finish from the chasing pack to win the title in three minutes 45.87 seconds.

With the intention of improving the way it handles weblogs and blogs, Ask Jeeves has bought the site Bloglines, which has become enormously popular by giving readers a central place to read, search, and discuss all their favorite weblogs. Ask Jeeves says it has no intention of changing the design of Bloglines but will use the three hundred million archived pages to improve its own Web index. How much Ask Jeeves paid for the service was not disclosed. The service has become popular because it makes it easy to follow the latest news from all the sites a reader wants to read without having to visit each of the sites. To do this, it uses the technology of Really Simple Syndication, which many weblogs have adopted so that other sites know when a new entry has been made. This move follows similar ones by other search engines. Google bought Pyra Labs, which had developed the popular service of Blogger, in 2003. In 2004, MSN introduced its own weblog reader, and last year, Yahoo! said it was making improvements in the way it deals with weblogs. The vice-president of Ask Jeeves in the United States, Jim Lanzone, said the company had not bought Bloglines just to gain a foothold in the weblog publishing industry. Rather, he said, Ask Jeeves was interested in presenting searchers with information rather than helping them publish. “The universe of readers is far greater than the universe of writers,” he said. The service would be an excellent complement to the Jeeves personalization service, which lets users build their own web pages. “Search engines are about discovering new content, and RSS is an ideal way to keep track of new sites,” he said. There were no immediate plans to make major changes to the service. “We will take the time we need to figure out the right business model, rather than trying to monetize it right away,” he said. He did say, however, that Ask Jeeves’s own technology of indexing would be used to organize the three hundred million entries in the service’s archive. Having a way of searching the entire weblog world is in itself very useful, he said. The news of the acquisition was broken by the weblog Napsterization, which said it had been tipped off by people inside Ask Jeeves.

Muslims in this country must expect that people who look Islamic are more likely to be stopped and searched by the police, a minister has said. Hazel Blears said innocent Muslims were being singled out in the hunt for Islamic extremists, and that she was also looking at whether the entry qualifications for Islamic leaders should be made more stringent. The comments have been condemned as “outrageous and irresponsible” by the Islamic Human Rights Commission. The Conservative MP for Salford told the Commons Home Affairs Select Committee that the threat was most likely to come from people associated with an extreme form of Islam, or from those who falsely claim to be Muslim. “If there is a threat from a particular place, then our action is going to be focused on that area,” she said. And she said that she would ask religious groups to consider whether their faith leaders needed to have additional skills such as a knowledge of British citizenship and the ability to work with the wider community. Ministers last year introduced a requirement for all faith leaders to have a high level of English. IHRC chairman Massoud Shadjareh said the minister was playing the “Islamophobia card” in the run-up to the election. “She is demonising and isolating our community,” he said. “It is an invitation for a backlash, and for the bigots to unleash a savage attack on the Muslim community. This is the kind of comment that plays into the hands of the bigots.” Later, the prime minister’s spokesman urged people to see Ms Blears’s comments in context. “She understands there is a perception that stop and search is directed against a particular community,” he said. “But it is not directed against any particular community, and it is not police policy to direct such measures against any particular community.” facts. Of the 17 people convicted of terrorism in the UK since the September 11 attacks, only four – or a third – whose ethnic origin was known were Muslim. Meanwhile, it has been reported that ethnic minorities are increasingly being targeted by police in stop-and-search operations. During 2003/2004, Asians accounted for 12.5% of all stops, although they make up just 4.7% of the population. In July last year, Muslim groups accused the police of “extreme Islamophobia” after a study found that the number of Asians stopped under anti-terrorism laws had risen by 300% since the measures were introduced.

Greek sprinter Kostas Kenteris' lawyer is demanding that the anti-doping charges against the former Olympic champion be withdrawn. He is claiming that his former Olympian client has not cheated. Last December he and fellow countrywoman Katerina Thanou were convicted of failing to report for the pre-Olympics test in London. The Greek Olympic Committee is due to announce its decision next week. Both had been forced to withdraw from the Olympic event in Athens last year after failing to report for the drug test on the eve of the opening ceremony. Before that they had been accused of failing to appear at the drug test in Tel Aviv and Chicago. But the lawyer, Yiannis Ioannidis, claims that the Olympic Committee's decision should be made to withdraw the charges. He added that he has provided evidence which will make it appear that the officials knew that Kenteris was in Germany on the day that he was accused of missing the Chicago test. In the meantime, Nick Davies, spokesman for the International Association of Athletics, which had initially imposed the two-year ban, said that he was unable to comment, as the hearings had been conducted behind closed doors. However, he did say that the Greek athletics federation would make its decision by the end of February, and that a statement would be made at that time. Kenteris won the 200m gold medal at the Sydney Olympic event in 2000.

The jockey John McCririck was the latest celebrity to leave the house in Celebrity Big Brother. He had been nominated to leave the Channel 4 show along with dancer from the Happy Mondays, Bez. Bez was once one of the most popular housemates, but has recently become surly and argumentative. Bez and McCririck were asked to leave on Monday evening after the first eviction of the series – the actor Sylvester Stallone’s mother, Jackie, and former model Brigitte Nielsen. Bez was furious at the news that five of his fellow housemates had nominated him to go, while John had only four votes against him. Afterwards, McCririck said: “Bez is a difficult man. There’s something wrong with him. Even though he’s trying, he’s not very happy here.” Former Holby City actor Jeremy Edwards had put Bez up for eviction after he became agitated on Friday evening and talked about climbing over the fence to go clubbing. He said Bez was being “strange” and “stressed”. According to the bookmakers, John McCririck was the favourite to leave on Monday evening, while Bez was third in the betting. McCririck was in the public vote last week and had 67 per cent in favour of staying in the house, while Sylvester Stallone’s mother, Jackie, was evicted.

How people get their digital entertainment in the future may change after the launch of an ambitious European project. In Nice last week, the European Commission announced the launch of the NEM initiative, which extends from the way digital content is produced through to the playback of such content. The Commission aims to give people the opportunity to find and play content in a unified way, whether they are on the move, at home or at work, and whether they come from a supplier of devices, networks, content or content protection. More than 120 experts gathered in Nice to discuss this vision of an interconnected future and to see if companies such as Nokia, Intel, Philips, Alcatel, France Telecom, Thomson and Telefonica would be willing to work together. It may be surprising that these seemingly competing companies are willing to work together. But time and again the participants stressed that incompatible and isolated solutions would not be viable. A long-term strategy was needed for the evolution and convergence of devices and services. The European Commission is taking a practical approach. They acknowledge that many groups have already defined the standards for digital content in the areas covered by NEM. NEM's approach is to carefully examine the standards that are already in place or in development, choose the best, pool them and then map out the gaps. Where gaps are found, NEM is looking at developing new standards to fill them. It is notable that such a large and powerful body has declared its wish for digital content to be accessible to everyone and playable on any device. This is likely to be welcomed, if not surprised, by many individuals and organizations who feel that the wishes of the content provider are usually put before those of the consumer. Many feel that the most difficult task for the Commission is to resolve the different digital rights management (DRM) schemes. The current solutions are incompatible, and so some kinds of content cannot be played on all devices. With the opportunity of taking a percentage of every media transaction, the prize for the supplier of the dominant DRM scheme is huge. In the first stage, it is a matter of digital entertainment, but later it will include the remote delivery of health care, the energy efficiency of a smart home and the control of the whole house. According to the Commission, the NEM project is a ten-year project that draws together the results of many ongoing research projects that the Commission has been funding for many years. Simon Perry, the editor of the digitallifestyles.net website, has described the key features of the planned NEM framework and described the efforts that have been made so far to find solutions to the various problems.

Usher leads the field of contenders at the Billboard Awards with 13 nominations, including “Best Male Artist.” Alicia Keys follows with 12 nods, including “Best Female Artist.” Other nominees include Maroon 5, OutKast, Kanye West, R. Kelly, Gretchen Wilson, Hoobastank, and Jay-Z. Stevie Wonder, the veteran soul singer, will receive the Billboard magazine’s “Century Award,” which recognizes his exceptional achievement in music, during the event. The show will be hosted by American Idol’s Ryan Seacrest and feature performances by Usher, Gwen Stefani, Nelly, and Green Day. Usher and Keys will vie for awards including “Artist of the Year,” “Song of the Year,” and “Album of the Year” for their albums, Confessions and The Diary of Alicia Keys. Maroon 5 and OutKast are also up for “Artist of the Year.” And Speakerboxxx/The Love Below, OutKast’s double album, is up for “Album of the Year,” alongside Closer, by Josh Groban. The annual Billboard Music Awards honor the year’s top artists and songs, as compiled by Billboard’s weekly charts.

TELLS the Mail that Liverpool will not sell Steven Gerrard, despite reports that Chelsea are about to make a second attempt to poach him from Anfield. After Wednesday’s goal, Gerrard insisted that he wanted to win trophies with Liverpool, and Parry echoed his words. “Stevie will not be going anywhere in January,” he said. “We are determined not to let him go.” Gerrard scored a brilliant late winner against Olympiakos to give Liverpool a 3-1 win and secure their place in the knockout rounds. “Of course, he is ambitious, but we are, too,” Parry added. “And we are convinced that if we can satisfy his ambition, he will stay with us.” “Stevie and I are on good terms and I believe that played a big part in his decision to stay last summer. But if he did not have the right attitude to Liverpool, he would have left long ago.” Gerrard had admitted before the Olympiakos game that he would think about leaving if Liverpool were knocked out of the Champions League, with Real Madrid also said to be interested in him. “I’ve said before I want to play for a Liverpool side that is constantly challenging for the Champions League and the title,” he said after the game. “I want to win trophies with Liverpool, not with another team.” “I am a fan, too, and I think what I have said is what the fans want to hear. We must build on victories like that, not just settle for good wins and not go any further.” “My goal was one of the most important I have ever scored, and I hope it will be one of the most important the club has scored for a long time.” “I knew my comments would put a lot of pressure on me, but I do not want to go around lying about how I feel.” But Reds manager Rafael Benitez said: “Steven can win everything he wants with us and we need him. He has seen we have a good side and we can win more in the future. But to win more of these big games, we need his strength, his mental strength and his quality. He wants the responsibility of leading the team.”

Church ministers are trying to prevent rap star Nelly from a concert in Arkansas because they don't want to see his "dirty and nasty lyrics" in their city. More than 20 ministers in Jonesboro called on fans to refuse to attend Nelly's March 12 concert at the University of Arkansas. "Jonesboro is a wonderful city because of what doesn't come here," said the Rev. Adrian Rodgers. But a spokesman for the event said more than 5,000 tickets had been sold. The Fullness of Joy Church leader said he was worried about Nelly's lyrics, which included drug use, sexual content and violence, and rap music, which the minister said degraded women. He and his fellow pastors said that bringing such rap music to Jonesboro could lead to trouble. "Tear up your ticket and don't go, and don't allow your children to go," he said. But Tim Dean, director of the university's venue, said sales had been good. He said: "It looks like many people have expressed their right to find Nelly's music entertaining and worthy of their time and money." Nelly has sold more than 30 million singles and albums worldwide and has had two number one albums in the US in September 2004. In the UK he has had 12 hit singles, including Hot in Herre, Dilemma and Over and Over, which recently topped the charts.

Brian O'Driscoll will lead the northern hemisphere in the game that will be played in the IRB event in London on Sunday, November 6, when a large number of world class players will meet to donate money for the Japanese disaster appeal. The southern hemisphere will be led by George Gregan, one of four Wallabies, and he will be accompanied by five Springboks and four All Blacks, of whom captain Tana Umaga. Schalk Burger, the South African flanker, has shaken off a leg injury and has been included in the starting line-up, together with John Smit, Cobus Visie and Victor Matfield in the back, and Jacques Fourie in the center. The northern hemisphere has been affected by the withdrawal of the Scots Gordon Bulloch and Chris Cusiter, and the French captain Fabien Pelous. However, the Leicester center and England Olly Smith has been included in the squad, which means he has an opportunity to impress the Lions coach, Sir Clive Woodward, who will coach the northern hemisphere. "It's great for Olly," Wells told BBC Radio Leicester, "he probably would have had the weekend off, so I hope that Clive can see in him what we and England have seen in him all year." Woodward will also be able to see the Scot Simon Taylor and Chris Paterson, the Wales Dwayne Peel, and Ireland lock Paul O'Connell. Woodward says he is looking forward to working with such outstanding players. "Both teams have assembled an excellent line-up and I hope that the entire rugby community supports the game so that it can raise as much money as possible for such a worthy cause. Despite the withdrawal of Wales wing Rhys Williams, who has to miss the game against Munster, three other members of the Blues squad, Ceri Sweeney, John Yapp and Jonathan Thomas, are included. "Not only are these players playing for a good cause, but they have an opportunity to play against the best players in the world," said WRU general manager Steve Lewis. Twickenham, which the public can visit for free on Friday, March 4, will host a number of games. Woodward will run his training session at 1030 GMT, while the South, under the guidance of former Wallaby Rod Macqueen, will be there at 1300. C Paterson (Scotland); B O'Driscoll (Ireland, capt), B Cohen (Ireland), D Traille (England), C Sweeney (Wales), D Humphreys (Wales), D Peel (Wales), A Lo Cicero (Italy), P de Villiers (France), J Yapp (Wales), R Ibanez (France), P O'Connell (Ireland), M Bortolami (Italy), J Thomas (Wales), S Taylor (Scotland), R Dallaglio (England), S.P. Taufa (Tonga), O Sititi (Samoa), M Rauluni (Fiji), T Delport (South Africa), A. N. Other.

An artist critical of the Welsh Assembly Government’s control of the arts in Wales has denied that he compared the idea to dictatorships in Russia and Germany. Shani Rhys James fears that the Arts Council of Wales may be taken over by the Assembly Government. But he said he had actually said that artists needed freedom. The future of the Arts Council of Wales has been uncertain since it was announced that most of the Welsh quangos would eventually be abolished. In July it was announced that three Welsh quangos, the educational and training agency, Elwa, the tourist board and the Welsh Development Agency would be brought under the control of the Assembly Government. The Arts Council of Wales may be next to go. But Shani Rhys James, winner of the £30,000 Jerwood Painting Prize in 2003, told BBC Wales that the arts should be kept separate from the government. “In a democratic society free expression is essential. There should be a separation, there should not be any interference, it can go badly wrong.” But he said reports that he compared the idea to the totalitarian regimes of Russia and Germany were not true. “The quotation I actually gave was ‘In a civilised society artists must be allowed to express themselves freely without government control.’ As we know from the history of Europe, from Russia and Germany in the early twentieth century, artists will go underground or leave the country rather than compromise their expression.” Artists need a free voice, they are the voice of truth.” He added that the Assembly Government was not the right organisation to run the arts in Wales. “It would be a huge change and would have a devastating effect on the arts.” It would set the arts back sixty years because the Assembly Government does not have the expertise. “If the Assembly Government take control it’ll be back to dragons and leeks and choirs. Wales has moved on.” It is now an international nation, not just a backdrop to How Green Was My Valley. In response to Shani Rhys James’s criticisms, the Minister for Culture, Sport and Tourism, Huw Evans, said: “We have already indicated that the structure of un-elected quangos is under review and further announcements will be made very soon.” The Assembly Government was being compared to Nazi Germany, which is a scurrilous and ignorant comment on a serious issue of democratic accountability. Shani Rhys James was born in Melbourne, where her parents worked in the theatre. She came to Wales about 20 years ago and now lives and works near Llangadfan. She has been successful in many art competitions, including the Wales Open in 1989 and the Mostyn Open in 1991.

D’Arcy, a second-row forward, has been ruled out of the Irish team for the Six Nations match at Murrayfield this Saturday. Like captain Brian O’Driscoll, D’Arcy has failed to recover from a hamstring injury and has to step down. Munster lock Paul O’Connell will now take over as captain. Shane Horgan, who has been playing at outside centre, moves to inside centre where he will be joined by Ulster’s Kevin Maggs. Girvan Dempsey comes into the team on the right wing, while Gavin Duffy has been added to the replacements. “We gave him a shot but it didn’t work out,” said Irish coach Eddie O’Sullivan. “We had to be careful with it. He should be fine for the next game but we don’t want to tempt fate.” Maggs, who is about to win his 67th cap, was always the most likely to come in at centre, while Shane Horgan was always going to be moved from the wing. The other change from the side that beat Italy last weekend is Johnny O’Connor in for Denis Leamy. O’Connell has won two caps since making his debut against South Africa in November. The team to play Scotland is as follows: Murphy, Dempsey, Horgan, Maggs, Hickie, O’Gara, Stringer, Corrigan, Byrne, Hayes, O’Kelly, O’Connell, S Easterby, O’Connor, Foley. Sheahan, Horan, O’Callaghan, O’Connor, O’Donovan, Miller, G. Easterby, D. Humphreys, G. Duffy.

The FA says it will not file a charge following the tunnel scuffle between Arsenal and Manchester United. Vieira had earlier denied he had threatened Neville before the game, which ended in a 4-2 defeat for Arsenal. He also got into a spat with the visiting captain Roy Keane, and it was up to the referee, Graham Poll, to bring the two men apart. “The referee has confirmed that he was satisfied that he dealt with the incident at the time,” an FA statement said. It means that United's victory will not be investigated by the FA, whose new chief executive, Brian Barwick, was present in the stands. “They are big boys, and they can look after themselves,” Vieira said. “I had a word with Roy Keane, and that's all. But it's up to them, the players, to decide whether to play or not.” “They were the better side on the night and deserved to win,” Neville said. “There were a few things that happened before the game that were disappointing, but it was not something that detracted from what we did on the night.” “Especially coming from such a highly rated player as him. But it's a tough game, and we've all been playing it a long time.” Neville admitted that he had not enjoyed the match, which was marked by fouls and the red card shown to Mikael Silvestre for a headbutt on Freddie Ljungberg. “I thought it was a dreadful game in the first half, and it wasn't much better in the second half,” he said. “There is no place for that sort of behaviour in a football match.” Keane said Vieira had started the fight. “He wanted to goad our players and thinks that if you intimidate our players, he'll intimidate our players. I'm not going to let him get away with that.” Sir Alex Ferguson said: “Vieira was primed for it. I have heard different things. Apparently Patrick Vieira threatened some of our players and things like that.”

This year a single player has dominated the men’s game, and one nation the women’s. After Roger Federer had been the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in the same season, Anastasia Myskina, the first Russian to win a Grand Slam, followed this up with two more, at the French Open and Wimbledon. In the meantime, Tim Henman had his best year, and Greg Rusedski had an excellent comeback season. Henman had the edge over his fellow countryman Rusedski on all three hardcourts and both won their events. Starting the year as world number one, holder of the Wimbledon and Master titles, Federer had a foretaste of his future dominance at the Australian Open. He destroyed his way through the field and beat Marat Safin in the final. Andy Roddick was the only man who posed a serious challenge to him at Wimbledon, and at the US Open it was Lleyton Hewitt who was swept aside by the champion. At the end of the season, Federer and Hewitt fought it out again for the title at the Masters. In Houston he won his 13th consecutive title, setting a new record for the Open era. His only major disappointment was to lose in the French Open to Gustavo Kuerten in the third round, and it will be Roland Garros that he focuses on in 2005. In the Olympic games he was beaten by an unknown quantity, Tomas Berdych, and Chile took all the gold medals with Nicolas Massu winning the singles and Fernando Gonzalez the doubles. Another title that looks out of reach is the Davis Cup, which Spain won 3-2 at home against the USA. Andy Roddick’s clay-courting record was mediocre and he lost to Nadal and then to Moya, the decider. Henman set a new record by reaching the semi-finals on clay at the French Open and at the US Open. The quarter-final loss to Ancic at Wimbledon was disappointing because of the way he played, but he hopes to do better next year. At the end of the year, Rusedski, number two in Britain, after being cleared of doping charges, was ranked 168, but he battled back in the second half of the season to re-enter the top 50. The Russian women lived up to the great expectations of their peers and, apart from Maria Sharapova, all three Grand Slam winners, were victorious in the Fed Cup at the end of the year. But if the Russians rose to the top, it was as if the Belgians and the Williams sisters had fallen off a cliff. The only woman to resist the young guns was the veteran, the fabulously consistent, and unflappable, American, Lindsay Davenport. After Wimbledon she went straight to the top of the rankings ahead of Mauresmo, whose wait for a Grand Slam goes on. An unstoppable Justine Henin-Hardenne beat her compatriot Kim Clijsters in the Australian Open. A virus infection meant that Henin-Hardenne had a very poor year, although she did manage to win the Olympic gold medal. Clijsters had a worse year than Henin-Hardenne, with a severe wrist injury, then the news of her split from Lleyton Hewitt. She was glad to see the back of this year. And in their absence, Maria Myskina beat Elena Dementieva in a dull but historic all-Russian final at Roland Garros. At Wimbledon, Sharapova’s nerves of steel were on show as she beat both Sharapova and Davenport, but at the US Open she was too unwell and lost to a powerful and unflappable Svetlana Kuznetsova. Dementieva went on to lose in another all-Russian final, as her wayward serve became a talking point. With the Russians still progressing, the likes of Henin-Hardenne, Clijsters, Davenport, Mauresmo and the Williams sisters need to be fit and in the mood in 2005. The only man who might be able to challenge Federer might be their fellow Russian, Safin.

The Olympic champions Justin Gatlin and Johana Hayes were awarded the Jesse Owens Trophy, the most prestigious award of USA Track and Field. Gatlin, 22, won the closest ever Olympic final of the 100-meter dash in 9.85 seconds, took a bronze medal in the 200-meter race and a silver medal in the four-man team race, and was the only male athlete to bring home three medals. Hayes, 27, set an Olympic record of 12.37 seconds for the 100-meter hurdles. The Jesse Owens award, named after the late Olympic great who won four gold medals in Berlin in 1936, is presented annually to the best male and female track and field athletes. The award for the year 2004 will be presented on December 3, 2004, at the annual meeting of the USA Track and Field Association in Portland, Oregon. Gatlin said, "It's such an honor to be given the Jesse Owens trophy. It's one of the greatest honors in track and field, and a wonderful ending to a wonderful year." Hayes said, "Knowing many of the great people who have received this award and knowing what it means, I feel a great pride and fulfillment and that everything I have worked for is worth it and will always be worth it. "

It is true that since the birth of the web as we know it today, the idea of an Internet channel has been talked about. But the first attempts to set up such a service – such as Homechoice in the United Kingdom, which was launched in 1992 – were thwarted by the slowness of the networks. Now that high-speed Internet is starting to establish itself, and for millions of users it is becoming a necessity, the big telephone companies are keen to start shooting some pictures over the Internet. Competition from cable companies offering voice over the Internet makes them desperate to be the first to offer IPTV. The software giant Microsoft believes that Internet Protocol Television is the future of television, and that it is an essential part of its “connected entertainment experience.” “Telcos have been trying to move into the video space for a long time,” says Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV, speaking to BBC News. “But the challenge has been the network, and until recently the technology hasn’t been ready. Compression technology wasn’t good enough, the Internet wasn’t good enough. But a lot of things have happened over the last 18 months to make it a reality.” Last year, he says, it was all about putting together deals and making alliances, forming the “IPTV eco-system.” In 2006, he says, things will be starting to happen, and he expects to see a number of new deals and launches. “It will also grow as the number of broadband users increases in South America and other parts of Asia,” he added. What the telephone companies want to do is to offer a “triple play” of voice, pictures and data over the same cable or DSL line. Some are talking about a “quadruple play” with mobile services added to the package. This is a new form of competition for satellite and cable broadcasters and operators. According to the British research group TDG, there will be as many as 20 million subscribers to IPTV in less than six years. The big advantage of sending the picture down the same line as the data is that the Internet can offer a two-way relationship between the viewer and the “broadcaster”. They are hoping to get more interactivity, something like the bespoke channel-listings of the DVD, with many, many channels, and a viewer’s personal library of tens of thousands of hours of content, all on a click. They can also send high-definition programmes direct to the viewer, without the need for a special set-top box. But perhaps the most significant, although many will see it as a non-issue, is instantaneous channel-changing. Changing channels on satellite, cable or digital terrestrial is a time-consuming business. With Internet Protocol Television, it is possible to change channels in less than 15 milliseconds. “That gets applause,” said Mr Graczyk. “We’ve been thinking about this for a long time. We think this will be the way we’ll all get our TV in the future, but it’s a few years off yet.” “It’s the way forward, because everything is going digital. We’re talking about a whole new generation of digital content, which goes from your TV to your phone, your games console, etc.” The plan is for the company to make its new Microsoft IPTV Edition platform do exactly that, offering a full end-to-end solution for telephone companies. This new offering has been launched in the US with the seven largest telephone companies in the US and promises to serve the 25 million broadband customers they already have. In fact, according to Mr Graczyk, they have just done the largest-ever deal in this sector, with the SBC deal for $2 billion. But it’s not just telephone companies. To exploit the Internet, there are already several companies offering services which will put the viewer in control, and offer them services they’ve never even heard of before. Jeremy Allaire, the founder and chief executive of Brightcove, told BBC News that this will be “a new dimension” in the way IPTV works, because it will use the Internet as the “channel” to deliver not just a lot of niche channels, but also a lot of content that would never normally get shown on television. “We’re focusing on people who own the rights to the content, but don’t have the distribution rights, and they can’t afford to go through cable operators and so on. We are their only option.” The new type of service can also be used by more established publishers who have unique content that they can’t sell through the cable and satellite operators – the history channel, for example, and its archives, for example. It’s also a sign that the future is bright for IPTV that there are several other companies offering similar platforms, such as Myrio and C-Cor. But it will be up to the public to decide whether this will be a success.

Former England captain Martin Johnson has announced that he will retire from the sport at the end of the season. In June he will play his last match. After winning 84 caps for England, he stepped down from international rugby at the beginning of the year, only two months after he had taken Sir Clive Woodward's side to victory in Sydney. The 34-year-old Leicester lock will play his last match at Twickenham on June 4. "I'm sure I've made the right decision to retire," he said. "I'm sure there will be times next season when I wish I was still playing for Tigers, but you know when the time is right to leave and I feel this is the right time for me. "I'm sure I could still play for another season, but the Premiership is a full-time job and I want to be out there for the right reasons. " He will always be remembered by England fans for the World Cup victory in Australia, but his achievements did not stop there.
