He was the only man to captain the Lions twice and he led England to a Grand Slam in the Six Nations. Also he had a hugely successful career as a club captain with the Tigers, winning the Heineken Cup in his first two seasons and a number of titles in the English league. In addition to being one of the best captains, he was also one of the finest locks to play the game. Teak-tough and imposing, he dominated rucks and mauls for the best part of a decade and was one of the reasons why England rose to the top of the world game. He will play his last match in his testimonial match, which he will lead to Twickenham against the Jonah Lomu side. The All Blacks star is planning to come back after a kidney transplant and the former England captain expects it to be a memorable match. Lomu, who was the first world-famous athlete after his achievements in the 1995 World Cup, said he was proud to be part of Johnson's retirement match. "We hold him in such high esteem," he said. "He is such a great leader and I am just honored to be on the same field."

“Irreversible damage to the environment” will result from the government’s plans to build more than a million homes in the south-east, according to MPs. Plans for sustainable communities are being promoted without a proper understanding of what ‘sustainable’ means, the parliamentary Select Committee on the Environment said. Energy use and transport were not properly addressed. A government spokesman said the report had been written before new initiatives were announced. He said: “We are working with our colleagues in Defra to create cleaner, safer, greener communities, while protecting and enhancing the environment.” The report said there was too little attention paid to a range of environmental issues, including water, which is in short supply in some parts of the south-east. Building regulations to ensure energy-efficient homes are too lax and are routinely flouted, the report said. Funding for transport improvements is only one-fifth of what is needed. The report was a stinging rebuke to the government, and particularly to the department of the environment, Richard Black said. Peter Ainsworth, the chairman of the Select Committee, said: “The government’s housing policy is a shocking example of a lack of joined-up thinking in an area where a coherent policy is crucial. “I accept the need to improve the supply of homes, but the main beneficiaries of housing growth are going to be housebuilders, and the main loser will be the environment.” The report included several recommendations: The government should acknowledge the shortcomings of the Treasury’s Barker review, which said 140,000 homes were needed every year. The government should consider the introduction of a national spatial framework for England, similar to the ones in place in Scotland and Wales. The office of the deputy prime minister should do more to promote brownfield development and higher densities of housing. The government should set a timetable for zero-carbon homes. The government should make clear how it would measure success. Caroline Spelman, the Conservative minister for local government, said: “There is now a growing body of evidence that the government’s housebuilding programme is a complete disaster for the environment, a concrete scar on the face of the countryside.”

Labour has unveiled the slogan that will form the basis of its general election campaign, which is, to use the popular expression, ‘looming’. “Britain forward, not back” (no, it is not one of the temporal mottos of some extra-terrestrial temporal philosopher) is to become as much a part of our daily lives as the sky: always there but we no longer notice it. The word ‘Britain’ is on a red background – a tribute to the Old Labour. ‘Forward’, italicized and sliding cleverly forward, is on a drab green background. As one of the journalists gathered at the unveiling explained, it was all post-modern, something or other. The colours are – and I quote – ‘brilliant’. They’re not in the least wasted. Incidentally, the ad men responsible for the flying pigs and the ‘Fagin’ posters, which provoked protests from the Conservatives, are not being sacked, as the general election campaign director Alan Milburn has declared, but are ‘doing a very good job’. In his latest instalment of a series of pre-campaign public pronouncements, Milburn explained that the slogan was a reaction to the polls showing that the public saw Labour and Tony Blair as the future, while Michael Howard and the Conservatives were the past. Not many people, he said, talk about the “golden years” of the years before 1997. The campaign will be fierce, he said, because it will come down to a choice between Labour and the Conservatives. He declared that nobody would believe that it would be Charles Kennedy walking into Downing Street on the morning after the election. They could see it happening to Michael Howard, and of course Tony Blair. It was only right, he said, that the campaign should be concerned with scrutinizing the Conservatives’ record and their policies. Tony Blair would be in the forefront of the campaign. Between now and the election the Prime Minister will spend more time outside London than in it, but in the UK, not abroad, Milburn assured them. “He’ll be the one to lead the domestic debate, taking the flak, not ducking it.”

The captain of the Reds, Steven Gerrard, said today that Liverpool had little chance of winning the Champions League. “We have to be realistic, there are some great teams left in the Champions League,” he said on BBC Radio Five Live. “We will do everything we can to get through as far as possible, but we know that this year might not be our year. ” Gerrard has never hidden his desire to play in the most prestigious club tournament in Europe. Last year he said that qualifying for the Champions League was the most important thing, and there are rumors that he will leave Anfield if the Reds fail to qualify. According to the rumors, Chelsea would be the most likely buyer. And today, when he was asked about Gerrard's statement that Liverpool was struggling in the Champions League, Jose Mourinho supported the idea. "Rafa has time to build a better team, but for now it is a bit behind," he said. "We still have a big two months. " Gerrard, who was the first to score the goal that took the Reds to the last 16 by a fantastic performance against Olympiakos in December, said he still hopes to help the team to win this season. “We are fighting for fourth place, the final Champions League spot, and we are still in the two cup competitions, which are very important to us. We hope to defeat Chelsea in the final and then reach the quarter-finals of the Champions League because it is very important for the club financially and personally for me.”

A group of Polish artists has taken the cacophony of noises produced by the constant thumping of the buttons of the little Nintendo console to a new level. The Blippop Orchestra has taken the sounds of these games and composed musical pieces that are like Donkey Kong meets Norman Cook or Tetris meets Kraftwerk. In any case, the sound is unique. All sounds come from six Game Boy devices, both older and newer models of the Nintendo Advance SP. The Blippop Orchestra takes these devices, tinkers with their software and then connects them to a mixing console. For years Jarek Kujda, one of the founders of the group, has been into both experimental music and video games. “Three or four years ago I was playing experimental music, and that was when I first started using a Game Boy as a drum machine,” Kujda says. He soon realized that the console could be used as a primitive synthesizer. So if one Game Boy could produce music, what would happen if he had six of them? Kujda gathered five people who were interested, and the Game Boy Orchestra Project was born. “The Game Boy Orchestra Project is a more improvisatory project,” Kujda says. “We prepare a few patterns before a concert, and then improvise during the concert.” The group only plays four or five concerts a year. “Malgorzata Kujda, Jarek’s sister and a fellow member of the band, describes a Game Boy Orchestra concert as an incredibly noisy event,” Kujda says. “For example, I play more of the heavy bass and distortion sounds,” she says. “But everyone creates their own music, their own sound. At the concert, we just improvise. I think that’s the most fun.” They say the audience reaction to the group is mixed. Some love the music, and others aren’t sure what to make of it. As far as a source of music goes, these Blippoppers are not alone. Jarek Kujda says a lot of people make music using old school computers—things like Commodore, Atari and ZX Spectrum. “We want to make experimental music and not just covers of other people’s music.” “We’re like an electro-jam band.” They’ve already put out a few tracks on the Internet, and the group is planning to produce a CD next year. They’ve even found a sponsor—the Polish distributor of Nintendo products. To be sure, the Game Boy Orchestra members are not likely to be displaced by any other game musicians anytime soon. A new Game Boy Advance costs about $200, which puts it out of reach of most Polish music makers.

The pop singer, Delta Goodrem, was named best female singer at the first M-TV Music Video Awards in Australia, where the presenter was also the best male artist. Goodrem, who is known in Britain and Australia for her role as Nina on the “Neighbours” show, also sang a duet with her boyfriend Brian McFadden. Green Day and the Black Eyed Peas were named best groups, while Goodrem and the Peas won two awards each. Goodrem also won the Pepsi Viewers' choice award, while Green Day won the best rock music with American Idiot. The Black Eyed Peas won the best R & B and the sexiest music awards for their hit, Hey Mama. The local singer and songwriter Missy Higgins won the award for the breakthrough artist, while the best pop music was won by the winner of the Australian Idol show, Guy Sebastian. Cher was awarded the VH1 Pioneer of Music, which honors her achievements in the industry. The ceremony was held at the Luna Park fairground in Sydney Harbor, hosted by the Osborne family. The live music program included Carmen Electra, Missy Higgins, Kelly Osborne, Green Day, Ja Rule and Natalie Imbruglia.

Charles Kennedy tells the electors that his party will offer them a choice that is “honest” at the next general election. While the two big parties are competing to put on the lowest taxes, Charles Kennedy is saying that the Liberal Democrats are going to raise them. Having already adopted his party’s previous pledge to raise tax by a penny in the pound to reinvest in the public sector, he has now changed his mind. He wants to put a “moderate” increase of a penny in the pound on all incomes over £100,000. It will enable him to provide free student loans, free long-term care for the elderly and replace the council tax with a local income tax. This last policy will mean that around 3% of the richest will pay more, while the rest, pensioners in particular, will pay less. Both Labour and the Conservatives have hit him for these proposals, which they accuse of being unworkable and badly costed. It is therefore natural that they should say that it is not necessary to raise taxes to improve services. The Conservatives claim to be able to raise the services and reduce taxes by £35 billion of savings. Labour has put forward a budget of £22 billion but has not yet come forward with its own tax plans. However, unlike the old Tories and Labour debates, the Lib-Dems consider that the people are ready to support the wealthy with “moderate” tax increases to pay for the improvement of public services. It is an idea which is confirmed by the last polls which show that the people would prefer a higher spending on services than on tax cuts. As regards the issue of asylum and immigration, Mr. Kennedy claims that the politicians must not “foment an artificial debate” about the issue and attacks Michael Howard’s proposals for quotas. In the face of the two parties, which resound with the same voice, he is showing a different and more liberal approach. He is also very optimistic about the election campaign, saying that the Conservatives would not be a “significant” party in the elections. He is also repeating his refusal to form a coalition with either party after the election. It looks as if the leader of the Lib-Dems thinks he will have a privileged position after the elections. This is a dream that has often been dreamed of by a third party.

This will not be remembered as one of Paula’s great marathons, but in the character department it was the most arduous race she has ever run. The victory in the New York Marathon does not make up for the disappointment of Athens, but it will make one feel more hopeful and confident for next year. Paula would have had difficulty looking ahead with optimism if her last memory of the year had been Athens. Now she can put a line under the year and make plans for the future. Even if she had lost this race, it would have been possible to learn a great deal from it. One would have learned that one can dig deep when one needs to. There was a strong field and a number of the girls went into the race with the intention of winning. And although 2 hours 23 minutes was not one of Paula’s best times, it was not far from the record on a difficult course. In the days before the race, Paula said that in a way she was not running the race. She said she was thinking that if she won they would say, “Why didn’t she do that in Athens?” If she had lost, they would have said that her career was over. And many people were wondering what would happen if Paula, as in the marathon and the 10,000 meters at Athens, was forced to drop out. But that was not to be. Even if she had been beaten, she would have carried on running. The things that had made her drop out at Athens—those injuries, the lack of energy, and the stifling heat—were not a problem in New York. The only question was what position she would be able to finish. But, most important, in spite of all the expectations in the newspapers, Paula never doubted. If she had not been confident, she would not have run. If one is the best in the world at something, one always expects to win. Now Paula will take part in the 10K run in London at the end of the year, then take a well-deserved rest over Christmas and start the new year with a good deal of hope.

James Costin should have been paralyzed. He himself says that he was paralyzed by the accident that occurred nine days before the start of the race at the Olympic Stadium in Athens. He tells the story with a touch of irony, remembering his first thoughts after a truck driving in the wrong lane hit his rented car. “I had a lot of pain, I felt like one of my toes was broken,” says the Waterford man. “But maybe with a steroid injection, it wouldn’t matter. The back was like a fire. The muscles were ripped off the hip. But maybe, maybe, I’ll manage with laser therapy and ultrasonic, and I’ll run again.” Ten hours passed before James could tell himself that he wouldn't run in the second Olympic games. “The back was broken twice, the base of one of the vertebrae exploded, so I was pretty lucky that I wasn't paralyzed. I also broke my big toe, which was on the brake.” James didn’t get to Athens Hospital until ten hours after the accident. “For the first nine hours, they didn’t give me anything for pain, and it was ridiculous, it was 35 degrees. But after they took the pictures, after I saw them, I decided, 'This is my situation. Then, in three days, the ambulance took me to Ireland. The Greek doctors wanted to operate on James immediately, but he didn't want to do it until he came home, and he is glad of that now. “The Greeks wanted to put two or three inches of titanium rods along the spinal cord. They would have fused the whole lower back and I would never have been able to run again. But they told me that I could completely recover in natural terms, and this is an opportunity for me to run again, which is very important to me. “The Greeks put a lot of pressure on me to have surgery. The people at the Mater Hospital have been absolutely wonderful.” Three and a half months passed after the accident, and for most of this time James was in a cast, and after that six weeks on crutches and ten days without support. He was delighted to be able to walk without crutches. He was also delighted with his physiotherapist Johnston McEvoy in Limerick. “Johnston has done very well with acupuncture, and it has helped me a lot.” “They put needles on my backbone. Yesterday, I had a three-inch needle and I’m quite bad today. In addition, James was treated at the training center in Spala, Poland, where he has trained with three-time Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski for the past five years. “I was there for over two weeks at the beginning of September and did a pretty extreme treatment called cryotherapy. They have a room with liquid nitrogen, and it’s minus 160 degrees, and this gives a deep healing effect. James is going to Poland again on Sunday, where he will undergo cryotherapy twice a day, as well as physiotherapy twice a day and swimming pool work. These are all small steps on the way to what James hopes to race again next year. “I'm trying to get movement back. It wasn't very strong to lie down for three and a half months. I spend about six hours a day on physio and swimming pool work. I'm also going to the gym to lift very light weights to build up my muscles. I'm pretty full on in everything. By March I would like to be in training again, but that's just one step in the process. Whenever I move too much, my pelvis and lower back get stiff. It's about waiting to see how it responds. Maybe in four or five months my back will stop being so stiff.”

Paula Radcliffe has decided that she will run in the Flora London Marathon this year, after deciding her program for 2005. The 31-year-old, who won in 2002 in her first attempt, won again the following year, and will be trying for a third victory on April 17. "You can't get a better 25th anniversary than this," said race director David Bedford. "Having already announced the greatest ever field of men, now we have the greatest ever field of women. Three years ago, Paula broke the world record with 2 hours 18 minutes and 15 seconds, then came back a year later and beat the combined record by one minute 53 seconds in Chicago in October 2003. After a difficult time in Athens, where she had to give up in the Olympic Marathon, Paula returned to win the New York Marathon in November. But he left the possibility of the "Great City Marathon" to try to get the "Grand Slam of Marathons." London, Chicago and New York, the only other possible goal, but the Boston Marathon is held the day after London. "Boston is a race I want to run, but London is a special race for me," said Paula. "I don't choose races to avoid the pressure." I choose the ones I want to do. "I love the atmosphere, the people, the course, and I know it's always a great quality race. This year it's the 25th anniversary, which makes it even more special."

The fifth seed, Carlos Moya, was the first of the big names to go down in defeat at the Australian Open, losing to fellow Spaniard Guillermo Garcia-Lopez on Monday. The fifth seed, who had started the year with victory in the Indian Ocean, looked ill at ease from the start in the Melbourne heat, while Garcia-Lopez, ranked 106 in the world, took control from the first ball and held off a last-minute third-set rally to win 7-5, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3. The 21-year-old Spaniard will now face either Kevin Kim or Hyoung Taek in the second round. He was thrilled with victory in only his third grand-slam match. “It’s the most important victory of my life, as Carlos is one of the best players in the world,” he said. “I’m full of confidence now. I think I can beat any of the top players.” Moya said he had been playing well before coming to Melbourne. “I had a perfect preparation, but today was not the day.” Four-time champion Andre Agassi began what could be his last Australian Open campaign with a thumping victory over Dieter Kindlmann of Germany. The 34-year-old American, who was recovering from a hip injury in the early part of the week, stormed to a 6-4, 6-3, 6-0 victory. “I was worried about the injury, but it was a lot worse than I thought it would be,” he said. “I’ve worked so hard to be here.” “But the last few days I’ve been pushing through it, and it seems to be OK.” In other matches, world junior champion Gael Monfils used a wild card to win a brilliant 1-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-6 (7-3) victory over American Robby Ginepri, while 2002 runner-up Thomas Johansson came from behind to beat Peter Luczak 7-6, 4-6, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, and French Open champion Gaston Gaudio won 7-6, 6-2, 6-3. While Dominik Hrbaty, Ivan Ljubicic and Mario Ancic had easy victories, Albert Costa, the former French Open champion, lost to Bjorn Phau.

Sarah Claxton, a hurdler from Great Britain, has great confidence that she will be able to win her first major medal at the European Indoors in Madrid in March. The 25-year-old has already broken the British record twice over the 60 meters this season, lowering it to 7.96 in the AAAs meeting. "I'm pretty confident about it," said the athlete. "But I'm taking it one race at a time. As long as I train enough and don't overdo it, I think there's a medal chance. " Claxton has won the British 60 meter hurdles title three years in a row, but has not been able to pass on the national success on the world stage. Now, the Scottish athlete is among the five fastest runners in the world, and in the Grand Prix in Birmingham, she left the favorite of the Europeans, the Russian Irina Shevchenko, sixth. For the first time, Claxton has trained exclusively for the indoor season, which could explain the significant leap in her performance. In the past, the 25-year-old athlete jumped long jump, but after moving from Colchester to London, she decided to refocus. Claxton will know if her new training is paying off during the European Indoors on March 5 and 6.

Nortel Networks has sharply reduced its profit for the 2003 fiscal year. In a much-anticipated filing, the company said it earned 434 million dollars (about 235 million pounds), down from 732 million previously reported. But these figures, revised following an audit that led to the resignation of the Canadian company's president, also indicated that revenues were about 4% higher than first thought. Nortel shares, which had lost almost half their value since the end of the year, rose 1.4 per cent on Tuesday. In January, the company announced that it had conducted the audit. In both the US and Canada, authorities are still conducting inquiries into the accounting procedures. Also, Nortel released new figures for the 2001-2002 period, which it had previously indicated were understated losses. "We now have a solid foundation for the future," said Bill Owens, the president and chief executive. Nortel said that 12 senior managers, none of whom had been involved in the preparation of the figures, had voluntarily agreed to repay a bonus of eight million dollars. The company said these members of the management team shared the board's "disappointment with the circumstances that led to the restatement. "

On Monday the shares of the German football club Borussia Dnustrihausen went down despite the club agreeing a rescue plan with creditors on Friday. The club, which has suffered record losses and has debts, said last week it was in a "serious and potentially mortal situation with regard to the economic and financial situation." The creditors on Friday agreed to suspend interest payments until 2007. The news had pushed the shares up on Friday but they fell 7% in the morning on Monday. Borussia Dnustrihausen will also receive short-term loans. It estimates it needs almost 30 million deutsche marks to cover its wages and other costs until the end of the month. The club is hoping that all of its creditors will agree to a three-year delay in payments for the use of its Westfalenstadion. Since Friday, almost all the banks involved in its financing have met with club officials. But there are still three creditors who have not yet agreed to the agreement of Friday. One of them, the property investment company Molorsir, which owns the stadium, has a meeting of shareholders on March 14, and it is expected to discuss the rescue plan. As we have already seen, the chief executive, Gerd Niebaum, resigned last week. The creditors want a greater say in the running of the club. Borussia Dnustrihausen has also come under pressure to hire outside management. It had a record loss of 688 million deutsche marks in the year to June. And to make matters worse, Borussia Dnustrihausen lost 0-five to Munich on Saturday.

An injury-time drop goal from Ronan O’Gara put Ireland to the sword over Argentina at Lansdowne Road. Argentina, who were magnificent, were leading in the last minutes. O’Gara scored all of Ireland’s points with two penalties and five conversions, and Ireland thus retained their unblemished record in the autumn series. Argentina, with their better drill and sharper players, upset the Irishmen early on with a try from Federico Aramburu, and Felipe Contepomi kicked 14 points. And indiscipline let Argentina fly-half Contepomi open the scoring in the third minute with a simple penalty. He scored again in the seventh minute, after the Irishmen had been caught in a line-out. Manuel Contepomi, in a beautifully executed move, broke the Irish defence and fed his midfield partner Aramburu to score under the posts. At last, in the ninth minute, O’Gara put Ireland on the board with a drop goal. Two minutes later, Contepomi landed his second penalty. Ireland, playing against the strong wind and driving rain, were second-best in every contest, and they lost possession in the tackle against a rugged defence. O’Gara scored a second penalty in the 36th minute, but Contepomi landed another penalty in injury-time. The second half started as the first had finished. O’Gara scored a third penalty in the 45th minute, but Contepomi responded with a penalty of his own three minutes later. The Argentine pack was so powerful Ireland had no time to settle. The three-quarters had no room to manoeuvre. Ireland were forced to rely on O’Gara’s boot to keep them in the game. He scored two more penalties, one from 48 metres, to bring the score back to 13 with 13 minutes to go. Then Ireland got their chance, when Gonzalo Longo, the Argentine No. 8, was sent from the field with six minutes to go for a slap at the line-out. O’Gara’s boot swung the ball over the bar for his fifth penalty, to set up a nail-biting finish. Then, with two minutes left, the Ireland scrum got up and down the field, hemmed in on all sides, but with coolness and determination they brought the ball down the field and O’Gara thumped a second drop goal over the bar to complete a magnificent, if somewhat fortuitous, comeback.

A limit on donations to political parties should not be introduced yet, according to the elections supervisor. Fears that big donors could influence politics by influencing politicians have led to the cap being proposed. In a new report, the Electoral Commission says that it is worth discussing a £10,000 limit in the future, but not now. Also, more state funding for parties and more freedom for candidates in election campaigns. It says that in 2001-2002, £67 million was declared to the parties for the three-year period, with almost £8 million in donations of more than £1 million each. The report says that public suspicion of parties continues, despite the transparency of who is paying what. The limit would mean giving the parties more state money, which first has to be agreed and proven to work. "We are not opposed in principle to the introduction of a donation limit, but we do not think it would be wise to make such a radical change from the existing system at this time," the report says. If there were to be a limit, it should be £10,000, which is a small enough limit to be effective, but which would have been £56 million in 2001-2003. And the commission recommends that parties seek more small donors and suggests that tax relief should be granted on donations under £200. Also, the state should provide more money for parties so that every party with at least two members in the House of Commons, the European Parliament, the Scottish Parliament, the National Assembly for Wales and the Northern Ireland Assembly gets help. And it also wants to promote elections and thus increase voter participation. All local election candidates should be allowed to send out election material for free by post. The election budget should be moved from national to local level to improve contact between voters and politicians. The report recommends doubling the amount of candidate spending and reducing national spending from £20 million to £15 million. The election limits for general elections should also apply four months before the election, as is the case with all other elections. Chairman of the commission, Sam Younger, said: "There is no doubt that political parties have an important role in strengthening the health of our democracy, and to do this they need sufficient resources. " Our research shows that people want to know more about party politics and see politicians more accessible. But they are also reluctant to give the parties state money and at the same time unhappy with big private donations. We therefore recommend an open discussion about party funding in order to get the consent necessary for radical changes to the system."

For a long time now, the makers of the world’s tv, film, and game industries have been preparing for a revolution in quality for what appears on our screens. It’s called high-definition, or HD, and it’s already hugely popular in Japan and the US. In the opinion of experts, it will do for images what the compact disc did for music. Though, as I said, you need a new set that can receive the HD signals, and they’re expensive. It will be at least 2006 before HD becomes a commercial success in Europe. But Europe’s gamer-fans may prove to be the first consumers who will drive the demand. For you to see the HD images you have to have a receiver that can cope with the high-quality resolution. The next-generation consoles, however, are expected to be launched towards the end of the year or in the first quarter of 2006. Most new monitors and plasma screens can already cope with such high-quality images. For the next generation of consoles, support for high-definition is mandatory, the games director of digital content group THX told the BBC. All games will be playable in high definition. So consumers who have spent all that money on an HD set and have nothing to watch on it will be blown away by these superbly clear images. It will change the way people think about playing games. At the end of last year, Sony Europe president Chris Deering predicted that there would be 20 million HD sets in European homes by 2008. Previously, market research company Datamonitor had predicted a mere 50,000 sets at the end of last year, rising to a staggering 4,650,000 by 2008. But why should Europeans bother buying such expensive technology (about $4,000) when there’s not much to watch on it? Sky is planning to offer HD services in 2006, and the BBC intends to produce all its content in high-definition by 2010. Until the rights, formats, and the logistics of introducing the technology are settled, the number of programmes available on tv will be limited. Of course, every tv picture is made up of horizontal lines and vertical pixels. Most British standard tv sets have a picture resolution of 625 horizontal lines and about 700 vertical pixels. The high-definition image has up to 1080 active lines, and each of these lines can contain 1,920 horizontal pixels. So the image is up to six times as sharp as on a standard tv. “For the time being in Britain it will probably be only games that can be shown off, until the broadcasters get the hang of it,” says Dr Tuffy. But in that respect they’re ideally placed to be the target audience for high-definition, because they’re always looking for the best possible resolution, and the most engaging and exciting gaming experience. The gaming audience is the “sweet spot” for the industry. The best-quality games are developed for those aged between 25 and 34, who are likely to have more money and therefore be able to afford to buy large high-definition screens and high-definition projectors earlier than others. They’re also going to want to play games on the next-generation consoles, which are expected to use a larger capacity disk format, such as HD-DVD or Blu-ray. This will make it easier to produce more detailed and realistic games. The high-definition format does have a number of production implications for game-makers. It might make game-making more expensive, says Dr Tuffy. “And you’re going to see cross-platform development, where they can adapt a game from the PC to the console,” he says. “A Lord of the Rings game, for example, will get closer and closer to the film itself, particularly with all the special-effects from the DVD. And the transition between the film sequences and the game will be pretty seamless.” In high-definition, it will be seamless and just as good as the experience you have at the cinema. This may lead to greater convergence between the film and gaming industries, although not until the generation after the next-generation consoles. “It’ll be more like film,” says Dr Tuffy.

In the meantime, however, Real Madrid's Beckham has no intention of becoming a coach. "I don't want to be a coach, but I would like to run schools, I've wanted to do that ever since I went to Charlton's school." Beckham plans to open one in London and another in Los Angeles. "My other passion is the benefit of the poor — I am an ambassador for Unicef and it gives me great satisfaction." However, he stated that his priority was winning the Spanish title with Real Madrid. Real Madrid have now lost thirteen points to Barcelona, after losing 0-1, on Wednesday in Seville. "It is very painful and frustrating to see the results with the team we have, because it would be great to win the title with Real Madrid — I've been here two years and we haven't done it yet." But in a long-standing interview, Beckham also stated that the dismissal in Argentina, and the storm that blew up as a result, was the most significant moment of his career. "I think my dismissal in Argentina was the worst moment of my career — it was not just the dismissal itself, but the consequences that followed. I was lucky because I had Sir Alex, who supported me, and I had a strong family behind me, but I think it changed me." "I think it changed me for the better."

We will build a tower with a widening attitude like a spring-well Flowing with the fire of charity For the unclothed crowd, ruined by want. We will give them power. We will build a tower with a many-windowed silence; with promises for the ceased-journeyers; for the young and the old; for those who no longer turn to the west; we will give them power; we will give them power; we will build a tower, for those far and near; for those who have lost their dreams, who have ceased their searching; for the old and the young who no longer turn westward; we will give them power. We will give them power, We will build a tower, They will climb up like goats and soar like eagles, for who can climb higher than these birds? They will look through rose-coloured Gothic windows, they will see rainbows of blossoms dripping colors. They will have power, we will build a tower,

The August day you wake to is an astonishment. Black sombre clouds. Its bitterness. Breezy downpour. A thick slush envelops the rented cottage, the towels and the bathing suits hanging on the line. Dry-drained gutters gulp down the clear rain. Drops splatter from a leaking gutter with hard slaps of implacable force. You think with almost tender remembrance of winter, of the run from the fuel shed to the back door, of the slow ascent of peat smoke, of the smoke of the neighbouring stoves setting their own gloomy temperatures. As you sit there and think up ways to amuse the family, you can recall how barefooted games on dry sand had been postponed. Slot machines? A snack bar at a hotel? In truth, as you move the crumbs of your buttered toast around the uneven edge of the table, you’d rather go back to bed, as though you had a light illness and could be pampered with quilt, whisky and cloves. Let it rain. Let the clouds empty themselves like reserve tanks. Let the worms burrow up to the surface from whatever dark swamp they hatched in. Let the coffin-like boards of the garden shed rot. Let the shrubs slip out of their hold in the wind, the nettles lose their sharp edge, the wet-combed rat scamper back to its drain. Let the rhubarb leaves become a reservoir, a makeshift pond, a reservoir. Let the patter of rain on the workshop be like the applause on an old recording of a love duet. Let the bricklayers on the building site wrap their dejected sheets of polythene around their doomed foundations. Let the limb of the tree, ripped out of its socket, float for a moment in the air, like an olive branch. Let the tail of the rainbow spread out like a bird of paradise. Let the inundations subside. Let there be light.3 A thunderstorm has lost its wind, but nature, which does not like silence, fills the void with birdcalls. The hen, forsaken in her narrow, airless brooding-place, repeats herself ad infinitum. Hearts are being refilled like the rain-barrels. The hammers are back. The hum. The gossip. The snore. The sun is strolling down lanes overrun by grass, drawing attention to the carved-brass finials on the hotel where the chambermaid, the window wide open, is relishing the fresh, reborn world. Convalescence for the body and the spirit. Will we ever feel more reconciled with life, or know a more hopeful moment? How easily pleased we are. We forget, for a second, the dark nights of the soul when wind-driven lightnings set the flames of brimstone alight. Sadness is the perennial mistress; happiness is a rare flower, perfumed the air, so that our breathing is as easy as the breathing of a chest decongested with camphor. Relief is ecstasy, until death finally makes it disappear, offering us complete relief.

‘My mother was fortune, my father generosity and abundance; I am joy, the son of joy, the son of joy, the son of joy. Look, the Marquis of Glee has passed sentence on Happiness. This town and its surroundings are filled with soldiers, drums, and banners. When I meet a wolf, it is the face of Joseph. When I go down a well, it is a heavenly paradise. Where is the envy and greed? When I look at my fellow man, whose heart is as hard as stone and as heavy as iron because of avarice, his heart softens before my eyes into the generosity of the god Hatem. The dust of this world turns into gold, the sand into pure silver in my hands. I have an idol, so fragrant that, should his sweet odour spread over the earth, even an idol of stone would receive life through joy.’ Sorrow is dead for joy in him of whom it was said, “May God multiply your consolation”; how could such a sword not strike sorrow on the neck? With tyranny it takes the soul of the one he desires; justice is a slave to such injustice and tyranny. What is that mole on that face?’ If she ever reveals herself, my aunt will become estranged from my father because of her desire for me.’ I said, ‘When I finish my story and send it to you, will you complete it and tell it to me?’ He answered, ‘Yes.’

During the school soccer match, I bumped into the English teacher who teaches my grandson. During the shouting of the two schoolboys, I complained about A’s English literature and English composition, and I yelled at him about his phonics. He agreed, but said “take it easy on him, he’s only thirteen,” “they all want to be fifteen and ‘grown up’ at that age, and they can’t appear to be ‘for’ anything too much, so they mock everything, it’s either pretentious crap if it’s new, or stupid ancient crap if it’s from more than a generation ago, they even say that Shakespeare is a sad wretch until someone mentions that he wrote the screenplay for that film, but they’re intrigued that Matthew Marlowe was a spy as well as a lousy writer, although they haven’t actually read him. The teacher said: “And it’s those little things, like that, that keep me in this stupid job.

He was still small, she was still a child, But they were both being tortured, And had been for some time. Their father was cruel, and he hurt them in a painless manner. He shut her in a room upstairs, And left the house drunk, leaving her there. He hit him with his hand from behind, On the face. Their treatment was shameful. He could not stand, he could not resist. He needed food to become stronger, And he had no food. The little girl was left alone, In the darkness. She was holding her arm, On which there was a mark. Her wrist had been used to extinguish a cigarette. Her flesh was cut, leaving a bruise. He had been kicked while he was lying down, Kicked for being there, Kicked and thrown down. She had been the person, Only for her parents, Whom they themselves could injure when they were at home. They had been abused, Both outside and inside. Their pride had long since gone, And they could not even stand up, and simply say no! They died, when they were still only three. The little boy was protecting his sister, The little girl was clutching her teddy. They had marks, On their arms. But they had been rescued, Saved from further harm. I wish that I had had the courage, to have told someone, About the torture they were suffering, Each week. I could have changed everything, For this little boy and girl, Changed everything so that they could change the world. So if you know of any case, Of abuse, Call the helpline, Tell them today, Before a life is lost.

The butterfly was young, its delicate wing lace; the cricket was agile, croaking a song. The butterfly swayed and stopped on a rose, spreading its delicate wings, slowly sipping the sweetness. The cricket hopped up and down, and the butterfly was looking far away.

Poverty seems to be a repellent stuck on the poor, whose only fault is that they have no possessions or wealth to show off. Among wealth admirers and worshippers who find poverty disgusting, the prurients of wealth seduce them, stripping the poor of the dignity that they possessed, as though the fleas of poverty were borne by them on purpose. And the fruits of affluence are sown and sown with utter scorn, degrading the human warmth into little more than a mere dog's drool, where the fruit of affluence is sown. Diminishing human dignity, which the simpleton equates with possession, in turn degrades and emasculates the simpletons of the spheres of affluence. And poverty lays bare, like the leprosy of humanity, the lack of perspicacity and sagacity, concealed by the lack of humility which often mars affluent circles. Like a dilute influence, the proponents of wealth see, without thinking of it, as it were, the power which the poor exercise to reveal the unity of humanity, stripped of wealth, affinity and mobility.

Far north there lies a land, a marvelous land which the wind blows over. This is a great, gray, chaotic land, where everything is open and nothing is moving. There the restless traveler's soul is frightened by the sphinxes of Nature. But nature is not indifferent to her victims, and the ancients' sacrifices are demanded. So these gray rivers slowly glide along, sloping with languor, splashing in the reeds on both sides, bending towards the North Ocean. The plains, on which the emus pass, are gray; the grass, perhaps, a little greener over the dead; down there in the world where people are working, Dame Nature smiles as the hands of people have taught her; only the dead have the right to her smile in the wide desert land near the gray gulf. For the strength of a man is the strength of an insect before this great plain and river, and the life of a man is only a moment before the life of the eternally running current. So they do not take part in the small world's worries; every stout traveler rides like a paladin, cheerful in his soul, with plains around and blue sky above. And the brown lark sings, singing the songs that the strange wild country taught her; with grateful thanks, the sweet song rings - and I wish I was again at the gray gulf water.

The little power we have we give to others They govern our lives and we follow their orders The media they control and only their lies are for us, They warn us about terrorists and terrorism and fill our hearts with fear Of strangers we do not know and whom we may never meet They make us look at each new acquaintance with suspicion, Though they may be good people and fair and just They are our enemies yet we think they are our friends For their political survival, they depend on our fears And our enemies, our leaders are the same They make them fear us, they too play the game of power. We are ruled by selfish men who use us to deceive us, When they tell us who to fear they have us in mind And they tell us with a smirk that God is on our side. To lie to keep power they do not consider sin, Some call it propaganda, others spin And when the civilians of our enemies die in a bombing raid, ’tis but a collateral damage, as they say Is it fair that human life can be dismissed in this way? The little power we have is never ours We give it to the power-hungry, deeming it worthless, And they spread the fear in our hearts to keep their power, In a garden full of weeds we may find no flower.

Amidst innocent women - innocence, innocence, how to stay calm, and to know a place of peace. Innocence, innocence, the lies I’ve told - can the earth hold me? Innocence, innocence, who’s dragging you down? Failed by the system, innocence was taken away from me. I long for it back every day as I lie crushed under the earth. I might have survived if innocence had stayed - my refuge, my ground, my roof that was meant only to protect me. When I looked you in the eyes, you had gone to seek wealth and left me in an empty chamber filled with only anger. It’s just a rage to be taken out of my misery and released from this cage. Innocence, innocence, how can I bear this? Innocence, innocence, who’s pulling you down? Innocence, innocence, why does my freedom have to be destroyed over something material? A negative, inner emotional existence. Innocence is a very strange thing. Looking at my situation and realizing that nothing will change. Pure injustice is not the same as innocent freedom. Taking mental pictures, putting them in a frame. When they enter hell, I hope they’ll be burned in the flames. I’ll never be the same. To death what is victory? To enslavement what is a chain? Innocence was slaughtered when they called my name. I begged for a change, and they gave me death. Forget my innocence, they’ve forgotten me. Freedom is a game they’re playing with tricks and I’m left to laugh. On this slab, on my way to the chopping block, reaching out for my innocence, I feel the dull thud as they step on my chest and touch my face. ... Is it God or innocence that I seek? Innocence, innocence, why do I weep? Innocence, innocence, where is the truth in the midst of lies? Innocence, innocence, can greed hold me? Innocence, oh innocence, who’s dragging you down?

My pillow is drenched, my eyes are crimson. My soul is aching, stricken. I ought not to have heeded my heart’s warning. I am the victim of love. I am weak, I am a dove. Sweep me away, scold me, put me to death, I am sorry that I have loved you on this earth. I beg you, stretch out your gentle hands, pull out my guilty heart, burn it, melt it like ice and suck it dry. Only when my heart is pure can I stop loving you. You are a snapshot of the heavens. I cannot take my eyes off you. I have chosen you. I shall love you now and when I am no more. Your beautiful smile will inspire me all my life. I am crazy about your eyes, which have so many things in common with heaven and the skies. Release your soul and let it embrace mine, this is how I felt when I saw you for the first time. When I touch the softness of your rosy lips, my heart leaves its resting place in my breast. You are a symphony of beauty and ugliness. Hold my hand and walk with me, through the road of our destiny. I am old, a sick man, I am your tormented patient. Hold me tight, you are my last refuge in the path of love. Speak to me, whisper in my ear: Your soft, pleading voice is music to my ears. Love me, embrace me and make me happy.

A mermaid is not a human thing, and courting one is foolery. I’d rather sing of flesh and blood – that doesn’t get melancholy! Oh, Berta! Berta! Horny! Happy! Ally! Our Alley! The sea is deep, the sea is wide, but this I’ll prove no matter what happens, I’m ally in our Alley! The Hoogli – her face is brown; the Hilo – she’s lazy. The girl in bte is good for a living death, wet your lips and let it slip! Gretna is a good ship – sing, alley! The sea is deep, the sea is blue, but here is good health to you and me, Ho! Alley! He may drop us in a fish bowl, to feed his precious fish, but may he forgive us our sins – our sins are tasty! Drink up, fill up your cup! The world owes us bite and drink, and Mimi, Ju-ju, Sally; the sea is long, the wind is strong; the best of men can go wrong – h! Sha-bang! Bowery girl, she knows naught, Frisco girl, she’s a fool, Haiti girl – she’s not snow white – they’re whiter down in Chili! Now what’s the use of avoiding a drink? You’ll have your bones tossed into the gills, South-west by south-westerly. The sea is green, the sea is cold; the best of men will get old – sing, alley! All over the world I wander, I’ve learnt this lesson well – when you have a brain you stay at home, and you save what you earn. Don’t bother with the odds! You can’t tell them apart, when everyone’s got his own god, and no two add up: when they’re all black and white and drink, and fight, and swear they’re all good at three things – sing, alley! When th’ double bunks, fo’c’sle end, Is all the kindness we can see, our manners will likely mend – we’ll probably get married. But till that day we’ll have fun as we’ve begun – sing, alley! When the time comes to hand over your soul – sing, alley! From Trinity to Whitsunday, from Sunda Strait to the Golden Gate, and back to the Bay of Fundy, it’s Mabel, and it’s Nancy, and – I love you, and – sing, alley! And we haven’t done it – to the right woman – sing, alley! Oh, we’ve had octets and they are naught; we’ve had a Portuguese ship painty, and a Chinese lass with eyes half moons, and a Japanese – sing, alley! When the sun goes down in Tokyo-town, it’s half-a-pint and a crown – sing, alley! Once a man’s done he can drift! Sing, alley! The Hunghri-gal’s got a brown face, The Hilo-gal’s a fairy; The ‘Obart-gal’s a lewd minx. Then pretty and plain, it’s Sarah Jane – kisses and hugs and come again! Sing, alley! The sea is deep, the sea is wide; but one thing I will prove whatever happens, I am well in my lane, sing, alley! Bully for the Allley!

They have convicted Saddam and given the freedom of Iraq, or at least you tell me they have, But I have always understood freedom as a life without fear, while daily we hear of violence from Iraq. If you think Iraq is a wonderful place to live, you should try living there, and then compare it with the basic freedoms you enjoy, for you do not seem to be very clear on the matter of freedom, and I cannot believe in your ideas about freedom. You should spend your next holiday in Iraq, with your wife and children. You talk of freedom for Iraq, and all you can say is “Iraq has freedom,” and daily we hear of dead Iraqis. I do not recommend Iraq as a vacation destination, unless you want to commit suicide and end your life.

Father, I come to you again to ask you for more blessings. Oh Lord, I ask you for more blessings every day. Every day more grief, more devastation, more rapes, more murders. Opiate use increases instead of decreasing. Father God, people have forgotten their reason for being, they are lost. Father, your son asked you to forgive them because they did not know what they were doing. Father, when will they understand what they are doing? I struggle, Father, to read the newspaper and to hear of murders, of a body found close to the spot where a woman was raped and stabbed to death. Father, what sort of people are they? Satan is very active and still finds followers. I am very worried about the minds that he is still able to poison. Father, I pray that you take total charge and stop him, that you will make these people stop and think before they act, that you will make these people who may be suffering from mental illness seek help and let the medical doctors do what they are best at. Father, we need people who can show sympathy, love and care for others and not think of hurting them. Father, you are much stronger than this wicked person; I beg you to teach him a lesson. I know you hear me, Father, and I know you will deal with this evil, when the time comes, and only you know when the time is. I will never question your decision-making process, and I trust you. Father, I pray that I will see changes for the better in my lifetime. Father, let me see people hugging and caring for each other, instead of beating and killing each other. You are the greatest, the most wise, the King of Kings and I will always trust you and follow you. Father God, I truly trust you and I will always follow and love you. Father, I ask all this in the name of your precious son Jesus. Amen. Written on February 24, 2008.

You young fellows, who to-day are skirmishing in your father’s loft with bows and arrows and wooden lances, playing at the Royal Welch Fusiliers; happy though you are, who has warned you how all games end? From the first time that you bend and swing Your spears of wooden curtain-rod, From the first time that you draw and slash Your bows of garden ash, Or fit a feather to the end of your arrow-shaft, You are bound by fate to be brave and true, As champions of this stony earth, Faithful and true in all things, pledged to serve your army and your king, ready to die, starve and sulk under some glare foreign sky, if only to keep the happiness of English boys. The war will soon be over, A worse, a more glorious war; Then, boys, you will play the whole game, The cruelest team will win. Hold your noses to the stench, and don’t stop to think; Wars change only in name; The next one must go the same way; And new crimes, which no one had dreamed of, will win and justify this war. Kaisers and Czars will strut and reel Once more in their pomp and greed and rage; Courtly Ministers will stop at home and fight till they die; In some new dreadful agony, men will die by the million, And children here will thrust and shoot, Die, laugh and die, playing at the Royal Welch Fusiliers.

Who will marry the old lady's youngest daughter, the captain? And who with a glass of beer will set up a groomsman in her yard? He moored his boat by a stake in the water and staggered with a sailor's legs into the hall, where he met her lady-in-waiting, round-skinned and no longer so pale. Or a thrifty burgher in boots and fancy tuxedos with a view to marriage? He was overwhelmed by the neat scullery maid, who kept the house from becoming worse and filthy; but a wife does double work and takes no pains, so he rode her home in his carriage. No, never the gaunt young scholar, who was their second choice; They had him wait in the crypt of the old library, And found him compromised with a Saxon book, Claiming that his true love, learning, kept this nook and promised him sweet pleasure. Desirée, christened with her mother's grace, will never marry, Though the fairest child of her womb. We'll take our revenge, said the offended lady. The nunnery will be your bed at the top of the stairs, and we'll say to the bad lovers, She's not at home.

This poem was written by a dying girl in a hospital in New York. It was sent to me by a doctor— all because of the word “Rain”! The day you came into the world, the time you could not wait for me to get old, when you were allowed to go slowly through the gardens and enjoy the butterflies? Let's dance slowly, the music is short-lived. Are you running through your days like a butterfly? When you ask: “How are you?” do you hear the answer? When the day is over, do you lie in your bed, with the next hundred things running in your head? Don't dance so fast, time is short. Music is short-lived. Did you ever tell your child: “Tomorrow we will,” And did not see his sorrow? Did you ever forget, let a good relationship die, because you did not have time to call and say hello? Slow down. Don't dance so fast. The music is short-lived. When you rush to arrive, you miss half the joy of being there. When you are worried and anxious, a day is like an unopened gift. Thrown away. Life is not a race. Take it slowly, hear the music before it's over.

One day I sat in front of the mirror and conjured up a vision, bare and naked, unlike the bright and cheery ones that once reflected there—the vision of a woman who was lost, with more than feminine despair. Her hair sat wildly over her head, her face was ugly. There was no envy in her eyes to hide what no one had ever imagined. She was alone with no one, in a solitary grove, surrounded by thorns of wretchedness. Her lips were open and no sound came from between the red lines, Her hidden wound bled in silence. No sigh relieved her dumb pain, She had no voice to tell her fear. And in her dreadful eyes there was The dying flame of life’s desire, Mad because her hope was lost, And kindled by jealousy and vengeance, By strength that could not change or be weak. Shadow of a shadow in the glass, O set free the crystal face, Let it pass like all the other visions, Nor come back ever again, a ghost of a distracted hour, Which heard me whisper, ‘I am her!’

Night that tears between you and you and you and you and me—jolts us apart like a man thrusting through a crowd. Among the sideshows, beneath the signs of moving pictures, pictures made of a million lights, giants that move and move and move again, amidst a cloud of heavy smells—hot dogs, roast chestnuts—or going up to some apartment, yours or mine, and finding someone sitting in the darkness: who is he, really? You turn on the light to see—you know his name, but who is he? But you can’t see. The florescent light dims—a pause. But you still have the command. The light reaches for each face and lays it out, mask by mask, before you. You and you and I repeat the gestures that speak when words fail. We laugh and say, “I”—meaning “you”—and I. Nobody.

Today we are writing many verses, by God’s grace and command, by our courage and conviction. We are writing today to tell you God’s message in many poems, which you will read today and tomorrow. Today we write and today you read; and tomorrow you will read, read and read. In order to learn what is right and what is wrong; to guide the masses with their all-accepting service; to enable them to enjoy the bliss of divine attributes, love, peace and forgiveness; God’s wisdom will enable them to know life. You will not be overcome by delusion if you are awakened; you will not be bound by anything if you are detached. You will learn to live your life free of all attachments if you read every verse that contains God’s word. All the things in this world—name, fame, property, relationships—are impermanent; acquire divine knowledge when the time comes. All material things are connected to the body; but you are different from your body. At the end of the time of change, you will leave your body and resurrect yourself; all material possessions will be left behind and will perish in the course of time. Dear soul, remain awake, stay awake! All rights reserved.

All this was not my composition. I had been taken by the impression of love, and the overall composition was that of a master’s portrait, with all its parts, each in loving detail, the vein following the arm, from the large picture down to its small, insignificant details, which were like the more minute signatures of a secret signet, hiding in the inconspicuous background, like a little locket of a visible but barely perceptible locket. To the unseeing eyes of the world, the perfect melody I had played in my mind while the long fingers and polished fingernails were stroking the strands of hair. The moment produced only by the blast of beauty from the beloved Helios, For me, for me, how can I express my thanks but say “Thank you”? A brief ray, soon, soon, gone, I ask only the gods one more precious gift, given from their hands. Eros, beloved Eros, have my heart as long as his becomes mine, for I have no mind to give it to you, only so that I may render my song. A melody of my heart; let his youth be forever diamond-like, as my devotion to you. For one whole minute the entire world, all the incredible forces we dare not admit to existence, rearranged time and life to renew in one minute my soulless heart, to create the one measure of time that will forever and forever remind me how golden and brave love can be.

Passion is the chief motivator to achieve greatness in life; The boldness of a great leader to accomplish a dream is because of passion; When passion leads, reason will take the reins. Do not underestimate the power of passion. Without passion, religion is without spirit; Without passion, history has no meaning; Without passion, art is without value. When one's passion takes over, there is no dream too big, no innovation unimaginable, no frontiers to be crossed. Follow your passion and success will follow you. Our passions are the winds that propel our ship, our reason is the helmsman who guides it. Without the winds, the ship will not move, without the helmsman, it will get lost. Follow your passion and success will follow you! Passion is the universal language of mankind; Passion is the spark that lights the genius.

“How do you define a river? Is it just water, or water abounding in floods? A river is the life-blood of a nation; a river is the life-blood of my own soul. As the river travels along a long path to reach the sea, so shall I through this body travel towards my omniscient Master. My life is the purest of all, look at it, see it; my life is unique, highly developed. It is I who must flow unimpeded, to my omniscient Lord.” My dear, I have experienced every season, every whim, every desire; I have sailed the rivers of sorrow and happiness, and have flowed with the river of time to find salvation here. In the course of my eighty-four thousand births, I have arrived at the threshold of my present life; I have heard the words of my Lord, who said to me: “Flow on, river, into the ocean, and swell out into the deep. You are my Lord, my lord, you say! Flow, I say! I am with the river, to the ocean!”

It really upsets me when someone doesn’t finish a thought and follows something I don’t understand. From my point of view it’s still over there, between the trees, or caught in the branches—this is something they felt I had to know, something that they felt I had to know about. Children are pointing somewhere now, and the kite, with its destination and duration unknown, is floating up there, high above their heads. But then they stop and close their mouths, all unaware or else in denial of the fact that they let the kite hang uselessly somewhere in the still obscure sky. The sun reflects mutely off its bare bones and the taut membranes, the uncaught kite can float forever, like an airmanless or unmanned aeroplane, but its seconds must be numbered. And the unknown colours and the possible direction nag at me like a deathbed confession that is never uttered, or the tongue stuck permanently to the palate. Somewhere it’s now burning with a dull glow, and its small trail of fuel is a black blob on the horizon. The treasure is gone, the information never came—no one was saved. No one was saved.

Leander. No more of Memphis, of her kings mighty, of Alexandria, where Ptolemy taught commerce to spread out her pearls, and made wisdom smile; no more of Greece, where the world was made to shine by the light of wisdom. No more of Athens, which saw its geniuses rise up: the free-thinking Plato, the mighty Socrates, who with irresistible eloquence revived the spirit of liberty and shook the thrones of Macedon and the proud King of Persia. No more of Rome, enlightened by her splendor, rekindling the fire of eloquence, of divine poesy; of the mighty empire of Rome, whose broad dominions extended over half the globe, whose eagle flew eastwards as far as the Ganges, and westwards as far as the British isles. No more of Britain and her kings renowned: Edward, Henry, those thundering kings of war, of her kings victorious over the French foe; of her illustrious senators, of immortal bards, of wise philosophers, no more. But a theme newer and not less noble, the rising glory of this new world, where now science reveals her light to the East and wakens the Muses to song; where freedom lifts her sacred banners high, where commerce floods her golden waves with every joy of life, where liberty is reigning supreme. Since you, Leander, are trying to catch the echoes of a new time, full of fame, and a friendly company, where the sons of America gathered together, begin, O Muse!” And would you review the days when first Columbus touched the shore of an unknown land, when he braved all kinds of trials and dangers, hunger and death, wand’ring over oceans bearing perpetual storms. But, haply found, why should we resume the story of Cortez, the furious chief, who was consecrated to dye the sands of the Indians’ land with their blood, to fill with dead bodies the streams of renowned Amazia, which had not yet been explored? Or why, once more, repeat the history of Atabilipa, whose appetite for gold deprives her of life, which neither Peru’s rich ore, nor Mexico’s vast mines, could redeem. The newer kingdoms, those to the north, well deserving to be told, those discovered by Britain for her children, those unsoaken by the seas of Indian blood, which cruel Spain shed in the lands of the south, to win by the sword what the generous heart might win by fair treaty and without bloodshed. High in fame is that mighty hero who stands, Who, from the shores of Europe, took the first step to sail across new seas, new oceans, yet unexplored by man.” “Bold Hudson straying to the pole, Thro’ the cold north sea, To the indignant, choppy, turbid waves, Where Europe and America oppose their shores, Where confined and indignant the northern sea roars between. Not less would the Muse celebrate the noble deeds of illustrious Raleigh, the great hero, whose unfortunate life deserved to be recounted. Let a muse still young borrow from your fame to grace her humble song; there are many nobler poets than you who have sung your virtues, Envy can no longer darken the memory of your virtues, They are poured a new lustre upon Britannia. And the Atlantic, bold and fierce, Forsook the dangerous floods, and saw fair Virginia hail’d. The simple natives beheld the canvas rolling, And gazed away at the dark shore. For in her woods, America held a savage race of men from the beginning. How should we know, how could we tell, Where the Indian tribes arose?” Intractable, it has long defied the sages’ skill to investigate it, For tradition hides that mighty secret from all mortal eyes, How the nations first appeared, of south and north, And where they came from, what nations. Whether from some primordial head, In their own lands, like Adam’s in the east, Which the sacred oracles deny, And reason would oppose the thought. For when the general deluge had engulf’d the world, Where had their tribes found shelter? Where could they have found their fate, but in the ghastly deep? Unless, as some imagine, some chosen few High on the Andes escap’d the general death, High on the Andes in endless snow, Where winter reigns in the wildest rage. But here philosophers depreciate the idea, the earth, and hills and mountains, nay the whole world, knew not the universal flood, but when the waters had mount’d, rolled up by the winds, they shook and tore the drowned world, ’til the world, all-consuming, retreated, And left its ragged bed to be seen. And mayhap, on a journey, e’er reaching the north pole, the icy range of the seas, And Greenland’s east coast near the northern compass of America, the brave tribes of Israelites, Tartars, Tartars, came, over the ice-ridges, or by rafts, to those shores, first hidden from the world. In Peleg’s days, So says the inspired Hebrew writer, the earth was cleft in two—cleft eastward and westward, While the deep Atlantic rolled between. And traces, undeniable, remain, Of that unhappy land now drowned and lost; The isles that rise from the Eastern mains, are but the small fragments of that continent, the two extremities of which were Newfoundland and St. Helen’s: one, where the British seaman, with strange astonishment, sees the pole star shine above him, The other, at the head of the southern tropic, Where now the Pole-star seems to him like the sun: the second in the tropic of the south. The Bermudas, and Canaries, and Britannia, and Azores, and the famed Hibernians, were broken pieces of the same, and both are but fragments of a prodigious continent, that nourished armies, where now only ships pass. ‘Tis human fancy delights to wander, And longs to penetrate the secret of nature’s soul; He thinks his mind, with unshakable haughtiness, may ascend e’en to Heaven. Take, then, your broken isles, Your Northern Tartars and wandering Jews, And listen to what history reveals. Their ships, venturous and venti, Sail’d through the straits of Gibraltar, ’cross the western coast of Africa, to the islands of the sun, By them called the happy Isles— Flaccus sings, ‘cause they sported eternal spring; They clad the earth with fruits delicious all the year round. From such a voyage, this I conjecture: Some barque, with all her crew, Caught by the eastern trade winds, was carried before the steady blasts to Brazil, to the Amazon, to the further lands of the south. They stood there, and could not return; They had lost their land, and their skies. And many years past, a number grew, And spread them round the coasts; Those we call now Brazilians, Mexicans, Peruvians rich, The tribes of Chili, Paraguay, and those who till the shores of the long-flowing Amazon. When the first forces of Europe first reach’d these lands, How vast were their empires, and their kingdoms, and cities, and palaces, And how cleanly adorned were the nations, When the arms of haughty Spain broke up the quiet lands of the South? This discussion leads the confused mind from one eyrie to another, to question after question, more perplexed than ever. But this is clear: If from the east they came, Where science first, then revelation beams, Long since they have lost all memory, all trace Of their first stumbling block: Tradition tells Of some great ancestor beyond the lakes Oswego, Huron, Mechigna, Champlain, Or down the Amazon, which rolls Through many a clime, While others merely dream, That from the Andes, or from the North, some hoary fabled ancestor came to people their world. LEANDER. Oh, how dark is human nature! ’Twas here perhaps a wigwam stood, With all its savage inhabitants, or round Some mighty fire a hundred savage sons danced and cried by night; How different to the brutal race That had fled before them through the wilderness, Where were all the numberless red tribes that swarm From Baffin’s Bay to Tierra del Fuego to the Oronoque. In what superior fashion to the brutal race, That fled before them through the unbroken wilderness, Were all those numerous red tribes that swarmed from Baffin’s Bay to Tierra del Fuego, from California to the Oronoque. Unknown to fame, their life was careless, in ignominious ease. No lofty science opened to them, nor holy truth lifted the soul up to God; No fixed home was known to their wandering spirit; No golden harvests crown’d the fertile glebe, No city adorned the river bank, No rising tower crowned the stream. You see the scene change; The seafarer now sees our mighty towns, hails the land’s view and beholds A new, a fertile world, springing up; Commerce’s fair white sails gleam on the sea; Science lifts up her head, grace smiles on man; And peace, established by terrible war, improves the splendor of this ancient time. But let us trace, friends, the steps By which this recent happy world has risen to this eminence of high renown, to this high estate of wealth, liberty, and fame. Leander, I have heard you, Eugenio, narrate the happy story of the first discoverers of this happy shore; the fair history and the glorious cause which first led our fathers To visit the untried climes and the wilder forests, than Tartarian and Norwegian had seen; and to enrich the soil with lovely culture. The sun towards the west moves faster; no story or verse can stay its course, not the one which sang the fall of Troy and the stream of Sccamander. But let us follow a part of it: By persecution, oppression, and popish cruelty, our fathers came from European shores to seek this blessed country, to find a shelter from tyranny and hateful men. So they left their fathers’ homes and their friends, and plowed the seas in search of peace, They found new shores, and sylvan settlements, raised by each adventuring chief; Who, hot in their enthusiasm for liberty and freedom, Seek’d out untouched tracts, untrodden wilds, And framed new plans of cities, governments, and provinces. In that first and fatal year of discovery, they found no more to ask than the young Canadian, who discovered and founded New France, or the Virginians, who founded the cities of St. Augustine and Charleston. But what was the result, what was the outcome, of all that suffering? And what blood was shed, and what Indians slain, before the peaceable time was fully returned to our fathers? By countless inroads on new paths, By a series of traps in the forest, And unprotected landings on the land... Once, at Monangahela, at the source of the Ohio, A stout hero fell in valor and died in the open plain; His soul was too generous for those base bandits, who kill in secret and hate the day. And he asks our song of Monangahela, the bloody stream: The bellowing tribes, from the dark groves, the heavy hills, Assault the invaders, the savage horde. What then, O Braddock, the flame, the generous flame which shook your valiant soul? What then, the armed men of Britain, the most noble of her state? The savage foe, In the woods, lying, secure, What could the brave Virginians do, overpowered by such huge numbers, and with their chief dead? In the midst of fire and death, they carried him from the field, where many a hero lay in his blood. “O Halkut, so valiant, so young, O Halkut, brave son of fame! We still regret this unripe fate, and the fair Albion mourns this premature end, And Caledonia drops a tear for him, who led the most courageous of her sons to war. But why, alas, mention only the dead? Why disregard those glorious heroes who still breathe the same air and see the same light? Eugènio.” It is Acasto who is dead to us, and he who died yesterday is as much to us as he who died a thousand years ago. A Johnson still lives, he is a very well known man among the peoples, A patriot who is a master of all the magnificent arts of peace and war. He won for Britannia the savage race, insecure as the sea, fierce as the wind, cruel as death, and treacherous as hell. None but he had won them by benevolence; none could conquer them by humanity, before he rose up, He pity’d the unnumbered tribes, how unlike Cortez and Acosta, the pride of Spain, who were satisfied with blood and death. See their sad regions, smeared with ten thousand deaths, From Mexico to distant Patagonia, Where the howling winds beat against the southern cliffs, And other suns, other stars are born. Such is the curse of Eugènio, the absence of a human soul; but we have no cite of cruelty like Spain’s unfeeling sons. All the power of Great Britain, and our sons and daughters learn from us To conquer and spare; for cowards only take revenge on a vanquished foe. Gold, that fatal gold, was the tempting bait To Spain’s ravenous mind, thus came the wars, From Chili to the Caribbean Sea, above Terra-firma and La Plata, a waste of mountains, a waste of stones, of fields and plains. Those mighty lands, whose glorious past Was great Peru before, sunk in ruins, with magnificent cities and sublime monuments, the tops of which were erect. Had we but the happy choice of gold metals, of flaming diamonds, of precious emeralds, of blushing sapphires, chrysolite, jasper, of nobler riches than any which might have been found by a mining art, where every worker, the wife, the children, and the servants could find their daily bread. No one would enviously look upon their blissful bowers, as a Grecian muse envied their charms to a mortal race. Who was not a sage-minded man, A laborer in the fields, or one of the lawful kings, Who once exercised their regal hand, or those whose virtue raised them to the rank of gods? Imagine Laertes in his shepherd’s tweed, far from his pompous throne and his august court, working the soil where the west wind murmurs through the old trees, laden with red apples, fragrant peaches, and every kind of luxury the earth can offer; and, over the fields, the industrious oxen draw the plough. Vassius and Camillus, two Roman heroes, loved this life of rustic ease and sweet simplicity; escaping from the crowded Forum, they spent their age in the woods and the fields. How grateful to behold the crops rise, and see the golden fields sown, The meadows, bushes, and herbs, the calm grass, while the lowing herds graze over the grassy meadows and the bending grass, or slake their thirst in a flowing river. He lives in a thatched hut, he sits without fear of the storm, and the blazing fire cheers every soul, while a thousand faces are calm and serene; such is the lot of those whom heaven has blessed with a love of the country. Eugenio. Agriculture brings us so many blessings, It grows in the thickets of the forests; Palaces are raised in lands that had been empty or had been bleak wastes, where once only the tents of wandering tribes had been pitched to seek pasture, wandering from clime to clime. Then came the nations that hunted prey, swarming over hills and mountains, fierce as tigers or wolves. In Arabia, or in Tartar-land, where the plow never trod, No one could live there, but in our happy land it fills all the fields, from the shores of Maine to the Gulf of Mexico, from the shores of the Orient to the Mississippi. There is no famine, and plenty reigns, With plenty’s gifts raining down on our heads. A great Bellona, with her wild rage, withdraws to other seas, to the Danube, to the Straits which connect the Black Sea with the Aegean. The great Britannia reigns over the ocean, And calls every brave adventurer to behold the wonders of the Ocean’s domain. Our fleets far to the east are on their way to trade, And to the west they will cross the boundless seas, which old Rome, Tyre, or greater Carthage never knew.
