From the mighty Hudson’s deep-black depths the great city of New York arises, And her numerous ships of trade are born, Like shady forests rising on the waves. From the shores of Europe or the Caribes, yearly they return to bring the riches of those lands. This happy city of the muses, where science’s mysteries are explained, where the depths of the earth’s great learning are open to her sons. The great Newton calls them to join him, And traces the spheres’ rolling courses, and the countless suns and moons are displayed. And a school of philosophy! Blessed are you, America, with Liberty’s fair rays, And a ray of a milder religion. Nor are those alone, America, your sons have built, in the short span of a century, On your shady shores they raised and adorned with your blood. Of the numberless towns and villages, On the lakes and shady waterways, From the northern coasts of Nova Scotia to Pensacola, On the unfathomable coasts of the Indian Seas, on the fertile plains of the Mississippi. From trade, from trade they were nurtured, and with their help, the rich cities of the East may still rise and flourish, Because commerce is the source from which all nations draw the streams of their wealth. It is commerce which binds disjointed worlds, Confines the Ocean to narrower limits, and makes half the world her own. Since the earliest ages of man, On trade’s savage course he’s stretched his nimble sail, or sent the caravan slow and worn with age, over desert wastes and eternal sands, where human forms never appear, and there is not even a single tree, nor a lone cypress, nor the sound of a single fountain. It was thus that the golden ore of old Golconda was sent, and thus the riches of Ophir were brought to the wisest of men. Great is the praise of commerce, and the men Deserve our praise who ply it from shore to shore; the perils are many and great, and every wave’s a gaping grave, But the glory of these great deeds are due to science, Hail Science, the blissful gifts of Crete and Rome; The fair muses no longer stop at Chios, or the Olympus swathed in green woods; nor do they tread the summit of Hmus, where once the harp of sweet Orpheus once played, And so the soul of the wretched wife of Orcus was healed by his divine song; and all these great works owe their splendor to Science, a thing that hails from distant climes! And even now we can boast of an inventive Franklin, whose electric discoveries illuminated the bright flash of lightning, whose most recent inventions were displayed in the noblest halls of Oxford. And to this continent, they have reached, the latest, the best, where the Arts are just beginning to grow, and become Luxuriant and gracious, and even now we boast of an inventive Ben Franklin, versed in deep philosophy, a genius whose knowledge is as sharp as the electric sparks of the lightning, and whose understanding of the lightning reveals it all. And this is a land where everything rejoices, a land where Life, Liberty resound, Sweet Liberty. Without her, the noblest geniuses fail, and science is snuffed out forever. Acasto. This is a land where the noblest light shines, the Star of Revelation; its beams shine upon us, as once upon Palestine, and on all the Gentile lands, where now the drowsy Turk lies, enveloped in a blanket of obscurity. As lighted lamps have given light to men. O Whitefield, the darling of Heaven, I dedicate a tear. That thy language, laid in the dust, no longer reaches the slumbering soul; no longer does thy bold imagination depict the horrors of the shades; nor does thy charity relieve the poor. Let Georgia mourn, let all her orphans weep. The melancholy lyre sings to the sighs from far away: “No pain is so great as that which mourns the departing souls of holy, just, venerable men. For them pity from Heaven flies, to illumine the way to God.” Eugeio. All the mysteries of the future await our eyes, But where, Leander, since we know the past and the present, where do we dare to see into the future? Shall we ask what empires will rise there, where there is now only a desolate, lonely expanse? Where the melancholy eye is waiting for the day when the sons of Great Britain will rule from west to east and north and south—from the Pacific to the Atlantic? Such a glorious theme, but how can mortals pierce into the mysteries of the future and unravel the plots of Fate? If we had been enlightened by the bright coal snatched from the altar of the Seraphs, if we had been enlightened by the spirit of Jeremy and Amos. We would have known how to seize the helm of the mysteries of the future and to steer the ship of our imagination, but, however, I will not call upon the Muse, and we shall see how she will guide us. I see, I see kingdoms risen and kingdoms being built, cities and men, numberless as the grains of sand on the shore of the Ocean; and where the Ohio now weeps, there, too, shall rise many a town. And where the odious Mississippi now weeps in the midst of shady forests, peoples will rise, nations will grow, and states will rise, like those of Greece and Rome. We too shall boast of Alexanders and Pompeiius, of heroes and kings, slumbering in the womb of time, waiting for the joyous hour when life and light shall come to them. Oh, take us with you, O Muses, to the days when our sons will hear of us as of ancient things, as of the dawning of happy ages! How would I weep that we have been born too soon, at the dawn of happier times! For one or two, perhaps, our fame will not die. The sons of genius scorn to die, Immortal virtue is not denied to them, the Muses allow only those to slumber in the tomb who deserve the praise that virtue can give them. Eugeenio. What has been, shall be, and shall be, in the end will not remain on earth, but shall endure in the heart of the Muses. Though we have seen the great Empires rise in quick succession from the Assyrians, to Macedon and Rome, then dominion from there drove her chariot, and enlarged her sway over many isles, seas and inhabited lands; now, now, she has advanced to the West, to a new world; she has pushed onward to the shores of America, and made them the scene of the earliest marvels. Yes, far off, in the Arctic heavens, I see the spires of a Petersburg, Bergen or Archangel, shining with ice, Far to the West I see a new Palmyra or Ecbatan, whose ships sailed over many a kingdom, from the shores of the Pacific Ocean. Where they would carry silks from Persia, spices from Arabia, from the Philippine and Marian isles, or pearls and treasures from India, now to be found in the land of the Acapulcos. Far to the south I see a Babylon, as it was at the Tigris or Euphrates, with gleaming towers, and astronomers who would see God with telescopes, and conceive more splendid ideas of his glory in the blazing suns and dazzling stars, than poor Chaldean did naked-eyed. undulating with a thousand isles where gold-plated buildings glisten. The great nation that would rise and hold the whole continent will be that which farms the banks of many rivers, and with a crystal stream from the Apalachian hills, bathes the sands of Carolina and Georgia, and stretches from thence to the burning line of Saint John, Clarendon or Albemarle. And you, you Potomac, that runs through the virgin groves of Virginia, will rival the Thames, Tiber or Rhine, in commerce and commerce; because I see a hundred towns, and countless ships, and tall ships borne down with the tide. At distant epochs, far from their ancient banks, guided by a great king, they will have changed their course, or their cataracts will be cleared, and they will carry a thousand ships, carrying goods and men. And from the coasts of Labrador, the peaked islands, a thousand ships will push the wind and spread out their merchandise to the ends of the earth, or they will carry their roar through the world conquered. Laedner. And forever, here, beautiful freedom will reign. it is a great procession of patriots, a long procession of those who have fallen with equal fame as those who died at Athens or Rome. The sons of Boston, brave and firm, the great protectors of our injured rights, will fade away in the rays of these famous patriots and the heroes yet to be born. I see the happy age come, all lit up, all radiant with the brightness of the midday sun, I see Homer and Milton arise, with the pomp and majesty of the song, which gives immortality to the deeds accomplished by heroes in the fields of fame. A second Pope, like that Arabian bird of which each century can boast, may yet arouse the muse on the silent Schuylkill, and will make new forests bloom there. The rocky Susquehanna, in its bright meanders, which the nymph of the mountains first heard the inelegant music of my country poem, will still resound with a heroic song when some future Hambden rises to fame. And the transparent waves of the James, the Roanoke, will murmur like music in the wind; another Denham will celebrate them in gliding numbers, in harmonious and flowing poems. In the background of the Tuscororah hills, as on the slopes of the Pindus, new Theban poets will reach the heights and swim through the azure depths of the air. In the midst of the green shade of their thick groves, sweet music breathes through the darkness of the night, and they sing about the origin of those fair stars that gild the firmament; why the wind murmurs in the green woods; why the waters flow from the summit of the mountains, and the ocean is lower than the land. They sing about the final destinies, about the big result of our efforts here, about the last day of glory and the renewal of the world. These are their topics, because in this happy age, the enraptured bard disdains the ignoble anthem, renouncing smirks of mind, enjoying the perfect harmonies of souls; the beautiful science smiling, the glorious truth, the peace which has set the world at rest, the happy prelude to Emanuel's reign. Ah! in the time to come, (so sang the exiled seer of Patmos), a new Jerusalem will descend from heaven to our earth, perhaps this one, where millions of saints will be received, although a little late, with their almighty king, to live and reign a thousand years in this paradise, which will not be lost because of a second Adam. No toads shall grow, no briers, no thorns, earth's curse before, the lion and the lamb will graze in mutual friendship; the tame deer will graze with the tame tiger on high meadows, on high plains. Another Jordan will flow, another Siloah will gush from eddies, the trees of life will adorn their banks, the happy population, escaped from a second death, will find their safe rest, the waters, still green, will flow under the green branches where the happy people, free from a second death, will rest peacefully, for no terrible diseases, no fevers, no violent and slow consumptions, no cruel plagues will again renew the perpetual war of death. The music of charms will swell the lofty soul, the triumphant reign of harmony will reign in all the groves, the cymbal and the lyre will delight the fallen man. “Ah! Ah! what days the world will see when the future comes, and when only the years of bliss remain. Acasto! This is your praise, oh best clime! by science visited, richly furnished with all the luxuries of life. , the last scene of Time's effusion, the theater where the kings will come, the last theater where the winds will raise their fair scenes, the waters will gush forth in dancing cataracts, the rocks will grow manifold, the white and the black will have no duality, the days will have no ages, the suns will not die and the moons, which are sacred, reflected in the eternal calm of the blue skies, the mists will not fall, the mists will not fall, when the Last Ruins, in their fiery car, will travel over the creation, when all nature will fade in the womb of the night.

My own, said the cat, stretching forth his gloomy paw. My lover, my friend, my slave, my plaything, said the cat, as he mimicked on his breast the gesture by which he sucked milk from his mother’s forgotten breast. Let us go into the woods, said the cat. I will teach you to read the odours, to become insinuated in the darkness, to wait like a trap, to hunt. Now I will lay on your doorstep this fat and warm mouse. You feed me, I will endeavour to feed you; we are friends, said the cat, although I am more equal than you. Can you jump ten times the height of your body? Can you climb trees, jump from roof to roof? Let us feel one another. My sentiments are as pure as crystals of salt, and as hard; my desires are as lucid as my eyes. I sing to you in the morning, as I walk around your bed and on your face. Come, I will teach you to dance as easily as to sleep, wake, and stretch yourself out. I speak of greediness with my paws, and of fear with my whiskers. Envy strikes me with its tail. Love speaks to me wholly, a word of fur. I will teach you to be as still as an egg, and to glide like a wind through the grass.

Sometimes in life I wonder, what am I doing? I have the energy, but there’s a storm brewing. I’ve lost control of myself; I just turned away, and now I’m with someone else. The days are flying by, but I’ve so much to do. I’m looking at a face to lead me through. Time won’t wait, it goes marching on. Everything seems to be wrong. I just turned away, and everything’s gone.... Sometimes in life I can’t believe what I see. I pick up the pieces, but some are missing. I look for the answers, but I seem to be guessing. Sometimes in life you can’t find what you need. You’re so empty inside, but there’s nothing to fill you up. It’s hard to find the path when you’re not sure what’s right. Sometimes in life I feel I know my way. It’s just around the corner, I’ll get there someday. When it seems hopeless, faith carries me through to a safe place. Sometimes in life I feel better. But the rain still comes down and it gets worse. It’s still a way to go until I get there, then I must stay. Sometimes in life I want the truth. But it’s surrounded by lies, and they’re breaking through. The answers don’t match the questions I find. Uncertainty steals my peace of mind...

She is not the end of my rainbow, she is the beginning; I am blinded by her colors; her red, crimson, blood-red lips, which promise me fire and burn me with the raging stream of the bloody river which she gives me in the eddies of her passion. Her cheeks are flushed with that same color, and above her violet eyes, her aureole shines and spreads its radiance, down into my soul, where our rainbow of yellow lives. Yellow is the color of joy; we are connected, shared, framed by her tresses of the same hue. Her orange, which is mellow, descends along the dotted line of her bared back, right down to her nipples, which are erect with desire and the color of orange. The blood in her veins is now violet and indigo, her blood, which flows beneath her skin, announcing the purple promises of her body, which is now high, forming a rainbow-shaped arc, which makes our colors merge, the semicircle reversing itself to let me into her deeper tones. Outside the trees are green, inside our rainbows sing, announcing another beginning. So I catch a rainbow every day, and marvel at it, lying on my bed of a thousand lilies.

Slap, slap, trot, trot, slap, slap, along the lonely highway, a little hot and lots of strength within, it is no marathon. Those morning runs I used to make in the cool morning air, wearing only one shoe, some of the neighbors said I was a lunatic. One day it was thick fog. I couldn’t see the houses as I ran by, but my strength was soaring, I had gas in me. That evening’s barbeque with chili beans and Weihenstephaner had given me the ability to run in seventh gear (carbohydrates). But chili beans can explode and blind insects with their steam and sound like a thousand vans. Outside a house that was more stately than most, it was a thunderbolt and it scared the bejesus out of a handsome gnome, and there she was, a dingaling. “You think it makes you run sso much ssshorter and ssssafer?” “No,” I said, “it’s just fun and afterward I feel fresher.” She nodded as if thinking, and I gave her a little wink, as if I had an idea, and then it happened again. The place had been darkened and I blasted off with all my strength into the fog, and a crimson glow came over me, I could not stay any longer. I ran off with all the strength I could, my face crimson red, and left the words: “You doggie! I understsnd.”

Imagine that I’m sitting here, hiding in the shadows, while you go chasing Beauty across the land and sea. Imagine that while bleak streets of brick and stone Vainly partake of heat, noise, and dust from morning to night, I escape from the dismal present and am left alone With a new and now enfranchised sense. I’m lifting on the wings of a rare poet’s song, I’m soaring in the sky as free as the wind. Who has a firm hold on things? Who wanders in the shadows? Who reclines in some darkly bright wood Between sleep and wakefulness, where pine needles Fill his couch with the soft brown drooping sprays of pine? Does he own the actual or do I, Who paint on the air more than his senses are receiving, See through closed eyes the shining pine tufts, Smell the strong resinous smell, see the sky quiver like a blue flame between the leaves, And open unseen gates with a golden key?

... At the lonely spot of the leaves, where they hung from the eaves, a bright, gay song-bird shot into the air, and the baby in the bed, his head lifted, his eyes wide open, woke his mother, and made her watch the bird; she kissed his sweet chin, the red soles of his feet, his wild-haired hands, which patted hers like wind-blown flowers; he twisted her blond hair around his neck as white as milk: “What does that birdie sing on its green sprig yonder?” “That’s a whole lot of songs,” said the baby. “Papa is coming home with the drums today, he says. Here’s your cup, birdie, you can drink all the milk; I’ll kiss you, birdie, you’re washed clean and pretty.” She got up, her eyes looked to the heavens, she sent her stout dove soul up through the light; she kissed her hand, and on it the golden band that bound the splendid scroll of her life and closed her simple story.

It is also an image, in which the way things are is drawn, a door, a crown, a shield, a scuff mark. And those who know you, or know their own sense of themselves, know where you are. There is a moment between utterances, when the present moment offers nothing; and one's thoughts withdraw from the present; one enters into a peaceful, orderly room; in it the shelves are set out by an unknown librarian, who knows you better than you know yourself. I sit quietly in that green-leather chair; but such is the power of the memory of you, of the pure memory of memory itself, that I need not pull down the well-thumbed book, but simply look toward the shelf, and where it rests; I sit for a moment, eternal; find myself; and then I get up, I walk, my back straight, my head up, my head high, my bearing fuller from the memory of who I am; turn the smooth handle of the door as it shuts, and then, outside of all love, comes the long-lost freedom of the watcher.

January is jumping around in the frying pan, trying to warm his frozen feet, like a Canadian. February crawls under the lid of any pot or pan, and believes she is dry, for she is completely hidden, but it rains all the month, and has always rained all the month. March is in the bathtub with the taps running. A good wash and a good rinse, more, more, more. April scurries about, sometimes inside, sometimes outside, escaping a shower of bright rain in an empty milk bottle, and then rushing out again. May is nowhere to be found, not even in hiding. It is always walking along the wall, proud as a peacock. May, oh May, so leafy and flowery! June takes off its clothes by the stream, and dips into a bucket of cream for the first time this year. July sits on the beach letting the sand run from its not-quite-so-stiff hand. Sometimes she thinks sad thoughts: “As I sit here, ah, I’ve lost more than half the year, a year that slips away.” August is the great August, once given a name by a king. It is golden and purple like a triumphal arch. (I know it rather cold and wet, though.) September lies in the shadow of the dying summer, hearing in the distance the silver trumpet of winter, and not very far off, the drummers of autumn. October is apples on the tree, partridge in the wood, big wind on the sea, mud starting in the lane, bright red berries, the big tree shaking its head furiously. November is when the fires are in the air, the shivering leaves and the mourning tree. November, November, a star shining with many things that were, but few things that are. A few weeks from now we’ll hear the silver bells of the sleigh of the stag and the hark of the sleigh bells flying in from the tundras and bringing us the gift of Christmas Day. December, last and twelfth.

One of my favourite poems.... The sea is calm tonight. The tide is full, the moon lies brightly over the strait. On the French coast the light flickers and disappears; on the English coast the cliffs sparkle and stand, glittering, remote, in the tranquil bay. Come to the window, the night air is delicious. Only, from the long line of spray where the sea meets the moon-white land, you can hear the ringing noise of the pebbles that the waves draw back and throw, on their return, up the high shore, start, stop, and start again, trembling rhythmically, bringing in the eternal note of sadness. Sophocles heard it long ago in the Aegean, and it brought into his mind the muddy ebb and flow of human misery; we also find a thought in this sound, listening to it from this distant northern sea. The Sea of Faith was once full too, and around the earth’s shore lay like the folds of a wide, glowing belt. But now I can only hear its melancholy, long, retreating roar, retreating, to the roar of the night wind, along the endless, dreary edges, and bare shingles of the world. Oh, love, let us be true to each other! Because the world, which seems to lie before us like a land of dreams, so diverse, so beautiful, so new, has no joy, no love, no light, no certainty, no peace, no help for our sorrows; and we are here as on a plain of night, rife with confused alarms of flight and battle, where ignorant armies clash at night.

Madame Doctor, Madame Brundrihg, take off your glasses, take off your wig. I am your entertainment. But frogs come from the sky like rain. They come like ugly, wild things. You are my judge. You are my jury. My faults are the things we're listing. I'll take a knife and cut up the frog. The frog has no nerves. The frog is old as a cockroach. The frog is my father's genital. The frog is a warped doorknob. The frog is a soft green bag. The moon does not want him. The sun wants to turn him off like a light bulb. At the sight of him, the stone washes in the washbasin. The crow thinks he's an apple, and drops a worm into him. The touch me nots are blown away by the frog like electric worms. The putty will have him. The putty has built him a house. Mr Poison is at my bed. He wants my wieners. He wants my bread. Madame Brundrihg, he wants my beer. He wants my Christ as a souvenir. The frog has a stye and a parasite in its throat. He says, kiss me, kiss me. And the ground is soaked. What an adorable princess who at that moment was walking in her garden, threw her golden ball up like a bubble and dropped it in the well! It was written. s the ills are given by the tarot. s the Supreme drills a hole in our heads and plays us the Boston symphony. But I'm getting out of hand. A loss has occurred. The ball is sinking like a cast-iron pot at the bottom of the well. Lost, she said, my moon, my butter cow, my yellow moth, my Indian rabbit. Obviously, it was more than a ball. Such balls are not sold at the Bon Marché. I had the moon, she said, between my teeth, and now it's gone and I'm lost forever. The thief robbed in the day. Suddenly the well is steaming and thick. A frog appears. The eyes are like two peas. The body is bound up. - Do not be afraid, princess, he said, I am not a beggar, a cattleman, a shepherd, a porter, a postman, a worker. I come to you as a merchant. I have something to sell. Your ball, he said, for only three things. Let me eat at your table. Let me drink at your cup. Let me sleep on your couch. The princess thought to herself: old toad, you will never do these three things, but she promised them, hoping to get her ball back. He took it in his mouth, like a cunning fox, and she ran back to the castle, leaving the frog alone. And in the evening, at dinner time, there was a knock at the castle door. A voice said: - Princess, let me in. You promised, let me in. I left the skunk cabbage to live with you. At that time the tenderhearted one had heard the promise and had to fulfill it. First, the frog sat on her lap. It was a coffin. Immediately he was at his plate, at his bacon and liver. - We will eat together, he said cheerfully. The fork trembled as if a little engine had been inserted. He sat on the liver and ate it like a professional. The princess was choking as if she were eating a puppy. He drank from her cup. That was not hygienic. He drank from the cup as if it were Socrates' hemlock. The bed came next. the king's silken bed. Ah! The seventh hour! - I was left in the river of the closed doors, he said, and I walked over the wet stones to live with you. She woke up with horror. - Frogs and birds I am sorry for, but not frogs, she said, and threw him into the corner of the room. Boom! A handsome prince rose up in the corner of the bedroom, like a genie from the samovar. And he was good-natured and gentle-looking, and his hands were sympathetic, and he was a friend to the unhappy. And so they were married. He had a princess encumbered. He had a night watchman and a fence around the room, and the well was closed so that she would not lose the ball again, the moon, the Krishna head, the blind poppy, the innocent globe, the Madonna bosom.

Someone I don’t know stuffed my car’s exhaust with newspaper. I have no enemy; I’m a stranger in town, so why is some stranger trying to ruin me? My car was behaving oddly, and I rang the RACV, And what the mechanic found surprised me a great deal. A newspaper rolled up, jammed in the exhaust pipe, by someone who wasn’t nice at all. I’m not without sin; I cast no stone, But if you don’t like the look of me, leave my car alone. Against the person who did this, I couldn’t hold a grudge, And since I’m not a judge, Of that karma will surely take care What goes around comes around, that seems fair enough. A shallow-thinking person with low self-esteem, Could only do such a thing, it seems. And I would like to tell this person, don’t harm my old car. You shouldn’t hurt my car because you don’t like me.

To find your true happiness, tempt fortune to discover your destiny. Remember the era when you experienced real happiness; opportunity knocks; open the door, you'll see it come. You may be surprised to find that fortune can conceal your fate. The fate and the destiny are not one. The fate is that which you have accepted in life, it is the daily pattern of life, a matter of life. The destiny is a gate at the end of the road, which opens to love and happiness. Is it really peaceful in the mind? At the end of life, the fate may leave you at the gate of destiny; you know only the suffering of the fight for life, but you do not know the joy of the victory. The gate may not open; you may feel lonely and sad at the end of life. The path of destiny is yours, yours and yours alone; do you want to be satisfied with the fate, or... do you want to tempt your fate and find the path? The dark side of life is that fear and uncertainty will obscure the path. Whether it is in your memories or in the situation in front of you, the path is always there. People who have known their love and the strength of their minds, the path is clear. In these traits, they can find themselves, and they will find the key to open the gate. The fate is the light, the light is the way. Your choice: be satisfied with the fate, or walk with the light. Find the key, open the gate, and find your destiny.

Why did I come to see you last night? Perhaps being alone and bored at home forced me to come and see you. Or maybe I needed an excuse for a meal, Because every good action needs a beer or two I was ready to leave, But suddenly, "We have beer upstairs. " I couldn't say, "Work and think about it" Because her boyfriend was pushing her to go to the bathroom. You're too old to fight, And yet you fight, Thank God for that boy. Why did I dance on the counter? Probably because it's more difficult to win the pink than to be a fool. I don't know, but the precaution was necessary to celebrate. Why did I kiss the town? It's like a kid, You don't know that, But the other one is twice your age. But it's better to be like a model with every coming drink, than to be like a bull. Why did I stay at his house? It's like you fell asleep in the evening, The children play with their mother, one is already in high school, The other is in college, Learning about the knowledge While Mom is sitting on you. I've already said it, I'll say it again, Don't make a mistake, stay out late, and fight, And if it doesn't work, let's fake it for today.  by David Desantis 1994

With a smile on their faces, they go and meet With the business of the country in a way, thousands of hours are wasted in procrastination The emergence of the rioting scene usually takes place One in a million chances succeeds to achieve a goal The whole country is in the grip of caste and religion No one has spared the Indian soil from the greed of the world. Who is still keeping the world? The people are very displeased with such a liberal democracy; it has established the supremacy of the people in every respect; Everything is done with the pretext of people's benefit; On the contrary, the interests of the people are overlooked, and their interests are being compromised. The judicial system has become inaccessible, and has failed, Some selected cases are getting public notice; It is very sad to see such a poor show in the world's biggest democracy, where you have not only promised but also imposed on the people; The people have a right to know what is going on in the sacred land. Each party is busy in its own interest. It is not a matter of concern to the national interest, but a necessity for its survival. All priorities of the country are a mess. We really hope that the country will survive in this situation. There are many good steps to be taken and revived. The country should protect the poor and their interests. The politicians should come forward to serve the country at their best.

I am a poet of the Hudson River and the heights above it, the lights, the stars, the bridges. I am also, by my own self-appointment, a poet of the Atlantic, of the hearts of peoples as they pass it in steerage, strange and foreign, to the land of the new America. And so I must map out the realm of emotions. For I am a poet of the kindergarten (in the city) and of the cemetery (in the city) and of rapture and ragtime, and also of the secret city of the heart and mind. My song is the song of the natural person, in the twentieth century. It is true, but only partially, that a city is a “tyranny of numbers.” (This is the refrain of the metaphysical, urban, metropolitan self, after the two world wars of this century.) The city person gazes from window to window at night, when checkerboards of dim yellow light shine on tombs and on countless mortal frames, like the boards and slabs of the old graveyards, in which many lives are buried. The city person sees and says: “More, more, more, always more.”

I wish my parents wouldn't fight; I feel like a cat in a corner that no one notices. They act like robots who have lost control of their motors, bumping, moving like clumsy cars, not like parents. They sound like gruesome black crows, if it weren't so serious. I am afraid that when my parents fight, they will divorce, or go their separate ways, and leave me. When I argue with my sister, it's usually because she's playing cards, but when my parents argue, it's like a knotted string, a winding yarn, I can't figure out the beginning. I want to help, but my words get tangled and don't come out. I want to be a bear for a while, go to sleep in a hole and hibernate forever, or run away, but I usually go to bed with my clothes on and lie awake. Maybe they won't separate, but I can't be sure, can I? It's just like an earthquake. This is a possibility I don't like. It's like something bad is always chasing me, and it's like I have a sign on my back that says "My parents fight", and everyone looks at me.

And a stork came one day to a city with an infant behind its wing, and it brought one to the house of a rich man, and one to the house of a peasant; he said to the rich man: "My son shall be the king of the land and seas," but the poor man said: "God has sent me to feed another mouth to bite." The rich man's son grew up to be strong and handsome, and he lived by the rule of a millionaire, and he crowded years in one day. He bought his position, his fame, his house; he bought his wife a fine-looking face; he traveled the world, but in his heart was discontent, like a snake hiding in the leaves; and life was as hollow as a gold elixir; he despised woman and doubted God, and he died like a beast and went back to the earth. The peasant's son plowed the earth, he thanked God for his health and labor; he married young and mingled two lives, in tune and time. His needs were simple, and his faith was simple: it was to trust God in everything; it met his need, and it helped him to work, and helped him to die with a smile on his lips and a hope in his eyes. So who was the richest of these two?

Lord, our refuge and strength, when we have to believe, O Lord, our Rock and fortress, when “in God we trust”, they have dared to attack an army that proclaims you, Lord! Save us from their hands, with your blazing sword, our Father in heaven, shield us, your battle axe, and give us victory in Thy name, Lord of Hosts, so that all the earth may know. “In God we trust” as the first priority. The Lord of Hosts is with us, He is our refuge, He makes wars cease, He breaks the bow, He breaks the spear, He breaks the chariot, He puts chariots to flames; He makes wars cease, to the end of the earth, He breaks the bow and breaks the spear, he places the chariot to the flame.

However, what if the Greeks were right? If, although some of us may want to climb up Mount Olympus (a rocky climb is exhilarating in the fresh, wet morning, and the smell of coffee, of baked bread rises from the valley below, the shrill call of a shepherd higher up, the shrill bleat of a goat, and finally the fog and the thinning air and the growing humility and surrender of the heart)—if we all, all of us, perhaps to varying degrees, aspire to the True, the Good and the Beautiful (perhaps not in that order, or at least at first, and believing or not believing that we shall know the moment when in their splendor all three will fuse, and become indistinguishable... for this, no ascent is necessary, since the gods, as the Greeks believed, dwell eternally in our hearts; they rest there and wait for our summons to show us ourselves to ourselves, and then burst out into the enthusiastic explosion of what we know as enthusiasm.) But those who love climbing, those who love the mountain air, the high vistas, the dangers, the thrill of sport and the risk of risk – the summit summits attained, the sandstone no longer playing its snakes and ladders with our feet and hearts and minds, the clouds lying over us like white, shrouding mysteries; the gods, who could not be seen from the earth, hastens to greet us in our hearts; for those who have not yet reached the top, the last boulder stepped over, the sand no longer playing its snakes and ladders game with our feet and hearts and minds; the clouds below like a white veil hiding mysteries, the gods briskly greet us in our hearts; we, pure oxygen for those still visible through the poetic cloud-breaks, rising on their way; we, pure oxygen for them, climbing up on their way, breathing pure oxygen to them, saying to them: yes, the climb is worth it, the Greeks were right.

(The Village of Gatlinburg, Tennessee, July 6, 1867) HE IS THE ICON OF AMERICA, THE LAND OF THE FREE AND THE BRAVE, HAVING HER HEADED IN OUR HONOR OUR PAINTING OUR POSTER MAN A CHURCH OF FAITH GROWN BY THE BLOOD OF OUR MOST PRECIOUS BERRIES AND IN HER TRIVETS OF FAITH, LOVE AND RESPECT, BUDDENING THE LANDS OF CHURCH A MONTH WITH POURS AND HER METALLING PIERS OF GRAIN GROWING IN VESSELS OF FAITH, LOVE AND HER OWN SURRENDER, AND OUR TRIUMPH, TO HER GENTLE BODY....

In the lovely green woods on the banks of the Tay, the beautiful and enchanting scenery is a wonderful sight to see, particularly the old abbey in the middle of the woods on a rocky hill, which the tourists can visit freely; the trees and the greenery are magnificent, especially the trees on both sides of the road, which leads to the abbey among the trees, and in the summer it is a place frequented by bees, as well as crows with their raucous croaking, and the townsfolk who live nearby have grown tired of it. In summer, there are mavises singing, and the woods are resounding with their charming notes, and gentle zephyrs waft about the gardens. And the castle of Balmerino stands, set amidst the trees, and is a magnificent sight; and on the banks of the silvery Tay, the visitor can spend a happy holiday. As they look at the castle and the wonderful landscape around it, their spirits will surely be uplifted, And if they want to see Wormit Bay, they can take a stroll along the banks of the silvery Tay.

Overwhelming sorrow now calls me to song. Out of death the sorrowful feeling springs. What flowing tears, what hearts rent with grief? What sobbing from loving parents’ breasts? The brother weeps, the hapless sisters join him; Their increasing grief makes the crystal salt. The poor, once fed by his kind bounty, are sunk and mourn his death. The death of the friend, the kind companion lies in death. And in one death all comforts are dying. The unhappy mother sees the rill of blood stop flowing, and the wheels of nature are broken. But see his soul, far from earth, no longer near. His spirit, flying faster than the wind, has left behind the world of death for glories unknown to the earthly state. The reward of virtue, the prize is a reward. The wonders of this wondrous prize to behold! But of celestial joys I sing in vain. Don’t make me sing the too adventitious strain. No more in briny showers, you friends around him, No more to bathe his earth, or bury it in the ground. But still you weep, you still wish for his return! How cruel to long for his return and to be sad! No more for him your flowing tears! But join him on the celestial shore! And tune your harps with immortal songs! Raise immortal anthems to your God.

She was to be in Washington at the Inauguration, a fifteen-year-old girl, to march with the band of the King College Prep High School, to see history made again by President Barrack Obama, and to hear loud weeping of parents just as they did at Sandy Hook, And then the early school dismissal, all seemed well. Finished with her exams, under an umbrella, avoiding the rain, Then at two-thirty in the afternoon, under the open sky, Under a few dozen others, then the shots rang out. A lone gunman jumped a fence and opened fire at the crowd, And like Sandy Hook, parents were weeping aloud. Two more bullets were fired, probably by rival gang members, but both times the intended victims only suffered injury. And so it went, With a gun, the gang member, regardless of whether his target was right or wrong, Must have been uncaring, with his dead eye, without regard for life, It mattered little whether he missed, Some in the crowd were her fellow students, members of the school's band, The shooting panicked everyone out of the park, And so it went, a child in the wrong, her hopes and dreams shattered, First the Capitol, and next a trip with classmates to Paris, France. In Chicago, last year, there were more than 500 homicides, but only 42 murders up to the end of January, In addition, in the gangs there were more than a hundred shootings. Statistics are often misleading, so it's hard to be precise, But this much is clear: if we continue to release convicted murderers, this is the sort of society we're in. The president's spokesman, Jay Carney, said: “Our prayers are with the family, it's a terrible tragedy,” Here is another idea: "Put a stop to it," the president should get to work with Congress to find a solution, Germany takes six months to issue a driver's license, Imagine if the time taken to issue a gun permit were six months, How many more would still be alive? With proper training and certification, with the proper rules and regulations, local governments could safely arm citizens, most importantly, teachers.

It’s a northern winter wonderland, Happy couples walking hand in hand, Stores aglow with lights, Christmas trees always in sight. And snow falls down on New York City, snow falls down on New York City, It’s true that the city is light and pretty And maybe the streets are beautiful at night And although the country may seem plain, Alabama is bright with sunshine when New York is dark, And while we may be simple we do our best To keep Christmas a tradition that lives in our hearts. So let the snow fall down on New York City, fall down on New York City, Let the snow fall down on New York City, Fall down on New York City.

It was as if God had wanted him to go to places of pilgrimage. The prince then went out from the South Gate. He asked his charioteer, “Why is this man suffering?” “He’s sick, and suffering from a disease,” the charioteer said. “But why is he suffering? How did he fall ill?” asked the prince. The charioteer explained: “Anyone, young or old, rich or poor, wise or foolish, can fall ill.” Siddhartha then felt: “If there is the possibility of this suffering, it ends in suffering, then pleasure has no meaning.” They returned to the palace. The prince’s mind became restless. Then he went out again, this time from the West Gate. A little beyond the palace a crowd was slowly moving. Four men were carrying a corpse on their shoulders; others followed them, crying. It was the prince’s third experience. This time the charioteer explained briefly: “Death follows every birth.” “So the whole world is an illusion,” said the prince. “For what we do not see is real, and what we do see is unreal.” He was saddened.

Stewed apples.  2 packages of pastry-crusts (four crusts) 3 cups raspberries, cut in half and rinsed in water. 3 cups sugar, dissolved in three tablespoons of water. Pereg. Let the raspberries be not tender, the cut pieces should not be crushed. Let the whole stand in a bowl for 30 minutes in the refrigerator. Start one box of crusts, roll out on a floured table. Put one crust on top of the other and pinch together firmly. Using the hand-made crust, the thickness should be 0.15 cm. Cut out the crust and press the crust into the two-and-a-half-inch pie dish. Save the left-over crust. The dish has twelve sections. Use a beaten egg to rub the crusts in the dish, if you want, sprinkle raw sugar or large-crystal sugar on the edges of the crusts. In each pie dish, put a filling of three or four pieces of rhubarb. Then sprinkle the egg and the raspberries on top of the pieces and let them stand in a large pot for 20 minutes. Cool the dish on a wire rack. Repeat the process with the second box of crusts, then put the scraps of the two boxes on a floured table and roll out the crust so that it is 0.15 cm thick. Depending on the taste, you can eat them as they are, or with a good vanilla sauce.

1-cup blackberries. 1-14 cups all-purpose flour, 14 cup granulated sugar, 1 tablespoon baking powder, 12 teaspoon baking soda, a teaspoon of kosher salt, 12 cup cold unsalted butter, cut into small pieces, 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract, 12 cup milk. If the blackberries are mashed, you can keep them separate and they will come out nice and rosy. Also, preheat the oven to 375 degrees and line a baking sheet with parchment paper or spray with cooking spray. Then, in a bowl, work the cold ingredients together until the butter is in small pieces, the size of peas. Make a well in the middle and pour the melted butter, the vanilla and milk mixture into the well. Then stir to make a sludgy, slightly crumbly mixture. Let the mixture stand for 3 to 5 minutes, so that the flour can soak up the liquid, and then stir once more. If the dough is just too dry and won't hold together, add a tablespoon of milk until it barely comes together. Add the frozen blackberries and stir lightly. Then scoop the dough onto the baking sheet, about 1 inch apart, or spread the dough and cut it into squares when you are ready to eat. Bake for 10 to 15 minutes, so that the middle is still soft and the edges are golden. Immediately serve with a glass of cold milk.

1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil 1 piece of meat weighing 1 pound 3 garlic cloves, sliced 3 pieces of shallot, sliced 3 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar 2 cups cherry tomatoes, halved 12 cup green onions, thinly sliced and chopped 34 cup balsamic vinegar 1 teaspoon pepper Salt and pepper the meat and put it into the frying pan. Then, cook on each side for five minutes or until it reaches the desired degree of tenderness. Transfer to a plate and rest for five minutes. Cut into thin slices across the grain. Add garlic and shallot to pan; cook 1 12 minutes or until golden. Add vinegar; reduce heat and cook 1 12 minutes or until liquid has almost evaporated. Add cherry tomatoes, basil, green onions and pepper to taste. Cook for two minutes, stirring occasionally, or until the cherry tomatoes have softened and begun to release their juice. Pour cherry tomato mixture over sliced meat. Top with remaining basil and green onions. Serves four. MyRecipes is a joint effort of the MyRecipes and MyPlate, a joint program of the United States Department of Agriculture, the Partnership for a Healthier America and the MyPlaque organizations.

This recipe contains: 2 tablespoons of poultry seasoning, 1 tablespoon of sea salt, 1 tablespoon of black pepper, 2 tablespoons of paprika, 1 tablespoon of butter, melted, 1 kilo of fresh turkey (or 12 to 14 lbs.). Take 2 tablespoons of seasoning and sprinkle it inside the turkey, lift the skin of the turkey, without tearing it off completely, and rub 1 tablespoon of seasoning under it, and then put it back gently. Rub the rest of the seasoning under the skin. Then smear the turkey with melted butter. Tie the legs with string and turn the wings in. Place the turkey, breast up, on a grid over a roasting pan. Pour three and a half cups of water into the pan. Cover loosely with aluminum foil. Preheat the oven to 325 ° F. Bake for one hour. Remove the foil and bake for two to two and a half hours or until a meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the thigh registers 165 ° F. Baste the turkey from time to time with the juices that collect in the bottom of the pan. Cover the turkey loosely with foil, after two hours, to avoid excessive browning. Let stand for twenty minutes. Transfer to a large platter. Serve with apple and bourbon gravy.

1 and 1/3 cups of flour 7 tablespoons butter, cut into small pieces A pinch of salt Two cups of sugar Four eggs, two separated Two tablespoons of cornstarch 3 lemons, zested and squeezed and zested, zested and juiced Preheat the oven to 325°F. Whisk together in a bowl the flour, butter, salt, and one egg yolk. Then knead the mixture to a soft dough. Roll the dough on a lightly floured work surface to a circle of about ten inches in diameter, then place it in a loose-bottomed ten-inch tart pan. Press the dough lightly up the sides, trim the edges, and pierce the bottom with a fork several times. Then line the bottom with a strip of parchment paper. It can be trimmed again. Pour dried beans or rice into the bottom, and bake for about twenty minutes. Then take the beans or rice out and bake for another twelve minutes. Let the tart cool on a rack for about forty-five minutes. Stir together the remaining two egg yolks and one egg. Whisk the cornstarch into a tablespoon of water. In a small saucepan bring the juice and zest from the lemons, and one cup of sugar to a boil. Take off the heat, let cool for a while, then stir in the cornstarch and eggs. Bring the mixture back to a boil, stirring constantly. Pour into the tart shell and let cool for two hours in the refrigerator. Whisk the three egg whites stiff and stir in the remaining three tablespoons of sugar. Pour the egg white mixture over the lemon filling and bake for about eight minutes. Let the tart cool, remove from the pan, and serve.

Set the quail eggs in a pot, cover with boiling water, then simmer on high heat. When the eggs begin to turn, they must be rolled about with a pair of cooking sticks. This will make the yolk spread out to the center of the egg. Afterwards the water must be brought to the boil, the fire turned off and the eggs left in the water for three minutes, then removed to cold water. When the eggs have cooled, they must be placed in a soup bowl, covered with another soup bowl. Then they are rolled gently, very gently, about twenty times. When they are cracked, they are put back in the water, the water goes in between the shell and the egg and the shell is easily removed. This is how it is done. The shell on quail eggs is very thin and firm, and it is easily removed. Then the egg is stripped of its shell. Any thin shells that may have stuck to it must be removed. This is how they are cooked. Then the eggs may be used in various dishes. They are delicious in the soup for yakisoba, in which they are used as a condiment. Quail eggs in Chinese rice are a delight.

In a large bowl, mix flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, and spices. Preheat oven to 425° F. Brush a cookie sheet with melted butter or put it on a parchment-covered baking sheet. Whisk together egg and pumpkin puree. With a fork, a pastry knife, or a food processor, cut butter into flour mixture until mixture is crumbly and no visible pieces of butter remain. Put aside. In a separate bowl, whisk pumpkin puree, milk, and egg. You are preparing a nice, thick batter. Fold into dry ingredients and form a ball. Roll the dough on a floured surface to about 1 inch thickness. With a large knife or a dough cutter, cut the dough into three equal parts lengthwise, then crosswise into six equal triangles. Place the triangles on the buttered baking sheet. Bake for 14 to 16 minutes, until the tops are golden brown. Let cool on a wire rack. Make a plain glaze. Whisk together 1 cup powdered sugar and 2 tablespoons milk. When the scones are cool, brush them with a plain glaze. While the glaze is drying, prepare the spiced glaze. Whisk all the ingredients together. Pour the glaze on top of each scone and let it dry for at least an hour before serving. Spray bottle or the end of a small whisk.

1 tbsp. Azuki beans 6 cups water a pinch of salt 1 tsp. Salt 1 tbsp. Granulated sugar Soak the Azuki beans overnight in water. Boil for five minutes in a large pot. Drain, rinse, and put back in the pot. Add the six cups of water and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil and simmer for two hours. Keep skimming off the scum on the surface. It will make it bitter, so it’s best to get rid of it as much as possible. While the beans are cooking, make the dumplings. Put the sweet rice flour and sugar in a bowl. Slowly add water while mixing. Add enough water to make the dough soft, but still hold together when pinched. Turn the dough out and make round balls about the size of a ping pong ball. In another pot, boil some water and drop in the dumplings. Reduce heat to simmer and cook until they float to the surface. When the beans are tender, add sugar and vanilla to taste. Cook for another 15 minutes. Serve the dumplings in a bowl, cover with the bean broth.

15 whole apricots, halved and stoned 4 tbsp honey, divided 1 tbsp dried ginger, divided, toasted slivered almonds, divided, 34 cup Greek-style yogurt, divided 1 tbsp. chopped mint, divided Preheat the oven to 400 ° F., cut the dried ginger into small pieces, and put them in a food processor or a mortar and pestle (or just use ginger powder, I had only dried ginger at home). Pour half the honey over the apricots, sprinkle half the ground ginger over them and bake for 20 minutes. During this time, toast the almond slices in a pan. Heat the pan over medium-high heat and add the almonds. Stir often, let them turn a light brown and a nice nutty aroma, this should take about 4 - 5 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool down a little. After the apricots have cooled, half of them go to the food processor with one tablespoon of honey (or more if you want to make it sweeter), and the rest of the ginger. Pulse until smooth and spread one or two spoonfuls of yogurt on each plate and add a spoonful of apricot puree on top. Add a few pieces of the roasted apricots, the almonds and the mint and finish with another spoonful of honey. Note: I like everything to be tart, so I used plain yogurt. The apricots themselves are quite sour, so if you want it a bit sweeter, use vanilla yogurt and add a little more honey. And if you are dairy-free, just replace the Greek yogurt with coconut or soy yogurt!

Prepare for roasting a duck stuffed with cheese. One cup of water, three tablespoons of butter, one teaspoon of salt, one cup of flour, four large eggs. Take the saucepan from the fire, put all the flour in all at once, beat energetically with a wooden spoon, then set it on the fire, cook the roux, stirring all the time, until it leaves the sides of the saucepan and forms a ball, which will be about two minutes. Remove the saucepan from the fire, and let it stand at room temperature, stirring a few times, till it is cooled a little, about three minutes. Add the eggs, one by one, stirring well, after each egg. Add the cheese, and put the paste in a pastry bag with a round nozzle, half an inch in diameter. On a buttered baking-dish, prick out balls one inch in diameter, an inch apart. Bake the gougeres in the oven, for twenty-five minutes, or until they are golden brown. Turn off the fire, and let them stand for twenty minutes with the door ajar. Move the gougeres to a large platter. Serve them hot or at room temperature.

One pound of minced beef, 1 pound artichokes in brine, 1 cup of fresh spinach, 1 pound, seasoned ricotta, 2 cups grated parmesan cheese, 6 cups ragusan, Set a 4-litre saucepan of water to boil, heat the oven to a temperature of 375°. Preheat a non-stick frying pan and add 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Then cook the artichokes with the onions until tender, add the spinach and cook until wilted. Leave to cool and remove from the pan. In the same pan, brown the minced beef and drain it. In the meantime, cook the pasta according to the instructions on the packet. In a square or rectangular tin, start layering with a third of the Ragusan sauce, then a third of the minced beef and the last third of the ricotta cheese. Cover with a layer of pasta. Then add another third of the Ragusan sauce and the remaining minced beef, then add the pasta again and top with a layer of parmesan cheese. Repeat the layers once more, ending with the pasta, the sauce and the cheese. Cover with aluminum foil. I prepare the day before and bake the next day. Bake for 45 minutes, then take off the foil and bake for a further 15. Take out of the oven and leave to rest for at least 15 minutes before serving. Enjoy!

All of the ripe strawberries, washed and hulled, cut into quarters and sliced into a dish. With the sugar, sprinkle the strawberries with three tablespoons. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Arrange six tartlet pans with a removable bottom on a baking sheet. (You can also use a 9-inch single-shell pie pan.) Spray the tart pans with non-stick cooking spray. Put the marichino and the piloncillo in a food processor and process to fine crumbs. Add the butter and process until the crumbs form a ball (this takes a few minutes). Press the crumb into the pans. Bake until the tarts are golden, about 10 minutes. (The crumbs will look too soft, but they will firm up as they cool.) Cool the tarts completely. Using an electric mixer, beat the cream cheese and sour cream until fluffy. Add the remaining half cup of sugar and beat until smooth. Add the meringue powder and beat until fluffy. Drain the strawberries and set aside two tablespoons of the soaking liquid. Fold the strawberries and the two tablespoons of the soaking liquid into the cream cheese mixture. The mixture is poured into the tarts. The tarts can be made a day ahead, covered and refrigerated. (I told you in the introduction that I ate this all week, and it was still delicious!) (Cook's note: * Galletas Mara, which is what marichino in English would be called, are a round, vanilla-scented, round cookie, which in Mexico can be used for the same layering as lady fingers.) They can be replaced by graham crackers.) (Cook's note: *) Piloncillo is a Mexican unrefined sugar, usually in the form of a small cone.)

2 Pork Loins 2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar HALF CHICKEN STOCK OR STOCK, halved 2 tablespoons honey 4 Sage Leaves 2 tablespoons grapeseed oil 1 cup shallots, sliced HALF a cup mushrooms, sliced (choose one kind), 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 2/3 cup dry cider (I used J.K.'s Scrumpy Dry Cider from Whole Foods), 1 tsp. whole-grain mustard, 1 Tsp. Chopped parsley preheat the oven to 400 °C. Salt the pork loins on both sides, and let them rest for a few minutes, but without putting them in the refrigerator. Open the dry cider and set aside a third of a cup of it; pour the rest into a cold glass for the chef's treat. Meanwhile, in a small saucepan, bring the apple cider vinegar, stock, honey and sage leaves to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, stirring, until the liquid has reduced to half a cup, 25 to 30 minutes. Take the sage leaves out and keep the syrupy liquid. Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in an oven-safe skillet over high heat until it's almost smoking. Sauté the loins on both sides for two to three minutes, then place the pan in the oven and roast until the meat is cooked to your liking. I cooked mine until a thermometer inserted in the center of the loin read 72 °C. Remove the loins from the pan and set them aside to rest. Reheat the pan over high heat, and add enough grapeseed oil to equal 1 tablespoon, then sauté the shallots, garlic, a pinch of salt and a pinch of salt until golden. Reduce heat to medium-low, deglaze the pan with the dry cider and reduce the liquid by half. Add the syrupy vinegar mixture, the mustard, and cook for another minute or so, then stir in the sour cream and the chives and parsley. Then add the mushrooms and cook until they're tender, two to three minutes. Add salt and pepper to taste. Slice the loins and serve with a generous dollop of the sauce and shallots. I served mine on polenta, mixed with a pat of butter and a little mascarpone.

The ingredients are: 2 pounds of cottage cheese or 2 pounds of yoghurt; one cup sugar; eight ounces cream cheese, crumbled; six large egg yolks; four ounces sour cream; one pint heavy cream; half a pound of ground almonds; one-half cup grated lemon rind; one tablespoonful of vanilla extract; one large vanilla pod, split lengthwise; one and a half pints of heavy cream; one cup of sifted almonds; two glasses of finely chopped crystallised almonds; one pint of cream, or four-ounces of cream, and the remainder of the milk; and blend the mixture thoroughly in the food-processor. Transfer the cream mixture back to the bowl. Add the ground almonds, lemon rind, lemon juice, vanilla, and vanilla seeds. Pour the mixture into the bowl and stir until blended. Add the raisins and stir well. Use a clean, unused, two-liter terra-cotta pot and line it with a double layer of rinsed and squeezed-dry cheesecloth. Put the cheesy-almond mixture into the lined pot and tuck the edges of the cheesecloth under. Put a plate on top of the cheesecloth and place a two-pound weight, such as a can, on top of the plate. This enables the pot to be set over a bowl in which the drippings will collect. Leave the pot to drain in the refrigerator for at least twelve hours. Remove the pot and plate, remove the cheesecloth and decorate the pot with the dried fruit, making the initials XB, for Christus voskres, that is, Christ is risen.

One or two oranges, preferably freshly squeezed, one cup orange juice, preferably freshly squeezed, strained. 5 tbsps honey (optional) 2 cups almond flour 1 cup sour cream (or 2 cups cream) 6 eggs 2 cups almond flour 2 cups sour cream 1 teaspoon almond extract 1 teaspoon cinnamon 2 teaspoons baking powder Ghee or lard for frying (or oil). The honey is to be added to taste. If you can’t find almond flour, make it yourself. Put the almonds in a food processor or a nut grinder and process until fine. Almonds will be more easily ground in a nut grinder. Add a couple of tablespoons of sugar to prevent the almonds from turning into nut butter. Put a cake pan in the oven and preheat to 200°F. First make the orange syrup. The orange juice, 2 tablespoons of the honey (if you want to), and the cardamom go into a small saucepan and simmer over medium heat until it’s reduced to about a quarter cup (use a glass measuring cup to make sure). Set aside. Cut the rind and pith from the oranges and slice the oranges in rounds about 38-inch thick. Put the oranges in a heatproof bowl and pour the syrup over them when it’s cooled a bit. Set aside. Put the cream and 1 tablespoon of the honey (if you want to) in a large bowl and beat to soft peaks. Keep in the refrigerator until you are ready to serve the pancakes. First make the pancakes. Put the eggs, cream cheese, almond flour, sour cream, milk, almond extract, cinnamon, ginger, baking powder, and the remaining 2 tablespoons honey (if you want to) in a blender and blend on high speed until smooth and completely blended, about 1 minute. Then pour the batter into a non-stick 6-inch frying pan and bake until golden brown, about 5 minutes. You can melt about 12 tablespoon of ghee or lard and pour about 14 cup of the batter into the pan. I pour straight from the blender. You should pour enough to make a 5-inch-thick pancake. Cook until bubbles pop up around the edges and the bottom is golden brown, about 45 seconds. Turn and cook until the other side is golden brown, about 45 seconds. Pancakes go on the cake pan and the oven will keep them warm. Wipe the pan clean with a paper towel and continue with the remaining batter.

From the special recipes in the Food & Wine Annual: Preheat the oven to 325° F. Put the rack at the lower shelf. In a large bowl, using an electric hand-held mixer, beat the egg whites until sour, 3 minutes. Add the cream of tartar and beat until stiff, 3 minutes more. Then sift the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt into a bowl. In another bowl, stir the egg yolks, oil, lemon juice, zest, and 14 cup water. Fold the egg yolk mixture into the flour mixture. Toss in 1/3 of the beaten egg whites, then fold in the remaining whites. Pour the batter into an ungreased 10-inch tube pan. Bake until a cake pick comes out clean, 50 to 55 minutes. Turn the cake out of the pan and cool. Then make the icing: In a small saucepan, bring the sugar and the remaining 2 cup water to a boil over high heat, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Then beat in the cream of tartar. Then beat in the hot sugar syrup. Beat in the vanilla, and then beat until cool. Pass a thin, sharp knife around the outside and inside of the cake to loosen it. Transfer the cake to a platter. Ice and serve.

Taking the flour for this bread, make sure it’s of a medium or short-grain rice, not long-grain rice. Prepare it 12 to 18 hours before baking. The first thing to do is to mix the rice flour and salt, and then make a well in the middle. Pour in the water, and stir from the centre of the well outwards, beating all the while with a wooden spoon, or at a moderate speed with an electric beater, and beat well. Leave it 12 to 18 hours at room temperature. Dissolve the yeast in the warm water. Add the honey, oil and yeast solution to the mixture, and beat thoroughly with a hand or an electric beater until the whole has become one even, smooth consistency. Then add the methocel, and beat thoroughly again. Using a spoon, fill three well greased 340-cup loaf tins with the dough, smoothing the surface with a wet finger or with oil. Leave the loaves in a warm, moist place to rise until the mixture has risen to the top of the tins. Watch the surface of the dough carefully, and be ready to put the loaves into the oven as soon as the first tiny pinholes appear. Bake at 180°C for about 45 minutes, or until done. When it’s risen, let it cool down well before cutting it. NB: If the mixture is too stiff, the surface will crack before it has had time to rise, and the bread will be tough. If it’s too wet, it will rise up into a large arch, like wheaten bread, but then it will fall down. Once you have done it a few times, you’ll soon feel how the consistency should be. Don’t use butter or lard in this recipe, as they make the methocel work incorrectly. Put the bread in a plastic bag in the bottom of the cold compartment of the refrigerator, and freeze any surplus loaves, as the bread ages very quickly.

These are simple recipes and don’t need special equipment. First of all, make the butter. Using the recipe for Candied Almonds below, roast the pears for a couple of hours until they’re tender but still hold their shape. Preheat the oven to 300°. Toss the almonds in a food processor and pulse them a few times to chop them coarsely. Scatter them in a single layer on a baking sheet. Bake them until they’re golden and fragrant, about 10 minutes. In a saucepan, heat the cream with the sugar. Scrape the seeds from the vanilla pod into the cream; add the pod as well for extra flavor. Stir the sugar into the cream and heat the cream to the boiling point, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Stir in the almonds and salt, cover the pan and set aside for 30 minutes. Pour the almond mixture through a fine-meshed sieve and press it with the back of a wooden spoon to extract all the flavor from the solids. Then discard the solids. Let the gelatin soften in cold water for 3 minutes; squeeze it dry. Stir the softened gelatin into the almond mixture while it’s still warm. Then stir in the buttermilk. Pour about half the almond cream into 6 straight-sided glasses. Pour carefully, so that the liquid doesn’t run down the sides of the glasses. Cover each glass with a layer of the remaining almond cream and refrigerate until the cream is set, at least 8 hours or, even better, overnight. Serve with a couple of pears arranged on top of each of the creams and garnish with the candied almonds. Preheat the oven to 400°. Spray a rimmed baking sheet with cooking spray. Peel the pears, cut them in half, remove the cores and cut each half into 6 wedges. Then place them on the baking sheet, so that the cut sides are down. In a bowl, stir together the molasses, sugar, rum, vanilla and salt. Then pour the mixture over the pears, toss them with tongs to coat and bake for 20 minutes, turning once, until they’re tender and golden brown. Take them out of the oven and let them cool until just warm. And put aside the pan of molasses syrup, which is terrific over ice cream.

Then, half a pound of rice noodles, a peeled garlic clove, four whole green peppers with the seeds removed (add more or less according to taste), one lime, cut into quarters, one tomato, sliced, one teaspoon palm sugar, 14 teaspoon shrimp paste, 1 unripe green papaya, peeled and shredded, 3 tablespoons fish sauce, 1 tablespoon palm sugar (or one teaspoon shrimp paste) 2 large cloves of garlic, crushed. Set aside in a bowl. The traditional Thai mortar is indispensable for this dish. I always buy it at the Thai market and I also use it for guacamole. Put the peppers and garlic in the bottom of the mortar and pound until they almost look like paste. Add the lime juice. Add the tomato and pound it lightly, then mix it. Add the palm sugar and the shrimp paste and continue to pound. Add the papaya and mix it lightly. Add the fish sauce and pound it lightly. When serving, put a handful of rice noodles in a large bowl, add the salad and then top with a layer of toasted peanuts. Finally, with a fork and a spoon, mix everything and eat it.

DISHES: • Butter a jelly mould 15 x 20 cm. • Line with a piece of greaseproof paper. • Pour the custard into the mould, layer by layer, leaving a gap at each end. • Pour into the mould, spread out evenly, and level off. • Make the meringue in a bowl with the egg whites and the sugar, stirring the mixture until the sugar has dissolved. • The bowl and the beaters must be absolutely clean, and the egg whites must not have come into contact with any fat. Stir in the vanilla and vinegar, then fold in the cornflour. • Spread over the custard, and sprinkle over the coconut. • Bake on the bottom shelf of the oven for about 20 minutes, until the meringue is a pale golden color. Make sure the oven is well heated, and then remove the cake from the oven. Cover a wire cooling rack with another piece of greaseproof paper, and carefully turn out the meringue on to the rack. Remove the lining paper, and let the cake cool on the coconut side up. Put the cream into a bowl, beat to soft peaks, and spread over the cake. Arrange the mango and passion-fruit slices on top. Then carefully roll up the meringue from the long side, keeping the greaseproof paper under it. Serve cut into slices.

Start with three tablespoons of unsalted butter, divided. Add a tablespoon of olive oil to a large, heavy pan and heat over high heat. When hot, add the mushrooms and stir until they give up their water and turn golden, about 8 minutes. While the mushrooms are cooking, heat the remaining two tablespoons of butter in a pan. Add the shallots and garlic and cook for a minute, then add the vinegar, half the chili or chili flakes, salt, and pepper, and stir. Add the greens, any greens except for spinach, which will be cooked for about five to eight minutes, just until soft. Then add the remaining butter, taste, and season to your liking. Tear the toasted bread into croutons and mix into the cooked vegetables. Set the cheese pieces on top of the croutons and vegetables, turn the heat to low and, covering the pan with a lid, let it melt. It will take between five and ten minutes, depending on the pan and the type of cheese. Put the chili on top, hand out the forks, and bring the pan to the table.

And here are the ingredients: 3 cups flour 3 cups of semolina 2 cans of coconut milk, low-fat, each 134 cups water 1 can evaporated milk, low-fat, 5 ounces, 2 eggs, beaten 1 cup sugar 4 ripe, soft bananas, mashed 1 cup butter, or margarine, 2 sticks 1 cup poppy seeds Add the water and the sugar to the can of coconut milk and cook over medium heat for 10 minutes, stirring constantly. In a large pot, add the coconut milk, the water to fill one can of the coconut milk, the beaten eggs, the sugar, and the bananas, and cook over medium heat for 4 to 5 minutes. Add the toasted semolina, stirring all the time. Add the butter, or margarine, and stir until well mixed. Then add the flour, and stir until smooth. Pour into the pan and bake until the top is golden, about 1 hour. Then sprinkle the top with the poppy seeds and broil for 2 minutes. Let it cool and then let it sit overnight. Then slice it into diamonds. The cake will be moist, but not fluffy. The rest will have to be refrigerated. Serve it at room temperature. This recipe makes 6 to 10 servings. Semolina is available in gourmet stores and health food stores.

1 cup soy sauce 1 cup caster sugar 1 teaspoon molasses 1 tsp. ground cloves 6 crushed garlic cloves 2 tablespoons grated fresh ginger 1 tsp. peppercorns 1 cinnamon stick, 8 in. long 1 tsp pineapple juice 4 chicken thighs without skin or bone In a saucepan combine all the ingredients except the cornstarch and the chicken, bring to the boil, then reduce heat and stir for 3 minutes. Remove from the heat and allow to cool. Remove the cinnamon stick, and add 1/2 cup water. Then add the chicken to the sauce and seal in a large, thick polythene bag. Stir to coat the chicken well, and refrigerate for at least 12 hours. Then pour the mixture into a saucepan, bring to the boil, then reduce the heat. Add the cornstarch dissolved in 2 tablespoons water, and stir into the sauce. Stir until the sauce thickens. Add more water to thicken it to the consistency of double cream. Take off the heat. Preheat the broiler. Brush the chicken on all sides with the sauce, then cook under the grill for 3 minutes on each side. Meanwhile, heat the sauce over high heat until boiling, then reduce the heat and simmer until it becomes syrupy. Simmer until the chicken is cooked, then cut into slivers and serve with the sauce.

Preheat oven to four hundred degrees. Whisk together first six ingredients. Pour two cups of sauce into saucepan. After rinsing hens, inside and out, pat dry with paper towels. Reserve remaining sauce. Remove and discard any visible fat from hens. Salt and pepper cavity and outside of hens. Stuff cavity of each hen with three quarters of onion and three garlic cloves. Arrange hens, breast up, on rack set inside large rimmed baking sheet. Roast hens ten minutes, then baste with sauce reserved in saucepan. Continue roasting hens until golden brown and juices run clear when thigh is pierced with tip of sharp knife, about forty-five minutes longer. Transfer hens to carving board; tent with foil to keep warm. Pour pan juices into glass measuring cup. Fat can be spooned off accumulated on top of juices. Add pan juices to sauce in saucepan. Bring to boil, then reduce heat to medium-high and simmer until sauce is reduced to about one and a half cups, about twelve minutes. Discard onion and garlic cloves from hens. Using poultry shears, cut each hen down the middle; remove backbone. Serve with watercress and lemon wedges. Serve with sauce.

HEADED TO MARKET AND PURCHASE: Bring a large pot of water to the boil. Cook for about one minute and then remove the tomatoes. HEAT TWO TABLESPOONS OF OLIVE OIL, stir in the onions, add the chopped tomatoes, salt and pepper to taste, then cook the linguine for about 8 minutes. HEAT TWO TABLESPOONS OF OLIVE OIL, stir in the beaten eggs, then add the remaining ingredients and stir until all is combined. Remove from heat and cool. Use a knife to cut an “x” in the bottom of each tomato and then remove the skins and discard. Cut the tomatoes in quarters, and chop the onions and fresh basil. Shred the cooked, rotisserie chicken. In a non-stick pot, heat the olive oil. Cook the chopped onions for about five minutes. Add the chopped tomatoes and stir to combine. Add the shredded chicken, salt and pepper. Cover and simmer on medium-low heat for 30 to 40 minutes. Meanwhile, cook the spaghetti according to the directions on the package. Serve with the tomato sauce. When the shredded chicken is cooked, remove it from the heat and stir in the chopped basil. Once the chicken is heated through, add the spaghetti to the pot and toss to combine. Serve with grated Parmesan cheese. Serves two to three people. This can easily be made a vegetarian dish.

A coffee was brought to me; I ate two and half of them, and he told me to pass one to him, because he was so hungry. Then, he told me to mix the flour with the sugar, butter, and vanilla, and mix it well. Add the last four ounces of chocolate. Now, beat the eggs at full speed in the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with a wire beater for five minutes. Refrigerate the dough until it is firm enough to scoop it out, for about ten minutes. Bake five scoops on each baking sheet for fifteen to twenty minutes in the lower and upper thirds of the oven, until the tops are shiny and cracked, and the cookies are barely set. Let the cookies cool for five minutes on the pans, then slide them on the paper, one after another, on wire racks, to cool completely. In the same saucepan, melt the chocolate with the butter, stirring it until smooth. Invert the cakes and spread each one with a tablespoon of the chocolate, letting it go all the way to the edges. Let them cool until the chocolate is firm.

1024 4 per cent. i 2cl of oil 1 ess of onion finely chopped 1 ess of tomato chopped 3 cloves of garlic 3 tbsp of tahini 1 tbsp of cumin 3 tbsp of tomato paste 1 tsp of dried bread crumbs Place the potatoes in a large saucepan with 6 cups of cold water and bring to a boil. Cook until tender, about 8 to 10 minutes. Drain the potatoes in a colander. In a large non-stick frying-pan, heat the oil and cook the onion, garlic, tomato and cumin, stirring, over high heat, until browned lightly and dry, about 3 to 5 minutes. Add the tahini, parsley, chick-peas and potatoes and simmer, stirring, for a few minutes. Let the mixture cool to room temperature. Season with salt, pepper and cayenne to taste. Pulse the chick-peas in a food-processor, adding the breadcrumbs to thicken. Using moistened hands, shape the mixture into 8 patties. Place the patties on a plate lined with plastic wrap and chill for at least 3 hours. Grill the burgers, or place them on a greased, non-stick tin, spray with oil and brown under the broiler. To sauté, heat a non-stick frying-pan and add a drop or two of oil and cook the burgers on both sides over high heat until crusty. Cook for about 4 to 6 minutes on each side. Serve on buns with lettuce, tomato and your favourite sauce.

1 and 1/2 cups water 14 cups sugar 1 teaspoon salt 12 cup butter 7 and 12 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons yeast 12 cup warm water 1. put all these in a saucepan and heat until melted. 2. Beat the eggs, add to the butter mixture, stir well. 3. Pour yeast and warm water or milk into the bowl and dissolve yeast. 4. Stir in 212 cups flour, add more flour as needed to form a soft dough, mix thoroughly. 5. Place on a floured board, knead until smooth and elastic, about 5 minutes, keeping the board lightly floured; put in a greased bowl, cover with a damp cloth or plastic wrap, and let rise at room temperature, 80 to 85 degrees, for 2 hours. 6. Punch down the dough and knead it for a few minutes to remove all the air, then divide it into 6 equal pieces. 7. Let rest for 5 minutes and roll it out into 6 long thin sticks. 8. Grease a baking sheet and put 3 sticks on the greased sheet. (Leave the other 3 sticks for the next braid.) 10. Cover with a towel and let it rise for a second time. 11. Brush with egg and water mixture, don't brush in the creases, and sprinkle with poppy seeds.

l'épicier 2 oeufs de pain, 2 table spoons de dri-esfruige, 2 de curcuma, 1 g of salt, 1 tsp of apigrillo, 1 tsp de marmite, 12 tsp ace de courmand d'aigue, 1 tsp du thé saout romarine, 3 cubes de gouts de currar esfraessée, 3 large girolle, 3 crocks de curé, 1 crocks de gibierkon, 1 tablespoon chopped parsley leaves, 12 grained, 3 gills d'or, some bread, a few drops of hot water, and, for garnish, a baby carrot, boiled or pickled, chopped into quarters, and for garnish a bunch of curly parsley..... a well-scrubbed pan, fill it with clean, hot water, and scald it.
