After the eggs are cooked, drain the hot water and immediately put them in a cold bath. Peel carefully and set aside. Pour in a pinch of salt, a pinch of turmeric, a pinch of salt, a pinch of vinegar, add a pinch of water, and mix the whole with a pinch of black pepper. Put the hot eggs in the tincture for about fifteen minutes or until they have become yellow enough. Take the eggs out of the tincture and let them dry on a cloth. Then cut them lengthwise and carefully remove the yolks and put them in a small bowl. Add mayonnaise, mustard, a pinch of pepper, a pinch of dill, and mash everything together. Add salt to taste. One quarter of the mixture is put into each of the egg whites and topped with curly parsley and finely chopped carrots.  leeks and oranges, as for eggs: cut off the roots and the greenest part of the leek, cut the leek in half lengthwise and chop the green part into small pieces. Cut the rest of the leek lengthwise and chop it into thin strips. If more dirt is visible after cutting the leek, rinse it in cold water and wipe it dry with a piece of paper. Pour into a bowl a mixture of flour and salt. In a saucepan, heat the oil. The oil is ready when it starts smoking. Once the leek is cooked, it is cooked and no longer green; let it become light to medium brown for ten to fifteen seconds to ensure that it is crisp. You can leave a few very light greens to make it look good. Add a pinch of flour and mix well. Then fry a handful of leeks in hot oil and drain on a piece of paper. When the leek is cooked and drained, put it in a clean bowl, sprinkle with a pinch of pepper and salt, and form into small nests on the plates. If you use a large leek, you will make four nests that each contain a fried egg or an orange.

1 pound of large or medium shrimp, shelled and cleaned. 1 tablespoon Shaoxing wine. 12 teaspoon salt. 1 piece ginger, finely chopped.. Throw shrimp into a big bowl, pour flour into a big bowl, and turn the shrimp into the flour evenly. Add oil to the depth of 5 centimeters, heat it to the fire, and mix the shrimp. The flour in the bowl can be removed by squeezing, and then shake the shrimp into the pot. The shrimp should be in a single layer, and then put them into the pan and fry them evenly. It is best to fry them in two batches. Leave the fried shrimp to dry on a towel, and fry the second half, and then pour off the oil and set aside. Stir-frying peas until they are half-cooked, and then stir in bean sprouts, Sichuan pepper, red pepper, and chives. Stir-frying until fragrant, and then add shrimp and soy sauce. Stir-frying evenly, and then mix evenly and mix evenly, and immediately put white rice on the table.

1 bunch beets, 6-8 pieces, with stalks and leaves removed, add to a pan with a little salt, bring to the boil and simmer about half an hour, until tender. In the meantime, mix the vinegar, garlic, honey and salt in a small bowl and set aside. Chop the other vegetables and eggs and set aside. Add the beets to the pan and simmer for about half an hour, until they are tender. They will retain a lot of heat. Remove the beets from the pan, run under cold water, and remove the skins. Chop into half-inch cubes and add the vinegar mixture while they are still warm. Allow to stand about half an hour at room temperature. Set aside some of the chopped vegetables, eggs and dill for a garnish, add the remaining ingredients to the beets and add the cream, or sour cream, to taste. (Note: I use only enough cream to make the salad cohesive, about one cup and a half.) Stir well, chill and serve. Canned Beets: Pour two tins of cooked beets into a large bowl. Add the liquid and heat until boiling, drain well and proceed with the recipe.

A 2lb bag of russet potatoes (not that you can’t do this with other potatoes, but the bigger the better) 1cup milk or cream butter salt pepper a small loaf pan lined with parchment and buttered. The potato was then added to the milk with the salt and pepper. Then you layer the potatoes evenly in the mold. A layer of potato and a layer of butter and repeat until the pan is full. Fold the parchment over the potatoes and cover with aluminum foil. This will be baked in a 225° oven for an hour. To check the readiness of the potato, you can stick a knife into the potato and there should be no resistance. Then you take a mold of the same size and put it on top of the wrapped up potato. Then you put some heavy books, tins or whatever on top of it. Leave it under this pressure overnight or at least 6 hours. When the slab has cooled, you remove it from the mold and cut it into the desired portion size. Then put some canola oil in a frying pan and bake the sliced bread in it until golden and crispy. If you want to go a little further, you can glaze it with butter and herbs and garlic. Serve it hot with eggs or as a side dish to a dinner.

3. Cut the avocado in half and remove the pit. Put some salt and lime juice on the surface of each half and then chop the first half into little pieces. You can do this with your fingers and then push the pieces into a bowl. Put the second half on top of it and then the third. This is a trick a friend from Costa Rica taught me and for some strange reason it makes the guacamole last longer. Then crush the pieces of avocado with a fork and stir in the rest of the ingredients. Be careful not to add too much Worcestershire sauce or Tabasco — only a few drops are needed. The quantities of lime and salt aren’t fixed. Add a little and then taste it and add more if you think it’s not quite right. Variations: I sometimes use salsa instead of fresh tomatoes or I chop up a tin of Rotel or something similar. I especially like the glass jar of Salsa Casera or a little tin of Embasa. You can add garlic or top it with grated Parmesan cheese. Please note: the quantities given here are approximate. You must use some common sense.

Citrus Curd (p. 257)  1 large egg white  Cream of tartar  25 g  Sugar  3 g  Rose water  1 tsp.  Campari  1 tsp.  1 tsp.  1 tsp.  1 tsp.  3 tsp.  3 tsp.  3 tsp. Put the egg white and the cream of tartar in the bowl of the maschine, set it to the lowest speed, and let the white rise gently for two minutes, to begin with. The white should be somewhat wet and still look like liquid. Then turn the speed up to medium and beat in 1 tbs. sugar. The white should have body and just be short of soft peaks. Add the rest of the sugar and beat to a smooth, glossy, nearly stiff white. Then beat in the rose water. In the meantime, bring a saucepan of water to the boiling point. Then put the meringues in the water with a spoonful of the meringue. They will double in size. Cook them for two to three minutes, then lift them out with a slotted spoon. Add the curd, which should be in the shape of little rosebuds, around the granite in a glass or in a bowl. And then top it with one or two meringues, some crumbs, and some crushed candied roses.

The materials for the cake: 1.75 cups of all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon of baking powder, 12 teaspoon of salt. 1.75 ounces or 227 g of butter, softened; 1 ounce or 2 ounces of brown sugar, 1/3 ounce of confectioner’s sugar, 2 eggs, 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. 2. Beat the butter and sugar together with an electric beater on high speed for 30 seconds; then add the eggs and vanilla and beat again until the mixture is smooth. 3. Add the flour mixture little by little, stirring with the beaters, until the mixture is completely mixed, scraping the sides of the bowl as necessary. Divide the dough into two parts and shape each into a round disk; wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 2 hours. Then flour a clean work surface and knead each disk for 3 minutes. Sift the work surface lightly with flour and roll the chilled dough into a thickness of 12 inch. Use a cookie cutter to cut out shapes and cut the shapes out quickly. If the dough becomes soft, refrigerate it on a baking sheet covered with a paper towel for 30 minutes, then transfer the shapes to an ungreased baking sheet and place them about 1 inch apart. Then chill the dough again for 30 minutes. Dust the shapes lightly with flour and bake at 325°F until the bottoms are golden brown, about 12 to 15 minutes, depending on the shape of the cookie. The left-over dough can be kneaded into a disk and refrigerated until ready to roll. Cool the cookies on the baking sheets until they are firm enough to be transferred to a rack; then decorate and serve. Store them in an airtight container at room temperature for up to one week.

One roasted turkey (or chicken) carcass with meat remaining; two onions, chopped; four sticks of celery; three garlic cloves; two bay leaves; one teaspoonful of black pepper; a quart of water, to be poured over it and brought to the boil, and a pint of beef-stomach. Add water to just cover the carcass. (As the broth will be reduced to half, if you want a larger quantity of stock, put in more water at the beginning.) Put on the lid and turn down the fire, and let it simmer gently until it has been reduced to half, two or three hours. Then remove the carcass, skim the dripping, and strain the broth into a saucepan. Then add salt and pepper to taste, add the carrots, celery, onion, and garlic, and bring to the boil. Cook till the vegetables are very tender. In the meantime, cook the buckwheat groats in a separate saucepan in boiling salted water. Drain. Add the boiled groats to the soup. Then add the shredded meat, including all the meat on the carcass. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

3 cups original Bisquick mix, 1 pound of pork sausage, 3 cups of shredded Cheddar cheese, 16 ounces, 1 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 cup milk, 1 teaspoon rosemary, crushed, 1 teaspoon salt, a pinch of pepper, a small shake of black pepper, a sprinkle of chopped parsley or a sprinkle of dried parsley, if desired, hot pepper sauce, mustard sauce or red pepper sauce. Stir all the ingredients together, using your hands or a spoon, and form into 1-inch balls. Place them on the sheet and bake for 20 to 25 minutes, or until golden. Immediately remove them from the sheet. Serve hot with sauce for dipping. High Altitude: Reduce the amount of Bisquick to 2 1/2 cups; add 12 cup flour. Oven, 375°F, 25 to 30 minutes. A cheesy appetizer for a party? Preparation time: 10 minutes. You can do so many things. Cover and refrigerate the unbaked balls up to 24 hours. Cover and freeze the unbaked balls up to one month. Heat oven to 350°F. Place frozen balls on an ungreased baking sheet and bake as directed. Cover and freeze for up to one month. Oven, 350°F, 20 to 25 minutes or until golden brown. Place 6 frozen balls on a microwave-safe plate. Cover and heat on High for 1 minute, then stir. Cover with wax paper and heat on High for 45 to 60 seconds or until heated through. Success. There is no need to cook the sausage before using it in this recipe.

2 pears soaked in brandy (I prefer it to brandy because the flavor is better) 6 tbsp butter 2 pears (canned), sliced 3 tbsp butter 3 tbsp mushroom water 1 carrot, cut up 4 tbsp of water 6 tbsp of flour 1 tbsp of heavy cream Seasoning: Salt and pepper. Soak the mushrooms in water and drained. Cook until the mushrooms have given up their juice and the onion has become transparent. Then add the thyme and the bay leaves and cook for about 30 seconds. Pour the broth into the pan. Bring to the boil and let it simmer for 30 to 45 minutes, stirring occasionally. Strain the solids, but keep the broth. You should have about 4 cups. Wipe the pan clean. Cut up 16 ounces of white or crimini mushrooms and cut them into the food processor, using short pulses, so that you get a coarse duxelle (which is basically chopped mushrooms, but duxelle sounds more festive). You should have 8 ounces of mushrooms left, which you cut into bite-sized pieces and set aside. Melt the remaining 3 tbsp of butter in the pan and add the duxelle, the shallot and the last 8 ounces of sliced mushrooms. Cook over moderate heat until the juice has evaporated and the mushrooms are starting to stick to the bottom of the pan. Add the flour and stir until the mushrooms are thick and gummy and begin to stick and brown at the bottom of the pan. Add the reserved mushroom gold, er, broth, the cream and the parsley. Stir constantly and cook over moderate heat until the soup thickens. Do not boil. Let it simmer, thicken and remove from heat. Add salt and pepper to taste and serve.

1 onion, 4 carrots, 2 celery-sticks, finely diced 1 lb of beef, 1 lb of bacon, a pound of parsley, a handful of black pepper, a pound of bacon, salt and pepper to taste. Preheat a saucepan over a medium-high fire, and put in the onion, carrots and celery. Add the meat, and cook until no longer pink. Then put in the tomato paste, and let it simmer for about two minutes. Add the garlic, and cook for half a minute. Add the flour, and stir well. Let it cook for two minutes, to eliminate the floury taste. Then add the stock, the tomatoes and their juice, the bay-leaves and the parsley. Bring to the boil, then cover, reduce the heat and simmer until the potatoes are tender, and you can insert a fork without resistance. Stir the stew from time to time. This will take at least an hour, depending on how small the potatoes are cut. When the potatoes are ready, remove the bay-leaves, stir in the oregano, and season with salt and pepper to taste.

6 tablespoons of virgin olive oil, divided into four. A head of broccoli, stems peeled, florets and florets chopped into half-inch pieces. A head of garlic, cloves separated. A tablespoon of honey. A tablespoon of wine vinegar. Half a teaspoon of chili. A pound of the stale sliced brioche soaked in water for twenty minutes and then washed. On another tray, with the edge of a square pan, put the broccoli and the garlic and add the remaining four tablespoons of oil. Toss to mix. Then spread out in a single layer. Immediately sprinkle with salt and pepper. Broccoli on the top rack, bread on the bottom, bake until the bread is golden and crunchy, ten to twelve minutes. Then take out the bread, turn the broccoli and garlic, and roast for another fifteen to twenty minutes, turning the broccoli a few times. Meanwhile, mix the honey, vinegar, and chili in a small bowl. Immediately after the garlic is cool enough to handle, squeeze it into a small bowl and mash it with a fork. Add the ricotta and mix well. Season with salt and pepper. Spread the ricotta over the bread and sprinkle with the roasted broccoli. Then place on a serving dish and pour over the honey and vinegar mixture.

1 kg of dry white beans. 1 tsp soda. 1 onion, peeled, chopped. 1 lb chopped smoked bacon. 4 tsp sugar. Bring to boil. Reduce heat and simmer 10 min. Rinse and drain. Onion in bottom of ovenproof dish. Half the bacon. Beans. Top with bacon. Sugar, molasses, mustard, salt, pepper, pour over beans. Water barely to cover. Stir. Cover. Cook 6 hours at 150°. (May need to add water during cooking, but you must be careful not to make them too wet.) Crockpot version: To fit into a 2 litre crockpot, halve the ingredients. Onion at the bottom of the crockpot. Half the bacon. Beans. The rest of the bacon. Sugar, molasses, mustard, salt, pepper, pour over the beans. Add just enough water to barely cover. DO NOT STIR. Cover. Cook on low for 10 hours. Cook on high for 5 hours. (May need to add water during cooking, but you must be careful not to make them too wet.)

A half-pint Greek yogurt; 1 cup whipped cream, 12 cup powdered sugar; Juice of 2 oranges (half a cup); 14 cup honey; 12 of a vanilla bean, scraped; 12 of a pineapple, peeled, cored, and cut into thick slices; 1 cup orange-blossom water; a 3-liter broiler-proof dish; 1 tin of condensed milk; a 7-inch broiler-proof dish; a baking dish; 1 quart sliced pineapple; a cup of fresh cream. In a broiler-proof baking dish arrange the pineapple slices, pour over the orange-blossom water. (You may have to reduce the syrup after the pineapple is cooked.) Occasionally stir until the pineapple is tender and the liquid has thickened. This will take about twenty minutes. Then set the oven on broil and cook the pineapple until it turns golden and has a slight brown crust on top, about five to ten minutes more. The drippings should be thickened and reduced to about a quarter of a cup. Add honey to taste and pour over the pineapple. Then if the drippings are watery, with a slotted spoon lift the pineapple into a medium bowl, pour the syrup into a saucepan, and boil down over high heat to about a quarter of a cup. Divide the yogurt into four portions and arrange the pineapple on top of each portion and spoon over the drippings.

To a medium-size mixing bowl add oats, salt, baking powder, brown sugar, and flour, and mix well. Add butter or margarine and knead until crumbly. Add egg and mix well. To the filling add 2 tablespoons cornstarch, 1 cup granulated sugar, 3 cups chopped fresh rhubarb, 1 cup frozen rhubarb, 1 cup crushed pineapple, 1 teaspoon cinnamon. Mixed well, add the mixture to the fruit and stir. Bake in a greased oblong dish in the oven at 350°F for one hour. Preheat oven to 350°F. In a medium-size mixing bowl, combine cornstarch and granulated sugar, and stir until blended. Add egg and mix until smooth. Add rhubarb and pineapple, and stir well. Pour mixture into oblong baking dish with the crumble topping, and sprinkle with cinnamon. Bake for 45 to 50 minutes at 350°F, or until the crumble is golden brown. Serve with ice cream or whipped cream.

Sift the flour. Whisk the eggs without foaming. Pour the water and the butter into a large bowl and cook for 4 minutes in the microwave oven. Add the sifted flour and mix immediately. Cook in the microwave for 1 minute. Preheat the oven to 200°. Add the eggs a little at a time, stirring vigorously after each addition, beat until the mixture is smooth and shiny. It is ready when it slowly drips from the spoon. Grease the cake tins and pipe or spoon 4 cm diameter patties on the greased paper. Spray with water and bake for 20 minutes at 200° then lower the temperature to 180°. After baking, turn the oven off and leave the pastry in the oven for about 15 minutes. Make the cream cheese filling. Soften the cream cheese or heat in the microwave for about 20 seconds. Add the sugar and beat until well blended. Beat the cream until it stands in peaks. Add the cream cheese, lemon juice and whipped cream, beat well. Make incisions in the patties, each half split. Add a lot of cream cheese filling to each choux pastry. Dust with icing sugar.

1  12 pounds of deer trimmed, a loin of about two inches in thickness, if possible; 12 cup port; 3 strips of orange peel, each three inches long; 1/2 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper; 1/8 teaspoon allspice; 2 tablespoons olive oil, divided; 1 tablespoon shallot; 1/8 teaspoon garlic; Salt and freshly ground pepper; 2 tablespoons cold butter, divided; 1 tablespoon shallot; 1/8 teaspoon garlic; 12 teaspoon allspice; the juice of half a lemon; 1 bay-leaf; 2 tablespoons flour; 12 cup fresh cream; the juice of one lemon; a cinnamon stick, 12 cup sugar; demigogues; juice of one orange, fruit of a lime; 12 pound sour gooseberries, halved in half; sauce, 1 quart jugful; 1 pint 60 ml. of white wine; 2 tablespoons cold butter, chopped; 14 cup brown sugar; 1 pint 60 ml. of fresh cream; a tablespoon of finely chopped garlic; 12 cup brown sugar; 1 quart of hot beef broth; 1 bay-leaf; 1 teaspoon of mace; 12 cup water; 1 cup cold red wine; 12 cup of veal; brown flour; stir together; then mix in the butter, shallop, garlic and sugar, season with salt and pepper, and put in a bag in the cellar. Tumble the deer overnight, turning once or twice. Take out the deer from the cellar, season all sides with salt and pepper, then add to the juice. Preheat the oven to 180 ° C. After boiling the ointment in the oil, fry the deer on all sides in the hot oil for one to two minutes. Then transfer the pan to the oven for 17 to 20 minutes, depending on the doneness you want. The venison is medium-rare when it registers 125 ° F on an instant-read thermometer. Take out the deer and let it rest for 10 minutes before cutting. Add a tablespoon of butter to the frying pan in which the deer was browned. Heated over medium heat, add the shallot and garlic, and sautéed, stirring constantly, for about 30 seconds, until softened. Add the reserved marinade, sugar and cinnamon, then heat to boiling and boil until reduced by half, about 3 to 4 minutes. This sauce should be syrupy and thick. Add the gooseberries and heat to a low simmer. Cook until the gooseberries have softened and the sauce has reduced and thickened, about five to seven minutes. Add the cream and cook for one more minute, then add the remaining butter and stir to melt. Serve hot with the venison.

Eight corn tortillas, 2 lbs ripe tomatoes, halved and coarsely chopped, two or three green or Serrano peppers, chopped (de-seeded and chopped for a milder taste), salt, a half cup of olive oil, a half cup of canola oil, one to two tablespoons of chopped garlic, 12 pound radishes (peeled, cut in half and removed from the root), 12 pound jalapeo peppers, seeded and chopped, a handful of chopped parsley for a garnish, etc., etc., until the pan is heated to its fullest. Put the mixture of chopped tomato, onion, chilies, garlic, and onion in a small glass jar, close the jar, and put it on the stove at a high heat, until the pan begins to bubble up. Add the puree, stir and cook for four to ten minutes, until the sauce thickens, darkens, and a cleft is left when a spoon is run through the pan. It must start to stick to the pan, then salt to taste and take it off the heat. Warm up four plates. Keep warm while you warm up the tortillas and fry the eggs. Fry the eggs in a heavy pan at a high heat. You won't need much oil if you have another non-stick pan, but if necessary, add the remaining tablespoon of oil. Cook them on a sunny side up, until the white is solid, but the yolk is not cooked. Then salt and pepper and put them aside. Put two warm tortillas on each plate, one under the other if you are only using one egg. Put one or two fried eggs on top. Scoop the sauce over the whites and over the plates, keeping the yolks in sight as much as possible. Garnish with chopped coriander and serve.

CIPOPOLIN OR LITTLE ONION CIBOLINE TO PORTER 2 POUNDS PIZZOLLINE OR SMALL ONION OF 1 12 INCHES 3 tablespoons of virgin olive oil 4 tablespoons of sweet butter 2 tablespoons of sugar 1 cup of balsamic vinegar 1 cup of white wine 1 cup of water 1 teaspoon of fresh rosemary sprigs MARIANTI CLASSICA BY Mario BTALI: Start with a spaghetto of plain water: this is the beginning. In a large saucepan, over a high flame, heat a little virgin olive oil, add the butter, and cook until it begins to foam. Add the onions and cook for 8/10 minutes until a golden yellow on all sides. Then add sugar, vinegar, tomato sauce, water and bring to a boil. Cook for about 10 minutes, uncovered. The water, if it evaporates, should be added again, a quarter of a cup at a time, and the sauce must stick to the onion. Remove from the fire to a ceramic dish and keep warm, or cool, if they are served later or for antipasti. Cook the onion and garlic in the oil over a gentle fire for about ten minutes without browning, but cooked well. Then add the thyme and carrot and cook for another five minutes. Add the tomato. Cook for a quarter of an hour, season with salt. The sauce can be refrigerated for up to eight days or frozen for six months. It gives four large cups.

1 tsp. salt, 1 tsp. chili powder, 1/8 tsp. black pepper, 12 cup fresh lime juice, 8 cups sliced onions (about 3 large), 5 cloves of garlic, minced, 8 chicken breasts, boned and skinned, 1 tbsp. vegetable cooking spray, 1 tbsp. olive oil, divided... In a large bag, put all the marinade ingredients and add the chicken. Seal the bag and shake it well to mix it all over. Let marinatee in the refrigerator for two hours, turning the bag every now and then. After two hours, remove the chicken and onion from the marinade, discarding the marinade. Spray the bottom of an oven-proof Dutch oven with cooking spray. Add 1 tbsp. olive oil and heat over high heat until hot. Add four chicken breast halves, cook for two minutes on each side, until golden. Remove from Dutch oven and keep warm. Repeat with the remaining oil and chicken breast halves. Remove Dutch oven from heat and put in the marinated onion slices. Return the chicken to the Dutch oven, arranging them among the onions. Cover and bake in the oven at 450°F for 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, remove chicken, stir onions and scrape bottom of Dutch oven to loosen any browned bits. Return chicken to Dutch oven and bake 15 minutes more. Serve on rice with the chicken and onions on top.

For the Beef 2 tablespoons soy sauce, 12 tablespoon sugar For the Soup 5 cups of dashi 2 tablespoons soy sauce 2 tablespoons mirin 2 tablespoons granulated sugar 1 pinch of kosher salt For the Rice 1 teacup of Otama rice Cooking oil 1 onion, sliced on the bias 1 pinch of Japanese pepper, 1 pinch of garlic granules 2 spoonfuls wakame seaweed 2 large, boiled eggs, cut in half 2 tablespoons wakame, chopped finely 2 cups of spinach, chopped finely For the Noodles Bring a large pot of water to a boil, and cook the frozen udon noodles for one minute. After cooking, drain the udon in a colander and divide them among individual bowls. While the udon is cooking, heat a large skillet, and sauté the onion in the hot oil until it is translucent. Add the beef, and sear on all sides. Then add the sugar and soy sauce. Add the dashi, and bring to a boil. When the soup is hot, pour it over the udon in each bowl. Add the beef, wakame, and spinach to each bowl, and top with the narutomaki and other toppings. If you like spicy food, sprinkle the bowls with the shichimi togarashi.

1 tbsp. sourdough starter 3 12 cups of rye flour 1 packet of yeast 1/4 cup of warm water 3 12 to 4 cups of wheat flour 3 tablespoons of salt Prepare the sponge: in a large bowl put the starter, add the water slowly until it is mixed well. Add 1 cup of rye flour, stir, then cover and place in a warm place (about 81 °) for 20 to 40 hours depending on the acidity. Dissolve the yeast in a quarter cup of warm water and add it to the kneaded sponge. Add the salt and then add the rye flour little by little, beating well each time. Add the white flour little by little, kneading each time before adding more. Then put the dough in a lightly oiled bowl, turning it to coat, and let it rise in a warm place for about 1 hour and a half. Then put it back on the floured board and divide it into 2 parts, reserving 1 tbsp. Cover and put in the refrigerator until the next day. Butter and flour the baking pan. Let rise very little. Bake at 81 ° C for 1 hour.

You ever feel like you’re missing something? Like a secret others aren’t sharing with you? I’ve got a music criticism page and one of my friends started a YouTube channel a year after me, doing exactly the same thing. I try to sift through all the metrics from TubeBuddy and YouTube Studio to get a sense of my audience and to see how I can grow it. My friend just shoots a vid and puts it up. He doesn’t even do much editing and he’s usually shooting in 1080p whereas I shoot in 4K. I have 393 subscribers, and he has 1302. That doesn’t make any sense. I’m sure the YouTube formula helped him out a lot, but it just makes me feel like I’m missing something. I know it’s not true and that everyone has their own unique YouTube journey, but it still makes me feel discouraged. Not that I’m wallowing in self-pity, but it’s nice to get it off my chest.

You see, a greatsword isn't something as easy as a "Knock Knock" sword, like a clumsy, simple-minded, tomboyish broadsword. A greatsword requires a certain level of intelligence. Because unlike other weapons, it is not necessary to learn monster patterns, nor does any other weapon reward a person who takes time to learn the timing when an enemy is most vulnerable to attack. In other words, the way to become a greatsword player is to possess a certain level of intelligence, because if you go into battle with a low IQ, or the kind of mentality you find in other weapons, you won't be able to even land a strong charge, much less a TCS. And even though I just said that crit-draw is for beta-version GS players, I'm still going to complain about how Ichinose made a complete downgrade to crit-draw in MhR. Because it was a unique greatsword ability that was demolished for no reason. The bottom line is: screw the low-IQ betas who wield the 2,900-point GS, and good riddance to the godlike greatsword.

I've been playing for a few years and used Ludwig Breakbeats. I love them but wanted to try something with a larger kick drum, since I do a lot of home recording and the 16-inch bass drum isn't as versatile as I'd like. I've chosen the Yamaha Customs with 20-inch bass drum. I've used it for a few months but still prefer the sound and feel of my Breakbeats, even with their smaller kick drum. I wonder if my small recording room is to blame? Anyway, I'd like to hear what other people think. I'll keep trying different tunings on the Customs but am considering either a return to Breakbeats or perhaps an 18-inch kick drum.

Can we all agree that huge maps, with only one point of interest, are bad. Their design is inept. With only one point of interest, if you don't get the good spawns, you're shit out of luck. Now have fun clearing out the resort with gigga-chads camping dark corners, and the infamous cage-d rats. And don't even get me started on the woods, oh god the woods. If shoreline ever gets a makeover, like customs, then at least add more than one point of interest, and future maps can put more focus on form than function. Maybe add beach huts and tourist areas, or since there's a power plant, then why not make a water treatment plant, with offices, a parking lot, and big silos. I'm not a game designer, but I can tell that this isn't it.
The way it was at the time—we don't know now. And we can’t have a fib about it....

Perhaps I am a bit biased because I have grown up at the seaside, but I have also seen the sea at its worst; and I would never go swimming in the ocean at such times; but when it is relatively calm, it is far nicer than lakes and rivers; for the bottom of lakes and rivers is a kind of mud, and there are far more chances for insects and fish to get you than in the ocean. If you are afraid of sharks, you can go to the shallows where the water is clear enough to see the bottom, but in lakes and rivers it is usually so cloudy, and you can’t tell what is there. However, I live in Australia, so all swimming in water is a little frightful.

So my desktop is a Dell Optiplex 3020, it should have the latest BIOS installed, I bought a used GTX 560 for $20 today, and I want to put it in there, but I get no display, so I connect to the iGPU, and look in the bios, and make sure it is plugged in and getting enough power, and it is, but it doesn’t show up in the PEG devices in the BIOS, except for once it showed up as an “Unknown Device.” I don’t have a DVI cable, but I put it in my other pc, which is a system made by Acer and I know the iGPU turns off automatically when you plug in a gPEG, and I turned it on and when I put in the gPEG, there was no display on the iGPU, which could mean that the GTX560 works, but it is not recognized by the bios of the Optiplex 3020, which is a little odd, but it’s not something that’s really obvious, it isn’t obvious at all, but since the GPU is from 2011 and the pc is from about 2015, I think it’s possible that it isn’t recognized by the bios, because of its age and the tests I’ve done.

I have a NEIPA whose fermentation is going full steam. My brother reported to me on Saturday that my blow-off tube was totally blocked, the Mason jar with the yeast was full, and the slurry in the fridge was collecting. I asked him to disconnect the blow-off tube as I was coming home. After a beautiful weekend, I only got home today. I loosened the PRV and it had a lot to say and then... a lot to spray. But I had to go to work and now I'm a bit afraid what I'll find when I get home. I want to try to slowly release the pressure with the PRV from time to time, and when it's not sputtering anymore, I'd like to put the blow-off tube on it until the pressure reaches serving pressure. Is that effective?

I don’t really know if this is the right place to talk about it, but I think it is. If I’m wrong please let me know and I apologize in advance. I was abused almost two years ago. I was basically taken against my will and stripped and physically forced to do something. I fought and shouted no and called for help, but the abuse happened anyway. This has bothered me for a long time and I have only talked about it with two people. I felt that there was no evidence and no reason for the police to believe me. I have been reluctant to take any legal action because I don’t want to upset my family and I will probably not do anything. But I would like to know for my own peace of mind whether they would even listen to me if I went without evidence. I am located in the United States. Thank you for your time. Once again, I apologize if I’m in the wrong place.

My mother is a wonderful person, never wishes any ill on anyone. Why her? We don’t understand. The lump that was detected in her neck is in the form of a lump; we’re waiting for the PET scan. We are all trying to be strong in front of everyone else. But I know that everyone is trying not to cry. I am worried that the cancer will spread; I don’t know how my mother will suffer; I don’t know how I’ll look at my father without my mother. My father has never cried before today. My mother is trying to be brave. My parents say it’s early, but I know it’s not early. I am afraid of everything that will come... I can’t sleep, I can’t stop crying, I pinch myself thinking it’s all a dream and it’s not. I want my mother to live longer. She’s only 55 years old.

What do women and girls do on that site? Almost all comments are sexual or suggestive or just nasty. It’s not funny. A lot of women suffer from a great deal of unpleasant, at best, premenstrual symptoms. Why do we do it? I mean, really. Men will denigrate and make fun, but why do women and girls put themselves through it? I’m not blaming women and girls, but almost all comments end up with the same comments from misogynistic people. The guys who post on the site get funny comments and are not greeted with boring, sexist insults. Especially when it’s a girl or a woman with a conventionally pretty face, the comments are so much more unpleasant. I have a feeling the number of pornographic films these boys and men have seen makes it impossible for them not to sexualize everything they see. Dear girls and women, think about it.

Is this a common feeling? I have known for ten days that I probably have cancer. Two days ago my doctor told me the result of the preliminary research and finally the final confirmation that I really have lymphoma. It is a third degree lymphoma, my spleen is also affected, so it is a serious case. On the other hand, it is estimated that there is a ninety percent chance that I will recover completely. However, I must be operated and I have to be operated on. I'm not afraid, I'm quite convinced that I'll recover. My family and some friends who have found out are amazed at how calm and firm I am... But I do not feel strong, I do not feel anything at all, I feel completely empty. Is this a common feeling? Do I still resist? Will sadness, anger or fear attack me soon?

I'm a real health nut, and when I combine this with an obsessional personality disorder, then, given the choice between an unhealthy meal and no meal at all, I would much rather not eat anything. I begin this post with that because recently I've had less and less time to myself and therefore less and less time to prepare a meal and all that. I was hoping to get some good ideas for some quick and easy meals that are a little easy to make and prepare and contain all the essentials in one dish. Also preferably something that is not too terribly expensive to make. I usually have white quinoa, brown rice, black beans, lentils, edamame, apples, pears, bananas, blueberries, blackberries, strawberries, broccoli, kale, spinach, a myriad of leafy greens, red onion, sweet potato and white potato, sweet peppers, peppers, carrots, mushrooms, sweet potatoes, extra thick rolled oats, unsweetened soy milk and tomatoes in the house, but I really need to begin to economize. I used to make it a lot in large amounts and make really big mixed salads and whatnot, slathered with a sugar-free thai sauce, but I want to step out of it too and start preparing it properly.

With the MYP eAssessment just around the corner, I realize I should have worked harder all year, because my predicted grades are all around 40. I’ve been procrastinating a lot, and now I’m very worried about the results. I was hoping to get a 45-plus on my eAssessment, but at the moment, my preparation and my grades are making me doubtful of getting such a good grade. Since the beginning of the final year, because of Covid-19, my focus has shifted away from my studies, and I haven’t been able to concentrate in my classes, which has affected my grades. I want to know whether the predicted grades matter, and whether I can still hope to get a 45-plus? If so, what strategies do you have? Please let me know, because this is making me very anxious.

I am a little surprised. I went to school with the elder sister of the little one. We were friends. I have met this little girl several times. She goes to school with my little brother, they are friends. We have just heard that the little girl has a kind of bone cancer. I have searched on the Internet, but there is nothing that says she will survive. How can we tell my brother? The prognosis is dreadful. I want to give him some hope and the family some hope. But all I can find on the Internet is definitions of the disease and a survival rate of 5 years, and nothing more. By the way, do you know anyone who has survived? How should I tell my brother? He is only in the fourth grade.

Hello, I was in a boarding accident, and the outcome was a broken neck and fusion of C6 and C7. I am filing in North Carolina with the Prudential for short-term disability and I am concerned that the benefits that have already been approved because of my obvious impairment will be suspended once the reports will show that I took amphetamines the week before. I wasn't on drugs when I got into the accident, but the hospital put it down in the medical report. I have been taking modafinil for a while now. I wonder if anyone else notices that they're on modafinil? I mean, can you tell that it's doing its job? I have seen that everyone who takes it for the first few months says that it feels like being awake, and so I have it too, but I'm wondering what it should feel like in the long run? I have already been used to it once, so I don't know if I'm just getting used to it again or if it's really doing its job and I'm expecting too much from it. I haven't had as many sleep attacks with my new dose, but I've noticed that I'm still tired and tired. I've started taking clozapine in the evening to fall asleep because modafinil was very awake. The feeling of being awake has gone and now it's more about staying awake, but it doesn't really help with the feeling of tiredness. I wanted to ask other users about their experience and how it worked for them after some months or maybe years.

I’m twenty-one. All my friends are my age or younger, and we’re all in our third year of college. They love to drink. I’ve cut down on drinking since I started this journal, and since then I’ve found that I don’t have much in common with them. I love my friends very much, but recently I’ve noticed that they turn down my invitations to do things that don’t involve going to a bar in the middle of the night. Even perfectly harmless, enjoyable things that most people would enjoy, they won’t touch. I can understand people who like to drink, but they seem to think that their purpose in life is to get drunk. When I talk to them sober—when we’re not drinking and partying—our conversations are lame. I don’t really know any new people, so I feel kind of lost. It’s as if I’d never met them before, and yet these are people I’ve known for two years or more. It’s really depressing. I work part-time on the weekends and I’ve had more fun with my co-workers than I have with my friends. It’s a shame that society expects college students to be wild, irresponsible, alcoholics. That’s how they justify their daily drinking, and they can’t have just a few drinks. They have to get drunk. I’d appreciate any advice you might have. I just had to get that off my chest.

I have spent the past ten years coming to terms with the fact that I was brought up by a nanny. But what really made me come to terms with it was when, in a couples’ therapy session, the therapist asked me something about the way my husband and I had been relating to each other, and how we could communicate more effectively. I somehow managed to splutter that this was the way my mother had wanted me to behave. She asked me for an example. I sat there, unable to find the words. My mouth closed, my tongue refused to budge. My husband and the therapist waited patiently. I finally managed to come up with an example that wasn’t really so bad. They were horrified, and I burst into tears, for if what I had been through was “not so bad”, how bad were the things that really were “bad”? Even now, I can’t talk about the things that were really bad with my husband or the therapist. I just can’t. My brain won’t let me. Although I’ve known my husband for almost twenty-five years, and trust him implicitly, and know that I am safe, I still can’t talk. Is this what other people feel?

Question: Can I transfer money from my TFSA Direct Investing Account directly into a chequing account to use as a down payment on a house? I would therefore be missing the opportunity to reinvest the cash in the TFSA. Basically, I’m wondering if I can’t have the best of both worlds: keep the money in the TFSA so I can reinvest it later, and then if I decide to use it for a down payment, have the money available immediately. Can I just go to the bank and say: I need $ x now, it’s in my TFSA, cash it out now? Hope that makes sense. Thanks.

Hello, I have a problem and maybe someone can give me some advice. At the beginning of December I bought something on Ebay via Shop&Ship. People are born with chronic diseases. My former boyfriend is only twenty-four, I am twenty-three, and he has pretty bad cerebral palsy. He hardly walks with the help of anything, let alone with crutches. He has to use a wheelchair. It's so difficult for him. And it doesn't help that he's young. Just because you're young and healthy, doesn't mean you can't get the coronavirus and die of it. I've talked to many young people who got the coronavirus and who were healthy before, and they said it was the worst thing they've ever been through. Being young doesn't mean anything. All people of all ages suffer from severe pain, illness, sickness, etc. Stop saying to people: you're young, you'll survive.

- Well, I've been thinking about how a possible remake of DDLC would look like. Normally, it's not a good idea to remake something that has such a close connection with the original as DDLC, but I have an idea that could work. The basic idea is that someone is going to download the game, and then something normal happens, but then the crew gets in touch with him and they find out that he has been a thief. Monika will then find a way to escape from the game into the real world. Maybe all the other dokis will follow her, I don't know. So the rest of the remake will be how the Dokis and the player react to this and so on. The basic concept is a bit like how the Sonic movie is about Sonic in the real world. Or at least that's what the promotion says. Actually, the twist is that the Dokis realize that they are not in the real world, but in the new media that is adapted to. And that's as far as I got. I don't really know how the rest of the movie will go, but I think it's a good twist that will surprise many. I also don't really know what media it should be adapted to. What do you think?

For the sake of clarity, here is the situation: In my youth I was crazy about pork rinds, and would wolf them down whenever I got a chance. One day my father brought home a bag weighing about a kilogram of pork rind, and of course I couldn’t resist. I’d go off and have a couple of pieces and then come back to my room, whereupon I’d start again and wind up eating half the bag all by myself. To cut a long story short, I wound up in hospital with severe dehydration, kept there a week, after which, every time I ate or even thought about eating a pork rind, I’d get a jolt to my head. To make a long story short, after that, every time I ate or even thought about eating a pork rind, I’d get a jolt to my head. To this day, at my twenty-five, I still have to put up with this; it’s a very hard lot of work, because my liking for pork carries on unabated, but I’m not able to enjoy it the way I ought to because I’d get the headache straight away.

I’ve been in a trauma-related therapy for almost two months, and I’m aware that I must get the treatment. I have been avoiding my traumatic memories for years by drinking alcohol, and I have been sober for about four months. I knew that the therapy would be hard, but I had no idea how hard. Some days I just want to give up because the world seems so much darker, so colorless. My therapist and my boyfriend both tell me that I’m doing a lot of work and that I’ll survive it, but it just takes time. I understand that. But I’m so tired now. I quit my job because I had panic attacks and suicidal thoughts all the time, and there are days when I just can’t get the energy to do more than get out of bed. I feel worse than I can remember. It is a big blow to me that even though I’m doing everything I can, or maybe precisely because I do, I feel so awful all the time, and I want to die every day. I know that I’m going forward, but it feels like I’m going backwards. It feels like I’m swimming with all my might against a much stronger current, and I’m lucky if I manage to keep from going backwards.

There are those who would say it isn’t an egg at all. The popular opinion seems to be that the egg is an intelligent fungus, but I don’t think this is true. The thing is, unless BadBoyHalo is leading us on, the egg would have told us that it isn’t an egg. The thing is, BadBoyHalo refers to the egg as an egg. Now then, let’s turn to theories. There are those who would argue that the egg contains a human being. If this is the case, the person must be important if we are to be treated to an important event. I personally think it unlikely that a person is inside the egg. I think it’s more likely that Quackity is bringing him back to life. What I believe is that the true purpose of the egg is to hatch. Once the egg hatches, Karl will be covered with its spores. He will then gradually increase in strength and will attempt to take over the whole world. With the help of the other side of the egg, he will then be able to cross over to another part of the world. The egg BadBoyHalo discovered was sent here by Karl of the other world. I believe that BadBoyHalo is a kind of chosen one. Eventually, when the egg is successful, Bad will become the egg’s consciousness in the next time stream. Billiam is the equivalent of Bad. Perhaps the present-day egg has Sir Billiam’s consciousness. In the next time stream, the egg is trying to hide itself from its prey. What do you think?

Things like tablets, smart phones, touch screens, etc. That we use in everyday life today, but were considered brand-new and exciting technological wonders back then. I’m sure that no adult back then would have imagined that you’d give a 7-year-old a whole iPad or iPhone. Parents at that time gave kids aged 7-13 maybe an iPod touch, and it was not a daily occurrence to have children with their own iPads and smart phones like today. In all fairness, there weren’t many child-friendly apps or content for iOS and Android back then; there was no TikTok or Musical.ly, no Vine, and the social media platforms of today were still so dominated by adults and no influencer culture. It’s still strange though that as a tween I was frowned upon for wanting an iPad while my five-year-old nephew has one. This is probably something that’s only happened to me and other people born in my year; we weren’t given technology from the time we were born, and we weren’t ‘digitally nomads’ like the earliest or the most core millennials either. Does anyone else have this experience?

I am wrapped up in blankets and crying. I do not know what to do. I was expelled from school because of my absence. It has been so hard. I have been in and out of the hospital, because I have tried to kill myself. People tell me it will get better. People lure me over the edge. I feel old even though I'm a teenager. I keep looking back and thinking it was brighter then. People around me have tried to help me, but it made it worse. I feel I have no friends, but I know I have them, wonderful people who love me. But I feel nothing. I have finally resigned myself to everything. I scream, I ask for someone to help, to understand. For anyone at all to save me, to help me. No one does. It has become so bad that I do not eat, sleep or leave the bed anymore. I'm still trying to do things, but I do not see why it should be worth it anymore. I have always wondered what it would be like if I did not exist. It is the loneliness that kills me. It has always been sad, but now it is like I am dead. Almost a corpse that walks around without a heart. My anxiety is also killing me. Everything is bad. Maybe death would be easier. You know... everything is downhill... do you have any idea what to do with me?

In April 2020 I applied for a small EIDL loan and used the short form, I think. I was guided by some videos on You-Tube. I received a grant of a thousand kroner and a loan of ten thousand kroner. Now, as I am waiting for a review of the targeted advanced grant, I see that I might have entered the wrong figures. I have closed down the old business and started a new one. Instead of changing the name, I started a new one. This was in September or October of this year. When I had made the transition, I probably had about two months of income reported in the turnover statement. In the PPP and all that I used the correct figures. I thought I had done the same in EIDL. Looking at the forms, I should have entered turnover from before January 1, and I suspect that I may have entered turnover for 2020, and that I therefore received a loan of ten thousand kroner. I am afraid I may be denied for the targeted grant, and that that may be one of the reasons why it is taking so long. The tax office has not yet dealt with my tax return for 2019. If I send in my tax return for 2020, will that help? Is it possible to correct it while it is being reviewed? Is it possible to get a copy of the application so that I can check?

I still have a few years on my contract, and I have always thought of the service as a career, but I honestly don't know whether I want to stay in now. The service is, of course, a challenge to my family, but lately the strain at home has really started to bite, and although I work in a pleasant unit with a great team, I feel my enthusiasm and passion for the job fading and depression starting. I'm taking the initiative and relying on the resources we have, but it's hard to see another 15 years in the service. I'm just curious to hear if there are any examples of people who have succeeded and struggled after leaving the service. I haven't decided either way yet, but it never hurts to hear outsiders' opinions.

Then I'll tell you what it would be like if Tom Cruise stepped out of his usual role as a spy in the science fiction & Impossible films. It would be even more thrilling & entertaining. In this series, Tom becomes Barry Seal, the new Ethan Hunt and the CIA the agency that determines his fate. But the difference is that Barry Seal prefers to go with the flow & never gets involved in anything that seems out of his reach, something every one of us can relate to. He's just an ordinary guy who just happens to be a pilot & wants to earn a little extra money with every extra mile. So what's wrong with that? Well, there is nothing wrong as long as you do it for the right people and nothing more exciting and dangerous when those people happen to be the CIA. You will definitely enjoy watching Tom as Barry Seal, who uses the CIA to his advantage, when you think that the only intelligent people in the world are those in the CIA.

Cecilia: As a girl from the Philippines, this movie touches me in a special way because my grandfather was killed by the Japanese during the war. I’ve been told that he was tied to a post and burned with kerosene. I am watching this film as a way of paying homage to him and to those who sacrificed themselves so selflessly to secure a future of freedom and humanity for all of us. It struck me, though, that the film didn’t give a true picture of what we as a people suffered during the war. It would have been more accurate to include other atrocities committed by the Japanese, such as throwing babies into the air and spearing them with bayonets, or raping women so that they would have breasts cut off, or the massacre of over a hundred thousand civilians during the battle to liberate Manila in February of 1945. Nevertheless, I am grateful to the director, John Dahl, for shedding light on an aspect of our history that few people know about, especially our younger generation: the Bataan Death March.

Is there any reason for me to read reviews of disaster films before I remember that most of the people who write them take themselves seriously as film critics? It’s a disaster movie. Yes, the science is terrible. Yes, the coincidences are improbable. If you watch these for deep, richly interwoven stories or for an Oscar-worthy performance by an actor, you’re watching for the wrong damn reason. This film depicts a future in which, because of rising global temperatures, a modern ice age has set in. It comes about by storms, hurricanes of gigantic proportions, which cause rapid freezing and bring with them a host of disasters, including blizzards, which drop so much snow that you can walk along the highway under the signs. It also tries to mix in some human elements that you can relate to, such as the struggle of a father who has to be away from home to try to get to know his son, a lonely boy with cancer and the deaths caused by the disaster. Do not watch for the science, although I feel that they got the cause of the ice age right. Do not watch for the plot. Watch it for the fun ride it takes you on.

I attended a sneak preview expecting it to be one of those “how a shy high school kid gets over his shyness” stories, but this movie is much more than that. This is a story with mature and moving characters and themes. The screenwriter and director said it best in the Q & A after the movie when he said the movie is about the emotional aspects of life at this age without being sentimental. I liked these three young people, Charlie, Sam, and Patrick, and their story never felt corny or sappy, just real, affecting, and touching. Go see it.

"I thought this was the beginning of your story... We are so limited by time," said Doctor Banks in the first thirty seconds of the film. Little did I know at first that this was the theme of the whole film. At the heart of the film lies the question of the power of language and how much it has influenced our way of thinking, of seeing the world around us, etc. When the alien race arrives on earth, Doctor Banks must find out what language they use and how to communicate with them in order to understand why they are here. The further she goes, the more she learns, the more she discovers that they don't think like we do, that they don't communicate like we do, and that they are not bound by time like we are. From the moment her daughter speaks to her, to the very spelling of her daughter's name, this theme permeates the whole film, from her daughter's thoughts to the big revelation at the end. We see the beginning of the film and think it's the beginning of a story, like everyone does, but as we become more and more involved and learn what Doctor Banks learns, we are also freed from the limits of time. The question is, if you knew your life from beginning to end, would you change anything? This film is more than just another alien invasion, a story we've seen a thousand times before; it's deeper than that, and we should appreciate it for what it is. The art of storytelling. Easily a 10/10.

Tom Hanks wrote and directed this paean to the glory days of rock ‘n’ roll, when the wildest music still had about it a sort of innocence which was long since gone but still present. The year is 1964 and a little band from Erie, Pennsylvania, called the Oneders (pronounced ‘One-ders’) but which was destined to become the Oh-nee-ders will start its music career. The drummer, Guy Patterson (Tom Everett Scott), works in his father’s electrical appliances shop, but when the drummer breaks his arm just before the first gig, he is asked to step in and the rest, as they say, is history. A lively and entertaining film in which luck, talent and chance play a part, which shows the bright side of fame, the joy of hearing one’s own song on the radio and the glitzy distractions of being in the public eye. But Hanks also shows the dark side, the creative differences and in-fighting that at some point affects nearly all bands, the petty jealousies and conflicts that are bound to crop up, the rudeness and insensitivity of the record-company employees who don’t give a damn about the people who put money in their pockets as long as they sell records. He sugars over the dark side, which makes it easier to take the bad things that happen and lessens the effect of the story as it unfolds, but he succeeds in keeping it credible and the realism of the characters he has created, and he is faithful to the fact that this is the story he wanted to tell and he has stayed true to his own original vision. 'A Hard Day's Night' and ‘Almost Famous’ have more in common with ‘A Hard Day’s Night’ than with ‘Band on the Run’. All three films are fairly true to life, but the question is whether you should hint at the truth as Hanks does, or make it explicitly obvious as Almost Famous did. With this film Hanks proves that he is just as good behind the camera as he was in front of it, he knows exactly what he is doing and when, and succeeds in doing it. And he manages to get some excellent performances out of his actors, especially Liam, Johnathon Schaech as the singer-songwriter, Steve Zahn as the guitarist, and Liv Tyler as his girlfriend Faye Dolan, who is stung by the side effects of his sudden fame. Hanks himself gives a fine performance as Mr. White, an employee at one of the record companies. The supporting cast includes Ethan Embry as the bassist, Charlize Theron as Tina, Obba Babatunde as Lamarr, Giovanni Ribisi as Chad, Chris X (Sol), Bill Cobbs as Del Paxton, Peter Scolari as Tony, Kristin Wilson as Marguerite, Chris Isaak as Uncle Bob and Dan Koss as Mr. Koss. - All in all, it is a pleasant, harmless and endearing film, which, like many others, is a way of returning to a time that was at least simpler and less chaotic. The more time passes, the better the good old days become. In reality they were perhaps not so good, but Hanks maintains the illusion by giving us a picture of how we like to imagine it. He does it with a touch of humor, but still very nicely. This is not only a pleasant diversion, but also a good film that can be enjoyed again and again, because it takes you back to a place you’d like to be, a place where you have been, even if only in your own mind. That Hanks is able to take you back to that place so easily is not only a credit to his talent, but also a beautiful example of the magic of film.

Ran is based on Shakespeare’s greatest play, King Lear, and stands amongst his other classics: Seven Samurai, Yojimbo, Ran, The Seven Samurai, Throne of Blood and The Hidden Fortress. He is a master at filming a great battle scene; there is no other director in the world who can film such scenes as he can. This is the most expensive film that Akira Kurosawa has ever made; in fact, it was Japan’s most expensive film ever. Even at the age of 75, he proved that he was still the best of the best. It is about an old lord, the head of the Ichimonji clan, who wants to retire and hand over power to his eldest son, Taro, but he must first exile his youngest son, Saburo, who speaks the truth. Soon, the old lord has been driven out of his castle and goes mad when he finds out that one of his sons is trying to kill him. The three brothers, all sworn to a sword, now face each other on the plains of the Kii Peninsula. The whole of Ichimonji’s peaceful kingdom is no more. Akira Kurosawa has created a great epic with a wonderful story, believable characters and battle scenes which are real battle scenes. All those who took part in this film deserve a reward. The acting is really good and is very believable. Kurosawa is a genius.

First, the downsides. There are parts that are a little too long; the movie is two hours long, and it felt that way at certain points. It's a bit silly, and I'm sure some people will roll their eyes, and there will be people who walk out of the movie saying "that was a stupid movie" (as so many did after seeing Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within). I'm sure many of those people will be saying that because of the violence and gore. Which brings me to the upsides. The movie has its moments of awe, tension, and sheer gore, especially during the climax, with nearly identical scenes from the game, and some even with similar monsters. If you've played the games, you'll be familiar with a lot of the scenes. For example, the camera turns at the same time and place as in the game. There are also lots of the sound effects and music from the games, and even monsters. The atmosphere of the games is preserved in the movie, and it will be difficult to stay on your feet during the entire film. The movie is definitely creepy, and even if you haven't played the games, you'll still be scared.

I must say that I enjoyed the most at the movies this summer while watching American Pie, which is the funniest film I’ve seen since last summer’s There’s Something About Mary. It’s a true comedy from beginning to end. Is the best if you like slapstick, grotesque or sex comedy. A superb cast of likable young actors. I think that this year’s supernova is Chris Klein. He was phenomenal in Election and is even better here as a sportsman who tries to sweeten his roughness in order to score at the prom. I have a feeling that Klein will become the next big thing in Hollywood and I hope he gets to try out different roles (I can imagine him in an action movie). Jason Biggs also plays the sympathetic character of Jim, the guy who is least likely to lose his virginity, and his manoeuvres are really amusing, and he gets most of the laughs. Finally, a huge clap for Eugene Levy, who gets the biggest laughs as Jim’s father.

Peter Jackson really did make a masterpiece when he created The Lord of the Rings: The fellowship of the ring and he doesn't disappoint us in the second part of the trilogy. The Two Towers shows us that he is not a one-hit wonder like so many directors, but I think The Two Towers even reaches the same level as The fellowship of the ring and sometimes even surpasses it. This is the longest movie in the trilogy. What do I mean by that? This movie has so many things going on, like the amazing Battle of Helm's Deep. Frodo and Sam have to travel to Mount Doom to destroy the ring. The one who leads them on their way is Gollum, who looks so realistic and frightening that he doesn't feel artificial. Andy Serkis did a powerful job as Gollum and should have been nominated for an Academy Award for best supporting actor. The best part of the movie is the end. The end of the Battle of Helm's Deep is just fantastic and in the distance you see Gandalf the White coming towards you with an army to help you defeat the orcs. When Treebeard and his army of Ents attack Isengard, the destruction and battle are so big that you really have to see it to believe it. When it comes to grandeur and scale, Peter Jackson has really changed the meaning of the word epic, and he also has the small details right that really make this movie great. I can highly recommend this movie to anyone, but I can only recommend that you see the first movie so you can fully understand what's going on. 10 out of 10 points.

The original but good idea of this romance, which is to say that the lovers are communicating spiritually because one of them is dead, had been produced by the director Steven Spielberg about eight months before Ghost was exhibited. Always, a film whose title was derived from the fact that the couple, one of whom is dead, and the other who is alive, had a high-class visual style and played with mystery; but it lacked the sensitivity to romance that characterizes the Ghost. The original idea came from the writing of the story of Chandler Sprague and David Bohm. The film Ghost, however, did what "Always" had tried to do and had not done. Thanks to the great acting trio of Patrick Swayze, Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldberg, who, by playing together, recorded memorable moments in the Ghost. We still remember how Molly and Sam fell in love with their thoughts for a while, and what they taught us was: "Love begins with emotions, ends with thoughts." So they never lost their faith in their long-term love. These unforgettable scenes in the Ghost were made by conceptually arranging the cuts, which made the story seem more believable, but enhanced the devotion of the lovers. The scene where Sam's ghost came to life in Oda Mae's body and was relieved of his yearning for Molly by kissing her is an immortal instant of film. I fell in love with someone, and February 10, 2005, when we both watched the Ghost on TV, I had a sudden impression of hearing the scene that Sam's ghost kissed Molly in Oda Mae's body. I thought that I was searching for the person I was talking to on the phone with the tears that I was hearing. She was sobbing and saying: "I never forget the first time you kissed me, and I don't need to be alive to remember it. " The Ghost is a masterpiece of immortality in the romance of cinema. (Incidentally, MTV ranked it as the best kiss of the nineties a few years after it was released.) The scene where Oda Mae reassures Molly that Sam's ghost is around her, and the scene where Molly explains to the police that Oda Mae knows something that no one but Sam and she know, are even more fantastical.

..... Amusement Park...... Disaster... of course I had to see it... The beginning is full of promise, and we are looking forward to the disaster, which finally comes. There are great action sequences, especially the glass ball with the chewable and soft children inside. Unfortunately, the final act is insufferable comedy. Bryce Dallas Howard is an insecure manager who initially clashes with the gentle and untiringly arrogant man. It is clear where the tension is going to go. In an attempt to humanize the park, two nephews (the boy and another kid) are thrown in, who serve as a gimmick. Then Vincent D'Onofrio appears as Hoskins, a villain representing the military-industrial complex, who is interested in weaponizing the velociraptors. He sneers and eats, and is so obviously evil that he has a goatee. D'Onofrio does his job well, but the devil's intention to which he is strapped makes no sense. I had no idea, because he let loose the raptors (nearly featherless dinos) on a crazy rampage on the poor tourists. Why? Because of the action! And it was even the most bizarrely prolonged death sequence that I've seen, which did not pay off anything, did not even return anything, but only was a happy massacre of a minor character. And it was the Itchy and Scratchy part. The final act: if you don't want to think, close your eyes and ears. The first film had proved that you can have a clever script and a lot of dinos in the same film, but with each new part the IQ of the series has been falling. The first one had chaos theory, amber, DNA extraction, and all sorts of nifty things. What does the third have? The usual intention of the devil, the worst of the worst in storytelling, and characters so stupid that they run away from the T-Rex in high heels. This series has had a lobotomy.

It may be true that every person has his fifteen minutes, even if it's usually more like a minute and a half, but how far can one carry that minute-and-a-half into the adult world? How does a healthy memory become a compulsion, which finally blurs the line between reality and imagination? 'Fan', a film by Tony Scott, with Robert De Niro and Wesley Snipes, is a disturbing and unnerving movie about what such a moment means for everyone involved directly or indirectly in it. It's about Gil Renard (De Niro), a San Francisco cutlery dealer and a fanatical Giants fan, who is particularly excited about the off-season signing of star centerfielder Bobby Rayburn (Snipes) and is sure that he will bring the team a pennant. Once a player himself, Renard, who had a hard time with his son, Richie (Andrew J. Ferchland), in little league, is now a divorced father of a little leaguer, Richie (Andrew J. Ferchland), with whom he has a difficult relationship, and who is constantly on the verge of being fired for his insufficient sales. A turbulent, restless man, he is at a turning point in his life and takes inspiration from the philosophy of the catcher he played with, Cooper (Charles Hallahan), who, he believes, was the best athlete he ever knew. As his life gets worse, his preoccupations and lack of perspective lead him to a point beyond which there is no return. Tony Scott's film is less about baseball than about how this game relates to life and the things that really matter. In the words of Rayburn, "We're not curing cancer." To those to whom the game has been reduced to that minute and a half, which they still cling to, it is everything. It is precisely this unhealthy obsession with this comparatively insignificant moment that Scott examines, which subsequently distorts the individual's reality. What is scary is that a close look at Renard reveals much that will find many a connection in the spectator: anger, annoyance, perhaps the inability to let go of this minute and a half, when it is threatened to become more than a good memory, but a sickening connection to a different past that may have never existed in reality. The eternal seeking for self-esteem, who does not realize its elusiveness and does not want to accept it, it is like a true basis for a ballplayer who no longer plays, a fan of his team, who no longer plays. As Renard tells his son: Baseball is better than life, because it is fair, because hitting a sacrifice fly doesn't count against your average. , an ideal that has always eluded Renard, who has never been able to give himself up for the sake of the team. Certainly, he is the son of an agent, but it was he who, as he says to his son, never knew how to give himself up for the sake of the team. Robert De Niro is the explosive Renard. One may think that his performance recalls Travis Bickle or Max Cady, and indeed there are affinities; but each has a personality of its own, and when viewed side by side, the differences become more apparent. Bickle is a sociopathic killer, Cady is a calculating murderer, Renard is just a man who has never been able to take charge of his life, and who has let his obsessions lead him on his way. There is something of the time when a life is going on behind the screen, as if you were looking over someone's shoulder, and that you recognize a face. His Renard is so much like someone you could meet in everyday life that it's scary to see him. Wesley Snipes, as Rayburn, also gives a solid performance, one of his best, which is not surprising when you consider the talent of the actor with whom he was working. De Niro's films, you may find a common thread between them and his co-actors. De Niro has a way of improving those who work with him, and this is something that remains forever. Think of Christopher Walken and Meryl Streep before The Deer Hunter, or Ed Harris before The Fog. Well, of course, they were already prestigious artists, but they are arguably better than they were before. And Wesley Snipes is not an exception to the rule, nor is Benicio Del Toro, who won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for the film The Trace, and who is memorable here as Rayburn's rival, Juan Primo. Then there is Patti d'Arbanville (Ellen), Ellen Barkin (Jewel), John Leguizamo (Manny), Chris Mulkey (Tim), Dan Butler (Garrity) and Brandon Hammond (Sean). A brainy thriller, very revealing on the mentality of the human being, The Fan is an open wound that may be too much for some people. To dismiss it as a mere "baseball" or "action" movie would be a mistake, for there is much more than meets the eye. I gave him nine out of ten. I rate him as a movie.

The review gives everything away, so go and see the film first. It is neither allegory nor satire, the two best genres in both novels and films, yet it approaches perfection. It is something else I can’t put my finger on, but it’s a something that unveils the truth and pulverizes falsehood. Nothing is more slanted with falsehood than the victor’s account of past wars. We are especially the children of the victors – especially the children of American World War II veterans like myself. Our image of war is formed by films like Audie Murphy in To Hell and Back or Saving Private Ryan: applause for the heroes and cheers for the enemy’s dead. But QT destroys this hypocrisy with a film where you first feel repelled by the enemy’s atrocities, then disgusted by the hero’s atrocities. That is the first moment. But the hypocrisy is pulverized in the second moment when we are first disgusted by the sight of American after American shot down by the German sniper hero, then we cheer the slaughter of a few hundred enemy by our hero. Tit for tat. This is why so many people dislike the film, without realizing it. High art, true art, a ten out of ten.
It’s quite brilliant. This film is astonishing in its characterization, pacing, characterization, and visuals. The novel is superb, but Sturges is a genius with Midas Touch.

Gladiator is a historical drama by the hands of Ridley Scott. Traitor to the new Caesar, the Roman general Maximus is sold into slavery as a gladiator, rises to acclaim as the people's champion, and finally gets the opportunity to avenge himself. The gladiator fights are especially vivid and exciting, and there are different styles of combat. The costumes and scenery are magnificent, and you can see Rome clearly. Hans Zimmer's music perfectly fits the mood. Gladiator is exciting and action-packed, and the story is very moving. "Are you not entertained?"

The sixth sense loves to play with our imaginations. What the eyes behold is not quite what there is. What the mind portrays is not quite what there is. In the world of the sixth sense, logic is the enemy. You see the obvious and the not so obvious, but you don’t see them because of your mental reservation. There is a novel I read called ‘Made in France, the Next Day’ which is like this film but in writing. If you are like me who like to be surprised by something intellectual, you must read it. It is too risky to spoil the film by saying anything about it. I would only say that the ending is simply marvelous. I don’t find this film to be terribly philosophical or intellectual, but it is one of those I like to watch over and over again.

The "Transporter" is a good film for what it is, a slick, smooth, high-speed action film that in no way asks us to believe anything and, above all, doesn't care. The directors have probably the best interest in mind in this case, since it allows them to devise various action and stunt scenes without having to bother at all about this pesky constraint of fantasy, called "believability. " Jason Statham has a lot of swagger in the role of "The Transporter," a former military who delivers various packages without asking questions, not even in a little he doesn't ask any questions, all over the French Mediterranean Sea, to, of course, pretty nasty criminals. He then gets a package in the form of a young Chinese woman, Lai Kwan, tied up and bluffed, and loaded into the trunk of the car he loves and on which he pours all the love and affection he has. Frank, despite his first selfish and ruthless indifference, proves to be a very nice and helpful criminal and helps Lai defeat his villainous father's plan to sell a crate of Chinese people as slaves. However, the storyline is the least of the matter when it comes to a film like "The Transporter". Basically, it's just a story to hang all the explosions, car chases and kickboxing fights that have become the staple of action films. It's well directed, well shot and well-edited. Pierre Morel, the cinematographer, gives the Mediterranean sea, the French Riviera, a sparkling, almost sparkling color, and François Berleand is wonderful as a sly and wise policeman who suspects Frank of something, but who trusts his instinct enough to give him at least the benefit of the doubt. Energetic and charming, she plays the role of a 'complication' in Frank's well-organized and neat life. "The Transporter" is the cinematic equivalent of junk food from a fast-food restaurant, with a slapdash nutritional value, but satisfying when you have no desire or time for something more demanding.

"Back to the Future Part II" is a worthy sequel to the first, which itself is a masterpiece. It's a time travel comedy that's a part of the trilogy, which deals with the paradox of time travel. The film depicts the time-traveling DeLorean, which has gone into the future and back into the past. I loved the whole trilogy, which is my favorite trilogy. I grew up with these films. I first saw the first one on VHS when I was a kid and saw the sequels later on the small screen. I love this movie to death, and it's my third favorite in the trilogy. But please don't get me wrong. I loved "Back to the Future Part III" more than this one, and I consider the third one to be the most underrated film in the trilogy. This movie has a lot of humor and comedy. It's a great movie with great direction by Robert Zemeckis and great writing by Bob Gale. The story starts on October 21, 2015, which is an important date in this movie and the trilogy, which celebrates its 30th anniversary in the year 2015. The films were released in Blu-ray. The plot continues with the Doc, Marty and Jennifer flying to the year 2015 to change the fate of Marty and his future family and save his son from being imprisoned. Then his archenemy Biff Tannen steals the Doc's idea and takes the DeLorean and a sports almanac, and Biff goes back to the past on November 12, 1955, to change the paradox, which Biff creates in the year 1985.
