It's the same alternate time line and the paradox that was also used in the season three opener of "The Flash," "Flashpoint. " So the plot has Marty and the Doc chasing Biff for the almanac in the year 1955, where Biff is a teenager. The chase and the car chase scene, in which Marty drives Biff's car to get the almanac back and Biff crashes into a manure truck, is my favorite scene in the movie. It's a very funny scene, which also includes the scene in the future in which Marty chases Biff and his gang in the year 2015 and outwits them, which ends up with the gang landing on a courthouse roof. Michael J. Fox and Christopher Lloyd are fantastic in their roles. Curtis Armstrong is great as well. I also loved Christopher Lloyd in the role of the Elder. There were a few things that I didn't like, and that's why I'm giving this movie a lower rating: I didn't like the dark future that was created. I hated Thomas F. Wilson's Biff character because he was such an annoying jerk. I also didn't like the death of George's father, George Sr. Then Biff marries Lorraine. I didn't like that the movie focused more on Biff than the Doc and Marty. There was a scene where they copy the first movie. I hated Biff Tannen in this movie so much. I didn't like the ending, where the Doc is hit by lightning with the DeLorean and sent back to the year 1885. Neither did the movie end with the satisfying happy ending that we wished for. I didn't like the way the movie portrayed older Marty. He acted so stupid in the movie, and that's why I like "Back to the Future III" more than this one. Claudia Wells and Crispin Glover are not in the movie. Neither is Christopher Lloyd. I'm surprised that actress Elisabeth Shue accepted the role of Lorraine but she declined to be in "The Karate Kid II." That's weird. "Back to the Future" is my favorite trilogy of all time, and I love this movie to death. I hope they never make a "Back to the Future IV" because it would be a disaster. This movie gets 8 out of 10 stars. It's rated PG-13 for profanity, some sexual content and action. I miss movies like this one. They don't make 'em like this anymore.

“*** SPOILER ALERT *** It made me embarrassed as an American to see this film, just knowing it would be seen abroad. It’s truly amazing how one sub can survive forty depth charges, while another can be sunk by two.” And, I believe it’s highly improbable that the Americans could stow away on a German sub, and vice versa. But the worst thing about this movie is its arrogant revision of history: it was the British who first solved the Enigma, not the Americans. Americans have no right to take credit for what others have done.” The movie just displays how ignorant Hollywood is about world history. But apart from that, it’s just a really dreadful film. No one with a brain in his head would be entertained by this trash.”

Back in the day, there was a big science-fi section in the bookshops; but if you think that science-fi films are filled with great, thought-provoking ideas, the truth is that they are full of alien invasions, space battles and pulp adventure, then Moon is an oddity. The film is about Sam Bell (Sam Rockwell), the only inhabitant of an isolated lunar mining station, and as his three-year contract is coming to an end, he wants to go home to see his wife. But his last weeks and days are going badly, and the events that unfold around him are confusing both for Sam and the audience, who cannot tell whether what is happening on the screen is happening in the real world or whether they are playing out in his mind. The film is however a thoughtful, thought-provoking story that touches on such topics as scientific ethics, corporatization, human identity and compassion. There are no aliens, lasers, wormholes, warp engines or spaceships here, just a lonely space-age concierge and a silent, monotonous robot and a lot of food for thought. This is science fiction as it should be.

Beyond its edifying subject, "The Judgment at Nuremburg" revolutionizes the criminal drama. The camera swerves and swerves and skims between the lines of the magnificent Abby Mann script, and Stanly Kramer conducts his orchestra of renowned stars with the precision of a Swiss watchmaker. The language problems and the complications of the setting are masterfully overcome. Spencer Tracy is absolutely superb, and we believe every word he says. His presiding judge is a monument of American humanity. Schell, the 29-year-old German, won the best-actor Academy Award, and his ardent performance has withstood the test of time. Montgomery Cliff makes his brief screen appearance one of those unforgettable moments that will never be forgotten by anyone who sees it. The man and his character are so closely identified that they fuse into a chilling and heart-rending truth. Marlene Dietrich, as a German aristocrat, lends a legendary aura to her screen personality. Judy Garland, over-fat and almost unrecognizable, breaks your heart and earns her last Academy Award nomination. My only annoyances were with the stern Burt Lancaster because I could not get over the fact that it was Burt Lancaster, and with the excitable Richard Widmark as the prosecutor. I have seen "The Judgment at Nuremburg" more than a dozen times, and I am still amazed that, despite its somber theme, the film always has enough stimulation and excitement to be a winner.

This is a very powerful and important film. The story tells how the Scottish peasant William Wallace, when his wife is murdered, is pushed into a revolt against the English tyranny. With Mel Gibson, Patrick M’Goohan, Sophie Marceau and Brendan Gleeson, it has a good cast and all of them produce outstanding performances. The battles are very brutal and bloody, which adds to the film’s authenticity. The composer James Horner’s music is magnificent and powerful. It is a truly brave film, a film that demonstrates the valor and the horror of war.

A great many people were disappointed with “Jackie Brown” when it came out because it failed to live up to the expectations created by the more outlandish “Reservoir Dogs” and “Pulp Fiction.” I must admit that I was one of these disenchanted spectators. But with the years I have come to appreciate this film more and more, and if you look at it for what it is and not what you expected it to be, you will find it is an underrated gem. The plot of “Jackie Brown” is much more character driven and its pacing is more leisurely than in the other two films. I have not read the Elmore Leonard novel on which it was based, so I cannot tell if this was intentional or due to the source material, but it may be a problem for people with a short attention span and a weakness for pop music. But fans of seventies crime films will find it quite easy to follow. The big names in the cast, De Niro, Fonda, and Jackson, are all very good, but the real standouts here are Pam Grier, the blaxploitation star of the seventies (Coffy, Foxy Brown, Black Mama, White Mama, etc.), and Robert Forster. Back in the day, he showed promise in “Medium Cool,” but was soon cast in a string of crappy B-movies such as “Vigilante” and “Alligator.” Forster’s role as Max Cherry is his best ever, and he is excellent in it. He is a wonderful character, but hardly an award-winner. I think the interesting thing about “Jackie Brown” is that Tarantino’s detractors accuse him of making shallow, violent, edgy crime movies, but the main storyline in this movie is about a middle-aged interracial romance, which is something I have never seen dealt with in a believable and realistic manner by any studio. It shows that Tarantino is a much deeper and bolder film-maker than some of his peers, and “Jackie Brown” is a fine film that deserves to be better known. Do not miss it, because it is not “Pulp Fiction: The Next Generation.”

Over the Hedge was based on a comic book series, which, unbeknownst to me, I have never read. But I can only assume that it is just as good as the film, if not better. Although it is not a great surprise, I can say that Hedge is truly enjoyable and great fun for all. Bruce Willis plays R.J., a raccoon, who makes the mistake of his life by stealing the enormous stockpile of food that his neighbor Vincent (Nick Nolte) bears for winter hibernation. The bear is very angry about the raccoon’s rashness, but gives him one week to gather all the food he has stolen and everything else he needs, or else he’ll eat R.J. When R.J. starts looking for the food, he finds a new suburb that has all kinds of food, food and everything else. In the forest next door he finds a family of animals, whose head is turtle Verne (Garry Shandling). They all go looking for food too, and R.J., after teaching them a few things they didn’t know about the human world, sets off to get the food he needs. Of course, this is the main idea of the film, but as with all animated films, it has a few unexpected turns, and as with many animated films, it has a good lesson, and is great for both children and adults. The film is full of small children’s laughs, and then even more laughs for the adults. The heart of the film is about how a suburb is created and what it does to the environment, and how we abuse consumerism. Although it’s only partly satirical, it has many pop culture references and others. It was also luckily spared the mandatory song and dance that plagues most animated films. The story is well written, but it seems very rushed. It starts, it goes on a little, and then it ends. It’s not as short as some films, but you can’t help but wonder what else they could have done with a little more time. Having said that, it’s still much better than other Dreamworks productions, such as Madagascar and Shark Tale, and it can compete with Shrek 1 and 2 in the best. The voices are all of a very high quality, from Bruce Willis’ no-nonsense raccoon to the sadly deceased Garry Shandling as a neurotic turtle. Steve Carell also shines as the completely crazy squirrel Hammy, and William Shatner shines as opossum Oswald. I’d read in advance that he was great in the role of opossum. I didn’t stop laughing every time his character showed up, he’s that great. All the rest of the cast, from Eugene Levy and Catherine O’Hara as hedgehog parents, to Wanda Sykes as a skunk, to Thomas Hayden Church as a pest exterminator, to Nick Nolte as bear Vincent, are also all good and suit their roles. They all have a lot of screen time, but none of them seem overly used (unlike Madagascar, where they were all overused with Ben Stiller). The insertion of Avril Lavigne as William Shatner’s daughter, Heather, was also a bit odd, but at least she at least tried to act in her role. And the animation is excellent as usual. It’s not as good as with other Dreamworks films, but it’s still a big step forward. The grass, the fur, the gestures and movements, everything is so perfect and beautiful to see. The colors are also beautiful. It’s a funny movie, and the cast is excellent. One of the best animated films in recent times. 8 out of 10.

Everyone plays well, and the film would have been excellent if it hadn’t been for the intrusive narration, which gave the impression that it was being told to children, and which, when it came to saying that the two of them had gone to bed together, had the effect of a nursery rhyme. It was very strange. I also feel that if it had been more conversation-based, the audience would have had a better sense of the characters. I watched it without any sub-titles, and found it easier to understand the relationship between Juan Antonio and his ex-wife (most of the conversation was in Spanish) than that between Vicky and Don; there needed to be something in their relationship that made it special. Anyway, Javier Bardem is wonderful as usual.

The third film about the young wizard is the most controversial, because it is this one that split the fans of the Harry Potter novels into two factions: conservatives and innovators. One of these factions denounced the film’s director, Alfonso Cuarón, for altering the Harry Potter stories to suit his own taste. They took exception to the strange werewolf, all the jokes that the director had inserted between the lines, and in addition they bemoaned the disappearance of the mystical atmosphere. So it should be, because the films are different from the novels. The fault lies at the very beginning. When Chris Columbus directed the first two films, the debate over what kind of films about Harry Potter should be reopened. The public is now accustomed to the mood of the first two films, so most of the audience took Cuarón’s novelistic approach to the film version of the third novel as a personal affront. Now the producers have made another mistake by entrusting two more films (The Order of the Phoenix and The Half-Blood Prince) to a new director, David Yates. This is an error that ought never to have been made. You have to preserve the diversity of director’s visions. Hogwarts is not the only place where you see it depicted in different ways in the films, and so is Hogsmeade. Everything is different in the novels, because everything is seen through the eyes of Harry Potter. But in the films, although it may be filtered through the director’s vision, the magic world must also be seen through the eyes of the young wizard. Alfonso Cuarón was still right with his original vision of the plot of The Prisoner of Azkaban. He made a delightful tragicomedy out of the young wizard’s growing-up. The whole film reminds me of the old Soviet films. For the very reason that you can take apart the whole film, the shots, the dialogue, the characters, the music, etc., etc. (Sirius Black) The third film, like the book, is dedicated to the vandals: James Potter (= Harry Potter), Peter Pettigrew, Remus Lupin and Sirius Black, a group of friends who were once friends... The film brutally shows how easy it is to lose friends and how hard it is to acquire new ones. It is worth praising the skill of Alfonso Cuarón, who with one brushstroke has sketched in the full range of characters of the magical world and their essences: the Minister for Magic dives into a puddle; the soothsayer with the glasses on her nose stumbles into a puddle; Remus Lupin, in his lesson, eats an apple; the portraits of Hogwarts castle sleep; Stan Shivell, despite all his bravado, carries a student’s trunk; Hagrid is hardly up to the job of carrying the trunks of the students; Stan, with his heroic words, is not much of a strain when it comes to lugging the trunks of his students; Remus Lupin, in his lesson, eats an apple; the Hogwarts portraits, it turns out, are fond of sleep as well; Stan Shivell, with his manly words, is not very strong when it comes to carrying the student’s trunks; Hagrid is not very good at wearing ties; Stan Shantipike, with his valour speeches, is not very strong when it comes to moving student trunks; Tom, the keeper at the Leaky Cauldron, has a dripping broom; Ernie, in glasses with a large glass, has to lead the Knights; and, finally, Sirius Black is now beginning to talk a morality... Meanwhile, if I am not mistaken, the two actors from the third film (the barmaid from the Leaky Cauldron and Aunt Marge) are already safely cast in his other production, “The Human One”, but that is another story. - “Potter, come here!” (Severus Snape, the Potion Master). In a word, long live Rowling and Cuarón!

He gave the best performance of his career. This madly twisting and dazzlingly stylized tale of a deadly plague that had forced the human race underground and the man sent back in time to find out what it was about is an adventure of mind-boggling complexity and also shows us that a man who goes back in time can't change the past, that things that have happened cannot be changed and that it is impossible to prevent a catastrophe, the outbreak of the plague. At one point, in a mental asylum, Bruce Willis says, “It’s already happened,” and the film doesn’t go forward as you might think, trying to save the world, but is instead an exploration of the naive, individual conflict of the man trying to survive in a constantly demented mental state. It is a new and original idea, which works brilliantly because of a script that Peoples has written tautly and in which Gilliam puts his special stamp. The movie is completely non-linear, full of dream, memory, present, past, future, and a scene lifted from Vertigo, and all of this is able to wrap the viewer in a disturbing and demented cacophony of madness and futility. As far as mise-en-scène and effects are concerned, Gilliam is a master of it, rivaling Tim Burton and his strikingly depressing and dismal settings and visual effects. Often bathed in an uncanny, antiseptic white light, the settings contrast with the often demented characters. Brad Pitt steals most of the scenes and has a very edgy and naive performance, which deservedly earned him an Oscar nomination. Bruce Willis gave his best performance of his career, not playing a heroic cardboard hero, but showing Cole as a sad, tragic and touching Everyman. Madeleine Stowe is equally good as the psychologist who helps Willis. for her “religion,” she has wild energy and strength, which then collapses under the weight of what she sees as a deceitful faith. Gilliam’s strong, visionary and highly complicated treatment of what could have been a straightforward action and science fiction film makes this a truly unique vision of a nightmarish and demented future. Along with the brilliance of the entire cast and the gloomy and bleak mise-en-scène, this is a true masterpiece of madness. My top ten films, a bleakly magnificent and ingenious spectacle. 10 out of 10.

In one of the first scenes of "Pulp Fiction," two assassins, passing in the streets of a large American city, have just come out of a restaurant and are discussing what is called a burger in other countries. Their conversation is amusing and witty, and the same time disarming because the thugs are very human, and it seems as if they were simply chatting on the way to work. Only the comic effect of the end of the scene, when they take advantage of the conversation to make fun of their victim, gives the scene its meaning. But without it, "Pulp Fiction" would not be "Pulp Fiction"; I have the impression that Tarantino has included in the film all the things that appealed to him, and, by the way, with such an unconstrained and at the same time disciplined selection, the film not only comes together, but also gains a wonderful variety of tones. No wonder that the abyss of the suitcase has left the audience puzzled and led to various interpretations. The film is so densely layered and so full of surprising details, many of which will not be seen the first time, that it almost demands a deeper explanation. But there is no deeper explanation. “Pulp Fiction,” as the title suggests, is just an exercise in technique and style, a brilliant and multi-layered exercise. It is, with its numerous allusions to other films, like a great abstract art work, or like an "art about art". It has all the qualities of great filmmaking: good script, excellent acting, unforgettable characters, and the most elegantly interwoven narration I've ever seen. But what's the point? Its completely self-contained story does not seem to relate to anything but itself. But it's a bit easier to understand when one sees that it is essentially a black comedy disguised as a gangster movie. Each of the three main plots begins with a situation that could easily be the basis for a standard gangster film, but something goes wrong, some small unexpected accident disrupts the situation and leads the desperate characters to absurd measures. The originality of the movie lies in Tarantino's ability to pay attention to small details and let them lead the story, even if they lead it away from the conventional gangster plot. Possibly no screenplay has ever made better use of digressions, or, more accurately, no character ever speaks in a straightforward manner. No, Jules, who has just said to Yolanda: "It's cool, nobody gets hurt," goes on to explain that he's a bit like Fonz, the theme of a different kind of pop culture. Every sentence is deliciously decomposed by Tarantino and instilled with brilliantly clever pop culture references. The sentences are not only witty, they also contain many clever observations about human nature. For example, when Mia says to Vincent: "You know you've found something when you can just shut up for a minute and enjoy your silence." What does this movie want to achieve? I'm not sure, but the central theme is power. Marsellus is one of those characters who dominates the film, although most of the time he is not visible. The big party scene, my favorite, is about Marsellus' power over his men, without his even being there. What makes Vincent act in a way that a stupid, inebriated gangster should not do with a pretty woman whose husband has left for a while, is the power of Marsellus. And it is this theme of power that also justifies the use of the N-word in the movie. It is not only used to describe the blacks in the movie; Jules, for example, calls Vincent that. Because it has more to do with power than race. The powerful characters use the word to show their dominance over the less powerful. Most of these gangsters aren't even racist in their daily lives. * they mingle among each other and have achieved a kind of equality that surpasses the behavior of many decent people. They use the N-word because it serves as a form of expression that marks them off from the rest of society. The story itself develops in a nice moral fashion. Vincent probably hesitates before sleeping with Mia out of fear, rather than out of loyalty. After that, Butch may have been inspired by honor, but it is never clear whether it was. Jules ends up making a clear moral choice, but the central question is whether violent gangsters can ever act for something other than self-interest. This is not a movie about hitmen philosophizing about hamburgers. And the film is not a satire, nor is it a comedy, although there are elements of both. It's a movie that doesn't have to be told, but for whatever reason, this movie does tell it. And it does so better than most other films of its genre or any other genre.

I've been writing for the Internet Movie Database for ten years, and I've noticed something very strange here. STRAIGHT OUTTA COMPTON is rated very highly by most of the film's reviewers, but despite all that, the nine and ten-star reviews are being demolished with negative ratings and all the comments are being downgraded to “1 out of 15.” What's going on? The American people shouldn't have been exposed to the real truth about how the police treat minorities every day. The general public shouldn't be so impressed by the story of how young blacks resist the oppression of the law and overcome it. So quick, delete the good reviews! Quick, let's start a backlash! Discredit Dr. Dre and Ice Cube for their past actions! Let's go and show sympathy for Eazy-E because he's dead and dead black men are fine. Dead ones are no longer scary or threatening. The problem with this film is that the directors had the audacity to portray the young, angry, and black men not as criminals or predators, but as heroic. It's okay to glamorize white criminals, that's how the whole industry was built. From Public Enemy to THE GODFATHER, whites have always loved to love their criminals. But it's not okay for rapping black men to rap about crime, even if they are not criminals themselves. In a certain old movie with James Cagney playing a gangster, that's fine. But today, it's irresponsible and dangerous! There are many very powerful people in this country who are very scared of this film, because this film is able to make whites see black men as something other than dangerous criminals. And the scene where the police were hitting the members of N.W.A., that's the worst threat for the powerful, the ones who rely on the fear of black men. Black male victims can't stand, so immediately, with the media, it's backlash, portraying the victims as criminals. I say it's a good movie, a powerful, compelling movie that shows a side of America that is rarely seen on the big screen. I know I'm not going to get many likes for this review, but I've already had enough of them.

It was my father who paid for me to go and see the notebook with my girlfriends because he kept telling me how great it was. I went just because it was free and had no expectations. But the notebook held me from beginning to end, and I cried for a long time afterward. I, and almost everyone I have talked to, was involved in the situations and the lives of the characters and cried with sadness and rejoiced with joy. I generally find that love stories are very predictable and somewhat boring (in my opinion) but this movie kept me guessing and twisting and turning all the way through. The Notebook was very well made and I would give it eleven out of ten.

You heard it right. Footloose is based on a TRUE story. It happened in a small town in Oklahoma in the year 1980. My father, whose real name is Leonard (Ned) Coffee, was at the center of it. Ren McCormack (also known as Kevin Bacon—hmm, coincidence?) was a junior at Elmore City High School. The population of the town was a mere 750 souls, and with around 50 Baptist churches, the local ordinances were rather conservative. The town had an ancient ordinance against public dancing that had never been repealed. In other words, Elmore had never had a prom. My father fought for a repeal with the help of his best friend, Rex Kennedy, president of the junior class, and they were granted their wish. Elmore has had a prom every year since. I don’t know who sold the story, but unfortunately, we didn’t get any money for it! It isn’t exactly like the movie (except that my father drove the same car Ren drove, which is why my father had to go to the prom in a nearby town). But, at the heart of the story, the real Ren was based on my father. And there you have it—the true story behind Footloose! If you haven’t seen it yet, go!

People who watch the Academy Awards have little interest in the Foreign Language film nominations. Incendies is the kind of film that leaves you empty of all emotion, which haunts you for days. It is like a deeply personal experience and it takes a long time to digest the film’s plot, a touching one, full of emotional ups and downs and catharsis. At the New Directors/New Films festival, where I saw the film yesterday, director Denis Villeneuve said that he had already directed four Canadian films, but that this was the first to be distributed in the U.S. “I can’t see why Villeneuve, or any of his actors, shouldn’t have a brilliant future.” Jeanne and Simon are twins who have just lost their mother, Nawal. In her will, Nawal instructs Jeanne and Simon to deliver an envelope to a brother they didn’t know they had, living in an unnamed Middle Eastern country. Only then will the two siblings be able to afford a decent burial for their mother. Jeanne is determined to deliver the envelope, and when she gets there she finds out some of the most painful things about her mother’s past. The film unfolds with each revelation about Nawal, and by the end the viewer has been stunned into silence. I have already praised the story, but one thing I must add is that Villeneuve has said that the script is four hours long. It is remarkable that the film succeeds so well in its compact form, because I can’t imagine that anything has been trimmed from it. But to back up this solid material, there is some truly fine acting. The whole cast has so much passion in their acting that it seems as if the film were autobiographical. The cinematography is so dreary, a tribute perhaps to the desert of the Middle East country where the film takes place, that it echoes the lives of Nawal and Jeanne. But the film is full of long, long, long takes that make the viewer gasp with their unnerving silences. I have no idea why Villeneuve had not received critical acclaim in the U.S. before this, but then I have seen a good number of films about the Middle East, and although some of them are deeply flawed and fail to evoke any emotion in me, others like The Hurt Locker or The Secret War have been spectacularly successful. Incendies is the best film I have ever seen about the Middle East, and although it has its faults—and it could have done with trimming by a few minutes—it is of the rare kind that remains in the memory after the first viewing. Incendies may some day be remembered as the brilliant film that brought fame to Denis Villeneuve.

“The story I am about to tell is my life story. I was born in Bombay in 1983. I was adopted by an Italian family when I was just two years old. My father told me that the nuns found me on the street and took me to an orphanage in Solur. My father took me away from there and brought me to Italy. We stayed there for a month and then came back to Italy. I don’t have any memories of that country. It will be very difficult for me to understand the place where I was born, but I will come back one day. I have to come back to India. The film ‘Pazhuvoor’ has changed my life.

With the workers’ strike in Russia, the crew of the Potemkin feels a special sympathy for their comrades, and when they are served rotten meat crawling with maggots, some of them object and are promptly pushed into front of a firing squad. And only at the last minute is the ordinary seaman Grigory Vakulinchuk to rescue the fellows by pleading with the firing squad to disregard the orders of their captain. After the officers take revenge and murder Vakulinchuk, all are drawn into a conflict that reaches all the way ashore to Odessa, where the rebellion spreads to the point of a bloody uprising. I had never seen this film before, but had seen many a reference to it in other films, and so considered it an important film to see at least once. The film is based on a real event, and that only makes it more interesting, but even without that the narrative is good. The characters are not all that compelling, but the events are brutal and unjust, and that is what drew me to the film—it shows its horror in its surprisingly violent manner (which implies more than sheer gore) and lets innocent people be killed on all sides in key scenes. The version I saw was said to be with its original score (I am not trying to be snobbish—to be fair, modern rescoring might be better—but I have no way of knowing), and the score is effective at enhancing and matching the film’s mood, whether it is dark and mournful, or dramatic and uproarious. The film’s technique held up rather well for my modern eyes, and though there were a few moments where the model work was unmistakable, on the whole the film is technically well done. The crowds, the ships, the cities, and the way the chaos is all so effectively filmed are very impressive, and could be accomplished even today. What is even more impressive is the fact that the film has a very clear and strong visual style; unlike many silent films I have seen, it is not as rough and flat, as many I have seen in the last few years have been, and it is instead very crisp and professional looking. Of course, in seeing it now, I am able to see how many images have been influenced by it, as well as interviews with directors who have mentioned it; but even without that benefit, the film is still a work of its time, and one can see how many of its shots are memorable, and two of the best examples are the step and the firing squad. The acting, though, might not be to everyone’s taste, as it is not to mine. There are a few moments when the actors seem to overdo it a little, as they have to show their emotions in ways that actors today would rely on dialogue. Besides that, it is a classic film that has influenced many directors, and the story is interesting and the acting is effective; the music is effective at creating the emotionality that a modern film would have to be earned by the acting and dialogue, and the whole is over much too quickly! The film is a must-see for film lovers, and it is also a very good film.

The best film to be made in the period of Daniel Craig's James Bond. Well acted. Best performances by Daniel Craig, Judi Dench and Javier Bardem, all three brilliant. Excellent action sequences. The story line is pretty complex and touches upon the relationship between M and Bond, of which little is known. Sam Mendes does a masterful job directing this installment in the James Bond series. After this film, you can compare Daniel Craig to Sean Connery.

I saw the movie earlier and even though I had very high expectations, I was still very pleased with it. It is known that the Turkish film industry lacks special effects. That is the main reason why we are unable to appreciate Turkish action films. However, in this film, we see many splendid examples of special effects. The scenes with the soldiers were so excellent, lively and natural. The movie has a plot that deserves the highest praise. In addition to the good special and sound effects, the movie has a good storyline. As I mentioned earlier, I had very high expectations and this film was even better than I expected. Thank you Mr. Alper Caglar for letting us enjoy such a magnificent film.

I have never written a review here before, but I feel compelled to take a stand for this film. The Bourne legacy was everything I had expected it to be. It couldn’t be too close to the previous Bourne films, but close enough to forewarn us of impending storms. Bourne’s presence throughout the film drives the action and I felt it was perfectly balanced. We all want Bourne, but this is the story of Aaron Cross. Renner and Weisz were brilliant, but the script has been panned by many. I had no issue with it and even felt the drive that made Renner’s character what he was. Someone who longed to be better, not someone who was already better than everyone else but had forgotten it. Let’s hope that we get what we all want and that Bourne and Cross are paired up in the next film.

This is the nastiest of the Scary Movie films. If you thought the first one was “too much,” then you will definitely be able to avoid this one because of its sluttish content and crude sex jokes. Here are your words. This was one of my favorite movies when I first saw it in the theater. I loved its crude sex jokes and sluttish spoofs. So if you’re into that sort of thing, you’ll love this one. The opening sequence is absolutely hilarious and, in my opinion, the best part of the film. It was about time the Scary Movie franchise gave us a spoof of The Exorcist! James Woods is hysterical as Father Merrin, and most of his scenes are filled with scatological jokes and profanity. For example, when Regan says, “Stuff it,” Father Merrin immediately crawls into her bed and pretends to penetrate her. Another example is when Regan’s mother says, “She won’t let me near her!” and the priest says, “Yes, sometimes that happens, you’ve got to give candy to the children”—a clear allusion to the recent child molestation scandals. On the other hand, the film does contain some classic but always effective teenage humor, like the scene where Father Merrin enters the room for the first time and gets scared and runs away when Regan turns around in her chair; and, of course, there’s the vomiting scene. After the spoof of The Exorcist, the film mostly spoofs Poltergeist and The Entity. It then heads off in a new direction and never looks back. You can expect to see spoofs of popular commercials and songs (Vitamin C), and even a few racial and homophobic jokes. Despite all the profanity, Scary Movie 2 never crosses the line. It’s just a funny R-rated comedy that has something for everyone—unless, that is, you take yourself too seriously. You must make sure to see it on DVD, because the TV version is heavily censored (especially during the dialogue). It’s my opinion that this is the best of the Scary Movies.

Don’t judge this film by the name. You can hate it for any reason you like, but this film is not just a stupid, mindless, meaningless, sexual fantasy. There’s much more thought behind it than you can imagine. However, the film was so poorly received by the critics because they couldn’t understand it, and the public blindly followed their lead. The film is essentially about Sweet Pea (Abbie Cornish), the star of the film. Director Zanny Snydman emphasized that from the beginning. Baby Doll (Emily Browning) is a figment of Sweet Pea’s imagination. She is the embodiment of Sweet Pea’s fantasies. She is Sweet Pea’s angel. The entire film is Sweet Pea’s inner struggle. It is she who narrates the film. All that we see with Baby Doll in the first act is Sweet Pea expressing her inner feelings, as she learned at the asylum. It is Sweet Pea expressing her inner feelings on the stage when she first enters the asylum, which is the theater. After that comes the lobotomy, which is the key to everything that follows. Sweet Pea, seen through the eyes of Baby Doll, loses contact with reality when the needle is injected into her brain. She retreats into her mind, as Dr. Gorski taught her to. She is no longer in the real world. This is what happened to Sweet Pea in real life. And the result of this lobotomy is this film. Yes, this film is the result of a lobotomy. It is a whole subconscious coping mechanism in order to find peace. And Sweet Pea is able to break in on the lobotomy, to interrupt her own story. She even has a way of turning the accidental death of her sister into a deliberate and necessary sacrifice to save her. This is the beginning of the second act. Sweet Pea imagines herself, with Baby Doll and the other girls, in a brothel, with an audience, in which she plays a role, with the audience watching her. That’s why we, the audience, are watching the performance in which these girls show themselves in various costumes. This means that, by choosing to watch the film, we have made ourselves complicit in everything that is going on. Of course, I am not criticizing you for your desire to see pretty young girls kick butts. The film is essentially about the difference between emancipation and exploitation. The film is in three tiers: the asylum, the brothel, and the fantasy-action scenes. Each tier represents a different phase of the feminist movement. The first tier, the asylum, is a dark reflection of the sixties, of the second wave of feminism, in which women were not seen as equals. And this inequality is accentuated in the second world, the brothel, which is even further back in time, when women were literally treated as property. the third tier, the modern world, reflects the dancing of Baby Doll through all the aspects of popular culture, in which the girls are dressed in all the typical outfits in which they are portrayed in popular culture: in manga, in comics, in manga, in animation, in science fiction, in action films, in horror films. Sweet Pea is aware of the sick side of this, and doesn’t want to be emancipated by it. But by seeing how the men are affected, they learn how powerful they really are, and how they can use their own sexuality to regain control over the men. For the men, who were once powerful over women, are now vulnerable. The reverse of the historic role of men and women is shown. This is then reflected to the same extent in the action-fantasy scenes, in which it is as if the women are seizing control of this male-dominated genre that has been dominated by men and their male fraternity for far too long. But the scene when Baby Doll is being lobotomized after Sweet Pea has found peace shows how even the lobotomized can have her moment. While Sweet Pea is imagining that she is escaping from her prison on the magic bus, Blue is preparing to do something about it. But it’s too late, she has already escaped, even if it’s just in her mind. Blue has power over her body, but without her mind he has nothing. And we see the importance of this in Baby Doll’s encounter with High Roller, who realizes that to love or not to love is a decision that can only be made by the one being loved. Whether it’s love or exploitation is entirely a matter of personal choice, and that’s the whole point of this film. Women have a right to control their bodies as well as their minds. This film is open to so many interpretations that it’s impossible to give a definitive meaning. It’s really quite remarkable that the director and producer are men, and that the man who defends the film is a man. If this film had been made by someone like a Kubrick, then everyone would have tried to understand the deeper meaning and wouldn’t have been bothered by the bad reviews. It’s really very sad that the people who have seen a Snider film are only prepared to see it in black and white, and see nothing beyond the surface, using no thought to interpret the images on the screen.

This film is never going to win an Academy Award, but it surprised me and has become my favorite movie this summer. The story is simple, as all good summer comedies should be. Two guys, who attend weddings to meet women, have some wild adventures and find out something. But the real joy of the film is the actors, who play their roles very well. It is a middle-aged surfer from California who is ready to grow up and Vince Vaughn is his best friend, a spoiled, but decent, young man. Christopher Walken is the slightly scary father of the bride. So if you have seen Owen Wilson in Shanghai Noon, Vince Vaughn in Swingers and Christopher Walken in... well, just about everything he has ever done, you've seen these characters before, but here they work together perfectly. The film is filled with just enough real emotion to make you care and just enough absurdity and wacky gestures to make you laugh. It's not Shakespeare, but it's fun. Recommended.

For the rest, the play is in three acts, with a brief epilogue. It is occupied by Briony, the younger daughter of the rich and aristocratic Tallis family, her elder sister, Cecilia, and by Robie Turner, a close friend of her sister’s, and a brilliant boy. Robie is the son of a maid-servant of the family; but he has received a good education, and has been a chorister at a grammar-school and at Cambridge, where he obtained a First. His prospects are brilliant in whatever direction he may turn; and he wishes to enter the medical profession. ACT I: We open in the Tallis family’s country house, on a hot summer’s day in the year ’35. Briony, a precocious thirteen-year-old girl, aspires to become an author; and she has composed a play which she and her three cousins are to perform. But the play is doomed to failure, because of disagreements among the performers. Robie is in love with Cecilia; and he sends her a passionate love-letter by mistake. Under other circumstances this would have been a matter for disgrace; but since she has returned his love, the accident proves to be a happy one. But the mood of the film is suddenly changed by the occurrence of a criminal charge, and the imprisonment of Robie, who has been falsely charged with the assault. Lola is unable to identify her assailant; but Briony, who was a witness, wrongfully accuses Robie. >ACT II: We now see Robie, freed from prison, fighting for his country in France. The war is going badly; and the enemy is about to reach Dunkirk. But the one thing that keeps him going is the hope of seeing Cecilia again. She has supported him throughout his trial and imprisonment, and has been estranged from her family. For her part, Briony is beginning to have misgivings about her identification of Robie as Lola’s assailant, and offers to recant her statement. She is determined to act as a nurse, and to give her life to the service of the wounded, as a means of atonement for the damage which she has caused to an innocent man and to her family. After his appearance in The Last King of Scotland and Becoming Jane, James McEvoy has come to the fore as the leading male star of British films, and his performance in this film is his best so far. I was a little disappointed in both the film and the story, and, above all, in the way that the story was handled. But whereas Dr Garrigan in The Last King of Scotland had an element of the sinister about him, and Legroy in Becoming Jane was, for the most part, a likeable rogue, Robie is unquestionably a hero. The casting of him was a good decision, and the fact that he is working with director Joe Wright (after Pride and Prejudice) is another guarantee of the film’s success. A good performance, too, from Keira Knightley, who, although she was very good in Bend it Like Beckham, is at her best in the films which Joe Wright has directed, and it seems to me that she should not look to the future of her career in Hollywood blockbusters like The Devil’s Double, where she was, if anything, out of her depth. She is not only the loveliest but also the liveliest and the most spirited of the film’s leading ladies. I would like to make special mention of Saoirse Ronan as the young Briony, and of Vanessa Redgrave as the elderly Briony in the epilogue, which is set in the year 1999. Her daughter, however, is convincing, and it was a good decision to cast her as little Briony. In the second film of his career, Joe Wright has shown himself to be an excellent director. His previous film, Pride and Prejudice, was excellent, but Atonement is even better. I doubt that any adaptation of the novel could ever have caught all its subtleties, for a number of reasons. Among other things, there is a central theme in the novel, a kind of dialogue between modernism and traditionalism in literature, which cannot be properly conveyed by the cinematic medium, and which Joe Wright and the scriptwriter, Christopher Hampton, avoid at all costs. The last twist of the plot is also kept, although the situation is changed slightly, with Briony finally telling the truth in an interview on national TV. The film, however, is not only capable of capturing the novel’s emotional undercurrents, but also of a very lively and vivid visual sense, something which is sometimes missing in films based on novels. Atonement now joins the list of films (like A Single Man and Girl with a Pearl Earring) in which nearly every scene has the feel of a painting. This is true of the first part, set in the beautiful stately home (the actual setting is the manor house at Stokesay in Shropshire), and of the second, which is set in the war, in which Joe Wright can see a horrible beauty in war, particularly in the burning town and the long shot of the beaches of Dunkirk in grey morning light. With regard to the war and the behavior of the characters, I found the line “Dear Lord and Father of Men” very touching, because the second line of the poem by John Greenleaf Whittier, “Forgive our folly”, was so apt. Also very good was Dario Marianelli’s music, which was an appropriate choice for a film in which writing plays an important role. It is a fine film, and I only hope that its British origins and the fact that it was released in the late summer (when blockbusters dominate) will not prejudice the Academy against it in next year’s awards. I give it a full ten out of ten in my opinion.

It was a true golden age of animation for both the purest Disney and the purest Pixar fans. For me, at least, this was the first time that I thought the Disney takeover of Pixar would prove to be a positive development for the animated film pioneers. It contained what were probably Pixar’s most beautiful scenes and character designs (sidenote: Merida’s is my favorite character design of any animated human being.) It also contained the studio’s best score. Besides, Brave was also a deft send-up of classic fairytales, with the same magical, eerie feeling that typified their work. I hope it gets better and better over time. If Wreck-It Ralph was Pixar doing Disney, Brave was Pixar doing Disney.

First of all, it's an Adam Sandler movie. If you hate Adam Sandler movies, you won't like it. I gave it 8/10 because it was one of the better Adam Sandler movies. The plot and storyline was better than I expected, the character development was quite good as well. There were a few moments when I wanted to hit myself in the face because it was so slapstick funny. Yes, it's highly unrealistic, but if you're looking for realism, what the hell are you looking for? Yes, I know, it's a dumb story about an ugly woman who fucks her a lot, but she played it quite well.

After reading the first couple of Harry Potter books before the year 2001, and having heard about the buzz surrounding the first movie, I was excited. It was going to be a British cast (which seems only natural), and we would be seeing on screen one of the great novels of our time. I think I went with my family and a family friend on the day after Christmas to see the movie and was pleasantly surprised. I sat through the credits and recognized some of the names: the late Alan Rickman, the late Dame Maggie Smith, the late James Bond, James Bond, Robbie Coltrane, and the late Warwick Davis, and many children, some of whom were making their first movie. But it was a good movie and a party of sights and sounds for the whole family. This is easily my favorite of the Harry Potter movies. The igniting spark for the whole series!

Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a movie like no other I've ever seen, nor probably will I ever see again. It's a real epic that leaves me completely speechless. It achieves so much with so little. Everything about it is sublime, from the elegant direction, to the understated and brilliant acting, to the fantastic music. It makes you feel not only for the death we see, but for the unbelievable life that is revealed to us. It deals with obvious moral issues, but also with the premise that we all experience the same joys and sufferings, but not all of them in the same way. This is a major story, worthy of no less than greatness. This visually and emotionally rich movie tells the story of the life of a very strange man, born at the beginning of the twentieth century and growing old backwards. The story is told in his diary, which his beloved Daisy is reading. Through his life, he experiences what we all experience, growing up and then, finally, aging. He is a thoughtful observer, learning to see life from all sides. But it is not his life that makes him unique. It is his love that makes him unique. He spends a lifetime trying to understand how he loves Daisy, and still only manages a few incredible years of loving her. And as their lives show us, the years of frustration and struggle are all worth it for a few moments of happiness. The direction is nearly perfect, and I hope this movie will bring director David Fincher the recognition he deserves. He keeps time so well and with such grace that the movie has an unavoidable flow, and is enjoyable from beginning to end. At nearly three hours, there is not a minute wasted. Each shot is absolutely stunning, and although some may complain about the time, I think it is very well used. This is Brad Pitt's best role, and he is so believable and so natural throughout. His subtlety is extraordinary, and despite the heavy makeup and CGI used to show us his character, it is Pitt that makes him so strange. There is not a single part in this movie that I would not like to see again. After so much anticipation, I was not disappointed. It is an extraordinarily elegant picture of life, love, and loss. However, this is probably not a movie for everyone. It is not the ordinary romance, and it does not hold your hand. But it is a great and astonishing movie, and it is certainly a gem. What makes our lives unforgettable are the moments we don't seem to want to keep. Life is a very strange thing in itself, and Benjamin Button is no less a miracle.

I have liked most of the digital animated films that have been made so far, from the Pixar Toy Story and The Incredibles to DreamWorks’ Shrek. But ‘Finding Nemo’ is unique, not because of its comedy or its originality, both of which are equalled in the Toy Story films and “Monsters, Inc.”, but because it really, more than any of the other digitally animated films, reinvents the genre of children’s animation. In the case of ‘Finding Nemo’ the funny is more subtle. Often it is based on physical and social comedy, and when seagulls crash into a boat you can see their beaks cocking on the other side of the sails. But it is precisely these details that make the film all the more astonishingly different from the cartoon clichés of the past. It gives a surprisingly scientific appearance to its world of thinking animals. All animals are based on real species. The tanks in which the fish live are built according to genuine instruments. There is a strong sense of place, since Marlin (Albert Brooks) travels across the Pacific to Australia, and even the animals speak with an Australian accent. A pelican and a group of fish discuss the finer points of dentistry. The fact that the animals can talk and understand the events that are taking place is taken as natural. This realism is so striking that by the end of the film one believes that fish can indeed escape from the tank. But this approach, far from making the film pedantic, results in an intelligent but entertaining film, based on parodies of human behaviour: remorseful sharks start an AA-like club, a school of fish makes itself into an impressive pattern and behaves like some embarrassing Djs and goes about its business with an impertinent and destructive energy. Concluding with Marlin’s (Albert Brooks) finding his son in the most original way, it is worth the film’s reliance on coincidence. This film follows the same general pattern as Toy Story, in which two people, one fussy and the other uneducated, are forced to travel together through a world of animals that are much more intelligent than people think. But the movie creates a unique and ingenious character in Dory (Ellen DeGeneres), a fish with short-term memory loss. To give a cartoon character a genuine human disease is certainly daring, and it is a good thing that the makers had the courage to do so, because not only does this device give some of the best jokes of the film, but it is also a key factor in the interaction of characters, which is the whole point of the film. At this point, we see true character development: on the journey, Marlin learns to be more adventurous, receiving parenting advice from a surfer-like turtle (voiced by the director, Andrew Stanton), while his son Nemo learns to be independent. And all the sharks, jellyfish, whales, gulls, pelicans, lobsters and humans that Marlin encounters on the way mean nothing but their business. According to Nigel the pelican, “Fish swim, birds eat”. This is perhaps the film’s most interesting insight, that there are no real villains, only creatures acting according to their nature, and a few who transcend it.

What a marvellously fearless and honest portrait of a relationship! I have never seen such a precise and accurate filmic transfer of these emotions as in Before Sunrise. What a crime that neither Ethan Hawke nor Julie Delpy have been nominated for an award for this film, but a great deal! Neither have Richard Linklater for the screenplay and the brilliant way of directing these wonderful actors. I loved the ending (though it also hurt), I loved that it returned to all the places the couple had visited. I loved the way the dialogue never wavered, that it did not directly deal with the relationship, but indirectly showed how the bond between the two grew through body language, facial expressions and words. Every word of it comes from those top ten talks we have all had with a close friend, either seriously or playfully. And respect to Richard Linklater for keeping it real: the film was rated R for two or three swear words, which could easily have been taken out, but which he left in anyway. No, to hell with you, Hollywood, your romantic comedies, your Freddie Prinzes, your take the glasses off and she's a pretty girl pictures! Here is real love! This is what I come to the cinema for, to be challenged, to think, to be transported by that magic that only cinema can create. Before Sunrise alone has reminded me of why I go to the movies...

I saw this film on the 19th of July in a small advance screening, knowing nothing about it except that it had a fantasy adventure theme and starred some familiar actors. The storyline is really original and originality is highly appreciated when everything that is coming out is the same thing. Despite first impressions, the film is not at all tacky, corny, trite, stupid, and it is actually incredibly funny and enjoyable. The story is paced well; nothing feels too rushed or too drawn out. The music, or as I call it, is very magical and really enhances the film, rather than just filling silence as often happens in films and on television. I must admit that even though I perhaps suspected what was going to happen at certain points, I still couldn’t take my eyes off the screen, and as far as I know no one in the auditorium left during the screening. My only complaint is that there doesn’t seem to be much marketing for this film and with it being as good as it is, I don’t understand why.

The advertisements of this film do it a great disservice. I stood in the lobby of a movie theater where there was a free screening, and I almost didn’t go in because the advertisements and trailers had convinced me that it was just a pointless waste of time. It appears that this film is nothing but a big number of shirts kicking each other and a few pretty girls in bikinis. Not only are there many of both, but it also has a good storyline and a strong theme. In terms of the theme, the film is about taking responsibility for your actions, about controlling your emotions and making good decisions. It is as much about the reasons for the courage as about the macho. Yes, it is a teen film, rich kids run around in mansions and drive expensive cars, but it’s only the setting. There are also people who kick the living daylights out of each other, but it is only a means to an end, the heart of the film is about personal development and choices. It is not the best film of the year, and it is possible that it will be a midnight film on cable in a few months, but it is by no means as bad as people think. It is worth the price of a rental and worth ten dollars to see it in the theater, if you have nothing else to do. I blame the negative reactions on the advertising, which seems to sell it as “just another fighting film.”

Silver Guardian is a Chinese webcomic, created by the Zero-league and illustrated by Mooncake. It is compiled by the Tencent Comics Cloud service and has 237 chapters. The Chinese-Japanese animation series Silver Guardians was produced by Emon and directed by Masahiko Okura and was broadcast on Tokyo MX in April, 2017. The license was taken over by Funimation and a new series began on January 13, 2018. The plot is: Suigintou is a high school student, and he is also a high-level gamer. He entered the prestigious Shinry Academy, which is only for nobles and rich people, and he became a hero of the moon. However, he is very poor, and he has to do a lot of part-time work to pay for tuition. One day, while doing a part-time job cleaning a pool, he saw a cat rushing into the water, and he jumped in without hesitation. To his surprise, he couldn't swim, and he was struggling in the water. Just as he was about to drown, a beautiful girl appeared and saved him. He did not know that she was the daughter of the game designer who created the game he loved.

Nightflight to Venus is the third studio album by the mixed group of Germans, Americans, and Caribbeans Boney M. It was released in July of that year and scored big successes in Europe, Scandinavia, and Canada, where it hit the top of the album charts in the second half of '78, as well as becoming their first number one album in the United Kingdom. It was nominated for a Canadian Juno award in 1980 for 'Best International Album'. The album features the worldwide hits 'River of Babylon' and 'Brown Girl in the Ring', which topped the British charts and sold more than two million copies. The next hit single was another classic Boney M. single, Rasputin, which in most countries was coupled with 'Painter Man', originally by the Creation. Both were separately released by Atlantic as A-sides in the UK, where they both reached number 10 on the chart. ' River of Babylon', which reached number 30 on the Billboard Hot 100, was their first real hit in the United States.

Cassandra Law is a former American rugby union player, and a member of the World Cup-winning team in 1991 and the 1994 team. She began her career at the University of Oregon in 1985, and after graduating in 1988, moved to San Francisco, where she began a career with the Veterans Administration. Her career continued in California with the Bay Area She-Hawks (BASH), with whom she competed from 1988 to 1995, winning three national titles, representing the Pacific Coast Grizzlies in the South West League and being selected to the US Eagles from 1990 to 1994. It began with the first World Cup in New Zealand in 1990 and continued with the first World Cup in Cardiff in 1991, where the US won gold by defeating England in the final, and the 1994 Women's World Cup in Edinburgh, where the USA lost to England and came second. In March of this year, she was inducted into the United States Rugby Union Hall of Fame in San Diego, California, along with the 1991 U.S. Women's World Cup Championship team.

Marco Anelli (born 31 October 1968, Rome) is an Italian photographer. He began his career in Paris, where he specialized in darkroom techniques. His photographic researches span long periods of time and cover diverse subjects. His works include architecture, landscape, portraiture, sports and classical music. In 2010 he realized a project called "Portraits in the Presence of Marina Abramovic" (Damiani) in which he photographed the 1545 people who took part in the Marina Abramovic's performance at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. He also photographed the transformation of an old calculator factory into Magazzino Italian Art, a new center for contemporary art in Cold Spring, New York, founded by Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu. Artists' studios in New York (Damiani, 2020) reveals the personality and working space of world-famous artists such as Alex Katz, Cecily Brown, Francesco Clemente, Joan Jonas, John Giorno, Julian Schnabel, Kiki Smith, Lawrence Weiner, Matthew Barney, Robert Longo, Shirin Neshat, Ugo Rondinone, Urs Fisher. Tino. Nivola in America (Silvana Editoriale and Magazzino Italian Art, 2021) is his last published work and in which Anelli's photographic research focuses on Costantino Nivola's sculptures, disseminated all over the United States.

Born June 4, 1965, Andrea Jaeger is a former American tennis player, ranked world No. 2, who in a short but very successful career was forced to prematurely stop because of severe shoulder injuries. He came to the singles final of the '83 Wimbledon tournament and the '82 French. He also reached the semi-finals of the Australian and the U.S. Open. In addition to 10 singles titles, in 1981 he won the French Open in mixed doubles with Jimmy Arias. During his career he won $ 1.4 million in prize money and millions more in various advertising contracts. Since his retirement in 1987, he has been engaged in the field of philanthropy and public service and in 2006 he became "Sister Andrea" as a member of the Anglican Order of Preachers. She is now living in Santa Rosa Beach, Florida. Tennis career: While attending high school at Stevenson, suburban Chicago, Jaeger was ranked first in the U.S. among under-18s and won 13 junior titles in the United States, including the most prestigious junior tournaments: the 1979 Boca Raton and the '79 Orange Bowl.

In computer science, formal specifications are mathematically based methods intended to assist in the development of systems and programs. They are used to describe a system, to analyze its behavior, and to design it by verifying certain important properties by powerful and precise reasoning. Formal specifications are those which have a syntax, a specific semantics, and are adapted to the derivation of useful information. The motivation is that, with each decade, the power of the machines increases and their impact on society increases. Better tools are needed to assist in the design and implementation of reliable software. The traditional engineering methods are based on mathematical analysis, a foundation which enables the design and the proof of the design of the products. Formal specifications are a way to achieve this in the case of the reliability of the software. Other methods such as testing are used more often to ensure the quality of the code.

Cosimo de Torres, also Cosma and Cosma de Torres, was born in Rome in 1584, son of the Marquis de Torres and Princesse Julie de Papareschi, and was born into a Spanish family that had settled in Rome, having been exiled from Malaga in the sixteenth century. He was born in a noble family of the Marchesi Giovanni de Torres, and was the son of the marquis Giovan Battista Giovanni de Torres, and Princesse Giulia Mattei, Princesse Papareschi. He was educated at the Jesuit College, where he had studied, and had been consecrated as a cardinal. His uncles, Girolamo Mattei (appointed a cardinal in 1586) and Ludovico de Torres, junior (appointed a cardinal in 1606 and a cardinal), were also cardinals. Upon graduating, he was assigned to the Apostolic Protonotary College under the leadership of his uncle, Cardinal Mattei. In 1608 he was a referendary of the Vatican offices of the Apostolic Signature of Justice and Grace.

Ralston Alexander Cash (born August 20, 1991) is an American professional baseball pitcher. Cash was educated at Lakeview Academy in Georgia, and was chosen by the Los Angeles Dodgers in the second round of the 2010 draft. He has played in the Ogden Raptors and the Arizona League Dodgers. His season was cut short by a major hip operation and he missed the whole of the following year. He came back to the game in the Midwest League in the 2012 season, going 1-6 with a 6.42 ERA in nine games, but then went on to win four games in Great Lakes in the 2013 season and earned a 3.19 ERA in eight starts. In 2014, he went to the bullpen and was involved in 29 games for the Great Lakes Loons and six for the Chattanooga Lookouts of the double-A Southern League and was 3-1 with a 2.90 ERA combined. He played in the Texas League in 2015 with the new double-A affiliate, the Tulsa Drillers, where he was 2-6 with a 3.47 ERA in a career-best 49 games. After the season he played for the Glendale Desert Dogs in the Arizona Fall League and was selected for the AFL All-Star game. He started the 2016 season with the Tulsa Drillers and was 5-3 with a 3.00 ERA in 29 games, before he was promoted to the triple-A Oklahoma City Dodgers, where he was 4-0 with a 2.62 ERA in 17 games. After the season, the Dodgers assigned him to the Glendale Desert Dogs in the AFL.

Ted Quinn (born November 12, 1958 in La Porte, Indiana) is an American musician, record producer, radio host, and actor. In his childhood, Ted appeared as a child actor in many advertisements, films, and programs. His first appearance was as Mike in a one-minute Bayer Aspirin ad in 1963. The script extolled the virtues of a mother who cares about her children's health, and Quinn's final line was "Mothers are like that... yeah... yeah..." and the last three words were an ad-lib that caught the public's attention. One columnist wrote that "There's probably no one in the history of the commercial that so completely captured the interest and affection of the public as Ted Quinn, who overnight became famous for saying: "Mothers are like that... yeah, yeah..." The hundreds of letters that the company receives on Ted Quinn are an indication of how popular he is. They come from all over the country and most of them are asking for the ad to be repeated." Ted's success in this ad attracted the attention of Hollywood agents, and his film career began, with roles in Bonanza, Dr. Kildare, The Virginian, The Courtship of Eddie's Father, The Accidental Family, and as a long-standing regular on General Hospital as Scott Baldwin. His film career included such films as Madame X, The Ghost and Mr. Chicken, The Ballad of Josie, and Necromancy.

FiB Stahl Brandenburg is a German football club based in Brandenburg an der Havel, Brandenburg. Founded in 1950 as BSG Einheit Brandenburg, they played their first seasons in the 2. East German football division. In 1955, the name BSG Stahl Brandenburg was adopted, reflecting the club's ties to the local steel mill. With the help of the sponsor, the club built a strong team by paying top money to "second-rate" players from other clubs, who were drawn into the ranks and became popular with fans. They were promoted to the DDR-Oberliga for the 1984/85 season and played there until German reunification in 1990. BSV Stahl Brandenburg was renamed for the 1991/92 season in the 2. Regionalliga Nordost. After the steelworks closed and with it the main sponsor, the name Stahl was dropped. From 1992 to 1994 the club played in the third-highest level NOFV-Oberliga Nord, won the title and was promoted to the newly established Regionalliga Nordost. After one season in the Regionalliga, the club was demoted to the Oberliga and then to the Verbandsliga Brandenburg in 1996.

Francis Lillie Pollock, February 4, 1876–1957, Canadian writer of science fiction, was born in Huron county, Ontario. He wrote “popular fiction” under the pseudonym of Frank L. Pollock, “Western fiction” under the name of Frank Lillie Pollock, and “literary fiction” under his own name. His first stories appeared in Youth’s Companion. He also published stories in Munsey’s Magazine, The Atlantic, The Bookman (New York), and the Canadian Woman’s Journal, now the Canadian Woman’s Annual. He left the Toronto Empire and Mail in 1907 to devote himself to writing. Pollock’s career as a writer was complemented by his occupation as a beekeeper; many of his works were influenced by his interest in bees. He kept bees in Shedden, Ontario, and farmed commercially. He and his second wife, Zella Taylor, retired to Georgetown, Ontario.

Food First, also called the Institute for Food and Development Policy, is a non-profit association based in Oakland, California. Founded in 1975 by Frances Moore Lappé and Joseph Collins, it calls itself a “think-tank and action centre for the public”. Its mission is to fight the injustices that lead to hunger. According to its own site, the objective is “to establish food sovereignty in the interest of human rights and sustainable development”, and to this end it has three programs of action: local agri-food systems, farmers building food sovereignty, democratizing development. The organization carries out policy studies on poverty, agriculture and development, and is harshly critical of the policies imposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. It is particularly critical of the green revolution which was supported in the seventies, and which did not achieve the development that was expected. It established a system of farming that has high costs, but which does not give much higher yields than those of traditional agriculture. A resurgence of the same ideas has been seen lately, especially with the support given to genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and to agribusiness of high yields. The policy of Food First is that these are incompatible with the goals of a fair and lasting development. Several policy papers have been produced to this end.

The shrike-babblers are a group of small birds in the genus Pteruthius, which are native to the Indomalayan region. Until recently they were considered part of the family Timaliidae, until molecular phylogenetic research in 2007 proved that they belong to the family Vireonidae, then thought to be restricted to the New World. They were classified into five species with several subspecies; but changes in their classification in the light of the phylogenetic species concept point to the existence of many more species in the cryptic species complex. Many species occur in mountain forests, but some of them also descend to lower altitudes during the winter. They vary in size and coloration, but all have a thick, black, hooked beak, a short, bristly rictal bristle and a distinct scapular bristle. Sexually dimorphic coloration is obvious, and males are generally brighter. The song is simple and monotonous.

August 1, 1968, Kenneth Bae was born. In April, he was sentenced to fifteen years of hard labor. In November, 2014, he was released with fellow American Matthew Todd Miller. In April, 2016, he founded NGO Nehemiah Global Initiative, which aims to remember, save and recover the North Koreans and to resettle them in China and South Korea. Bae was born in South Korea in 1968. He was eighteen years old when he came to the United States with his family. Bae (then he went by the name of June-Ho Bae) graduated from Torrance West High School in 1988, twenty years old. He studied psychology for two years at the University of Oregon in Eugene and later attended the Covenant Theological Seminary in St. Louis.

“Kathy Arendsen, born October 10, 1958, is an American coach and former professional softball player. Born and raised in Holland, Michigan, she starred in pitching at Holland Christian High School and won the state title before embarking on a successful collegiate and professional career. In college she played for the University of Texas and California State College at Chico, and won a national championship in her senior year. Arendsen received the Broderick award as the best female athlete in softball in 1978, and was selected to play for the United States in the Pan-American Games in 1979 and 1983, winning a gold medal in the former and a silver medal in the latter. When she completed her college career, she played for 15 years with the Raybestos Brakettes in the women's pro league. During this time she was named All-American thirteen times, won nine national titles, and three world titles. During the 1981 Baseball Strike, she drew attention for striking out Major League Baseball player Reggie Jackson three times in an exhibition game. Also, in the year 1999, Sports Illustrated named her one of the 50 Greatest Athletes from Michigan.

Brian Alan Holzinger (born October 10, 1972) is an American retired ice hockey center. He played in the National Hockey League with the Buffalo Sabres, Tampa Bay Lightning, Pittsburgh Penguins and Columbus Blue Jackets. In the sixth round, 124th overall, of the 1991 NHL Draft, he was selected by the Buffalo Sabres. He played high school hockey at Padua Franciscan High School in Parma, Ohio, and then four years of college hockey at Bowling Green State University, where he won the Hobey Baker Memorial Award for the best men's college hockey player in his senior year. In the 1994–95 season, he made his NHL debut for the Sabres, playing in four regular season games and two playoff games against the Philadelphia Flyers, scoring two goals. After four and a half seasons with the Sabres, at the trade deadline of the 1999–2000 season, he was traded, along with Cory Sarich and Wayne Primeau, to the Tampa Bay Lightning for Chris Grattton and a second round draft pick.

The American voice actress Cassandra Lee Morris (born April 19, 1982) began as a presenter for a teenage audience on the educational video series Real World Science. She has also worked as a freelance journalist in New York and Los Angeles, writing for local newspapers and magazines, and numerous fashion and lifestyle web sites, including About.com, David’s Bridal and Patch.com. She began her career as a voice actress with the role of Alice, and later as Yubel, in Yu-Gi-Oh! GX and has since appeared in a variety of animations, anime and radio dramas. Her best-known roles include K-On!'s Ritsu Tainaka, Suguha Kirigaya / Leafa in Sword Art Online, Kyubey in Puella Magi Madoka Magica, Taiga Aisaka in Toradora, and the second Godzilla film. She has also appeared in several games, including the role of Fie Claussell and Alfin Reis in Trails Cold Steel I-IV, Totori Helmold in Atelier Totori and Atelier Meruru, that of Edea Leblanc in Bravely Default, Lina Lee in Xenoblade Chronicles X, the villain Morgana in Persona 5, the heroine of Atelier Totori: The Adventurer of Arland, and the heroine of Atelier Totori: The Apprentice. Also Angie Yonaga in Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc – Trigger Happy Havoc. An example of her works is as follows:

Since that time, a physicist, acoustician, Floyd A. Firestone (1898–1986), was the first to use a practical ultrasonic testing device and method. He was granted a patent for his invention in 1942, and the device, manufactured by Sperry, was variously known as the Firestone–Sperry Reflectoscope, the Sperry Ultrasonic Reflectoscope, the Sperry Reflectoscope, and, finally, sometimes as the Supersonic Reflectoscope, the name given by Firestone to the instrument. The technique is not only used for quality control in the factory and for rejecting defective parts, it also revolutionized the safety of transportation. For example, ultrasonic testing is used for safety maintenance of railcars, mainly of wheels and axles, airplanes, mainly of the fuselage, and other ships for the fatigue strength of the materials. Dr. Firestone's ultrasonic pulse–echo method for metal defect detection later found application in medical diagnostics, giving birth to the field of echocardiography and the field of medical ultrasonography. Dr. Firestone served as editor of the Journal of the Acoustical Society of America from 1939 to 1957. Among many other inventions by Firestone are, in a single year, an "automatic device for minute flaw detection", "a new and useful way of connecting electric devices" and "a noise measuring device", and even a "musical typewriter" later. In 1933, Firestone proposed an alternative analogy to James Clerk Maxwell's analogy of the analog in which force is analogous to the voltage (impedance analogy). In the Firestone analogy (now known as the mobility analogy), force is analogous to the current. He introduced the concept of "through" and "over" for the variables, and showed that there are analogs for these variables in other energy domains, so that the entire system can be treated as a whole in the analysis. Firestone's analogy was a favorite among mechanics for designing mechanical filters because it had the property of preserving the topology of the network when transforming between the mechanical and electrical domains.

Dokis (meaning “our pots”) is a First Nations reserve and community in Ontario, Canada, under the jurisdiction of the Dokis First Nation. It is situated about twelve miles southwest of the centre of Lake Nipissing, on the French River. It is divided into two parts, one of which consists of a large northern island called Okikendawt and a large southern peninsula. The two land masses, which are engulfed by the waters of the French River, occupy an area of 154.36 square kilometres. The French River watershed of northern Ontario was formed more than ten thousand years ago by the retreating ice of the last glacial period, leaving a network of rivers and small lakes.
