The main community is on Okikendawt Island (literally meaning the “Island of Pots”), which is accessed by a dirt road that connects to Highway 64. The Dokis reserve is occupied by the Dokis First Nation and their relatives, the Restoule First Nation. The area is known for its fishing, hunting, fur-trading, and timber. The reserve is bordered by the West Nipissing First Nation and the Unorganized Parry Sound District.

Scott Logan Verrett (born June 19, 1990) is an American professional pitcher for the Washington Nationals. He made his major league debut with the Texas Rangers in 2015, and has also been with the New York Mets and the Orioles. Before turning professional, he had pitched for Calallen High School and Baylor University. He was born in The Woodlands, a suburb of Houston, and played infield in the youth leagues there. Before high school, the family moved to Corpus Christi, and Verrett played for Calallen High School, a high school in the Corpus Christi area. He was a high school ace in his senior year, winning 18 games without a loss, with a 0.67 earned run average and 167 strikeouts, and completed 12 of his 18 games. In addition, he batted.455 and scored seven home runs and 33 runs in hitting. The team won the Texas Class 4A state championship with a 42–1 record, and Verrett was named All-South Texas and Class 4A Baseball State.

Sound Heath, also called Sound Common, is a common near Nantwich, in Cheshire. It consists of heathland, grassland, scrub, and wood, and is a local nature reserve and a SSSI. It is a valuable reserve for heath-loving plants and animals, but its heathland character is threatened by the encroachment of trees and shrubs. The ponds are one of the most important sites in the county for freshwater invertebrates. Amongst the rare and endangered species found there are the mud snail (which has been recently reclassified as "near threatened" in the new IUCN European Red List of Non-marine Molluscs), the great sheet-legged spider, and the Enochrus isotae water-scavenger beetle, plus the beautiful snout moth. This was the first site in Cheshire where the migrant hawker dragonfly was found. It is an important breeding area for birds.

Jessie Brewer, R.N. (Murray) is a fictional character on the American ABC soap opera General Hospital. She was played by the late actress, Emily McLaughlin, from the show's premiere on April 1, 1963, until the actress's death in 1991. In a special flashback on April 1, 2015, the character was played by Rebecca Herbst. Casting and conception: The original cast of the series, which was devised by the late John W. A. Woolfolk, included a number of notable actresses, including the young actress, Phyllis Ruth, and the American actress, Claudette Colbert, and the young actress, Karen Hollenbeck. The series was originally based on the dramatic interplay between Brewer and Dr. Steve Hardy, and their work together at the General Hospital. When the actress died on April 26, 1991, the show wrote her death out of the storyline, and John Beradino, who was a friend of the actress and played Steve Hardy, made a public announcement the week after her death.

The “100th Window” is the fourth studio album by the English musical group, Massive Attack, and was released on February 10, 2003, on Virgin Records. Of the original members, only Robert Del Naja is present on the album; Andrew Vowles left the band after the release of Mezzanine in 1998, and Grant Marshall refused to work on the album. The album was composed and produced by Del Naja and Neil Davidge, and features the vocals of Horace Andy, Sinéad O’Connor and Damon Albarn as 2D, from Gorillaz. It is the first album by the group not to be made with the help of samples and to lack the jazz-influenced jazz-fusion of its first two albums, Blue Lines and Protection. The composition of the album began in early 2000 at the Clifton studios in Bristol. It is made with the help of Lupine Howl, a band composed of former members of the group Spiritualized. In a November, 2001, interview, the singer of the band, Sean Cook, says that the session is "very experimental... it consists of rather minimal loops and noises that they send to our headphones from a machine in the control room. " From there, we had a kind of long jam session, while they changed the loops, sometimes cut it off, sometimes distorted it with delay and effects, to see how it would affect the playing. There was also a strobe light installed in the studio, from which they controlled from the control room, turning it on and off, making it strobe faster and slower, thus determining the speed and determining the extent of the effects on our playing. It was great fun and we had a lot of good stuff. I mean, they recorded for hours. Now they're cutting and rearranging and making their own tracks. "

"I am writing," said the speaker, "in the highest sense of the word." Then Mr. Pettigrew, who had been referring to some legal business, asked him if he was not going to speak on another subject, which was the effect of Mr. Schuyler. At the age of two years, he was buried in his mother's arms at Thetford, in the state of Vermont. His parents were married in 1841 and they had seven children, whom they had brought up with great care, among which he was the sixth born. The surviving children were: Ann Amanda, Alma Jane, Henrietta Adelaide, Luella Belle, Justin, Frederic (Fred) Wallace, Elizabeth Medora, and Harlan Page. Andrew Jr. sold his shop in 1853 to the association of Emerson and Richards, and moved to Wisconsin in 1854, when Pettigrew was six. Then, to please his neighbors, who suffocated with his anti-slavery feelings, he circulated there an abundance of anti-slavery literature. But the store was boycotted by the angry pro-slavers, who threatened the Pettigrew family with violence.

ATHLETICS Carole Louise Quinton (born 11 July 1936) is a former British female track and field athlete who won silver medals at the 1958 British Empire and British Home Championships, the 1958 European Athletics Championships, and the 1960 Summer Olympic Games. She competed for Great Britain at the Summer Olympic games in 1956. She was not originally included in the British team but was chosen to replace Pam Elliot who withdrew due to pregnancy. At the 1958 British Empire and British Empire and British Empire and British Empire and British Empire games she was second to Norma Thrower. Both Quinton and Thrower ran 10.7 seconds, which beat the previous record of 10.8 seconds, but because of the wind was not classed as a record. The following year she was part of the British team that finished second in the four hundred metre relay at the European Championships in Aix-les-Bains, France. She was also in the Great Britain team that competed in the 1959 Great Britain versus West Germany athletics match at White City in London. She finished second in the eighty metre hurdles.

Batfoot, stylized as BATFOOT!, is a pop punk and punk rock band from Sydney, Australia. The band was formed in 2008 and consists of members Craig Hughes, Justin MacLoughlin, James Campbell and Lucas Woods. Heavily influenced by punk rockers Teenage Bottlerocket, Screeching Weasel, The Queers and Chicx Digget, as well as The Ramones, the band describes many of its songs as "Rammocore". Bands Batfoot has played with include Teenage Bottlerocket, The Tenants, No Fun At All, The Flatliners, Strike Anywhere, Magic Dirt, Rehab For Quitters, Guttermouth, The Dickies, The Adolescents, Me First And The Gimme Gimmes, C.J. Ramone and The Hard-Ons. The band has been featured on Triple J, and the now defunct Rest Assured webzine referred to Batfoot as "the kings of Australian leather-clad punk rock".

Fiskerton-cum-Morton is a civil parish in the district of Newark and Sherwood, in the county of Nottinghamshire, England. It lies on the south-east border of the county. The parish has about 900 inhabitants. It is situated about 110 miles to the north of London, 12 miles north-east of Nottingham, 5 miles west of Newark-on-Trent and 412 south-east of Southwell. The parish lies on the river Trent, and is largely a suburban area, serving Nottingham and Newark. The name Morton appears in the Domesday Book, 1086, with the spelling Mortune, meaning a farm on the morass, and it became Moreton. Fiskerton owed its origin to the abundance of fish in the rivers, and was so called, adding the Saxon word for fish, fishere, and the suffix tun, and therefore meaning a fisher’s farm. It appears in the Domesday Book as Fiscartune, and afterwards as Fiscartun. The parish of Fiskerton-cum-Morton was created in 1884, by the union of two separate parishes.

Ancient Greek medicine was a system of theories and practices, which were always evolving, with the aid of new ideas and discoveries. The spiritual was assimilated with the material, and they considered in health the humors, the position, the diet, the position, the shocks, the thoughts, the doctrines. Early Greeks believed that illnesses were divine punishments and that cures were gifts of the gods. As the experiments continued, in which theories were applied to symptoms and results, the doctrines of the pure spiritual, of these punishments and gifts, were replaced by those of a physical foundation, a principle of cause and effect. Humorism (or the four humors) is composed of blood, phlegm, yellow bile and black bile. Each of the four humors was related to an organ, a temperament, a season, and an element. It was also thought that sex was an important factor, since there were some illnesses and remedies that were not appropriate for women. Also, the situation and the social position of the people determined the way of life and the way of life of the people; the conditions of their daily life, as for example the humidity, the mosquitoes, the rats, the lack of pure water, were considered. They also considered diet to be an important factor, since the food was not considered to be sufficient, and they looked at the shocks and other accidents, such as bites from dogs or other accidents. Besides these, the beliefs and thoughts of the patient were of considerable importance in the doctrines of diagnosis and treatment. They realized that the mind was a part of healing, or that it was the cause of the disease.

Maharashtra Day is also called Maharashtra Din. Maharashtra Day is celebrated in Maharashtra, as the official holiday, on the first of May every year. Maharashtra Day is a state holiday, in Maharashtra, commemorating the formation of the state of Maharashtra from the erstwhile Bombay state on May 1, 1960. The States Reorganisation Act, 1956, laid down the boundaries of the states of India on the basis of the languages spoken in those states. The Bombay state, which was created after the enactment of the States Reorganization Act, was, however, composed of areas where people spoke different languages: Marathi, Gujarati, Kutchi and Konkani. The Sanyukta Maharashtra Samiti favored the creation of two states, one of which would consist of Gujarati and Kutchi speaking areas, the other where people spoke Marathi and Konkani.

Upon receiving the official correspondence from the Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Minister endorsed the draft treaty confirming the independence of China and welcomed it, as he did that of other African countries. He had been a diplomat at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Botswana and had spent four years working for the independence of the country. The Government of Botswana follows the policy of One China, and has no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan). After the Sichuan earthquake of 2008, the Government of Botswana donated P1,000,000 to the Chinese people. Since the Eighties, Botswana has been the first country to develop economic relations with China. In 2008, the total amount of trade between China and Botswana was almost P3 billion, and from January to October 2009, the amount was P193,840,000, despite the international financial crisis of 2008. In February 2009, Chinese officials came to Botswana to discuss the expansion of economic relations. At the same time, they also said that China was becoming a major buyer of Botswana's diamonds, and other large economies were falling in demand for diamonds.

Hazardous Mutation is the second album by the American cross-over thrash band Municipal Waste, and their first album for Earache Records. The central theme of the album is based around a party with zombies, monsters and ghouls and the lyrics are quite funny and violent. This was the first album produced by Nick Poulos. Hazardous Mutation was released in a special edition with a bonus live DVD. After the release of their debut album Waste ‘Em All!, Municipal Waste, whose name is taken from a garbage truck, were dubbed “Party Thrashers.” On the Hazardous Mutation bonus DVD, the band were asked about this. “We don’t really thrash, but we do like to party,” said bassist and vocalist Ryan Waste. “Someone else combined the two.” Also on the bonus DVD, the band were asked about their thrashy style, and what they brought to the genre, in a new way. “We’re trying to rejuvenate the scene,” said guitarist Garret “Tank” Smith. “We’re taking things bands did in six-minute songs and fitting them into two.”

Don Pedro Island is a barrier island in southwest Florida, in Charlotte County. It is located just north of Little Gasparilla Island, with which it is separated by a narrow strip of sand and mangrove swamps, and west of the designated locality of Rotonda West, which is separated from it by a narrow strait. Don Pedro Island is one of a group of islands that includes Little Gasparilla Island, Knight Island, and Thornton Key, which are collectively known as the Isles of Palm Island after the resort located on the northernmost island in the group. These islands were originally separated by narrow channels that led from the Gulf of Mexico to the Intracoastal Waterway, which separates them from the mainland. These channels have since closed off as a result of beach replenishment, and a single strip of beach now connects them. This island cluster, which looks like a single island now, is separated from the Stump Pass Beach State Recreation Area to the north by Stump Pass. To the west, it faces the Gulf of Mexico. Don Pedro Island State Park is located on the island. There is no bridge to the island; it is only accessible by boat or car ferry. There are many private residences on the island, and most of the island is occupied by the Palm Island resort. There is only one restaurant on Don Pedro Island, the Rum Bay Restaurant, which is located on the north end of the island. The only small general store on the island is located on the ground floor of the Rum Bay Restaurant.

Automobile Internet is the term used for the Internet in a car. The connection is usually via tethering to a mobile phone or via a mobile hotspot that can be built into or carried by the car. Among those which have been built into cars are: General Motors OnStar, which is a subscription-based communication service which offers telecommunication, security, a free number of telephone services, a navigation system, and an automatic diagnostic system. BMW Assist, which is a telematics system that helps the car find help if it gets into trouble. Mercedes-Benz mbrace, which can connect the car to a smart phone or a personal computer. The data subscription-based system Cadillac CUE. Ford Sync, which can be connected to a personal computer via the O2 network. The Chrysler Uconnect Web, which has a hotspot with a range of up to 150 feet via the 3G EV-DO network of Autonet. The hotspot includes Bluetooth for cell phones, a hard drive, Sirius XM satellite radio, and GPS. It is a subscription-based service, which is free for the first year. The Toyota Safety Connect, a telematics system introduced in 2009, which provides telecommunication, assistance, safety, remote diagnostics, and other services. On the Entune system, it is integrated with the Entune App. On the Lexus, it is part of the Enform system, which adds telecommunications and destination services. The subscription is free for the first year, after which it can be renewed annually. The dangers of connecting a car to a cellular network are that it may expose the vehicle's control system to hacking.

Dissolving the text, I read, “Secretary-General, the purpose of the discussion was to examine the present state of the world as a whole. By what natural law does it follow that if we could not change ourselves for the better, then we must change our environment in which we live.” Then I read on, “We must consider that which determines our environment for us. This is the most natural of laws, namely, the principle of least resistance. The challenge is to realize that it is not within ourselves, but the environment that we live in, which determines us. Having passed the examinations, a certain person is able to achieve certain results. For instance, if a man is to live without hard work, his body, the very thing that made him, will start to deteriorate in a short time. “A certain element in the body can be restored only by an effort. This is the principle of least resistance.” At the end of the reading, the room was silent. Immediately afterwards a woman, a black female student, walked up to me and said, “Mr. Chairman, I am here to inform you that I am a student at the University of Georgia, where I am pursuing my studies under the sponsorship of the IBM Corporation, and my name is Barbara Bell.

The “Jinzhong Forum on Literature and Art” was held in May 1942 in the city of Yan’an in China, and was an important event in the Yan’an Rectification Movement. It was most notable for the speech delivered by Mao Zedong, which was subsequently compiled and published as ‘Talks on the Jingxing Forum on Literature and Art’, with its two main points being that all art should be based on the life of the proletariat and serve them as its audience, and that art should serve politics and its aim of promoting socialism. The former of these points was excessively emphasized in the Cultural Revolution, so the current party policy is to reject it while continuing to support art based on the life of the proletariat. Before that time, the art organized by the C.P.P., such as the People’s Anti-Japanese Art Society, had mainly had the purpose of expressing resistance to Japan, as in “Resisting the Japanese” and “Fight the Japanese”. The Party had also established in 1938 the Lu Xun Academy of Art in Yan’an in order to train people in literature, music, fine arts and theatre.

Kirk Alan MacLean (born 26 June 1966) is a former Canadian professional hockey goaltender who played in the National Hockey League (NHL) for the New Jersey Devils, the Vancouver Canucks, the Carolina Hurricanes, the Florida Panthers and the New York Rangers. He played as a “standing goalie”. He was drafted in the sixth round, 107th overall, by the New Jersey Devils in the 1984 draft. The following year, he was sent to the American Hockey League (AHL) to play for the Maine Mariners, the Devils’ AHL affiliate, before being traded to the Vancouver Canucks in 1987. He is best known for his 11-year, 10-12-year career with the Canucks, when he was a finalist for the 1989 and 1992 Vezina Trophy, was chosen for two NHL All-Star games and was named to the Second All-Star Team. In 1994, he led the Canucks to the seventh game of the Stanley Cup finals against the New York Rangers. In the spring of 1998, he was traded, spending his last three seasons with the Carolina Hurricanes, the Florida Panthers and the New York Rangers, before retiring in 2001.

Dan Lavery (born June 11, 1969) is an American professional musician who was nominated for two Grammy awards as a member of the group Tonic. Lavery joined Tonic after recording the album Lemon Parade and has remained with Tonic since. When Tonic broke up in 2004, Lavery turned his attention to songwriting for film, including songs for the film The Passion of Christ. Lavery began to play bass for the group The Fray in 2007. Lavery is currently working on a studio album with his Tonic bandmates, which will be released in 2010. While attending college, Lavery and the other members of the group True (except for bassist Dave Nitti) went to Los Angeles in the hope of becoming professional musicians. They were discovered by Paul Rothchild, who managed The Doors. True was short-lived and dissolved. Paul Rothchild's son, Dan, was the bassist for Tonic at the time, and after Dan left the group in the mid-1990s, Tonic's Emerson Hart asked Lavery to replace him.

Mzilikazi High School, also known in the local Ndebele language as eMgandane, is a government school of the first tier, also known as the academic stream. It is situated in Bulawayo, on Old Falls Road, which is a route that was formerly used to link Bulawayo with the Victoria Falls. It is situated in the Greenspan suburb of Bulawayo, between the cemetery and Mzilikazi township. Mzilikazi High School is in turn linked to a chain of schools named after the great kings of the Ndebele Kingdom. These schools were, amongst others, named after Mzilikazi himself, his son, Lobhengula, his wife, Princess Lozikeyi, and others, such as the first chief, Chief Lo. As such, some of the most notable primary schools that feed Mzilikazi High School include Mzilikazi Primary School, Lobhengula Primary School, Chief Lo Primary School, Lobhengula High School, Lozikeyi Primary School, and St Patrick’s and St Columbus Primary Schools.

In the month of February 1965, Sandie, the first album by Sandie Shaw, was released on Pye, and although it was the first album to appear on the British album chart, it only managed to reach No. 3. Two hit singles of the period were sung by the album, namely "Always Something There to Remind Me," written by Bacharach and David, and "Girl, Don't Come Here." Andres Andrews, who was in charge of writing for Sandie, contributed four new compositions to her first album, later to be released as an EP under the title "Talk About Love". The remaining eight songs on Sandie were interpretations of the songs of other artists. Sandie was eventually reissued on RPM in the nineties, in a double pack with Me, the second album. The reissue of Me and Sandie, in September 2005, was released by EMI, and included French versions of two Andrews compositions.

WDAE (620 kHz AM) is a commercial radio station licensed to St. Petersburg, Florida, and serving the greater Tampa Bay area. WDAE is one of the oldest radio stations still operating in Florida. It began broadcasting in 1922. The studios and offices are located on West Gandy Boulevard in South Tampa. The transmitter is located in St. Petersburg near the Gandy Bridge. The station is licensed to broadcast with 5,500 watts during the day and 5,600 watts at night. 620 AM is a regional broadcast band, but since 620 is also used by strong stations in Cuba, the Federal Communications Commission has authorized WDAE to operate with higher power, 11,280 watts day and 10,100 watts night. The station has a directional antenna for night use. Daytime broadcasts are in iBiquity Digital, and a translator on 95.3 FM, W237CW, as well as a digital subchannel of sister station WBTP-HD3 (95.7 MHz).

Michael Arthur Sayman (born August 24, 1996), is a Peruvian-Bolivian-American mobile applications entrepreneur, a political activist, a software engineer and an author, known especially for the entrepreneurship he developed at the age of eighteen in order to provide for his family in the great crisis, and for his subsequent work at Facebook. Semana magazine called him "the most influential Latino in Silicon Valley"; he was included in the 2019 list of 30 under 30 by Forbes and featured in TED Talks. Sayman published his first application for iOS when he was thirteen years old, and, when in the tenth grade, the turn-based photograph game FourSnap got Mark Zuckerberg's attention. Later, he was hired by him and, at the age of eighteen, was chosen to be the "teen in residence" at Facebook and collaborated in the creation of the Stories for Instagram. His success with mobile applications has grown as he has grown up, bringing him millions of dollars as a high school student. At the age of eighteen, CNET magazine named him one of the twenty most influential Latinos in the field of technology.

Varza was born in Palo Alto, California, in a Zoroastrian family, and grew up in the American state of California. Varza, born in 1985, is the director of Station F, the large entrepreneurship hub in Paris, where she is regarded as one of the most influential personalities in the French start-up community. She has been referred to in the French press as the “young queen of start-ups,” the “queen of tech,” and “the new pope of high-tech and start-ups in France.” Her parents emigrated from Iran during the Islamic Revolution of 1979. Varza studied French at the University of California, Los Angeles, where she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 2007. She joined the French Investement Promotion Agency in 2009. Varza decided to continue her studies in France. From 2009 to 2011 she was a double-degree student at Sciences Po and the London School of Economics, where she obtained a master’s degree in international business and a degree in international economic policy.

Albrecht Dürer (; ; ; May 21 to April 6, 1528) was a German painter, engraver, and theoretician of the German Renaissance. Born in Nuremberg, he was famous throughout Europe during his youth for his high-quality woodcuts, and he was in contact with all the leading Italian painters of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Leonardo da Vinci, and from 1512 on was in the service of the Emperor Maximilian. Besides woodcuts, he also made engraved prints, was connected with the greatest Italian artists of his day, Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Leonardo da Vinci, and was one of the most important members of the Emperor Maximilian's court. His woodcuts are more Gothic than the rest of his work; his famous engravings include the three "masterpieces": Knight, Death and Devil (1491), Saint Jerome in his study (1514), and Melencholy I (1514). His watercolors make him one of the first European landscape painters, while his woodcuts opened up a new world of possibilities for the art of the picture.

Motocross Championship is a racing game developed by Artech for the 32X in 1995. The goal of the game is to ride a motocross on twelve different tracks while attacking the other riders. Motocross Championship has been given a mixed to negative review, with critics pointing out many aspects of the game. Some critics have claimed that the quality of the game is detrimental to the 32X. The game is based on the motocross sport. Races are played from behind the rider, who can be hit or kicked while passing by. The player races against 11 other riders in each game. There are twelve tracks in the game, each with obstacles. Like motocross, the track is filled with hills, so the rider jounces and slides. The rider can also perform some tricks, such as a wheelie, a bend over the handlebars, a sliding curve, and an acrobatic jump. The player can choose from three types of vehicles to drive. There are also two player and one-player modes, as well as a single-player season mode that contains 36 races. The season mode uses a password to save progress.

Gifford Pinchot, the third, was born in Boston, Massachusetts, December 29, 1942, and is an American businessman, author, and inventor, who is president of Pinchot & Company, Inc. of Tarrytown, New York. The first book of Gifford and Elizabeth Pinchot, titled Intrapreneuring: Why You Don't Have to Leave the Company to Be an Entrepreneur, appeared in 1985, and was said to be "a great influence in the business world." The company he owns with his wife, Elizabeth S. Pinchot, serves half of the Fortune 100 companies and has helped to launch more than 800 new products and businesses. The company provides live and virtual training in intrapreneurship, both for intrapreneurs and for their leaders, as well as consulting services on the systems and culture that support intrapreneurship.

The China-Japan Friendship Hospital, also known as the China-Japan Hospital, was established under the sponsorship of the Chinese and Japanese governments in the early 1980s, and was directly under the supervision of the Ministry of Health since its inception on 23 October 1984. It is located on Yinghuamen Street in the Chaoyang District, Beijing. The hospital covers an area of 2,000 mu and has a total area of 200,000 mu. It has 1,500 beds, 58 departments, and a clinical research and teaching center. It is mainly for the treatment of serious illnesses and has the qualifications of an acupuncture hospital and a Japanese hospital. The hospital is also a major hospital for the treatment of leaders from more than 100 countries and regions. It is also a clinical hospital for the medical school of Beijing University, the Chinese Medical University, and the Tianjin Medical University. The hospital carries out medical treatment, medical education, medical research, health care, and rehabilitation.

Alisha Farrer (born 19 October 1993) is an Australian film actress, television actress and model of Indian origin. While still a college student, Farrer had a number of modelling jobs. She later did a number of advertisements and appeared in the Miss India Australia competition. She has acted in a number of Bollywood films. Her first role in a film was in the romantic drama Love games in 2016. She later gained popularity on the reality show Splitsvilla and finished as a semi-finalist. She received critical acclaim for her role as Lubna in the comedy Hotel BeautiFull (2017), directed by Sameer Iqbal Patel. She is currently filming for her upcoming film M.O.H., directed by Rajesh Rathi. Farrer was born in Western Australia on 19 October 1993 to an Indian-born father and an Australian-born mother. She was brought up in Beechboro, Western Australia and finished her high school studies at the Hampton Senior High School. After she graduated in 2010, Farrer's parents encouraged her to work in modeling. Besides modeling, she also worked as a makeup artist and started her own makeup business, Farrer Beauty, in Perth. She then signed a contract with a top modeling agency, Scene Model Management. She was immediately offered offers for modeling for clothing brands and advertisements. She also walked the ramp for a number of shows and designers like Rocky Bay, Models of the Future, Manish Malhotra and Manish. She was also a finalist at the Miss India Australia, and represented the city of Perth. Farrer was critically acclaimed for her role as Lubna in the comedy Hotel Beautyfull (2017), directed by Sameer Iqbal Patel.

In his day he was respected as a historian and collector, a botanist and writer of occasional articles. He is best known as one of the first Abolitionists and the author of The Butterfly’s Ball, and The Grasshopper’s Feast. Early Life. Born in Liverpool where his father, a market gardener, kept a beerhouse called The Bowling Green at Mount Pleasant, Roscoe was withdrawn from the school he was attending at the age of twelve, after he had finished all the knowledge his master could impart. He helped his father in the garden, but spent his leisure in reading and study. This he said later: “This mode of life gave me strength and health in my body, amusement and education in my mind. I recall the delightful sleep I had after an early morning’s labour and the awakening of my earlish rising. If I am asked what sort of people are the happiest on earth I will answer those who till the soil with their own hands.” He worked as a bookseller for a month but gave it up, and entered a solicitor’s office. He was a diligent student of law, but kept up his classical studies and began to cultivate his great love, Italian literature.

Anil Nerode, born in 1932, is an American mathematician. He studied at the University of Chicago, graduating in mathematics under the supervision of Saunders Mac Lane. His doctoral thesis is on the abstraction of the substitution in a several-sorted free algebra and its relations to the equational definition of partial recursive functions. In 1954 he began work at Professor Walter Bartky's Air Weapons Institute, which deals with secret work for the Air Force, and he continued to work there after the end of his doctorate, until the end of 1956. In the summer of 1957 he attended the summer school of the National Science Foundation at the University of Chicago. From 1958 to 1959 he was a researcher at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, where he worked with Kurt Gödel. He also took a postdoctoral course at the University of California at Berkeley.

Zigmas Zinkevicius (born 4 January 1925 in Juodauciai, Ukmerg district, died 20 February 2018 in Vilnius) was a linguist and scholar of Lithuanian origin, professor at Vilnius University and a member of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences. He was the author of many studies in the history of Lithuanian language, onomastics and other linguistic fields. He was a recipient of the Herder prize, awarded to him in 1994. Zinkevicius wrote thirty monographs and several hundred scientific papers in various languages. He graduated from Ukmerg secondary school in 1945 and entered Vilnius University, where he studied linguistics until 1950. In 1955 he defended his thesis "Historical features of the genitive pronouns of the Lithuanian language" and was granted a doctoral degree. From 1956 to 1962 he was dean of the Faculty of History and Philology at Vilnius University. With colleagues, he worked out a new classification of Lithuanian dialects. He defended his work Lietuvos dialektologija in 1966, and received his doctorate of humanities two years later. In 1973 he received a new position at Vilnius University, he was the chairman of the Lithuanian department, and in 1988 he was the chairman of the Baltic department.
sampled: Xie et al. — The method of thalamus extraction is very important for studying the brain disorders and revealing the functional organization of the brain. In this paper, a new multi-contrast magnetic resonance method for thalamus extraction is presented. The method combines the information from T1 and T2 MRIs and diffusion tensor images and uses the complementary information from them. Deep learning framework combining convolutional neural network and recurrent neural network is presented for accurate and robust thalamus extraction. Experiments on a large dataset show the effectiveness of the proposed method in comparing with the previous ones and the importance of using multi-contrast MRIs for thalamus extraction.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is a scientific paper that introduces a new method of cutting graphs based on the power law distribution. This paper presents a new way of cutting a graph, which uses the power-law distribution of real networks. The paper shows that this method can deal efficiently with large graphs, and the method also shows that it outperforms other methods in terms of both runtime and solution quality. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis and experimental results to prove the efficiency of the proposed method. The paper Power-Law Graph Cuts makes a valuable contribution to the field of graph cutting, and provides a useful solution for the application of network analysis and optimization.

This paper presents a new approach to automatic 3D biventricular segmentation of cardiac images based on a shape-refined deep learning method. The proposed method uses a convolutional neural network in combination with a shape refinement method to precisely segment the left and right ventricles in cardiac images. The convolutional neural network is trained on a large set of annotated cardiac images to learn the spatial and contextual information needed for accurate segmentation. The shape refinement method then refines the initial segmentation by incorporating shape priors and enforces smoothness constraints. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness. This method can potentially assist the diagnosis and treatment of cardiac diseases by providing reliable, accurate biventricular segmentations of cardiac images.

This article deals with the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. A full analysis is given of the various curvature tensors which can be defined on such manifolds, such as the Ricci curvature tensor, the scalar curvature tensor and the Weyl curvature tensor. The relations between these tensors and their properties are studied. A few examples and applications of these tensors on Hermitian manifolds are presented. In conclusion, the article gives a better understanding of the geometrical properties of Hermitian manifolds and is a starting point for future research in this area.

This paper presents a novel method for fusing localization and segmentation of objects in images and videos by the concept of clustering. The method first generates candidate segmentations from a convolutional neural network, which have been previously trained, and then uses the foreground clustering technique to group the proposals into coherent foreground objects. The clustering technique combines the appearance and motion information of foreground objects to detect the coherence of foreground objects in space and time. The experimental results show that the proposed method is very effective for segmenting and localizing foreground objects in images and videos. It is also very suitable for the following computer vision tasks: video object segmentation, object tracking, and scene understanding.

Here we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for thalamic segmentation. The fusion is performed using a 3D convolutional neural network. This network is trained on a large set of segmented thalamus from different MRI contrasts. The model is then tested on a separate test set, and the results indicate that the method can reliably segment the thalamus. The thalamus can then be used for other analyses such as network analysis. We are also presenting a comparison with other methods. WIREs Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery, 6:e17001, pp. 1–13. The thalamus is a major brain structure which is involved in all types of incoming and outgoing communication with the brain. MRI is a useful tool for studying the thalamus and other brain structures. Here, we are presenting a multi-contrast MRI method for thalamic segmentation, based on the fusion of T1 and T2 and DTI scans, using a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN). The network is trained on a large set of segmented thalami from different MRI scans. The model is then tested on a separate test set, and the results indicate that the method can reliably segment the thalamus.

We introduce a new formulation of the reconstruction of a conductivity distribution inside a uniformly conductive, opaque, periodic sample from the measurement of the electric field at the sample surface. The classic reconstruction of E-M is based on the Kirchhoff approximation, where the conductivity is expressed as a finite set of values and the inverse problem is solved as a non-linear optimization problem. Unlike the classic approach, which fails when the discretized conductivity imposes a significant distortion on the internal electric field, we show that the convex-constrained power-law graph cuts, a new convex optimization technique, can recover the true conductivity distribution quite accurately even in the presence of significant distortion.

We introduce a novel approach to the study of the formation of agglomerates of polymers based on the statistical mechanics of a large number of mutually interpenetrating forces. We formulate a generalized master equation describing the evolution of the conformational space of the polymer over time, which we then use to deduce a set of self-consistent equations governing the equilibrium properties of the system. Our method enables us to study the effects of different types of interaction and to determine the conditions under which the formation of the agglomerate occurs. We find that the formation of the agglomerate is a multistep process, with the initial stages of formation controlled by the local interactions between the constituent parts, while the subsequent stages of formation are governed by global properties of the system, such as the total number of constituent parts and the average size of the aggregate. Our method provides a quantitative understanding of the process of aggregation and can be used to predict the effects of different types of interactions on the aggregation process.

In this short paper, we compute the curvature tensors of a Hermitian manifold endowed with a certain type of contact structure. This extends a recent result of P. Bagniaz and M. Cahen who studied the case of an almost Hermitian structure.

We present a new method for combining object segmentation and localization in images and videos. Our method exploits the spatial coherence of objects in images and frames to optimize the segments and the boxes simultaneously. To do this, we introduce a new energy function that tightly couples the segmentation term, which is based on a variant of the GrabCut algorithm, and the localization term, which is based on a new objectness measure that we introduce. To efficiently optimize the energy function, we propose a new foreground clustering strategy that allows us to handle the sparse and irregular object pixel assignments, and simultaneously optimize the segments and the boxes. To evaluate our method, we propose a new fully automatic evaluation measure that estimates the accuracy of localization in terms of ground truth object bounding boxes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art results on the VOC 2012 object segmentation test set, substantially improving on the previous best method on this test set, while running at near-real-time speed. In addition, we show that our foreground clustering strategy can improve the performance of recent methods for combining object segmentation and localization. This makes our method a strong foundation for future research.

The abstract of the academic paper Semantic-guided encoder feature learning for blurry boundary delineation would be: The paper proposes a novel method for blurry boundary delineation by using semantic-guided encoder feature learning. The extraction of boundaries from blurred images is a challenging problem due to the lack of clear edge information. Our method aims to utilize the power of semantic information to learn encoder features that can capture the subtle detail of blurred images. Combining the advantages of encoders and semantic-guided feature learning, we obtain the best performance in the literature for blurry boundary delineation. We evaluated our method on a standard dataset and obtained significant improvements compared to existing methods. We also showed that our method is robust to noise and variation of texture, and can obtain accurate and reliable boundaries in blurred images.

This paper aims to explore the concept of quantum objectivity, mainly with respect to observation. It is assumed that a quantum system has no properties until it is observed, and that the act of observation is not passive, but rather an active process that influences the results of the measurements. The paper tries to draw the consequences of these ideas for the concept of objectivity in the quantum world and suggests that objectivity in the quantum world is not as simple as in classical physics. Also discussed is the idea that quantum objectivity may be dependent on the observer’s state of mind and that the observer’s expectations and beliefs may influence the results of the measurements. The paper concludes that the concept of quantum objectivity may be more complex and multiple than previously assumed and that further research is necessary to fully understand it.

The LeViT-UNet method encodes images faster and better than other encoders for medical images. Previously, the encoders were designed with a series of convolutional and pooling layers, and the resulting model was redundant, and the processing was largely inefficient. This method takes the LeViT concept introduced by Johnson et al. and combines the advantages of the Transformer model with the efficient encoder. It is faster than other encoders, and its performance in medical image segmentation is comparable to that of other encoders. The code and related materials are available at:

I propose an active contour method for image segmentation which is based on the diffuse interface theory of phase transitions. The active contour in the image is treated as a diffuse interface between two phases. The propagation of this diffuse interface is governed by a set of partial differential equations (PDEs) derived from the diffuse interface theory. In the physical model of the active contour, the energy function of the active contour model is expressed in terms of the form of a Hamiltonian, and the evolution of the active contour can be found by solving the system of PDEs governed by the Hamiltonian. An efficient level-set method is proposed for solving the proposed model. The method is tested on several images. It is found that it is effective and efficient in the task of image segmentation.

ANOTHER way of classifying the objects is to work with the plane figures which are represented by the straight lines. It is easy to use the plane figures for the purposes of the recognition, but to classify them based on their reciprocal relationships, with the help of the Markov random field (MRF). The Markov random field is a mathematical device which is able to carry out operations which the other methods of classification are unable to do. The advantages of this method are: The Markov random field enables the individual objects to be combined and compared with one another in different ways, which are impossible with the other methods. Our method uses the polarization of the SAR images to obtain additional information for the purposes of the classification. The 3D DWT is used to extract the multiscale and multiorientational features from the polarimetric SAR image, and the Markov random field is used to model the spatial dependencies between the pixels and refine the results of the classification. Our results have been tested on the publicly available dataset and compared with other methods. The results have proved that our method achieves a significant improvement in the accuracy of the classification.

We introduce a method of segmenting images into regions, which we then use to improve the performance of other methods for image classification. We apply this method to various kinds of images, with high resolution in the horizontal dimension (as in satellite images), with a low resolution in the vertical dimension (as in still images), and with a combination of both. Our method is able to be applied to a large variety of images, with a high resolution in the vertical dimension (as in satellite images), a low resolution in the horizontal dimension (as in still images), and with a mixture of both.

This paper deals with the method of supermodular functions extended by slack and margin resizing, two useful methods for improving the performance of a linear algebra program. In particular, it shows that the method can be combined with other methods such as gradient descent, which achieves a higher convergence rate on certain practical problems. The results of this method are comparable with the results of the other methods, but it also has some advantages over them. First, it does not require special knowledge of the problem, and second, it can be used for the same problem. Third, it provides a simple way to implement the margin resizing method without a library. Finally, it is shown that the method has a good generality that can be applied to problems with different inputs.

The problem posed here (the mapping of non-zero, n-dimensional real numbers into words) is quite different from most other common machine-learning problems. We could ask, for example, whether there is a mathematical representation of semantic relations that allows us to obtain a more precise picture of the semantic relationships among the objects of a language than can be obtained by other methods. Many efforts have been made to carry out linguistic analysis on data of the kind we propose. They usually involve searching large data bases with a combination of iterative and search methods such as linear models or tree-based methods (such as progressive or tree-progressive hybrids). In general, the structures extracted by these methods are quite context-dependent. The context cannot be captured by a mere distribution of word meanings, unless it includes a symbolic representation of the entire distribution of human behavior, be it in terms of things or of ideas (or both, depending on the context), such that the system itself would also reflect this representation. This approach is not only extremely complex, but also slow, since a large number of instances collected under varied conditions are needed to perform significant analysis. It should be noted that while our goal here is to obtain evaluations, this idea could be used for similar tasks of a somewhat similar nature, such as learning to classify text samples, feature generation, etc. We propose here a variant of this approach—namely, a two-stage procedure using sparse matrices and two hidden layers, based on a deep neural-network representation—and then compare its performance with two of the best current implementations: SVHN and its improved variant WordNet. The proposed method combines three novel, unrelated ideas: namely, a combination of hierarchical Bayesian modeling and sparse matrices without projections. Compared with existing methods, which need to be able to retrieve the entire set of examples to be used in learning, our results imply a much faster learning process, which might be useful for speech recognition tasks where we seek both high accuracy and speedup in taggers.

The method of weighted Susan clustering for fuzzy clustering is the subject of the following study. The SUSAN clustering procedure is a generalization of the clustering procedure of the Euclidean distance. The method is based on the fact that the Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster. The Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster. The Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster. The Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster. The Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster. The Euclidean clustering procedure is a non-parametric procedure that uses a weighted sum of the distances between the clusters to find the closest cluster.

The purpose of this study was to study brain segmentation potentials during cusum scanning using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and contrast MR data in a patient cohort with hippocampal damage caused by a stroke, by using T1-weighted imaging data. Three groups of subjects, having lesions of the anterior temporal lobe at the time of the initial examination, were subjected to two different scans 50 days apart. One scan was without a scan, one with an EPI cusum-tube, and one with a whole-head CT scan with the help of an artificial brain. During both scans T1-weighted images could be acquired, which may contribute to normal tissue preservation in the case of a brain injury, and the number and location of such areas was compared between the groups with different damage in the field of their examination. The result of this study can serve as a guide to the development of cusum-tubes with a high dynamic range, low signal attenuation, low noise and small spatial volumes. The brain segments produced by the SPM2 and 3 cusum-tubes can serve as a guide to the cognitive-neurological examination, and it may be possible to determine whether certain regions can be related before the pathological damage, such as a stroke, in patients with hippocampal damage caused by cortical injury.

In this paper, we present a method for automatic thalamus segmentation in MR images by a multi-contrast approach. We use a registration and segmentation method that combines the use of T1-, T2- and T2-weighted images with atlas- and model-based approaches. We evaluate our method on a dataset of thirty subjects, and compare our results to those of a state-of-the-art method. Our results show that our method is more accurate than the state-of-the-art, and much faster.

SUMMARY: A new method for constructing cuts is presented, based on the distribution of the degree of a graph. This method finds cuts that are significantly better than those found by other methods, at the same time being significantly faster.

We develop a theoretical framework for the study of the effects of protein aggregation on the structure and thermodynamics of biological systems. Our approach is based on statistical mechanics of interacting particles, and we use it to study the formation of aggregates from proteins of different primary sequences. We find that the aggregation process is driven by the entropy of the system, and that the primary sequence of the constituent molecules plays a role in determining the size and shape of the aggregates. Also, the aggregation process is influenced by the presence of other types of molecules in the system, and the properties of the aggregates depend on the concentrations of the constituent molecules.

Here we generalize the Bochner-Weitzenbock formula for the curvature tensor of a Riemannian manifold to the case of Hermitian manifolds. We get a formula for the tensor Riem+ Ricci* * Id, where Riem is the curvature tensor and Ricci the Ricci tensor of the manifold. We also get a generalized formula for the first Chern class of a Hermitian manifold.

Recently, the study of the semantic division of images and videos has seen great progress with the help of powerful deep learning neural networks. But most of these methods can only identify a single object class in an image or a frame of a video. In this paper, we present a novel approach to the joint localization and segmentation of two or more object categories in images and videos. Our method is based on a new foreground clustering method that we call foreground-aware clustering, which can cluster foreground objects in an image or a frame of a video. In terms of their layout in the image. Then use the foreground objects to train a DNN for the task of joint localization and segmentation. We have evaluated our method on the difficult YouTube-Objects dataset, and the results are significantly better than the best joint localization and segmentation methods.

This paper presents the UNet++ architecture, which is a more advanced architecture based on the U-Net model, and it is specially designed for the segmentation of medical images. The proposed model can effectively capture the local detail and semantic information of medical images. The comprehensive experiments show that the proposed UNet++ architecture is superior to the original U-Net model on various image datasets and three kinds of tasks, that is, nucleus segmentation, liver segmentation and lung segmentation. The results show that the UNet++ architecture can be used as a new approach for medical image analysis.

This paper gives a thorough study of the mathematical basis of power law graph cuts, a new method of partitioning large graphs. It also discusses the significance of the power law distribution in graph cuts and its implication for network analysis. It also proposes an efficient method for computing power law graph cuts, and proves its effectiveness in extensive experiments on real data. The experiments demonstrate that power law graph cuts produce more meaningful and more accurate partitions than the standard method, especially for graphs with a skewed degree distribution. It opens up a new way of thinking about complex network analysis, for example in the study of social networks, the web, and biology.

This paper presents an automatic 3D cardiac image-based bi-ventricular segmentation approach based on a deep learning multi-task structure. Deep learning methods are increasingly being used in medical image analysis, where they have achieved a significant increase in efficiency and accuracy, but they have been plagued by the complex anatomical structure of the heart. The main objective of this paper is to enhance the precision and efficiency of image segmentation by developing and implementing a novel re-trained multi-tasked structure. This method, which uses sagittal, axial and sagittal planes simultaneously, takes advantage of local contextual information for better estimation, and also uses a shape refinement method for even greater precision. Through a deep analysis of the proposed method on various datasets, the superior performance of the proposed method is compared with that of previous methods. This robust method can substantially increase the trustworthiness and accuracy of the diagnosis and treatment of cardiac diseases.

This work treats in depth of the properties and functions of curvature tensors with reference to Hermitian manifolds. The relations between the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds and some standard differential geometric objects are carefully outlined. The notation and terminology relating to curvature tensors used in complex differential geometry, with particular reference to Hermitian manifolds, are discussed. The pertinent properties and applications of the curvature of Hermitian manifolds are also considered, with particular reference to theoretical physics and complex geometry. The results obtained by this study can be viewed as an expansion of the literature on the subject and as a new insight into the nature of the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds.

RA-UNet, a new hybrid deep attention-aware network, was developed to detect liver and tumors in radiographs. The proposed model combines the advantages of the U-Net architecture with the residual attention mechanism to enhance the feature representation and focus on the goal regions. The RA-UNet model was tested on the publicly available data set, showing superior performance in terms of accuracy, sensitivity, and Dice coefficient compared to other state-of-the-art methods. The RA-UNet model could be an effective tool for automatically and accurately detecting the liver and tumor regions, which could potentially improve the efficiency and accuracy of cancer diagnosis and treatment planning.

We present an analytic approach to the problem of matroid representability, a fundamental problem in combinatorics and algebraic geometry. Our approach is based on the study of k-independence of finite sets of vectors. We show a novel connection between the problem of matroid representability and the maximum distance separability problem. We prove a lower bound on the size of such sets and use this to establish new results on matroid representability. In particular, we prove that a matroid which can be represented over a finite field can also be represented over a sufficiently large finite field with a bounded number of elements. This result has important consequences for the study of matroids and their representations, and it gives a new perspective on the maximum distance separability problem. Using this analytic approach, we also study the behaviour of k-independence of finite sets of vectors as the size of the field increases. We show that the cardinality of such sets behaves in a surprisingly simple way which is closely related to the maximum distance separability conjecture, which gives new support to this conjecture and shows the power of the analytic approach to the problem of matroid representability. In this paper, we have developed a new perspective on the problems of matroid representability and maximum distance separability, and established a new analytic framework for further work in these areas.

Clockwork convolutional neural networks are designed for the classification of videos and not for the classification of still images. They can take advantage of the temporal structure of the image, and be a much more efficient method of obtaining good results than convolutional neural networks. The outputs of the convolutional neural networks are then combined into a single segmentation mask, and the process is repeated for multiple frames, thus capturing the short-term and long-term temporal dependencies of the images in the video. The framework is evaluated on the cityscape, Pascal VOC, and Cocoa datasets, and significant improvements in segmentation accuracy are demonstrated. We also carry out a series of ablation experiments to investigate the effectiveness of different components of our framework and show that both the parallel and hierarchical processing of the frames contributes to improved performance. The main contributions of the paper are: The first is the proposed clockwork convolutional neural network. The second is the ablation experiment which demonstrates the effectiveness of the method. The third is the method of extracting information from the frames.

The results of this study show that three-dimensional shape segmentation by means of a convolutional network of shapes of a simpler structure than the convolutional network of a convolutional net, is a method of obtaining data from raw data in a more convenient way. Our method uses the neural net for shape analysis, a three-dimensional convolutional net, a method that is fast, because it does not use the convolutional net, and this method yields three-dimensional shapes which are more precise and efficient than those obtained by the method of CFS or by means of the classical methods of vision. The proposed method uses a multi-scale method, where the convolutional net is trained at several scales and local and global features are learned at the same time., allowing the accurate division of three-dimensional shapes at different levels of detail. The results of this method are verified by evaluating it on various public point clouds, and it is found that this method can successfully divide the three-dimensional shapes with high precision and speed. We also show that SH-FCNs can be used in real time for a three-dimensional shape division in various applications, such as object recognition and scene understanding. Our method can be used in various fields, such as robots, driving, and design. The speed of three-dimensional shape division from raw point clouds will allow the recognition and understanding of objects, and three-dimensional shape division will speed up the division of objects.

In this paper, we propose a novel method of semi-supervised 3D left atrium segmentation by means of an uncertainty-aware self-assembly model. Left atrial segmentation is a crucial step in many cardiac applications, such as atrial fibrillation detection and ablation plan. However, annotating the left atrium is a difficult task. The lack of sufficient labels may hamper the performance of supervised learning methods. To address this challenge, we propose a self-assembly model that combines multiple separate segmentation models to improve the accuracy and robustness of left atrial segmentation. Our method exploits the strengths of different models by aggregating their predictions and uncertainty estimates. Moreover, we introduce a novel uncertainty-aware self-assembly strategy that weights the contributions of different models based on their uncertainty in the result. We evaluate our method on a large dataset of cardiac magnetic resonance images, and compare its performance to that of the state-of-the-art semi-supervised learning methods. Our results show that our self-assembly model outperforms these methods in terms of accuracy and robustness. We also perform a series of experiments in order to examine the effectiveness of the proposed uncertainty-aware self-assembly strategy and demonstrate its superiority over the existing methods. Our method has important implications for the development of semi-supervised learning methods for medical image segmentation, particularly for left atrium segmentation. The proposed uncertainty-aware self-assembly model can also be used in other medical image segmentation tasks where annotated data is scarce, thereby improving the accuracy and robustness of the segmentation models in these settings.

We prove that if X and Y are two real or complex Banach spaces, then there exists an angle $theta$ in the interval $[0, pi$ such that any linear operator $T$ between X and Y$ can be written as $T = U + V$, where U is unitary and V has a spectral radius no greater than $sin(frac12theta 2)$. This generalizes several known results in the literature. In particular, it implies that any continuous linear operator on a Hilbert space can be decomposed into a sum of a unitary operator and a compact one.

Abstract: We present an approach based on deep learning to automatically detect pneumothoraces on chest X-rays. We use a pretrained ResNet50 on 124,739 images of the ChestXray8 dataset, which allows an accuracy of 96% on a test set of 1,000 images. This result shows that the proposed method can be useful for radiologists to quickly identify patients with a pneumothorax.

INTERPRETATION Semantic segmentation is an important task in remote sensing image processing, and aims to assign a semantic label to each pixel in the image. In this paper, a new edge loss is proposed to enhance the performance of semantic segmentation. The edge loss is used to make the model only predict the boundary of the target class. We also propose a strategy of the weight between the edge loss and the background loss. The proposed edge loss is simple and effective. It is easy to combine with the existing semantic segmentation model. The experiments on three remote sensing images show that the proposed edge loss can improve the performance of semantic segmentation. The full text of the paper is available here.

This paper presents a new method for segmenting scanning tunneling microscopy images. The method is based on the variational approach to image segmentation, and uses a new class of empirical wavelets that are derived from the local statistics of the image, and are thus designed to capture the local structure of the image. The wavelets are used to construct a variational formulation that is minimized to obtain the image segmentation. The method is applied to a set of STM images and the results are compared to those obtained by other methods. The method is shown to be effective in segmenting STM images, and to capture the local structure of the image. The paper is available here.

This academic paper gives a complete review of the experimental simulations used in the DUNE CDR. DUNE is a high-level experiment that aims to find evidence of new physics beyond the standard model of elementary particles, namely oscillation and appearance. The CDR includes various experiments and simulations of different neutrino-detector simulations, including: beamline simulation, detection response simulation and Monte Carlo simulation. These simulations allow scientists to study the sensitivity of the experiment to different events and optimize the experimental parameters for maximum performance. The paper gives an overview of the different simulation settings, their advantages and disadvantages, and their role in the DUNE CDR. In summary, this academic paper is an important contribution to the understanding of the DUNE experiment and its potential to answer fundamental questions about the nature of the universe.

Neutro-connectedness Cut is a new method for dividing a graph into separate connected components. The Neutro-connectedness Cut uses a measure of the relative connectedness of the nodes, which divides the graph into disjoint sets of highly connected nodes. The method has been proved to be very efficient and is very promising for use in the field of data mining and network analysis.

Abstract of the paper "Attention U-net: learning where to look for the pancreas": This paper proposes an attention mechanism for the U-net convolutional neural network used in medical image segmentation. The aim is to improve the performance of the U-net by adding spatial awareness and enabling the model to focus on the most relevant regions of the image. This is achieved by introducing an attention mechanism, which learns to determine the relative importance of each input feature map in the U-net encoding and decoding layers. This is achieved by predicting a weight map for each feature map, which is then used to scale the map before it is fed to the next layer. This enables the model to selectively attend to different regions of the image and adjust the weights of the input based on the relevance of each region to the task. The experiments on several data sets show significant improvements in accuracy and speed compared to the U-net without attention. The attention mechanism improves the performance of the model by enabling it to focus on the most relevant regions of the image. The attention mechanism is therefore a useful tool for medical image analysis and can be applied to many other tasks in image analysis.

In recent years, a considerable amount of interest has been taken in modifying the deep-learning models to improve the performance. But training and obtaining an efficient self-organizing method for medical image processing is a formidable task due to its size and complexity. The goal of the present paper is to propose an uncertainty-aware self-organizing model that can be applied to segment left atriums from CT volumes with the limited or defective labeling commonly encountered in clinical practice, without sacrificing robustness and efficiency. Our method combines unlabeled data with partially labeled data to learn both spatial relationships among points in the same organ and the relationships between organs. The proposed method consists of three main components: (i) a series of convolutional neural networks (NNs); (ii) a graph neural network for intermediate output processing; and (iii) a loss function which takes into account the output uncertainty and the smoothness of the outputs in order to balance high flexibility and stability. The results of experiments on two publicly available datasets show that our proposed method achieves comparable results to the best supervised methods with significantly greater robustness, efficiency, and scalability, despite limited or missing data. Furthermore, it provides additional uncertainty estimates, which can be used as a valuable clinical metric. The proposed method is thus very promising in reducing the computational cost and achieving accurate results in a practical environment where semi-supervised learning is more and more important.

These field-induced atoms, where the internal oscillations of the atoms are induced by external electric fields, have been studied in terms of structure evolution and dynamics. The studied structures were changed by pulses of electric fields with a frequency ranging from 1015 hz to 1THz, depending on the atoms in question and their state of charge. We hereby report the structure-changing observations made using X-ray diffraction under room temperature conditions, where a pulsed electric field of up to 100 kV/cm in z-z-directions was applied along the normal to the sample surface, with each pulse causing a formation of new phases, which could be identified by their diffraction patterns. We may find that it will lead us to some unexpected destination.

In this article we study the Morse-Gell-man boundaries in proper geodesic metric spaces. It is proved that they are compact. We construct an explicit example of a noncompact boundary which is not cut at infinity and also does not satisfy any of the known conditions on the asymptotic behaviour of a boundary, such as Gromov hyperbolicity or finite Hausdorff dimension. See the second theorem below, where these properties fail even though there is some point which satisfies all three of these criteria at the same time. This is evidence against the third conjecture of Minsky [3,4]. This gives rise to questions about the uniqueness of some relationships, which depend only on the time reversal symmetry, and are thus broken down completely in certain classes of manifolds, such as Lorentzian manifolds.

Some non-uniform, inhomogeneous noise is also common in practical applications. Taking this into account, a novel image-segmentation method is proposed. It is based on the KL divergence of the Finite Element Method and morphological reconstruction. The two popular image analysis methods, image regularization and wavelet decomposition, are combined. KL divergence is one of the most widely used methods of regularization because it produces the best results in many clustering problems. We use the morphological reconstruction method to smooth the original image based on a Gaussian kernel and morphological opening operations. Using the morphological wavelet decomposition, we pre-process the smoothed image, namely, the smoothed image is decomposed into a set of sub-images, each of which has a different scale, or a set of sub-images for each scale of the frequency spectrum. Then we combine the wavelet and morphological decompositions with the Finite Element Method to obtain a mask for the segmentation. According to the experimental results and analysis, the proposed method gives good results and can be used to segment various types of images.

And now we will present an estimate of the parameter of a two-region or multi-enviroment model, which are used as mathematical tools and in a very wide range of scientific fields, such as biology, ecology, and epidemiology. This method is based on Bayesian inference and Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling techniques, which allow us not only to estimate the parameter, but also to give intervals around it. This interval can be useful in comparing different experimental conditions, or in making future predictions on the basis of previous data gathered in similar conditions.

This paper describes a weakly-supervised learning approach for glioma feature localization. This approach uses a training dataset that is labelled only at the image level, thus avoiding the need for annotating the training data. It has promising results in identifying important features in glioma images, which are important for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. This research contributes to the development of automatic feature localization methods in medical image processing, which reduces the burden of annotating medical images and improves the efficiency of diagnosis and treatment.

ATTENTIONBOOST is a method which makes it possible to enhance fully-convolutional neural networks by a boosting method which iteratively refines the attention map of the network. AttentionBoost allows more efficient and precise processing of visual information, which makes it a useful tool for a number of applications in computer vision.

The paper presents a novel method for semantic segmentation using convolutional conditional random fields. It uses convolutional neural networks to extract features from the input images and integrates them with CRFs to learn the spatial dependencies between the neighboring pixels. The experimental results on the standard image datasets show that the proposed method can improve the accuracy of the current state-of-the-art.

This paper studies the properties of a class of non-split and non-intersecting paths on a grid. It gives a detailed analysis of the structure and behavior of such graphs, examining their intersections, their links, and other properties. It proposes a number of new methods for generating and manipulating these graphs, and shows that they are useful in many applications. This paper makes an important contribution to the theory of graphs and gives a new insight into the properties of complex networks.

The shepherdess and the chimney sweep is a touching fairy tale about two porcelain figurines, a shepherdess and a chimney sweep, who are spirited away from their life of captivity and into an adventure that they do not even expect. The story begins when they are placed on the mantelpiece in a cosy little cottage. As time goes by, they come to love each other, and as the days go by they dream of life beyond the chimney. One night, when the wind blows the cottage window open, the two figurines find themselves outside, free to wander. They meet a wise old dog, a mischievous cat, a wise owl, and learn lessons about love, friendship, and the importance of staying true to oneself. At every turn, they are confronted by obstacles that test their courage and resourcefulness, until they learn that they are here to make others happy. With unfailing love for each other, they find a way to return to the cottage, where they awoken their wonder at life and what it could bring them. This is a charming fairy tale that speaks to the power of love and the transformative power of adventure.

‘Irish Thoroughbred’ is the story of Adelia Cunnane, a young Irishwoman who comes to America to start a new life. She ends up working on a racehorse farm owned by the handsome and rich horse breeder, Travis Grant. In spite of their different backgrounds and personalities, they soon grow close and develop a deep affection for each other. During this time, Adelia is introduced to the world of thoroughbreds and the complexities of breeding and training them. But when the past returns to threaten them, Adelia and Travis have to face their fears and fight for their love. Against the backdrop of the beautiful Irish countryside and the vibrant world of horse racing, ‘Irish Thoroughbred’ is a compelling story of love, passion and the pursuit of dreams.

'To Live Forever' is a captivating novel, presenting a young woman obsessed with immortality, a new world in which medicine and technology have made it possible to greatly extend life expectancy. Emma, haunted by the early death of her parents, is convinced that in a life of infinity lies the supreme happiness, and she is set on finding a way to get it. Embarking on a quest to unravel the secret of immortality, she delved into ancient writings, searched for fountains of youth, and travelled to far-flung regions, in search of mythical beings reputed to have the secret of eternal life. Along the way, she encounters many people with their own beliefs and desires. Her encounters with them cause her to question her own motives and her definition of happiness. She also learns about the existence of a secret society, the Immortalists, who claim to have made a revolutionary scientific discovery which would enable its members to live forever. She decides to join this group, believing that she has finally found the key to infinity. As she enquires further into the society’s activities, however, she begins to question the ethical implications of achieving immortality.
