It said it had reached out to her to apologize for the overbooking situation. As we learn more, we will update you accordingly. "

The Scottish Football Association yesterday made the bold claim that his country can go all the way in the World Cup, provided that his players are willing to play for Ireland without fear, something that the FAI has never allowed before when selecting the team. “We can, if the Irish players are willing to get up and play for Ireland without fear,” said Togus Finnan, Assistant Secretary and a member of the Scottish FA’s Governing Body. “That’s all it takes to go to the World Cup; that’s all we lack.” We can go to the World Cup; it won’t be a problem. If we win the group and play well, we can win the tournament. We have four games left, and we can do it.” Finnan’s comments were met with a considerable round of applause from the other representatives in the room at St. James’s Park. As for who he believes will play in Brazil, he wouldn’t say. He remarked, however, that some of the others he regarded as the top Irish players were not playing because of the fear of being punished.

Japan's economy contracted in the third quarter, the government announced on Friday, due to a decline in exports and a fall in domestic demand. The economy contracted 0.2% in the third quarter of this year, which is the biggest contraction since the third quarter of 2009, when the economy contracted 0.3%. The fall was caused by a 0.2% drop in industrial production. The government forecasts the economy to grow 0.6% annually during the current fiscal year, which ends in March. This is an increase of 0.2% from its previous forecast. The government is trying to boost the economy by cutting taxes and increasing spending. The government is also hoping to raise domestic demand by increasing the consumption tax from 8% to 8%. Besides, the government wants to raise the consumption tax to 8% from 5%. That would be the biggest increase since 1997, when it raised the consumption tax from 5% to 8%. The government also wants to raise domestic demand by increasing the consumption tax to 8% from 5%. It also wants to raise domestic demand by increasing the consumption tax from 8% to 8%. The government also wants to raise domestic demand by increasing the consumption tax from 8% to 8%.

The police do not suspect any foul play, but an investigation is being conducted, the police reported late on Tuesday. Two people who were walking in Regent Street are being questioned, and a further examination will be carried out to establish the full extent of his injuries, the police said. Witnesses reported hearing two strong bangs, and two police cars arrived at the scene shortly before three o'clock in the afternoon with a man who lay unconscious on the ground where he had fallen. The victim has a small laceration and is in stable condition, the police said.

Anastasiya Isinbayeva, the first modern ballet star from Russia, has come to Britain, to a scholarship at Queen Mary's University, after a brilliant career in the Russian ballet, where she is now known by the nickname 'Istina' (meaning 'Miss').... Last year, she danced to an audience of thirty million people in the Russian winter festival where she became known by the nickname 'Istina' (Miss'). Her career as a dancer began when she fell from a horse, and her initial role was as Princess Elisabeth who fell when her sister left Prince Albert alone, and had to be rescued from the castle. The film was based on Balanchine's famous 1913 ballet, which had already won two Academy Awards... Istina declared that she "loved" British culture, like football and the shopping mall, although it took her some time to really appreciate it... During the filming of the film, Istina's mother Nadezhda Galkayeva, found out and tried to stop it, standing in front of a tank so that it would not shoot her... Eventually, she gave up the fight, and instead of killing her, they filmed the scene... Comment from the BBC:

The remuneration of the Foreign Secretary William Hague has been disclosed in the Register of Members’ Interests. This reveals that he received £90,000 for his memoirs as leader of the Conservative Party, and £64,000 for dinner speeches, and £36,000 for two articles in The Daily Telegraph. In all he received £140,000.

Illva Saronno, the Italian producer of Disaronno, has bought a majority interest in a Chinese winery, in order to benefit from the country's growing thirst for wine. The maker of the popular brand of liqueur Disaronno, for a price of twenty million lire, the company, which owns the brand, will take a majority of 51% in Great Wall Winery. The Chinese wine market, it is estimated, will grow by twenty percent this year. Illva said that it would become a leading player in the Chinese market and that, in the next three years, it would invest a further ten million lire in Great Wall. "This is a strategic investment for Illva in one of the most interesting and fastest-growing markets in the world," said Mr. Marchesini, the company's chairman. It will enable us to become a leading player in the high-quality Chinese wine sector. Great Wall, based in Shandong Province in the east of the country, currently produces ten million bottles of wine a year and sells its wine in more than twenty countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, and Japan. The transaction should be completed by the end of the year.

A MICHEL J. FOX, who has received an Oscar nomination, is now helping to fund a theater project in the Canadian town where he grew up. The Michael J. Fox Theater, with a capacity of 1,200 seats, is being planned for Burnaby, British Columbia. A child of this town, which borders on the city of Edmonton, where he was born, the film star called the theater a "great asset" to the city. "I have wonderful memories of growing up in Burnaby and attending the shows at the Burnaby High School," he said in a statement. "It would be wonderful if there were a theater in Burnaby, and it would be a great asset to the whole community." The projected costs amount to C $ 60 million (C $ 34 million) and it could be started as early as next year.

The future of ballet in England is in danger, say a group of dancers. They claim that the art is declining and that opportunities for the advancement of young talent are being neglected. In a letter to The Times, they say that England is “losing its position as a world leader in ballet.” The letter has been signed by 26 dancers, including the former principal dancer of the Royal Ballet, Tamara Rojo, and the current first soloist, Francesca Hayward. The letter says that the art is “in decline.” They claim that young dancers are being neglected, and they want the government to support ballet. The letter has been sent to the department for digital, culture, media and sport, and to Arts Council England.

Despite a drop in European Ford production of nearly a quarter, the American giant still says it will show a profit for the year. Ford Europe president Nick Scheele said the company's operating losses were "more than offset" by good results from its American finance arm. "This year we're showing a profit, and we've experienced a very large drop in production," he told the BBC. Last year Ford Europe lost $254m (£130m). "We're expecting to show a profit this year, thanks to a very strong performance from our financial division in North America." Ford's finance division has been helped by low interest rates in the US, which has meant it has been able to offer cheap loans. Ford has also benefited from the recent devaluation of the euro against the dollar. In spite of all the problems the European car industry faces, Mr Scheele is confident that Ford will maintain its market share in the region. "We will do that by continuing to develop new products, continuing to reduce our costs and continuing to invest in our brands," he said. "We think that's the right strategy, and we're beginning to see the results."

Former British Foreign Secretary William Hague has allegedly earned a six-figure income from his positions outside of Parliament, as documents leaked by a financial intermediary reveal. The documents show that Mr. Hague earned a considerable sum as a public speaker, author and consultant, in addition to the parliamentary pension he receives for his years as a member of Parliament and minister. Since 1997, the Conservative Party leader and the Foreign Secretary, he has been a key figure in British politics for several decades. Since he left the Foreign Office in 2014, he has been paid quite well in the private sector. The financial documents indicate that Mr. Hague has earned more than 800,000 pounds from his speeches alone. The Washington Speakers Bureau, which represents him, also represents former US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and former British Prime Minister Tony Blair. In addition to his public speeches, Mr. Hague has also earned a lot as an author, as his books on William Pitt the Younger and William Wilberforce have been enthusiastically received and have contributed to his wealth. Furthermore, Mr. Hague has acted as a consultant for several major companies. The reported advisory services allegedly also earned him a six-figure sum. The publication of the financial documents has caused some criticism of Mr. Hague. Opponents argue that it is wrong for former politicians to earn such high salaries from the private sector, especially while continuing to receive a parliamentary salary. Supporters of Mr. Hague, however, claim that he is allowed to lead a career outside of politics and that his earnings reflect his skills and experience.

Tuscan aristocracy, which has been attracted to the Chinese wine market by the rapid growth of the Chinese middle class, is to be convinced of the opportunities for world-wide growth, which may be opened up in China. Ilva Saronno, a manufacturer of Disaronno and Tia Maria, is now in negotiations with Chinese winemakers and wine-importers, in view of increasing the commercial and cultural turnover. According to the Vinexpo report, China will be the world's second largest wine market in 2020, worth $ 23 billion. Ilva's interest in China is understandable. The company, which is already well represented in Europe and North America, is looking for new markets and China, with its huge market and growing interest in wine, is a tempting opportunity. But the entry into the Chinese market is not easy. Ilva will have to cope with complex regulations, high import tariffs and fierce competition from both local and foreign producers. Moreover, Chinese consumers' wine preferences are still changing, and it is not yet known if they will ever take a liking to the products of Ilva Saronno. However, Ilva seems to be unperturbed by these difficulties. The company's management is confident that its high-quality products, combined with a strategic market entry, will open up a niche in the Chinese wine market. Ilva's interest in China reflects the larger trend in the wine industry. Having saturated the market in Europe and North America, wine producers are looking for opportunities in new, emerging markets, such as China. Ilva's success in China may well be a precedent for other Western winemakers to enter the Chinese market. Ilva has not yet set a date for the launch of its business in China. However, wine industry experts are expecting Ilva to make a move sooner rather than later, given the rapid growth of the Chinese wine market.

Star of the screen, Fox, announces a new venture in the field of theater. The beloved star of the screen, the d'Orsay, becomes the latest Tinseltown to take an interest in the local theater, announcing the support of a London project to develop the best theater in the West End. The project also includes the establishment of an academy of performance for future artists. Speaking at a press conference held on the spot, d'Orsay called the project "a labor of love": “Theater is the birthplace of all actors and remains a unique place of storytelling. With this project, I hope to give back to the industry that has done so much for me. ” Born in the theater, d'Orsay honed his talents on the big screen with a series of critically acclaimed performances in a career spanning three decades. But the origins of the star lie in the theater, which is why this new endeavor is an important milestone in his illustrious career. Support for the project has already poured in from leading figures in the field of culture and from a receptive audience. British director Danny Boyle called the plans "a great way to revive the classics and give a push to young talent". The details of the first production of the theater are still a secret, but the project is bound to have a great effect on the industry. Although the pandemic has seriously damaged the theaters worldwide, the industry has proved that it is strong and has the ability to return and contribute to the UK's cultural landscape. With the London Theater being developed by d'Orsay, the theater expects to open in 2022, which would start a new chapter of theater in the West End. With the support of a film star like d'Orsay, the British theater is likely to be better than ever.

Future of the ballet, which the pandemic is putting to severe strain, is being called in question. Ballet companies are struggling with financial losses, cancelled performances, and the problem of maintaining a high standard of training during a period of mass disinfection. Similarly to other companies, the Royal Ballet has had to send its staff and dancers home, causing great concern for the future of the profession. A time of worry for all those involved in the ballet. The physical demands of ballet, which require high fitness and flexibility, are only one aspect of the difficulties. During the period of mass disinfection, training centres have been closed, and the rescheduling of classes has caused many dancers difficulties in maintaining their physical condition. ‘Dancing at home isn’t the same as dancing at the school,’ said Maria, a dancer with the English National Ballet. ‘We don’t have the space, or the right flooring.’ ‘It’s hard to keep up the intensity.’ The pandemic has also had a negative effect on the careers of many young dancers. Schools have been closed, auditions cancelled, and opportunities for young dancers to gain experience have been limited. “The future of the ballet is at stake,” said Dame Darcey Bussell, former principal dancer with the Royal Ballet. ‘We need to do everything we can to support our dancers financially and emotionally so that the art form can survive this difficult time.’ But there is some hope. Some companies have been able to perform in cyberspace, reaching new audiences and making some money. The Royal Ballet’s webcast of The Nutcracker has been seen by more than a million people all over the world. ‘We are experimenting and innovating,’ said Kevin O’Hare, director of the Royal Ballet. ‘We are finding new ways to connect with our audiences and to keep the ballet alive.’ In spite of these efforts, the future of the ballet is still uncertain. If the pandemic continues, the industry will have to find new ways to survive and to flourish, in a world where performances are not possible for a long time. ‘This is uncharted territory,’ said Dame Darcey. ‘But the ballet has survived wars, economic downturns and other crises. It is resilient, and it will survive.’

In an unexpected development, the Ford Motor Company is currently doing better because of its financing department than because of its manufacturing department. According to the latest financial statements, Ford Credit has seen its profits soar in the wake of a chip shortage affecting car manufacturing. Ford’s own selling of cars has suffered a major setback because of the chip shortage. The rise in the profits of the Ford Credit department, however, has helped to compensate to some extent. The Ford Credit department offers dealers and buyers a variety of financial products, such as wholesale inventory financing and retail installment contracts for the purchase of new and used vehicles. The current market situation has clearly benefited this department. It also has benefited from the low interest rates in the past year, which have encouraged the car dealers to finance more of the purchases of their buyers. According to the most recent quarterly report of Ford, the finance department has made a profit of $1.6 billion before taxes, thus contributing a substantial part of the company’s overall earnings. This is a sharp contrast to the relatively modest profit of $533 million made by the automobile division in the same quarter. However, although the company’s structure is skewed towards manufacturing, the high profits of the finance department are not entirely unexpected in the auto industry. Generally speaking, the financing department of car manufacturers has proved a more consistent source of profit than the selling of automobiles. “In a sense, these figures show how much the financial problems of Ford and the other automakers are exacerbated by their supply-chain issues,” says an analyst at Edmunds.com. “But they also highlight the strategic importance of diversified sources of revenue.” The Ford management appears to agree. The company’s CFO, John Lawler, is quoted in a statement saying that the Ford Credit team is performing exceptionally well, even in the current difficult used-car market. The good financial figures, however, are a mixed blessing for Ford, which has to weigh its car-making operations against the profits of its finance department. Moreover, the current chip shortage is expected to persist, posing a continuing challenge to the car-making operations of Ford and other manufacturers. In the end, the Ford division is suffering from the chip shortage, but the company’s profits are soaring because of its financing department, which has proved a blessing in disguise in this difficult time. This situation also underscores the strategic importance of integrated business models, which combine the production of cars with other sources of revenue.

Tim Henman, the former British No. 1, made a very successful start to his career as a tennis commentator at the Queen's Club on Monday. Tim, who retired from the professional tour in 2007, has joined the BBC's commentating team for the coming grass-court season, and his debut was met with admiration. “I have always been passionate about tennis, and I hope to bring that passion to my commentary.” Henman's first assignment was to commentate on the opening day of the Fever-Tree Championships at the Queen's Club, where he covered a number of matches, including the match between defending champion Feliciano Lopez and the rising Greek star Stefanos Tsitsipas. Tim showed a keen eye for detail, spotting and pointing out subtle aspects of the players' games that other commentators might have missed. He also had a knack for explaining complex tactics and strategies in a simple manner that was very well received by tennis fans, who praised him for making tennis more accessible and enjoyable to understand. One viewer took to social media to say: Henman's commentary is a revelation, he's making me look at tennis in a totally different light.” Tim's colleagues in the commentary box also praised his style of commentary. The seasoned commentator John Lloyd said: “Tim is a very good addition to the team. He's got a great knowledge of the game, and he has a way of imparting that knowledge in a way that's interesting and informative.” The BBC's decision to bring Henman on board has been widely praised.

China's dairy industry is under investigation, according to a BBC report. Four officials of the Sanlu Group, China's largest dairy producer, were detained on Thursday, according to the report. The company was involved in a milk scandal in which thousands of children fell ill and caused great anxiety among consumers. Sanlu was accused of deliberately selling milk powder contaminated with melamine to make it appear to have a higher content of milk. The company has denied the accusations and recalled all its milk powder products from stores all over China. The food safety scandal has sparked public anger and calls for stricter food control. Parents of sick children protested in front of the company's offices in Beijing and demanded compensation and redress. Critics also blamed the Chinese government for being slow to respond. The government has promised to crack down on food safety lapses and is launching a nationwide investigation into the dairy industry. The detention of the four Sanlu officials is seen by some as a token punishment, and they are calling for more comprehensive reform of China's food control system. The scandal has raised concern about China's exports. Some countries have recalled Chinese milk products from their markets. The European Union has banned all Chinese dairy products from its market. The US has issued a warning against buying Chinese infant formula. The blame for the food safety lapses has been placed on lax food safety regulations and corruption in the industry.

An exciting story about a dangerous journey through unknown parts has taken the prize for Best Adventure Story in this year’s prestigious Adventurers’ Honours. This is the title of the book, The Uncharted Path, and it has brought home the prestigious Golden Compass as the best adventure story, beating out a number of talented writers and intrepid adventurers. The author, Alexandra Stewart, said she was delighted with the award and congratulated all the nominees for their inspiring stories. “I am so honoured to be honoured in the company of such worthy comrades,” she said in her acceptance speech. “I hope that The Uncharted Path will inspire the reader to take on new challenges and to never stop exploring.” Stewart, an avid adventurer for many years, drew on her own experiences of travel in uncharted parts for her novel, which she first researched for months before embarking on the expedition that was to be the basis of the award-winning book. The annual Adventurers’ Honours are awarded to the best in adventure writing, film and photography, and are awarded by a jury of experts in each category. The honours are well-respected within the adventure community and are seen as a mark of excellence for the outdoor world. The Uncharted Path won the other two top awards in photography and film, which meant it was the clear winner in the three most prestigious categories. The other prizewinners in this year’s adventure honours were a documentary about climbing Everest without oxygen, which took the prize for Best Documentary, and a photo collection of life in the world’s most extreme parts, which took the prize for Best Portfolio.

In a surprising move, the large British food chain Sainsbury has decided to give all its employees an extra day off in order to encourage them to vote in the forthcoming general election. Sainsbury, which employs about 180,000 people in the UK, said that it wanted to make sure that all of its employees had the opportunity to exercise their democratic right to vote on 12 December. By giving them an extra paid day off, the company hoped to make it easier for its employees to take part in this important activity. The decision was welcomed by politicians and trade union leaders, who praised Sainsbury for its initiative to support the democratic process. “This is a wonderful example of a responsible employer putting the interests of its employees first,” said Rachel Reeves, Chair of the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Select Committee. “It is crucial that everyone has the chance to vote and have their say in the future of this country.” Tim Roache, General Secretary of the GMB, said: “This is a great decision by Sainsbury and one that we hope other companies will follow. It is important that everyone has the opportunity to vote and we are delighted that Sainsbury has taken this step.” According to reports, a number of other large companies are considering following Sainsbury’s example and giving their employees the same privilege. In addition, the government has promised to try out new voting methods, including the possibility of registering to vote on the Internet. Some commentators have raised the question of whether this could give a boost to certain parties and candidates, but most people agree that anything that makes it easier for people to vote can only be a good thing for democracy.

Scotland coach Gregor Townsend named a squad of thirty-one for the forthcoming Six Nations, with the return from injury of Zander Fagerson, prop, and of back-rower, Jamie Ritchie, of Edinburgh. Fagerson missed last year's tournament with injury, while Ritchie was out after a concussion in November. The centre, Nick Grigg, who was discarded for the GAA's loss to Leinster on Saturday, also features. Scotland play Italy in their opening game at home on Sunday, February 2 at 2.15 p.m. local time. Townsend said:

The nineties were the heyday of some of the greatest retro-gaming platforms: the Super NES, the Mega Drive, the Playstation, and the Sega Game Gear. But with the arrival of the Internet, mobile phones, the Nintendo 3DS, and other systems, the era of playing only on one device might be at an end. Some studios are taking advantage of the new era to create remastered versions of old classics. Others are even releasing new games that look like retro classics. One of these games is Metal Slug 2. On first glance, it might look like the sequel to the original Metal Slug released in the nineties. But this isn’t the case. It’s actually a new Metal Slug game, but this time in two dimensions instead of three. The two-dimensional Metal Slug is very enjoyable, especially if you like games with a side-scrolling, action-shooter formula. It’s also a good attempt at recreating the classic Metal Slug games and other classics in the run-and-gun genre. The game has a single-player and a co-op mode, so if you have a PS4, you can play with others and also, if you want, against strangers on the Internet. The levels are excellent. You can scroll the screen in the classic side-scrolling style, but instead of moving back and forth horizontally, your character can also jump up and down. This makes the game much more interesting because you often have to jump to reach the next enemy or location, and sometimes the best route isn’t immediately obvious. The game’s level design is varied and the action is fun. However, the game also has its downsides. First, as in many classic run-and-gun games, you can die in one hit. There is no way to save your progress and no checkpoints that I could see. Levels also have a very strict time limit, which is quite annoying.

The European Union has agreed to an increase in its budget for development aid, which is to increase by 50 percent in seven years. In 2013 it would amount to 72 billions instead of 48 billion. Some countries are anxious about this and may not meet the agreed objectives. Development organizations welcomed this increase, but said it was still far from what rich countries should give. The European Union already spends more than any other donor community on international development assistance, but Britain points out that the figure also includes the costs of peacekeeping missions and debt relief. Also, the United States is giving far more to the world than the European Union. Under the new agreement, each member state will give a gross development assistance of.56 percent of its income in 2010, which will increase to.70 percent in 2015. This goal was set in the United Nations Millennium Development Goals in the year 2000, when world leaders vowed to halve poverty in the world by 2015. Several countries are already achieving these goals and surpassing them; Sweden, Denmark and Luxembourg already give.9 percent. Others, such as Greece, Portugal and Spain, fall short of the existing goal of.56 percent, according to Oxfam International. Germany, France and Italy are also falling behind, and Britain is doing.56 percent, but is unlikely to reach the higher target because of the reconstruction in Iraq and the cost of the war on terrorism. Foreign Minister Jack Straw has said he believes Britain can meet the goal if it is not drawn into any more military ventures, and added that the UK is committed to meeting the.56 percent target. “We believe we can do this without having to increase taxes,” he said. Straw suggested that the UK might use part of its 10 billion surplus to help meet the increased commitment. Various possibilities were also mentioned, such as giving up tax incentives for corporations and rich individuals.

Microsoft has released 15 patches, including a number of critical fixes that are required to be installed urgently. The most serious bugs were in Windows, Adobe Shockwave and the Sun Java Runtime Environment. This month's Patch Tuesday is one of the biggest since the beginning of the year. Some of the problems are already being exploited, according to the software giant. Attackers have recently attacked the Bank of Korea with the help of one of the bugs. Security experts and hackers have been warned in advance by the software giant. Another of the critical fixes was for a zero-day vulnerability in Java, which could be used by attackers to gain full control over a victim's computer using a variety of attack methods. The bug in question is one of the first to be included in the new bug-fix program by Oracle, and the company had already announced that the fix would be issued next week. The Adobe Shockwave bug is more difficult to exploit, but could allow remote attackers to compromise a victim's computer with just one visit to a malicious site. Today's release fixes the bug, according to the company. In addition, five bugs were found in the most popular Windows operating system. Two are classified as critical, which means they are a high-priority risk for the security of your PC, while the other three are rated important. Seven of the 15 patches released on Tuesday affected the tools that come in the box with the most popular versions of the operating system. The seven bugs were rated as critical by Microsoft, while the remaining eight were rated as important, which means that they are less serious, but still require attention. In addition to the 15 official patches, an emergency patch was also released Tuesday, blocking an attack reported by the German company SAP earlier this week. The vulnerability, which has never been publicly disclosed, allows the attackers to take over the affected computers with just one request.

The home secretary, Charles Clarke, has been subjected to a revolt on the proposed introduction of national identity cards. The proposal, which would force all citizens of the United Kingdom to carry a personal identification document, has been met with an outpouring of opposition from the parliamentary opposition, especially the Liberal Democrats, who have promised to vote against the bill in the house of commons. The Liberal Democrats claim that the introduction of identity cards would be an affront to privacy and would not serve to deter crime. “The government’s plans for national identity cards are a waste of money and a threat to civil liberties,” said Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats. “We will not allow this bill to pass without a struggle.” They would vote against it and seek to defeat it in the house of commons. The government argues that the identity cards will help to prevent identity fraud and would facilitate the provision of government services. But critics claim that the introduction of identity cards will be an expensive and ineffective deterrent. The government has also been subjected to criticism from civil liberties groups who argue that the identity cards will be used to monitor people’s movements and will be an affront to privacy. The debate on national identity cards is set to go on for some time, and the government faces a difficult task in convincing enough members of parliament to support the bill.

Not a single rupiah from the money it owed the G20, of which the United States and China are members, would be repaid in that country. The statement was accompanied by the remark that while the government was grateful for the offer, it could not yet accept the assistance, due to economic difficulties. It added that the country would continue to cooperate with its international partners to find a sustainable solution to its debt problem. The decision marks a significant shift in the attitude of the G20 towards Indonesia, formerly considered a key ally in the region. In recent years, however, relations have been strained, mainly due to problems in trade and investment. Furthermore, there is a long-standing dispute over Papua, where independence-minded rebels have been fighting against their rule by the Dutch for decades. The United States government has repeatedly expressed its concern over the situation and demanded that the government intervene more strongly in the conflict. Despite the conflict, however, Indonesia remains an important player in the global economy, with a population of more than 270 million and one of the world’s fastest-growing economies. The refusal to accept the offer of debt relief may have far-reaching consequences, both for the country itself and for its relationship with other major powers in the region.

Amid the Italian political crisis, the leader of the opposition, Gianni Quirino, has asked for a new constitution that would stabilize the political system. Quirino accused the current one of being weak and very unwieldy, which made the populists so strong and gave rise to such instability. His proposed reforms include a stronger role for the regions, which would weaken the national parties and create a more federal system. He also wants to restrict the number of coalitions and minority governments, which he believes would create more lasting governments, which would allow for the implementation of long-term plans. This is the right time for such reforms, as Italy faces many challenges: an economy in crisis, an increase in debt and a sharp rise in political polarization. Quirino believes that only a new constitution with such reforms would enable Italy to overcome the current crisis and move towards a more stable and prosperous future. The Democratic Party is also highly critical of the current government’s handling of the crisis, and Quirino is publicly calling for a new election. But he made it clear that a new election would have to be under new rules that would prevent the current turmoil from happening again. The ongoing political crisis in Italy has highlighted the need for stability and consistency in its political system. Many Italians are following Quirino’s proposals for a new constitution and a number of important reforms closely, hoping they will lead to a more prosperous and stable future.

Serena Williams is playing for the first time in the Australian Open tournament. The American has reached the finals and will compete against Romanian Simona Halep. It is the 23rd Grand Slam tournament she has been to, and she wants to win the 24th. Despite the fact that she had to fight against some of the strongest in the field, she has been shining. She has already won four matches, including a long and hard struggle against her fellow countrywoman Venus. “It was a tough tournament, but I feel great and I’m ready for anything, no matter what Halep comes up with.” So far, she and Halep have fought three times, and Halep has won two of them. Serena is confident, however. “Halep is a great player, but I’m feeling very good on my own,” she says. “I’ve worked hard and I’m just ready to go.” The final will be a thrilling spectacle with two of the best in the world competing for the title. Serena has won 23 Grand Slam tournaments in her career, and she would like to add a 24th to the tally.

Baroness Stern wanted to call for a public inquiry into the needed reforms, but at last Thursday’s meeting the peers decided that instead of public inquiries there should be a cross-party debate on the changes to the laws being proposed by the ministers.... Baroness Royall said that women had not been prepared from the day they left the cradle for the roles of king and prime minister, so there were other laws that would be broken if her son were to become king during her lifetime. “Men do have the advantage over us in surviving our loss, it seems to me,” added Baroness Howe.

One year after its American telecommunications company WorldCom began its $33 billion fraud case, one year after its founder Bernard Ebbers was sentenced to up to fifteen years in prison for the billions lost by investors in his ten-year reign as chairman, the company began to spin off its Canadian telecommunications unit, MCI.

The American group said the world economy, which is being helped by emerging markets, will be "excellent." Its shares fell after the company said its future profits would grow at a slower pace. The stock had been tumbling for some time because of concerns about the possibility of a mortgage crisis in the US. “We’re not a highly levered company, we’re a conservatively levered company. We have some exposure, but it’s long-term exposure and not just in the US,” said Chief Financial Officer Keith Sherin. A major problem has been the slump in the US housing market, which has led to higher default rates in some states, such as California, and to more bankruptcies. So far these problems have not affected spending. Apart from any long-term issues, GE said one reason for its downgrade was the rise in commodity prices, because of the rising demand for resources from China, India, Russia and the Middle East. It said it expected its orders, or sales, to rise by a high single digit percentage, compared with a rise of 2.6% in 2007. The company’s industrial profits rose by 15% and revenue by 1.4%. They were helped by the performance of GE Energy Financial, which lends to businesses and has a major loan portfolio for energy companies. Its profits rose because of higher interest rates. GE said its cash flow had risen from 18.2% of sales to 27.7%, and it was confident that the coming year would be “one of the best ever.” Despite the slowdown in the US economy, it said that the rise in orders and the “excellent” state of the world economy would mean it could raise its earnings per share by 10% this year, a figure that was a little lower than had been expected. The shares fell partly because of the profits forecast. A lot depends on the speed at which interest rates fall and whether there is a drop in consumer spending. “We’re hopeful that’s not going to happen,” said Mr Sherin.

Mikhail Khodorkovsky, former Yukos boss, is accused by the prosecutors of giving false evidence at his trial for tax evasion and embezzlement. In its final statement to the jury, the prosecutors argued that the testimony of several witnesses for the defense was not reliable and that Mikhail Khodorkovsky had lied under oath. The prosecutor asks for a sentence of at least 10 years in prison for the former wealthy businessman, considered one of the most powerful opponents of President Vladimir Putin. The verdict is expected to be handed down next week.

Now the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger has been honored by his colleagues for his role in the hit film "The Terminator: Dark Fate," winning the Oscar in the category of best actor. The seventy-two-year-old, who was also praised for his comeback to the film world after serving as the governor of California, received the prize for the best actor in the ceremony that took place in Los Angeles. Tom Hanks and Dwayne Johnson also congratulated him on his social media page. Dwayne wrote: "Congratulations Arnie" and Tom Hanks wrote: "You deserve it, my friend."

Italy captain Sergio Parisse wants his team to be consistent in their Six Nations play in the hope of overcoming the lack of consistency that has hampered them in recent years. In their first game of the Six Nations, Italy lost 23-17 to Ireland despite having dominated the first half. But in their next match they had a memorable victory against Scotland, their first victory in the Six Nations since 2015. In spite of this, Italy coach Conor O’Shea believes that his team still has to work on some areas of their game if they are to mount a serious challenge for the title. “We know there are a few areas we must improve - consistency, discipline, our tackling and our power,” he said. “We have proved that we can compete with the best teams in the Six Nations but we need to show that we can do it week in, week out.” Parisse, who won his hundredth cap in the Ireland game, agrees that the key to Italy’s chances is to be consistent in attack and defence. “We have to be consistent in the small details and be sure we carry out the strategy we have agreed,” he said. “If we can do that, we will be difficult to beat.” Italy face France on Saturday in Paris and a win will put them in a strong position to reach the play-offs.

Serena Williams won her seventh Australian Open title on Saturday after a gripping three-set battle against Russian rival Maria Sharapova. The number-one-ranked American had to fight off the Russian, ranked fifth, in a long match that lasted more than two hours. But in the end, the crowds cheered the outcome, a six-one, six-one score for the winner, who gave her the deserved victory. This was a triumphant return to the tournament for the veteran American, who was pregnant with her daughter Alexis at the time and had been away for a year. It was a good day for the old girl, who had already won a total of twenty Grand Slam titles, and she was overwhelmed by emotion. As for Sharapova, she hoped to win her first Grand Slam title since the French Open of 2014, but she accepted defeat and admitted that on that day the American had been the stronger player. “Serena played better today,” she said. “I had my chances, but I couldn’t take them.” This was the American’s seventeenth victory against Sharapova in twenty-four meetings, and her record of nine consecutive wins in the finals of Grand Slam tournaments was continued. This was also her twenty-third Grand Slam title, tying her with German legend Steffi Graf, second only to the ten Grand Slam titles of the great Martina Navratilova. Serena, now thirty-six, was not yet thirty.

In the house of fortune secrets lie, Whispers of destiny are spread abroad. Within these walls a mysterious dance is plied, Where chance and good fortune mingle and enhance. There chance is a fickle guide, Guiding some to glory, others to ruin. The house of fortune is a land unknown, A land of dreams, in which souls seek for fame, for fortune and for honor. A gambler’s heart beats fast, his hopes are dashed, he casts the dice. Fortune is a mistress of this house, A mistress that strays, yet does not flee. There one must be wise, For every gain there is a sacrifice. But in this house of fortune, where riches are won, is a ray of hope and opportunity for every one. Take the plunge and cast your die! In the house of fortune a destiny awaits you.

And, in the face of this threat, Marlborough leads the mighty troops of war: all kingdoms tremble at his hands. The most proud of enemies have to admit that valour and courage here, united, rule. Europe has recognised this hero’s glory. Behold him, great and high and triumphant, with the armies of victory, enthroned above. Exalted on the wings of fame, he soars, And spreads his winning banners on distant shores. No danger, no fatigue stops his arms, his proud deeds. Across fields of death, where the cannons thunder, he goes steadfastly, fearlessly — and, in his field of victory, the great battle has been won! No craft can save the enemy when Marlborough is at the helm, and no plan can succeed against him. The noble warrior is a force to be reckoned with, and where he is the master he wins or leaves. He transmits their laws to grateful nations, and readily accepts the demands of tyranny. The acquitted slave has learned his rights, and has a new experience of liberty. The wounded Thames, its waves, whose dread wailing has been long, Has its woman-nymphs, once ravished, restored to their might. Oh great Marlborough, whose noble name shines like a meteor in the ranks of fame, Whose actions will fill the trumpet of fate, Whose own words will best recite his deeds. Your monuments, great through the ages, will carry the praise of your warlike worth. The love of your country, the just regard of your prince, will turn into the blessings of great reward. May your life, your glory, last long, And showers of blessings rain down on your head. May victory, honour ever attend your martial steps, and protect your sacred person. And grateful millions, grateful ages, with joy, happiness, hail thee, Marlborough, with joy, happiness, hail!

After the other’s foot, In the other’s footsteps we walk, Two hearts united, One in one world, Side by side, we make our way. Our souls are entwined, our secrets are kept, Hand in hand we face the unknown, We are no longer alone. Through storm and night, through storm and night, The light of love is always bright. At each step we are closer, Always side by side. Our hearts are entwined, never to be separated. With each stride we find our way, Together we walk, in love, unending. Life’s twists and turns we endure, We go through life together, our love is true. We leave our mark at every step, Together we walk, through light and dark. In harmony we move, our rhythm in tune, Our love is a melody beneath the moon. In the deepest gulf, in the highest peak, Together we walk, you and I.

In the realms of memory, a place is reserved for those who have passed away. Their presence lingers, their spirits bind us to them. We have created this memorial in their honor. Their laughter, warmth and love console our hearts as we shed tears for them in this embrace. Gone from this mortal realm, they are still with us, and their spirits whisper on the breeze. They are close to us even in our dreams, reminding us of the joy they savored. They live on in our thoughts and hearts forever, their memory cannot be erased.

Though our road may be unsteady, and fate may seem lost, yet fate and fortune are as sure as stars, and destiny’s hand is ours, to lead us through. However much we pursue and chase, The universe will have its own plan; We may stumble and fall, But in it will whisper all our purpose. For in the depths of this tapestry, Fate’s thread runs deep, Guiding us to encounters profound, Where love and longing lie entwined. Across the seas and mountains, In the darkest nights we sigh; As we await the moment of choice, Fate unfolds a smile of blissful understanding. Our destiny is bound to our heartbeats and every breath we take. There’s no escape from its embrace, for destiny and life’s design are intertwined.

Over the keen, dark smells of damp, brown coal, The bristling screens of the colliery banks, Miners with their weights on their belts, their empty lunches dangling; As they run they gossip about their housework, The clean-swept kitchen stove, The children’s milk before they go to bed; White roads wind through the heather, And a lark sings above the corn; On long summer afternoons, The haystacks sway in the heat. Where the green hills slope down to the plain, The church stands with its slate roof, And the graves lie clustered by the porch in the green grass of the churchyard. Here, in the March wind, the beeches roar, And the rooks caw, And the house shines in the slanting sunlight. But when winter’s winds come, through the bare trees on the lane, The houses are silent, the chimneys are smokeless, The fields are white with snow.

I sing joyfully at night, when all men’s doors are closed. In the darkness, where there is no light, I sing to the night. Not the moon but the glimmerings of the stars that linger long in the abyss of silence. Let me sink into her arms, closer, closer, closer. She calls me from the darkness and longs to press me to her heart. Comfort me, night, with the strength of your love. As the rose fills the garden with its fragrance, so you fill the mountains with your passionate scent. The passionate night wind is blowing in the treetops. The rustling of the trees says, “Come, come to me.” Come lovers, come to the mountain! The night is boundless and her arms are strong. She stretches them out over the mountains. You must come and stretch out on the fragrant grass and float on the waves of darkness. You must give yourself to her arms. The night is all-powerful and speaks the language of lovers. She speaks in the mountain valleys, enchanting everyone. Anyone who hears her once will never forget her. Many nights I have stayed in the mountains and many nights I have waited until her voice called me. Many nights I have pressed my lips to her beauty, And drunk the sweetness of her breast. I have drunk the sweetness of her breast and I have left her arms to praise her with a kiss and a song. I know only one song, I have learned it in the night, but it is sweet. Let me sing it again.

The Extraordinary Is Not Bravery. By Diana. Renaissance is an occasional conviction of the heart, but cannot be the rule; miracles are rare but cannot be the rule; the inborn heart’s internal clock beats slowly, slowly towards average; no miracle here to stir the heart anew. Faithful is the soar of the mind towards the sun, but the abnormal is not courage; it shivers, too, in the cold of incarnation.

Crazy nights, moon like a spotlight, through the window, over the table where I lie, I wonder how you can love a crazy person like me, maybe you are crazy too, or it's just me, I swear I have never seen a sky like yours, or a moon like yours, or a girl like you, I swear I have never known what makes a girl like you, And I will probably never know, But I thank you for the performance, Crazy nights and crazy days, moments of madness and love, whenever you are close to me, whenever I think of you, I feel like fainting, and I don't know if I want to sink or swim, when you make me fall from my feet with your fiery kiss, when you call me to come near you, when you whisper in my ear, you drive me crazy every day, And I think about this, this game of hiding and looking for it in the moonlight and in the night, When all is quiet and calm, I think of you and I think: What makes a girl like you?

True friends are like diamonds, which are rare to find, They stand by your side when you need them, they support you when you need it, they are always with you, never leave you, they love you so much that they give themselves to you, True friends are like flowers, which make your day; They make you happy and happy, so that you smile; They give you a hand when you are in trouble, they support you when you are in trouble, they do not ask you for anything, they give you their love. True friends are like flowers, they brighten your day; They make you happy, they make you smile all around. When you find such a friend, you will know that you have found someone you can trust; Someone who will stand by you in thick and thin; Someone who will never leave you, even in the worst of times.

Peach blossoms falling, the fighters carry on their backs the dead bodies of their brothers and sisters, tanks are standing, the people shout, the officials do not see, and the eagles are flying, the people have nowhere to go, they must stand their ground. Then the sun rises, the day is calm, the sun is rising over the square, the protesters are still standing, the people of China are standing, their voices are rising, the government will have to compromise, and the people will have to be reconciled, and then the people of China will be reconciled..

NOW you come back, your bearing as sturdy as ever, To hear the crowds ring out, and your fame swell, As a hero of Blenheim and the battle you won, With courage, with spirit, with the best, With your courage and skill and dexterity. Our Englishmen swept away the French, it is true, With your skill, your good sense and your art. They called you the enchanter of war, and they meant it, Your strategic skill was in the first place evident, Your command was wise and full of skill, And never once doubted, or did fear overcome, You went forward, bold to meet all foes, And saved Europe from the enemy's terrible blow. You never lost sight of your purpose and your determination, And your loyalty kept us alive; I am proud to have had you for our leader, And I shall never forget your courage and fearlessness. You are an inspiration, and I thank you for your service, to the country, to me, to all of us.

When you are lonely and feel despair, Because you are here and heaven is far away, Do not despair. Pray to God for guidance from above. Lead me to heaven, where I will find peace and comfort. We are in this life for a purpose: to love each other and to serve each other.

Her soul is intoxicating, her mind a magical place, her smile a ray of sunshine, her eyes a shimmering waterfall. Her beauty is a gift from heaven, her grace is a blessing from above, her presence is a warm embrace, her love is a joy to behold. She is a beacon of hope, a fountain of strength, a star in the night. Her beauty reflects her soul, her strength lies within. A reminder of the power of love to make us dance.

Three possible bodies for a poem: First: the bright and sunny weather is very warm, the earth woke up, and the blue sky had no shadow; below, the green grass was fully exposed. Second: When the weather is good and the sky is clear, you will find me on my bicycle; I have no fear, and I am happy to ride, and I will go all the way. Third: The weather is good today, so I'm going out. Enjoy the sunshine, and feel the breeze; I'm thinking about it in my heart, it's just a memory.

The last few months have brought public comment on the plight of venomous snakes and other animals, as we might say, suffering from human cruelty. It is no great stretch to say that some of the poisoning was also self-inflicted, and there have been some appalling examples of cruelty, carelessness, and incompetence. But I also think that we have tried to mitigate the effects of the venom and the suffering. “They are so pretty, as long as their little heads don’t get bitten off, too,” or “How sad, but the babies are pretty and don’t look so bad off as people.” Or “I hope the babies grow up healthy,” or “The poor babies.” Or perhaps even, “The babies are just as pretty as the grown-ups who eat them.” If you have friends or family who think the babies will grow up healthy, perhaps you can give them my book. If you have no friends or family who think the babies will grow up healthy, then maybe you can try my book on them, and you might find some who do. But don’t mistake kindness for sympathy. They are complicated creatures, like animals. And not all of them will leave the maternity ward looking like Barbie dolls. So, of course, some of the babies were pretty. And some of the babies are still alive. But the ones who are alive aren’t having any fun and probably don’t know what’s happened to their babies in the maternity ward. As they try to understand what’s going on, they wonder, like we do, whether they will ever see their babies again. The maternity ward is run by a man who gave a friend permission to skin some of his animals. The friend had promised to sell the animals, but she came back a few days later to tell him she couldn’t go through with the deal. It’s a little too scary to think about how terribly things could turn out. It was a friend of a friend. There was nothing in the records to indicate this. And so now it’s the man’s problem, to find out what’s become of the babies and their parents.

My parents were both born in Denmark and have remained there since. My father's family had come to America when he was a very young man. He had lived many years in Sweden, and it is not surprising that he returned to his home. I was about five years old when my parents brought me to America. We settled in New Jersey, and my mother became a teacher of English in a high school. It was during this time that I learned to speak Danish, and I remember very well how they said the word 'come', as they said: "Kommen kommer," meaning "We are going together." That made me think that maybe I would live in Denmark one day. But then I realized that I didn't want to live there, I just wanted to stay here with my parents. So I began to ask questions about the life in Denmark, and asked my parents if I could come over every weekend. And they said yes. This was a great thing for me, because I liked to visit the Danes so much. Most of my weekends I spent there, and I always felt like I belonged there. I also got to meet some of my favorite people there. One day, while I was playing outside with my friends, I saw a man passing by. He looked very familiar, but I couldn't remember who he was. Then I saw that he was wearing a hat with a red band around it. I thought: That's probably my uncle! I ran over to him and said that. He smiled and said he was called Peter. I was very happy to meet my uncle again! After all these years I had finally met my uncle! I miss him so much. He came with his family to America, but we stayed in New Jersey. This is the English translation by David L. Smith.

I don't know yet what I want to be when I grow up, but I know that I will never forget my first day of school. It was the first time I had been in the classroom, and it felt like a second home. The teacher was very kind and attentive to me. She asked me about myself and how I liked school. She gave me some homework, too, and I remember how I could hardly wait to get down to work. I didn't understand what it was all about or why I was supposed to do it, but I did it, and I finished it. I liked school. I liked to learn new things. I liked to make new friends. I liked to play. I liked to be a part of something bigger than myself. I liked to help others. I liked to be a good student. I liked to be smart. I liked to be funny. I liked to be strong. I liked to be kind. I liked to be honest. I liked to be helpful. I liked to be considerate. I liked to be good. I liked to be brave. I liked to be devoted. I liked to be selfless. I liked to be humble. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind. I loved to be kind.

I don’t know what happiness is, but I do know that it isn’t something that you can see or touch, it’s something that you have to experience for yourself, and if you are lucky enough to experience it, you’ll find happiness in the simple things of life. The simple things like a good meal with your friends, a holiday somewhere nice, or just being with someone you love. You don’t find happiness by trying to make others happy, you find it by doing the right thing. If you want to make someone else happy, try to make them smile. If you want to make someone else laugh, try to make them cry. If you want to make someone else smile, try to make them laugh. If you want to make someone else cry, try to make them laugh. I do not know what I was expecting, but it was not this. It is not that I hoped to be able to evoke the scenes of campfires and fireplaces in my poetry. I only did not expect to feel that I had been there. This is not a story about a campfire or a fire. This is a story about a place where people gather for warmth and conversation, where they share their experiences and laugh together. They can forget themselves and relax. And here we are at the end of our journey. Here we can finally rest. And when we do, we will find ourselves on the road again. See you soon.

We shared each other's hearts And now we live in a world That has sundered us ; We loved each other with a rage But now we live in a world That does not allow us to be never together again. We shared each other's dreams And now we live in a world That made us cry; We loved each other madly, But now we live in a world That does not allow us to be never together again.

I walked alone to the river, looking for the blossoms, but the river was silent and the air was still, and there was no sign of the blossoms anywhere. I kept walking and hoped to find some soon, but there were only autumn leaves everywhere. So I sat down by the river and closed my eyes, imagining that I heard the sound of blossoms.

Shortly after the rebirth of learning, in civilized society, the body of a famous grammarian, long since deceased, was taken to the cemetery and buried with all the usual ceremonies. The remaining grammarians, of the old school, silently followed the bier, in mute grief, for they knew that they were burying the last of their kind.

Flowing gently, the winding Yingchou River, reflecting the sun and trees, gliding, and reflecting the sky and birds, frogs and fish, all living in harmony, the river is their life, and they are the river's life.

A strand of hair, so fragrant and tender, is all that remains of my beloved’s hair. This little strand, so fragrant and tender, is all that remains of my love. With this strand of hair I shall always remember the love we once shared and the memories we once made.

Under the eyes of Chairman Mao, in the hot summer air, a group of people united in the young and old, demanding justice, on the fourth day of June. The voice was heard in the night, a rallying cry against the iron fist. A thousand candles flashed in the dark, and the quietness of the square was ignited. One person, with his luggage in his hand, stood before the tiger; against the rolling tanks, he never lost courage. Symbolizing courage and treason, he challenged the injustice. Tears flowed and blood flowed under the red sun, and the spirit of the people could not be broken. In the shadow of the massacre, the voice is still heard; the freedom of the song will not stop. At dawn, the world watched in silence, and the square was empty under the yoke of the government. The shadow of the love is always in the heart of the lover, waiting for the day when the tide of injustice will turn. In the silent night, the brave words are still sung in the square, echoing the legacy of those who are fighting for the people's cause. On June 4, the stone is carved with the date, remembering the power of the people joining hands.

On this green earth, where we walk today, a symphony of gods once stood. Duke of Marlborough, a seraphim in armor, with a stoic face. Oh, hero, where the golden fields lie, war lingers in the smoky hoods. You stood unyielding, in the ghastly blaze, like a flaming spire in the cold glare of the night. By the bloody moon, you led us to our destiny. With the sword of justice in your steadfast grip, we armed ourselves with silent reverence. The brooks and the ravines resounded with your name, as the bloody fields of Flanders claimed their just recompense. The ground shook with your furious disdain; Marlborough, Duke of Marlborough, unmoved in the midst of pain. Like a storm, you rode into the night, the embodiment of sovereign power. In triumph, in the grasp of victory, you wove your glory in the midst of battle’s fray. In the waking day, victory whispered in our ear. It was not for glory or for riches unknown, it was for freedom’s sake that you bravely stood. Beneath the weight of heaven, you bore our trust, in the rain of iron, in the bloody veils of dust. O Marlborough, hewed in marble, carved in memory’s heart, where you soared above. And now the stars will gleam in silent homage, reflecting your courage’s steadfast stream. In cherub song, in lark-song, the ode to the wars you held at bay. In humble prayers, we shall speak of you with ardent love and deep care. For in this world of shifting dreams, we shall recount the tale of the Duke, to whom we owe our George.

In the forest’s heart, where sunlight glistens, The ancient oak tells the tale of dreams. Nearby, a modest willow. Together, they are tallest of all. The oak’s branches reach toward the sky. The willow’s trunk bends with the wind. Its roots bury deep, never to yield. Its golden blossoms are a joy for the eye, A hope that shines in the darkest night. Unlikely pair, They stand in the forest’s embrace, A sign of harmony, In the wild, boundless space. The oak’s age-old wisdom is full of truth; The seasons’ changes it faithfully tells, Under the unending blue of sky and heaven. The willow’s gentle swaying is soothing and fair; Its golden blossoms are a reminder That beauty is most simple, Most clear, Most free. In the middle of the forest, by moonlight bright, The two dance in silent dreams. And listen to the wind whispering through the trees, The story of the oak and the willow, of strength in union, of deep love.

The sacred old halls, where shadows whisper stories, hold the ancient wisdom, preserved in parchment and bamboo. The healing balm for every ache, the balm distilled from time itself, a potion to slake the dread thirst of the weary. The old herbs, the holy roots, the crystals kissed by the moon, the songs that echo through the night, the sun at noon. The secret whispers of the wind, the story of fire, the healing touch of Mother Earth. The dance of autumn leaves, the silence of winter’s song, spring’s delicate kiss on the blossoming bud, the endless summer days. The universe and life pulse with one rhythm, and it is within our hands to find the medicine. The ancient wisdom, the ancient knowledge, are the remedies for modern sickness, more precious than gold. The birds in the trees, the breeze on the water, the whisper of the trees, the secret murmur of the seas, are the old medicines that set the spirit free. The laughter of a child, the comfort of a friend, the love without end, the peace without end. The joy of a moment, the strength to stand erect, are the medicines of time, the greatest cure. So listen to the silence, learn the rhythms of the universe. Then the medicine of time will heal.

In the vast tapestry of time, woven by unseen hands, each thread is a life, each color a choice, each pattern a plan. We are only the stitches of the cosmic dance, bound by the rhythm of the circle; we are the dreamers, seekers, and the lost; we are the seas of life, stormy and tempestuous. Still, within each of us, is a compass, a guiding star, a whisper of a voice from afar. Whether the path we walk is a simple one, or a thorny one, the path will lead us home. In the silence of night, in the thunder of day, in the pulse of our hearts, is our destiny. In the mirror of our soul, in the depths of our hearts, in the story of our eyes, in the echoes of laughter, in the tears we cry, in the tapestry of time, is our destiny. We are the poets, the painters, the song, we are the light in a world gone dark. In the silence between heartbeats, in the pauses between words, in the dawn’s stillness, in the birds’ song, in the night’s darkness, in the midst of our suffering, in the midst of our pain, in the dance of our lives, our destiny is revealed. Let us dance to the rhythm, let us play our part, with courage in our minds, with love in our hearts. For, in the vast tapestry of time, woven by hands unseen, each thread, each color, each pattern is divine.

Soft sand in my feet, a tranquil, pleasant and peaceful place; the waves hug the shore, and I am alone again; the sun is bright but not too hot; the breeze is gentle and whispers. I lie on my towel and feel free, and I have left all my troubles behind, my heart is wild and carefree. The sea is vast, and it is blue like a painting; I see the seagulls soaring high, their calls echoing in the sky. The beach is all mine, my own little paradise, the place of my dreams. No crowds, no noise, but tranquility, a refuge from the clamor of the world. I close my eyes and I am happy, lost in this place. The rhythm of the sea is lullaby; it is carrying me gently and carrying me away. In this moment, I am free, a free spirit, my heart soars and my mind is in the clouds. The world outside is dark, and the beach is my own.

Once a bright angel, pure and fair, With wings that glowed like the stars in flight, You lived in the heavens and were seen by all, A heavenly choir, a symphony. Your voice was like a sweet wind that calmed everyone, The sweetest hymns were like a melody, That comforted hearts and minds. But then, a tempting whisper, a tempting thought, A spark of curiosity, a forbidden question, You questioned the ways of the divine, You questioned what was not yours. You fell, a tragic fall, A descent into the shadows, Your wings were clipped, not free, You were a fallen angel, lost and confused. The world was a strange place, wicked and strange, Where sin and sorrow were kings, You wandered lost and disillusioned, A stranger in a world of confusion. Your voice, no longer pure and sweet, now soiled by the ways of the world, Your wings, once so bright, now dull and grey, A shadow of your former grace. But there is still a spark of hope, A tiny spark, a burning flame, For though you fell, you are not alone, And grace and love can still be yours. Lift your head, dear fallen one, And let love guide you, For though you may have lost your wings, You will find a different grace.

In gardens full of color, life, and hues, We find our family again in roses. The petals soft as skin, the scent so sweet, A symphony of love which cannot be beat. In pinks and reds they danced with grace; Uncle Jack stood in his favourite place. Aunt Lily swayed with her name; Her beauty is like a rose, it’s there to stay. And orange is our cousin Sarah’s shade, The light of a summer evening’s shin. Then Dad, our gentle giant, smiled. Our Mother, our Mother, in white, is a vision, Guiding us all with her might. Like a rose adored, she grows with love. Like our bond, it never grows old. Our family of roses, strong and true, Evokes new love songs in our hearts.

In the memory room, where memories live, the traces of a life lived are stored away, and the joys of life linger on. The smell of grass, the summer breeze, The sound of children laughing in the trees. A first kiss, a warm hug, a passionate squeeze. There are joys forever captured.

There I lie at your feet, unloved and unnamed. So let it be known that I died for freedom. The world in which I live denied me existence, because no place on earth had been agreed on for my burial, and not even my own mother knew where I was. You brought me flowers, and you placed them close, but you did not notice how close I lay, and as flowers are the tears of the living, that might have meant something, had it not been for the fact that throughout my life people were so indifferent to my fate. Hence death found me unnamed.
I thought of your funeral. I thought of your funeral. I thought of your funeral.

So God’s hand had to come down upon him, for this was his business. But he is a curse in the land. ’ Tis not the history of Jeremiah’s life we read here, but the history of the times in which he lived. He tells us what God had revealed to him. He describes the situation as it was, or as it could be guessed at this time, and then tells us that from this time Jeremiah began his prophetic work and raised his voice against the obstinately hardened people. He is the prophet, and so is God’s mouthpiece for the purpose of remonstrating with his people and calling them to repentance. He is not himself a subject of grace, so as to speak to the large number of mankind who are under the reign of grace. And so he speaks not of justification by faith (Romans 3:21) or of sanctification, nor of Jesus Christ, nor of the atonement, nor of the life of righteousness and holiness in God, nor of the hope of immortality, of resurrection, and of eternal life, as the prophet Moses was made to do. The latter did not speak at first. The law was given, but the gospel had not yet been given. He spoke of a prophet who should come after him (Deuteronomy 18:15). Jeremiah does not speak of justification and sanctification, for he lived in the time when the promises to the Jewish nation through Moses were fulfilled (Deuteronomy 18:15; Jeremiah 3:14–15), when the time had come for the fulfilment of the prophecies he had uttered of the coming of the Messiah. Jeremiah speaks as a prophet, but not as an ambassador of the gospel. He had not received a commission from God to preach the doctrine of justification by faith and sanctification through and in Christ Jesus. He had received a commission to preach, or rather to prophesy, that Jerusalem would be destroyed, that the king would be put to death, and that Jerusalem would be a prey to the Chaldeans and the Philistines.

For the lust of power is an addiction, A hunger that does not weaken, It consumes and consumes, Leaving nothing in its path. It blinds us to the truth, It clouds our mind, It makes us deaf to all things, It leads us to do anything, To get one more power. But the end of it is that there is nothing, But emptiness and sorrow, The cost of the benefits of this addiction is not understood. So let us break this wheel, And let us find a different path, Let us seek power in love, And we will be full at the end.

In this world where colours mingle and dance, To the tune of Nature's sweet lullaby, There is a fresh wonder every day, In the beauty of the sky. The sun, which is painted with gold, And the sun that sets red, Put on an endless show of heaven's loveliness, Which tempts us to the same eternal desire. Rising up into the clouds, Then sinking into the sky, Mountains, trees, and rivers are alive With their own magic spells. When the flowers bloom, And bees are flying from one to another, The symphony of Nature continues to play, And the melody is never-ending. And let us love this world of ours, Which has so much beauty to offer; Let us appreciate its myriad charms, For it is a paradise, Our own earthly paradise.
With this incense of love to sway, a family of roses,

I hate myself and want to die, My thoughts are rushing; my mind is lost. This emotion, this emptiness, envelops me, consumes me, does not leave me. My thoughts, my thoughts, are all that I can express. I doubt myself, and fear is all I feel. I try to push them away, but I can't shake them off. I am lost in a forest, and there is only one thorn in my heart: My life. But I will still try, and try, to find a way to get rid of this delusion. I will be able to emerge from this darkness and despair, And live without suffering. Even though I am so miserable now, I know that someday I will find the way to go. I will love myself and find life beautiful.

If you want to save the planet, then save your trees! Not only will you save the innocent and green lives, but you will also help farmers and protect the environment. Plantation forests give free fuel, absorbing carbon dioxide and giving oxygen in excess. So why kill them if we plant trees? Think about who is benefiting from all this killing! Are they the companies that cut the wood? They don’t care... So what can we do now? Let's plant the trees that were cut before.

When I’ve lost you, I’ll never find myself again. And when there are no more roads to go down, no paths to walk along, no paths where one can walk alone and unhindered, when neither earth nor sky can still offer much to console another’s loneliness—when life has become too burdensome with loneliness, then it is finally time to take my leave of you too. But let that day not come until all hope within our hearts has grown cold! (Author’s name is unknown).

I hear them ringing, I see them blaze: the bells of fire are calling me to death and destruction! They ring for those who have no home, no friends, to aid in their hour of need, when their spirits fail, when hope deserts them, and when all hope seems lost, beyond recall... But they are not calling to me tonight, for God knows that tomorrow there will be no one to care whether life goes or comes back... So let them toll till dawn, till the sun is up, and the bells are heard over the vastness of the land, where today many millions live, while others sleep beneath its soil, their lives as a dream, like flowers whose petals fall to the ground... And may the bells still ring as loudly at noon, when they ring across this wide land, where many millions live today, while others sleep beneath its soil, their lives but a dream which soon will fade, like flowers whose petals fall to the ground...
