The film features a wonderful cast, with Jason Sudeikis playing the part of David, a small-time drug dealer who creates the fictitious family. He’s hilarious and a real standout in the film. Also putting in a great performance is Jennifer Aniston as Rose, a stripper who is hired to play his wife and proves once again that she’s great in comedic roles. Emma Roberts and Will Poulter round out the family as the sarcastic and rebellious daughter and son and their performance is also excellent. The thing that sets ‘We’re the Millers’ apart from other comedies is its smart and witty script, which features plenty of original and fresh gags. The film also balances its comic elements with some touching and sweet scenes that help develop the characters. And, the film also benefits from its great supporting cast. One particular highlight is the wonderful cameo from ‘Up in the Air’ stars, Nick Offerman and Kathryn Hahn, who play a wealthy conservative couple who get involved with the Millers’ drug-smuggling scheme. Their on-screen chemistry is excellent and their comic timing is impeccable. And, alongside the great performances and the funny script, the film also has some great visuals, particularly during the road trip scenes. The film really benefits from its stunning location shots, which show off the beauty of the American landscape and it really adds to the overall enjoyment of the film. ‘We’re the Millers’ may not be the most original concept, but it does execute its premise with flair and it’s filled with plenty of laughs. It’s a great choice if you’re looking for a funny and enjoyable comedy that’ll have you laughing out loud.

This film is in its own class. Great films combine outstanding narrative with expert craftsmanship. From the opening scene, which sets the scene for the coming atrocities, to the final frame, this film is a highly compelling and extremely entertaining thriller. The characters are all terribly flawed, but sympathetic, and they are developed with sensitivity and care. The victimized woman is without self-confidence and lacks the usual feminine charms, she wears a man's shirt for much of the film, and yet she is still a nice and sympathetic person. This film is exciting, tense, and entertaining in every respect. It is also surprisingly funny. The humor is dark, but does not detract from the suspense. The excellent acting, the beautiful music and the luscious photography are additional factors that make this film a great film. This is an action film that inspires, a crime novel that makes you happy and an art film that makes you dream.

But sequels are always, by their very nature, formulaic — mere re-runs of the original. This, unfortunately, is what Ocean’s Thirteen does: it repeats the same formula as the first Ocean’s film, with diminishing returns. This time, the story is centered on the casino owner who was fooled by the team in the first film (Al Pacino). The owner is now forced to sell his casino, and the team decides to make one last heist in order to get hold of a further $160 million. Most of the original cast members return, but new faces have been added, including Ellen Barkin and Bruce Willis. The film has plenty of glitter, and the cast are game. However, the plot is often incoherent and there isn’t enough humour to carry it through. It is difficult to care for these “heroes”, because they are, after all, merely a bunch of crooks. The result is a disappointment: neither the originality nor the excitement of the first two films is here.

As far as laughter is concerned, Borat provides a surprisingly large quantity in its sometimes salacious 88 minutes. Quite a few of the laughs come from shock value, but even the milder jokes are refreshingly funny. Much of this comes from the extremely competent Sacha Baron Cohen, who with a devout innocence presents Borat. His absurd antics are often predictable, but he always manages to keep the audience in suspense as to what Borat is going to do or say next, and thus the audience is regularly treated to new laughs. Borat also works extremely well as a sharp tool to deftly expose the American underbelly, which is often stupid, vulgar and sometimes bigoted. Borat is clearly an American film, and the Americans are never portrayed in a good light; they are, according to Borat, a nation of rednecks, race-haters and xenophobes. Often crude, Borat is rarely malicious. There is a certain amount of bile in Borat, but it is seldom acrimonious. Borat is a vulgar film, but it is childlike in its curiosity; the film often goes places the audience would rather not go, like to a debutante ball or a beauty contest. But once Borat gets there, the audience is glad they went.

A modern tale of a peaceful warrior. The hero of the film is Dan Millman, a gymnast who has gone to Los Angeles to compete in the Olympic games despite his parents' wishes to go to college. He is an ambitious gymnast who has dreamed of winning a gold medal at the Olympic games and who, having got there, is asked to be a clown. When on the plane to Los Angeles Dan reads the address of the director of the Olympic games and this makes him reflect. He decides to give up the Olympic games and go in search of the meaning of life. He starts on a four-year world tour, in the course of which he marries an exotic dancer and has two sons. But still he has not found what he seeks. A series of tragic events leads him to meet and study under a great spiritual master and to find the meaning of life.

The movie does not get its R rating because of foul language, but because of violent sexual content and scenes of extreme violence. Throughout the film, however, there are frequent f-bombs. It's a comedy, but the dirty, sexual jokes are the burden. I gave it a try, but I should have left the cinema when the guy behind me started to yell at the screen about half an hour into the movie. There are better and cleaner comedies. I think the public knows what it's going to see when it's this movie, so it would be unfair to lower it any lower than a ten. It's done what it had to do and leaves no question unanswered, I understand that. But it's not my kind of movie.

I still love Iron Man, but this movie didn't do it for me. It was fun and action-packed, but it was also too much a sequel to the first film, and it didn't work. It tried too hard to be a thriller, and it wasn't. The story was weak and the acting was less than stellar. This was a miss for me.

Leviathan, he still shines brightly in his eighth film, in which he again faces the mad Oswald Cobblepot, and in his mysterious duels with Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer), who possesses the notorious banker Max Shreck (Christopher Walken). Philosophical and analytic, this film version of the Dark Knight is given the opportunity to explore the hero's subconscious through the eyes of the psychiatrist, Alfred Pennyworth (Michael Gough), who emphasizes the appearance of things as the most important thing in perception. Accordingly, Batman Returns has a dreamlike look, and the whole of Gotham City is depicted as a mixture of Coney Island amusements and medieval fantasies, all enlivened by Gothic architecture and amusements like roller coasters. This city can be interpreted as a reflection of the hero's mind, where the heroes, as positive psychological phenomena, are struggling with their shadows. The main antagonist in this film is Cobblepot, a deformed man who pretends to be someone else to deceive others and gain power. The character of the penguin represents the violent and murderous instincts of the batman. The Catwoman, in turn, represents the dark side of the batman's character. The hero faces many trials in the course of the film, which deepens the understanding of the characters. For example, when the penguin traps the batman and the catwoman in a house of mirrors and throws fireworks at them, he shows the deepest layers of the character's psychology. The entanglement of the batman and the catwoman in the incomprehensible environment not only shows the mastery of the penguin in the situation, but also the deranged state of mind of the characters. 'Batman Returns' is a film that analyzes the complexities of the Dark Knight's character, and it is through these complexities that it creates an extraordinary, thinking experience that continues to shine in the memory of the viewer even after all these years. Returning to the screens to celebrate its anniversary, it has become a timeless classic.

The Chamber of Secrets is a film classic in the Harry Potter series. It follows Harry's second year at Hogwarts, where he and his friends Ron and Hermione must solve the mystery of the Chamber of Secrets. It is full of adventures, magic and suspense and is a must-watch for all Harry Potter fans. The acting is brilliant, and the special effects are wonderful. In a word, it is a great film which will entertain and delight you of all ages. Would you like to know more about the film and the Harry Potter series?

No, without the ground-breaking animation in Who Framed Roger Rabbit, there would be no actors in virtual reality playing the roles of live-action movie stars who are unwilling or unable to take part in a particular movie. Who Framed Roger Rabbit may have the best of intentions, but it’s really a vehicle for the animators and graphic artists who made it possible for Bob Hoskins to interact with animated characters like Roger Rabbit—the reason we’re here—and his girlfriend, Jessica Rabbit, who for some reason attaches herself to Hoskins’s private-eye, Eddie Valiant. The film’s plot is something about how someone framed Roger for the murder of a rich businessman, and Eddie Valiant has to clear him—but mostly because the police department, under Chief Bogus, refuses to do so. Also, the slimy Peter Tortise, who is Roger’s agent and also a bit of a creep, wants Roger to sign a contract that will end his career and give him a terrible contract that makes Eddie think twice about helping him. But at first, Eddie needs the weasel’s help in his investigation, so it’s really a misunderstanding between the two of them. But that doesn’t really change anything in the plot. The animation is brilliant, and there are some funny moments, most of them involving cartoon characters, such as Donald Duck and Daffy Duck (not the “duck” in question here). In the end, the movie is amusing, if not particularly memorable, and serves as a wonderful example of the then-ground-breaking technology of bringing cartoon characters to life.

There is no doubt that in “Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows” the film contains the most remarkable action scenes of any film featuring the character of Sherlock Holmes. Robert Downey, Jr. demonstrates his full physicality in a largely wordless scene at the beginning of the film and in this way he is able to make the rest of the film unfold with great rapidity. It begins where the first film ended, with Holmes and Dr. John Watson pursuing the evil-minded Lord Henry Blackwood. It seems that Blackwood is committing a series of heinous murders in an act of homage to an earlier, more cruel period in English history. Of course, nothing is as it seems and once again Holmes and Watson are involved in a conspiracy which threatens not only their lives but the lives of the whole country. Downey, Jr. and Law are in the best form of their lives and their interplay is the best thing about the film. Though the film is more than ten minutes longer than the first one, it does not seem to be. With its rapidly unfolding plot and rapid-fire dialogue, it has a fresher feel than the first film, although it is also benefitting from a larger budget. But the star of the film is Jared Harris, who manages to make the villainous Blackwood one of the most interesting antagonists in any of the new action films. He is as intelligent as Holmes and manages to make a character who could easily have been one-dimensional into a three-dimensional one. The scenes between him and Downey, Jr. are ecstatic and provide the film with its most impressive moments. The rest of the cast is also excellent, with Stephen Fry playing the unforgettable Mycroft Holmes. The always dependable Rachel McAdams is unfortunately underused as Mary, Watson’s wife, but Kelly Reilly does the best she can with a small role as a former love of Watson’s. The action sequences are quite wonderful, a delicious mixture of practical and special effects. One especially impressive sequence is a circular fight in a burning building, which seems to have been taken directly from the original novels. In a summer which has been dominated by super-heroes and lightweight fare, “Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows” is a refreshing change and a worthy sequel to the first film.

It is the best possible choice for all Transformers fans. This film has it all: from a witty and intelligent script to incredible special effects and a well-constructed plot, it is an absolute must-see. The story of Wreck-it Ralph is the story of a blue, red and purple hero called Ralph who uses his unique skills to win “Wacky Races” (or as he calls it “Rally Races”) in order to be the hero who can get the girl! What Ralph doesn’t expect is to have to go to school and put on a suit, which is pretty easy with his colors! This movie is one of the few cartoons with a PG-13 certificate that can really make the grandmother dress up as Ralph. It is not very long, but the short time between shots makes these short scenes seem like they last for a long time. Otherwise, I really enjoyed this movie and I say that as someone who is bored with this genre, not in the sense that I don't like it, but I find it hard to choose a cartoon and really enjoy it. As much as I love the show 'Transformers', Wreck-it Ralph is a completely different animal. If you are looking for an action comedy that is Titanic-inspired and that looks like the all-new Titanic and plays with the main premise of the series 'Transformers', then I think you will like it. IMDb: 3.5/5 I hope you will like it.

In the last moment, the director and the author use High-Fidelity records to construct a montage of well-known movie scenes. High-Fidelity was originally invented by Wally Heider, a renowned mastering engineer, to re-create the finest acoustic characteristics of motion pictures. In the course of time, however, we have made our own of it, and our favorite movie elements are now rendered by digital sound. Two separate recordings were made in different places around Los Angeles. This film uses both High-Fidelity and the most famous radio commercials.

This documentary, presented at the Sundance Film Festival in January of this year, is devoted to three gangs of New Yorkers. One of them, the Gang of One, is composed exclusively of Hispanic prisoners in state prisons and other local prisons, the others are mostly black Americans convicted or in prison because of their affiliation to street crime. While I like the story and the look of the whole thing, there are several glaring mistakes. We learn very little about the members of our gangs, who they really are, what difficulties they have had while growing up (and how to resolve them) and why some of them seem to be more criminal than others. Every character has different properties and needs, so we can switch back and forth without really giving anything the stability it requires to be in a movie. It was a very good concept during the filming, but it becomes apparent when the film is finished that there are certain mistakes that will prevent people outside the film industry from seeing it. So, I gave three stars. Despite the shortcomings, the film works because it is presented only from one point of view. There is not enough information, but many things we learn can be easily translated into everyday life. For example, the main character at one point begins to see himself as a public figure and not as a person who is merely trying to survive, he wants to use his criminal past to help the civilized people and then ends up helping the prison guards who did not even know he was in the service of the state. And yet, despite the great faith he has in his goals, he doesn't always get what he wants, he just goes for it. But despite all this, his view of himself does not really change, it just looks arrogant.

This is not a comedy, it is rather an adventure film, with a certain degree of comedy. Its story is that of two young cops who are sent to investigate a series of robberies committed in local bars and clubs, and they find themselves on the track of a serial killer, who seems to have a particular taste for women. This leads them into a world in which they must struggle against their own inclinations and against each other, in order to solve the case before it is too late. It is not clear to me whether this film is comedy or adventure, but it has something of both, and it is certainly amusing. If you are looking for something different, it might be just the thing for you.

At the opening scene, when young Sam (Ezra Miller), a twenty-year-old stoner (a real-life example, see the book Billionaire Boys' Club), gets off the bus at a gas station and rides toward the city in search of a good time and a few bucks, it is obvious that this is not a high-spirited musical noir of the best Hollywood type. Even though these films do not refrain from drugs and alcohol abuse, they also generally include a spirited and rousing musical score, but music can't even hint at the mature issues and concerns that the Village takes on with full-blown passion. The story centers around Sam, but the ancillary characters are as essential as his mother, stepfather, best friend, former neighbors, and the police, who take their jobs very seriously. It gets dark at times, like when the boy now hangs out with the wrong crowd, and he buys a barbiturate to get high, but he just does it for himself and leaves his high gang friends to be caught by the police. What starts out harmlessly, meanwhile, turns into hellish levels, with the police trying to catch the gangs and the gangs using violence to maintain control over streets and terrain. The acting is exactly what you would expect from these people who have gone through the same fights together (the guys called Bob and Tommy are not part of the Village), but one thing they do that is surprisingly unexpected is that they make sure everyone gets his due, so that this movie becomes a film with substance. This is especially true when one of them is being pressured to testify against others. By allowing him to play the good cop, or actually be the cop ("No Good Cop") as the script writers want us to believe at first glance that there are many sides to this character, and that any one of them can stand true or not, depending on whether Sam will hold back or take part in the conspiracy. Besides, everything takes place right next door, so that everyone is in close contact and all have something worth fighting for and don't want to forget about it, either from people, from gangs, or from society itself. Basically, the Village shows that it could be different than most of the other Hollywood films.

A thick, fast-paced, well-acted mystery, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is a popular and well-detailed thriller that keeps the audience on their toes until the very end. Journalist Mikael Blomkvist (Michael Nyqvist) is convicted of libel for exposing a crooked Swedish businessman and is looking for a way out of the public eye. He is approached by Henrik Vanger (Sven-Bertil Taube), the patriarch of the Vanger family, to investigate the circumstances surrounding the disappearance, which occurred many years ago, of his niece, Harriet. On the hunt for the truth is Blomkvist's assistant, the indestructible Salander (Noomi Rapace), a punk-looking loner with a photographic memory and a tragic past. Although she seems at first like a mere tool, Rapace's performance is so complex and so captivating that she soon becomes the most interesting character in the film. This fat and somber detective novel is based on the first part of Stieg Larsson's best-selling Millennium trilogy and is translated into English by Niels Arden Oplev (script by Nikolaj Arcel and Rasmus Heisterberg). It is beautifully filmed with long shots of the Swedish countryside and impressively dirt-ridden cityscapes. The music by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross is also very good, giving the film a very unnerving, anxious feeling, which perfectly suits the atmosphere of the film. But not everyone will love The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo - the plot is complex, the pace is slow and the film is a little dark and depressing. But if you like a good mystery, you should definitely see this one.

The third and last part of the Ocean's trilogy, the third part is the best. The caper is more complicated and interesting than in the first two parts, the cast is at its best, the humor is correct. George Clooney, Brad Pitt, Matt Damon return to the screen as members of the gang led by Don Ocean, who now avenges himself on a crooked manager of the casino, Willy Banks (Al Pacino). They plan to rob him during the opening of his new casino. The heist is brilliantly rehearsed, and the cast seems to be having a good time, Al Pacino is excellent as a sleazy owner, and there are many laughs. If you love the first two parts, you will love the third one.

‘Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan’ is a British-American mockumentary film directed by Larry Charles, starring Sacha Baron Cohen. It was released in the United States on 3 November 2006, and in the United Kingdom on 26 December. The film depicts the travels of Borat Sagdiyev, a fictional Kazakh journalist, through the United States of America in order to make a documentary about American culture and society. Baron Cohen plays Borat as a non-semitic, misogynistic, homophobic and chauvinistic man who is unaware of his offensive behaviour. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $262 million on a budget of $18 million. The film was generally well received by critics, and Baron Cohen’s performance was singled out for praise. The film was nominated for the Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy, but lost to Little Miss Sunshine.

You want to watch an excellent movie that inspires and motivates you? You will not find anything better than "Peaceful Warrior". The film is based on the true story of Dan Millman, a world champion gymnast who suffers a life-changing experience and goes on a journey of self-discovery. The film's acting is wonderful, especially the roles of Dan Millman and Socrates played by Nick Nolte. The film's music is also excellent. If you are looking for a film that inspires and motivates you, this is it. It's an excellent film that will stay with you for a long time.

We're the Millers is a-f-f-n-t-t-tastic. I laughed until I cried, which doesn't happen often. The cast is terrific. The story is unique and interesting, the ending is a bit predictable, but all in all, the movie is great. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to have a good laugh.

"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a darkly tense detective film that manages to mix mystery and character study in the best way. The film is based on the first book of Stieg Larsson's Millennium trilogy, and the film is directed by the extremely talented American director David Fincher, who never fails to bring a deeply realism to the story. Rooney Mara's acting as Lisbeth Salander is a true revelation. She not only appears ice-cold but also somewhat vulnerable and heartbreakingly quiet. The complexity of the character is brilliantly portrayed, making Lisbeth not only a righteous hacker, but a very complicated person with a difficult past. But Daniel Craig is a pleasant contrast to his macho James Bond and shows up as the relentless journalist Mikael Blomkvist with such eagerness and humility that it does not remind you of the tough Bonds at all. Mara and Craig's chemistry adds greatly to the film's dynamic. It is a masterful film in its heavy tone, which uses the Swedish arctic nature not only as a background but almost as a central character, which provides the bleak but beautiful background for the disturbing story. The magnificent music of Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross freezes the spine and gives the darkness and sinister atmosphere a very special and haunting feeling. The magnificent images of Jeff Cronenweth make sure the story stays fresh and carry it through the somewhat boring parts. Although the film is gruesome and brutal, the violence is never seen as extravagance, but is only used to emphasize the film's dark, malicious mood and Lisbeth's anger against the world. The screenplay is praiseworthy for its tension, which makes the narrative never get dragged away and makes the mystery go hand in hand with a study of the main characters. Finally, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a wonderful crime thriller with powerful performances, a brilliantly woven story, a menacing setting and a hypnotic sound. The film is violent and confronting like the protagonist, which makes it a movie that leaves a lasting impression.

On this basis the Ocean's Eleven, so far considered the best film of the year, is itself but a prelude to Ocean's Thirteen, which was an equally brilliant if not so elegant production, which combined the old virtues of its cast with a fresh slant on the old crime plot, and was not without its share of wit and verve, to which is added the still greater fun of watching it in colour. The film reunites George Clooney, Brad Pitt, and Matt Damon, who again give wonderful performances as respectively Ocean, Ryan, and Caldwell. The three of them work wonderfully together and effortlessly show the wit and coolness of their characters. Al Pacino, as the ruthless casino owner Willy Bank, is a welcome addition to the cast, and his performance is absorbing and complicates the plot. Ocean's Thirteen is a well-crafted, exciting story; the heist of Bank's casino is elaborate and full of unexpected turns, so that the audience remains on the edge of their seats. The film succeeds in balancing the tension of the heist with moments of humor and friendship between the cast. The film is aesthetically stunning; the splendor and glitz of Las Vegas are beautifully captured, and the filming is outstanding. The sound design is also appropriate and adds to the general mood. The film is not without its flaws; certain events in the plot are a bit too convenient and the pacing can be inconsistent. However, these are minor flaws that do not detract from the overall enjoyment of the film. In short, Ocean's Thirteen is a pleasant and entertaining film that successfully recreates the charm of the first part; it is a stylish and engaging heist film with excellent performances and a cleverly devised plot. Despite a few minor flaws, it is a worthy sequel to the Ocean's films and is a great example of the continuing appeal of the spirited cast.

Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan is a movie that is as audacious as its title. The man behind the Borat persona, Sacha Baron Cohen, gives a performance that is at once both funny and degrading, breaking through the comedy and satire barrier, and pushing the boundaries between comedy and commentary. The film follows Borat, a journalist from Kazakhstan, as he travels around the United States to study its culture. This movie’s genius lies in the fact that it is an unscripted documentary of the interviewees who have no idea that Borat is a fictional character, which makes for outrageous and unforgettable scenes that will make you laugh and then cringe. Cohen’s portrayal of Borat is nothing short of brilliant. He fully commits to the role and never breaks character, even in the most uncomfortable situations. His comic timing is impeccable, and his ability to improvise is truly astounding. The rest of the cast also does a fine job, especially Ken Davitian, who plays Borat’s producer, Azamat. It is a movie that is not for the faint of heart. It tackles controversial issues and uses the gimmick of shocking the audience to make its points. Some may find the humor offensive, but it is important to remember that this is a satire, which is supposed to make people think about the absurdity and preposterousness of our society. The movie will make you laugh, cringe and think, and frequently it will do so at the same time. The movie is not for everyone, but it is a must-see for those who appreciate this style of humor.

The film The Way of the Peaceful Warrior by Victor Salva is an uplifting tale of philosophy, spiritual awakening and personal growth. Based on Dan Millman’s novel of the same title, it features excellent performances by Nick Nolte and Scott Mechlowicz that deeply impress the viewer. As Dan Millman, played by Scott Mechlowicz, he gives a wonderful performance. He catches the struggles, the growth and the enlightenment of a competitive athlete who seeks a higher understanding of life. As his mentor Socrates, the mysterious Socrates, who is Socrates, but not Socrates, the one with the wise strength and subtlety needed for the character, Nick Nolte is brilliant. The film tells a moving story with emotional, dramatic and spiritual elements. It reflects on subjects like presence, living in the moment and the meaning of happiness, which are so often ignored in the broader filmic genre. In capturing the film’s essence, the director of photography, Sharone Meir, expresses it visually in the spiritual growth of the main character, as well as in the telling of the story. The musical score by Bennet Salvay also provides an emotional journey. The only possible criticism of the film is the slow pacing, which could be difficult for those who demand fast action. However, The Way of the Peaceful Warrior is not a film that leads you to a goal, but rather a movie that you can experience the journey. The film is an uplifting and rewarding experience for those looking for answers to life’s deeper questions wrapped in an emotional and dramatic experience. It has a certain wisdom and warmth and strength that remains with you after the credits, making it a gem in the self-help film genre.

We are the Millers is a contemporary comedy that is not at all like the other comedies we know. It surprises us, thanks to brilliant performances from its main characters and a script that is brilliantly written. Its strength is a special family: a smuggler, a stripper, a runaway teenager and a dull neighbor. The concept is new and is filmed in a way that is both familiar and unfamiliar. Jason Sudeikis, as the streetwise smuggler David Clark, is the pillar of the film. His stoic humour, which shows in his constant unease in the midst of increasingly chaotic situations, is the key to making us laugh. The impressive performance of the comedian Jennifer Aniston as the stripper Rose, who is at the same time hard, shows us a surprising emotional side of the character. The two young actors, Emma Roberts and Will Poulter, as the runaway Casey and the innocent Kenny, are also highly praiseworthy. They also have to be commended for their fine balance between comedy and emotion. What makes the film so enjoyable is its perfect blend of comedy and action. The comedy is not forced and the timing is impeccable, so there are several genuinely funny moments. The action scenes are exciting and well filmed, bringing excitement to the story without detracting from the comedy. However, We are the Millers is at heart a heartwarming story about an unusual family, which cares for each other and falls in love despite their reckless illegal adventures. Although their different backgrounds are sharp and they begin to bond reluctantly, their relationship develops in a believable and touching way. Although there are some adult jokes and controversial content, the film is packed with so many funny and crazy things that it becomes an integral part of the story rather than just shock tactics. In a nutshell, We are the Millers takes a fresh approach to comedy and ends up as a surprising and enjoyable film. It delivers continuous laughs with its actors, who are superbly comic, while at the same time creating an emotional attachment to the viewer with its occasional emotional highpoints. The film is recommended for anyone who likes comedy and a storyline.

This film tells the true story of a black student, Herman Boone, and the integration of a white school in Virginia. The film is very well written, very well acted and directed and is a must for any lover of sports films or the history of the civil rights movement. Washington gives a strong, delicate and complex performance that could have easily been a cliché. The rest of the cast is also excellent, especially Julius Tennon and Ryan Gosling as two star players on the team. The best thing about this film is its emphasis on the social and cultural context in which the events of the film take place. The film does not shy away from the painful issues of race and equality and provides a powerful and moving depiction of the difficulties of blacks during this period. At the same time, it celebrates the power of sport to overcome prejudice and bring people together. The football scenes are exciting and well-choreographed and serve as a spectacular backdrop for the team's long journey towards unity and understanding. The final scene of the film is a dramatic and suspenseful confrontation between the school and its arch-rival and is full of tension and excitement. In the end, this is a powerful, uplifting film that well worth watching. It is a reminder that, in the face of the most difficult circumstances, people can overcome their differences and achieve something great together.

The film The Dirty Dozen is a classic war film, telling the story of a bunch of misfits and petty criminals who are recruited by the military to carry out a dangerous mission behind enemy lines. The film boasts a good cast, which includes, among others, the star, Charles Bronson, as well as the brilliant and unsparing performances of Ernest Borgnine and the unforgettable Charles Bronson. The film is distinguished by its brutality. The film does not avoid brutality and bad language, which enhances its authenticity. The training scenes are particularly painful, showing the team the physical and mental hardness required for the task. The characters are also well drawn, each of the dozen having a different personality and his own story. The closeness of the characters is so well shown that the spectator easily becomes interested in their adventure and is sympathetic to them as they face their difficult task. The film is well paced, going from moments of great action to those of reflection. The tension is continuous, as the team encounters many obstacles and setbacks. However, the film is not without its defects. Some characters seem to have been left unused, while some events seem contrived and predictable. The words used and the attitudes towards women and minorities are outdated. In spite of these drawbacks, the film remains a war film that is always engaging and still manages to surprise after several viewings. His impact on the genre is undeniable, and it is easy to understand why it has become a classic of the genre. If you like wars at the edge of brutality, The Dirty Dozen is definitely worth your time.

Having seen “Shrek Forever After” I was somewhat disappointed. As a fan of the previous “Shrek” movies I was hoping to see how this one would end the saga of our favourite green ogre and his friends, but sadly, it disappointed in several ways. The first was that the storyline was too worn out and predictable. The basic premise of Shrek making a deal with Rumpelstiltskin to trade a day of his childhood for a day of ogrehood was interesting, but the movie relied too heavily on familiar storytelling devices and failed to deliver any truly original or unexpected outcomes. The second disappointment was that the characters we had grown to love were reduced to nothing more than caricatures of themselves. Shrek, Fiona, Donkey and even Puss in Boots were reduced to little more than cameos, and even Antonio Banderas as Puss in Boots was less than the usual highlight. The voice actors, who had always been one of the highlights of the movie, were also a disappointment. Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy and even Cameron Diaz’s characters seemed more like impersonations of the actors, and were not as energetic and enthusiastic as they had been in the previous films. Only Walt Dohrn as Rumpelstiltskin really worked his magic and added a much-needed dash of humour and personality to the film. The movie also suffered from inconsistent animation. While some scenes were stunning, with gorgeous colours and fluid animation, other scenes were too jerky and poorly executed. Similarly, the 3D animation seemed to have been tacked on at the last minute and detracted from the movie instead of adding to it. Shrek Forever After was a disappointing end to a much-loved series. It lacked the heart, wit and charm that made the first three films so enjoyable, and failed to give a satisfying conclusion to the story.

This film is a war movie directed by Brian G. Hutton, starring Clint Eastwood, Telly Savalas, and Donald Sutherland. The film is about a group of U.S. soldiers who are sent to find a trove of gold in enemy territory during World War II. I recently saw this film for the first time, and was blown away by the sheer fun of it. The cast is just great, with the two stars, Eastwood and Savalas, particularly outstanding. Eastwood plays a no-nonsense lieutenant whose job is to command the searchers, and he is the picture of grizzled, gruff machismo. Savalas plays “Oddball,” the driver of a Sherman tank assigned to support the searchers. Their interplay is terrific, and they offer the movie’s most entertaining moments. The plot is good, and the film is full of action. There is a nice balance between comedy and drama, and you’re on the edge of your seat the whole time. The action sequences are well staged and intense, with several great battle scenes. And the film also touches on such themes as loyalty and camaraderie, which adds depth to the characters and makes the movie more enjoyable. I was particularly struck by the music. The theme song is memorable and the music in the action scenes is suspenseful and intense. The music matches the movie’s mood perfectly, and really adds to the enjoyment of the film. All in all, I would recommend this film to anyone who enjoys war movies, or just a great action movie with some comedy in it. It is a true classic that still holds up well after all these years, with wonderful acting, an engaging story, and a great score. You can see it here:

This movie left me somewhat in the air, but it was funny and amusing enough to be worth spending money on. It has its excellent moments (the opening scene where Will Ferrell roller skates in his underwear), and also its awful ones (the spoof of The Rocky Horror Picture Show). There are many good things here, and if you like Will Ferrell and Jon Heder, you'll have a good time. Will Ferrell is Chazz Michael Michaels, an incredibly conceited ice skater who is taken out of competition for life because he hit his opponent during the performance in the Olympic games. And so now he cannot compete with the same person, who was hit, that is, the one who beat him, that is, with the man he beat, that is, the man Jon Heder. They must overcome many obstacles along the way, ranging from jealous rivals, corrupt judges, and their own egos, and finally succeed in coming together in time to achieve a resounding success at the competition.

‘Until a few years ago I was a very patriotic American. Then, thanks to the help of President Bush, Osama bin Laden, and a few other hateful people, I stopped believing in my country. I still hate them for it, but lately I’ve been trying to find reasons to believe in America again.’ As a matter of fact, I always believed in the Constitution, the sanctity of individual liberty, and the principle that, if attacked, we have the right to strike back. Now I believe in America again, but it’s more like a love affair.’ But to feel loved, one must have faith in the faithfulness of one’s beloved and also to know that at least a part of the attraction is based on one’s own merits. Somewhere along the way, I lost faith in my country. That’s why I dreaded my visit to the U-571.’ There’s no point in writing about it, because it’s all about the United States and nothing to do with the film. If someone who is a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences really wants to waste his time and his nomination on U-571, I won’t stop him.’ U-571 features Matthew McConaughey, Bill Paxton, Harvey Keitel, and Paul Fischer, and it’s an inexpensive rehash of Saving Private Ryan that will be profitable only because it’s a remake. Yes, it takes place during World War II. Yes, it features good-looking young men running around in uniforms, firing guns, and pretending they’re eager to die.’ Yes, Tom Cruise was the star of Saving Private Ryan, and Matthew McConaughey, as the star of U-571, is intended to appeal to a similar audience. But U-571 is no Saving Private Ryan. The script is too trite and flimsy, and the acting is not good enough.’ In a word, it’s a boring, hackneyed, and somewhat offensive attempt to sell World War II patriotism to a generation that has little or no sense of it. It doesn’t work, and it seems they should know by now that such a formula can never work.’

From the outstanding film of 2013, this year we present its terrifying sequel, The Conjuring 2 (aka The Enfield Case). It seems that James Wan is never to disappoint us in the realm of horror, and so it is that Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga are back as Ed and Lorraine Warren, real people who have helped countless families all over the world, and who once again will be doing their very own investigation at their home. We also get to see Annabelle at work, without her presence being too much emphasized on the screen. Perhaps it leaves more room for frightful and scary stories, which is good because it gives us hope for a third The Conjuring film. In any case, fans will be pleased with every minute they spend watching this film, even though it seems to us at times to be a bad old B movie from old times rather than the film we are about to see, but you will be fooled. Fantastic direction by James Wan with a few very exciting special effects that get under your skin while making your hair stand on end. (Such as a scene in which the whole family sleeps and then suddenly everyone hears noises coming from everywhere without you being able to explain why, and then to see a ghostly image appear on a monitor behind a family member who is watching the images on the screen)... The film gets five stars because even if this happens a lot, it's still scary, especially if you believe, like Patrick and Vera, that it can really happen. But this time, they find themselves in London and face a situation much more terrifying than the original story, where everything happened in the summer of a few years before, the summer of the Amityville Horror, and it goes further north, to the ancient English city of Northamptonshire, in the town of Harlow Hill, which has become inhabited overnight because of some kind of great event caused by some kind of unethical event in the past, but which happened too close to today for us to recognize the names, and not surprising when we later learn about the horror story in the neighborhood that led to the death of several people, among others, children in the same house, and even other people who lived there afterwards, leaving their homes abandoned, which has become popular on You tube through several horror movies.

‘Twelve Years a Slave’ is a powerful, moving and disturbing film, which anyone who wants to understand the horrors of slavery in America should watch. The film is based on the true story of Solomon Northup, a free black man, who was abducted in 1841 and sold into slavery. The film shows how he goes from freedom to slavery and back again. It is directed by Steve McQueen, a director known for making uncompromising films about difficult subjects. He does not avoid the brutality of slavery, nor does he soften the horrors of what Solomon and the other slaves have to endure. The film is not easy to watch, but it is important. The actors are brilliant. Chiwetel Ejiofor, as Solomon Northup, gives a powerful performance. He is matched by Michael Fassbender, who plays the cruel slave-owner Edwin Epps, and by Lupita Nyong’o, who plays Patsey, a slave who suffers the most extreme cruelty. But the film is not without its flaws. Some of the scenes are too explicit and the pace is sometimes slow. But these are small flaws in a powerful and important film that everyone should see. The film reminds us of the horrors of slavery and of the strength of the human spirit.

"Remember the Titans" is a moving, heartwarming film based on a true story about a school football team in Virginia that won the state title in 1971. The film follows the team, nicknamed the Titans, as they overcome the obstacles of segregation and race while striving to achieve their goal of winning the title. The film features a great cast and Denzel Washington as Herman Boone, who gives a powerful performance as a coach who unites the team and inspires them to overcome their differences. The chemistry between the actors is visible and their portrayal of the struggles and successes of the Titans is both touching and fascinating. The direction by Boaz Yakin is also excellent, and the film is full of memorable scenes and moments that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The music by Jerry Goldsmith is also excellent and it is a good fit for the time period and the film. In the end, “Remember the Titans” is a must-see film that highlights the power of teamwork, determination, and the human spirit. It is a true story that will inspire and uplift people of all ages.

Captain Phillips is a thrilling and exciting film based on the true story of the pirate attack on the Maersk Alabama in 2009. Tom Hanks is really outstanding as Captain Paulsen and captures the terror and desperation of a man who is fighting for his life and against all odds. It is a perfect film directed by Paul Greengrass, full of tension, action and horror. The supporting cast is also excellent and Barkhad Abdi plays the ruthless Somali pirate leader whose every scene is thrilling. The relationship between Tom Hanks and Barkhad Abdi is electric and creates a thrilling confrontation. The camera work is beautiful and it is both in the large shots over the ocean and in the small shots of the tension and the emotion that can be felt in this situation. It is a must-see film for lovers of action and thriller films, and anyone who wants to know more about this event. It is a testimony to the power of storytelling and the talent of the actors and the crew, which gives you a truly unforgettable experience.

And in that kingdom he and his wife Fiona lived happily ever after, while an evil sorcerer brought about the abolition of their peace. He and his wife had a son, a very young man, who was a student at a school in his town. The animation of the film is stunning, with characters and details that spring from the story. The voices of the actors are also first class, and some voices are familiar, based on their appearance in the previous film. The humor is a constant, but it has changed and adapted to be loved by children and adults, making the film a truly family entertainment. One of the most important aspects of Shrek Forever After is its reminder of the value of memories and the past. The film is a reminder that, even as we grow older and our challenges change, the people we have known and the things we have done have always been part of who we are. In short, Shrek Forever After is a very entertaining film, which will give the viewer a feeling of good cheer. Whether you are a fan of the original film, or just looking for a family movie that is funny and engaging, this is a movie you can watch.

The film Footloose from 1984 is a classic coming-of-age story, about a teen boy called Ren McCormack (Kevin Bacon), who is sent to a new town where dancing has been banned for decades. And the boy gradually finds a passion for dancing and, through this passion, ends up by breaking the hard-nosed rules of the town. The film is full of energy and charm, with memorable music and choreography that will stick in your mind and will make you tap your feet as the end of the credits play. The young cast delivers strong performances, especially Bacon as Ren, who shows the confusion and determination of a teen boy, who is struggling to find his place in the world. The most important aspect of Footloose is its message of individuality and acceptance. It is still important to be oneself and to struggle against oppressive society, and we will still find these themes relevant today. Besides, the film features an ensemble of talented actors, including Penny Marshall and John Lithgow, who bring depth and humor to the story. Generally, Footloose is a timeless classic that continues to delight audiences of all ages. Its ear-catching music, its emotional storytelling, and its powerful messages make it a must-see for anyone looking for a uplifting film that leaves you inspired and inspired.

“It’s an unusual movie that really had me on tenterhooks—and not just because of the aliens attacking the earth. I kept asking myself what would happen next, whether we would be able to defeat them before they destroyed everything, and if we would, how. The characters also kept me interested. They all played their parts in bringing the movie to a satisfying conclusion.”

This film was made in 1999, but it takes place in New York in the thirties when jazz music and swing dancing ruled. It stars Sean Penn as Emmet Ray, an autistic savant who plays the guitar like no one else, has perfect pitch and, moreover, since his brain does not normally work with language, it is assumed that he is also mentally ill, but they are mistaken in this talented musician whose problem is in himself, not in his social environment, in which a person is judged by their appearance and not by his personality, which may not always correspond to the standards of society and the way that this talented musician has a disability which is not only within himself but in the way that people around us judge people by appearance alone, without taking into account the nuances and subtleties of character. After all, not everyone is exactly the same, but somewhere along these lines lies the truth of each one of us, and when the difference between the rich and the poor or the black and the white is really slight, or the straight and the gay, or the straight and the transgender, or the straight and the gay and the confused, and then until death, Amen! hehe hehe... The film shows him in various stages of his life, from the age of twelve, when everything seemed possible, then after ten years, then forty-fifty, depending on what mostly depends, mostly due, mostly likely, maybe, maybe, if I could say so myself, I would say that it really doesn't matter what happens since the important thing is what really matters, and in the end, all of it is a perfect storm.

——I found a brief description of “Little Birds” in the newspaper “Der Standesbegot,” No. 36, November 1, 2004. A man and a woman whose bodies have been shattered in catastrophic events twenty years before the present (as explained by the director during a Q&A session at Outfest, 2005) live as shells of their former selves, mainly so as not to let anyone see the beauty of life in them, because they feel guilty at having survived while so many others perished; one gives up his will, the other makes use of hers sparingly, but still finding that many days there is none left; later, with some help, they try again, but no matter how hard they try, it might be too late, if they are to survive before letting themselves give in to hopelessness and suicide. The result is a beautiful love story about a gay couple who fall in love with each other, reliving their love and dying to each other, the woman and the man having to get up again, a relationship that’s full of life, the woman’s and the man’s, which makes the world seem darker, the less vivid colors that fade away as light fades away, the depth of which can be measured by the pity of an empty place where once they felt nothing but love. What’s your take on this description? Do you think the characters should have gone through euthanasia, or would you rather they just let their bodies die, naturally?

It's a good idea and the casting was very good. The problem with this movie is that it's long. The first 45 minutes are intense and then it starts to get boring in the second half. The idea is interesting, but I don't know if it should be a two-hour movie. The second half just doesn't recover from the first half. I wish it had a better tempo and it had been shorter. I also wish it had been about Ray and his family. The film has a very strange rhythm. The first scene has a nice rhythm and then it starts getting too frantic and fast. The second scene has a good rhythm, but then it starts to go too fast and too fast. I think it would have been okay to have made it a two-hour film, but the rhythm and the style are wrong. The acting was good, but the rhythm and style are not good. I think this movie is good, but I just wish it had been shorter and more focused. I would recommend this movie to people who like a good story, but don't want to watch the whole thing so they can see the end before it gets too boring. I can't say I loved this movie, but I enjoyed it. I think that, although this is the first Rambo movie, it's not really good, but it's still good. It also looked good in black and white. It was perfect for it. I think people who are not familiar with the story and the characters will appreciate this film a lot. The action scenes were very well done and the way the camera positioned itself was really nice. I think this movie is really good and I'm sure that people who are not familiar with the story and the characters will love it.

I'm not used to doing movie reviews, but I felt compelled to give my opinion of "Batman: The Return." The movie is a masterpiece. Tim Burton's view of Batman's world is dark, twisted, and captivating. Characters are complex and well developed, and the performances are memorable. Michael Keaton's portrayal of Bruce Wayne/Batman is a triumph, and his scenes with Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman are electrifying. The rest of the cast, including Danny DeVito as the Penguin and Christopher Walken as Max Shreck, are just as impressive. The movie's costumes, sets, and visual style are stunning. The score by Danny Elfman is haunting and unforgettable. In short, "Batman: The Return" is a must-see for any fan of the Dark Knight or of fine cinema.

“I was captivated by Room. The acting is wonderful, especially by Brie Larson, who makes the character come to life and leaves you breathless. The story is heartbreaking, but also inspiring, and shows how human nature can stand up to unimaginable conditions. Director Lenny Abrahamson brings the film to a powerful climax without ever resorting to melodrama. It is a must-see movie that stays with you long after the credits are rolled.”

American Pie is one of those films that has become a classic, and with good reason! It's a comedy that follows a group of friends who try to lose their virginity before leaving for college, and it's not for lack of comedy that we are laughing a lot. But the film is also filled with emotional scenes that are still timely today. Despite the fact that there have been a few criticisms about how women have been portrayed over time, it cannot be denied that this film has had a strong influence on the current sexual comedies.

The sequel to the fantastically apocalyptic film, Hellboy, is a marvellously noisy, visually brilliant adventure in which Hellboy and his team are up against demons, monsters and evil magicians, left and right. Guillermo del Toro's second film offers more outrageous, intricate and detailed monsters than its predecessor, and Ron Perlman brings his own enormous, naive, good-natured strength to the role of the demon. The action is fast and furious, the practical effects are breath-taking. Hellboy II: The Golden Army is a dazzling, loud, colourful, magically stimulating film that delivers in every respect.

Lots International is a non-profit, non-partisan organization that works toward sustainable development and social justice. Founded in 1974, Lots aims to address issues such as poverty, environment, and human rights violations through various programs and projects around the world. Lots was founded by Dana and Anita Beal in response to the urgent need for humanitarian assistance and sustainable development in developing countries. Their desire was to help the local communities to improve their living conditions. The organization's work involves many areas such as agriculture, education, health, and sustainable energy. It believes in the possibility of self-reliance in the local community and prefers to promote long-term solutions rather than temporary assistance. Lots works with the local community to promote development that is culturally appropriate, environmentally sustainable, and economically viable. One of the major areas of the organization's work is the promotion of reforestation, sustainable energy, and sustainable agriculture. In this way, Lots International works with the local community to help it adapt to the changes caused by climate change. Another important part of the organization's work is advocacy for human rights. It supports the indigenous peoples, the disenfranchised, and the victims of human rights violations. Lots works through awareness, legal support, and the granting of the right to demand its rights. Lots has carried out various projects in many countries over the years, including water and sanitation work in Guatemala, sustainable agriculture in Zimbabwe, and health care in Nepal. It works with local partners, governments, and other NGOs to ensure long-term and lasting changes. Lots International relies on the support of its members, volunteers, and donors for its work. The organization welcomes people of all backgrounds and people to join in its work. For its commitment and achievements, Lots has received many awards and recognition. Lots has been recognized by the United Nations for its contribution to the environment and has been awarded the Goldman Environmental Prize. As the world faces many challenges, Lots International remains committed to its vision of a more sustainable and just world. The organization works through cooperation, innovation, and support to promote the vision of a world that is sustainable and equitable.

Tiffiny Blacknell is an American civil rights activist and lawyer based in Oakland, California. She is known for her advocacy for the marginalized and fighting against injustice. Born and raised in the San Francisco Bay area, her roots in a diverse community helped fuel her passion for social justice. After graduating from high school, she attended the University of California, Berkeley, where she earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in Sociology. Her experiences at UC Berkeley deepened her understanding of structural racism and the power of grassroots organizing. She then attended the University of California, Hastings College of the Law, where she earned her Juris Doctor degree. Inspired by her own experiences with discrimination and the struggles of those around her, she focused her studies on civil rights and social justice. Throughout her career, Blacknell has worked for a number of non-profits and community organizing groups that work to challenge racial and social inequalities. She has also been a vocal advocate for police reform, playing an important role in the development of accountability and community policing policies. In recent years, Blacknell has been a key figure in the fight against gentrification and displacement in Oakland. She has worked to protect the rights of long-time residents and tenants, advocating for more affordable housing and equitable development in the face of rapid urbanization. Through her work, she has sought to preserve the unique history and culture of Oakland, ensuring that locals are not displaced from their homes by rising rents. Her work as a civil rights activist and lawyer has been widely recognized. Her advocacy has been honored by the National Lawyers Guild and the American Civil Liberties Union. She has also been invited to speak at conferences and community events, sharing her expertise on issues of racial justice and systemic change. Beyond her legal and activist work, Blacknell also devotes time to mentorship and leadership development, seeking to nurture the next generation of change-makers. Blacknell’s commitment to the struggle for civil rights and her passion for tackling systemic inequality have made her a powerful advocate for social change. Through her legal expertise, her public speaking, and her advocacy, she has established herself as a leading voice in the fight for equality and social justice.

The Patidar agitation, also known as the Patidar quota movement, began in July, 2015, in Gujarat, India. It was started by Hardik Patel, a young Patidar activist, who held a mass rally in the state’s largest city, Ahmedabad. The rally attracted thousands of Patels, who expressed their frustration with the lack of government support and representation for their community. Their main demand was to be included in the Other Backward Classes (OBC) category, which would have the effect of giving them the benefits of reservation. The Patels have been an influential community in Gujarat, traditionally, in terms of economic and political power. However, they have long felt neglected by the state government in terms of access to opportunities and resources. The Patidar agitation made the government aware of the problems of the community and the denial of their basic rights. The movement quickly gathered momentum, and protests, rallies, and demonstrations were held in several cities and towns across Gujarat. The activists, who were using social media to spread the word and mobilize support, were gaining support and influence. The government, initially caught off-guard by the scale and intensity of the agitation, tried to engage with the leaders of the Patidar community in order to address their demands. These negotiations were unsuccessful, and the protests grew more violent, with clashes between the police and the agitators. It was a clash of fires, looting, and violence, with several people killed in the clashes. The government reacted by imposing a curfew, and arresting several leaders of the agitation, including Hardik Patel. The government’s repression of the protests merely heightened the anger of the agitators, which pushed the situation to a climax. Over time, the agitation lost momentum and the leaders of the Patidar community began to focus on electoral politics. In this effort, the Patidars formed the Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS), a political party dedicated to fighting for the rights of the Patidar community. The Patidar agitation was a wake-up call for the government, which raised awareness of the need for more inclusive policies and a greater level of participation for all sections of society. The agitation also brought to the forefront of national debates about affirmative action and reservations. Despite not achieving its immediate goals, the Patidar agitation has also brought to the fore the issue of reservations in India.

Pamela J. Peters is an American photographer, film-maker and visual artist whose work explores issues of Native American identity, representation and cultural preservation. Raised in Los Angeles, she is of Navajo and European ancestry. Her mixed heritage informs her art and has a strong bearing on her work, which frequently addresses the issues of race, cultural appropriation and colonialism. She wants to change the stereotypes of Native Americans in the media, and to show the diversity of experiences within the Native American community. Her first film, a critical success, the award-winning “The Legacy of the NDNz” has been screened at prestigious film festivals all over the world. The film focuses on Native American artists in Los Angeles and the issues of community and identity they face. It skilfully uses interviews, archival materials and interviews to show a compelling and nuanced portrait of urban Native Americans. Apart from her film-making, Peters is also an accomplished photographer. Her series “Chromatic Mythologies” challenges the notion that Native American culture is static or that it belongs only to the past. In this way, she highlights its contemporary relevance. Throughout her career, Pamela J. Peters has been recognized for her unique artistic vision and her passion for addressing important social issues. Her work has been exhibited at the Autry Museum of the American West and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. She remains an active member of the Native American art community and advocates for greater representation and visibility of Native American artists. She is also an esteemed teacher and lecturer. In this role, she shares her experience and knowledge with art students and film-makers, and aims to inspire the next generation of artists and film-makers to challenge the established ideas about Native American culture and identity. Pamela J. Peters’ work has had a profound influence on the world of visual art, particularly on issues of Native American representation and the portrayal of cultural heritage.

Vandwelling is the custom of living in a van, or in some other vehicle, often for a long time. Previously associated with homeless and marginalized people, the practice has gained in recent years popularity among all kinds of people seeking a more adventurous and less conspicuous way of life. Many vandwellers have therefore converted their vehicles, equipping them with a bed, a kitchen area with a gas or camping stove, shelves, and sometimes even a portable toilet. Depending on personal tastes and financial resources, the level of comfort and convenience varies widely. There are many reasons why people become vandwellers. For some, it’s a way to travel and explore the world, while still maintaining a certain degree of stability and independence. Others take advantage of the freedom of movement and the flexibility of their dwelling place, to travel frequently or to settle down for a long time. These are also people looking for financial independence, because living in a van drastically reduces their living costs, such as rent or mortgage payments. Community and support Despite its specialized nature, vandwelling has created a strong community, which communicates on the Internet, in the social networks, and on dedicated websites. This community is also a support group for vandwellers, bringing them together to organize events, to provide them with the opportunity to network and share information. Among the disadvantages, it is sometimes difficult to deal with the local laws on overnight stays, on car parks, on vehicle modifications. weather conditions can also be a problem, because extreme temperatures or bad weather can make living in a vehicle unpleasant or even dangerous. So a comfortable and sustainable life in a van requires careful planning, organization and flexibility. Popular culture has in recent years heightened the awareness of the phenomenon of vandwelling, through the appearance of documentaries, books and the works of the influencers who share their experiences of this alternative way of life. A vandwelling that is becoming more and more accessible, more and more accessible to those who wish to try it.

Plenty is a non-governmental organization which aims to sustainably eliminate world hunger, while respecting the environment. It was founded in 2004 by David Green, who is its executive director. Its method is to use three simple, integrated methods: teaching in agriculture, the exploitation of a drip, and the use of sunlight, to allow the poorest peasants to live on their own produce. Unlike most aid organizations, Plenty does not send food to the countries where it operates, but trains local peasants to cultivate and sell their products. The organization is currently active in East Africa, West Africa and Ethiopia. It has just completed a five-year program in sub-Saharan Africa, and in 2016 it is launching a new program, Farmula, aimed at benefiting some 500,000 inhabitants of the region. It is also establishing itself in Latin America and developing a project in Colombia. In March 2012, the mission of Plenty had already reached a million people, and its goal is to reach four million by 2025. In 2006, David Green received the Social entrepreneur award from Schwab Foundation, and in 2010 the NGO was classified as a top-level charity by Charity Navigator.

Jaafar Nimeiry was an Egyptian engineer and politician who served as president of Sudan from 1969 to 1985. He was one of the great figures in the twentieth-century history of Sudan. He was known for his stability, and for having steered the country during the famine of the early eighties. Nimeiry was born in Shendi, Sudan, and studied in Egypt. He returned to Sudan in the fifties and started a political career. He became prime minister of Sudan in 1966, and was known for his modernization projects. He was also a strong supporter of unity in Sudan, and played a central role in the negotiations that led to the signing of the Addis Ababa agreement in 1972, which ended the first Sudanese civil war. He was elected president in 1969, and re-elected in 1978. As president, he introduced a number of modernizations and reforms in the country, such as the establishment of a national currency, the introduction of a national education system, the building of roads and dams, etc. However, his government was also criticized for its violence and human rights abuses, especially during the famine of the early eighties. In a military coup in April 1985, Nimeiry was ousted from power and exiled to Egypt. Nimeiry was still controversial after leaving office. In 2009, he was sentenced to death in absentia for having ordered the massacre of civilians during the famine. The death sentence was later commuted to life in prison. Jaafar Nimeiry was one of the great figures in the history of Sudan. He was known for his political stability and for the modernization of the country. But his legacy is also marked by the human rights abuses that occurred during his reign.

‘Everyone Sing!’ is a variety show on MediaCorp Channel 5 which was first aired on 28 December, 2003. The theme song is ‘Sing Sing Sing’ by the Andrews Sisters, and the musical director is Derrick Ho. ‘Everyone Sing!’ first aired on 27 October, 1998, and it was originally a Sunday night programme. But after a revamp in late 2004, the programme was moved to Monday nights and was delayed from 21:00 to 22:00. The programme’s original presenters were Mark Lee and Sharon Au. The final series was aired on Fridays at 21:00. They were joined by Michelle Saramco in season three, and in season five, Michelle was replaced by Irene Ang. Each week there was also a guest host, a local celebrity. The programme also featured The Muttons, a comedy troupe comprising Richard Low, Adrian Pang and Colin Goh. The programme usually began with Derrick Ho accompanied by a group of singers, followed by the guest host. The guest host was then featured in a comedy skit, usually accompanied by the presenters, and this skit would usually end with all the performers singing a song. Other regular features were audience participation and Karaoke King, in which audience members would compete for the karaoke title. ‘Everyone Sing!’ has won several awards, including ‘Best Variety Show’ at the Asian Television Awards in 1999 and 2005, and ‘Best Entertainment Show’ at the Asian Television Awards in 2002.

Cornelis Verwoerd (Amsterdam-Rotterdam) [13], a South African politician and economist, was born on December 29, 1901, and was Prime Minister from May 25, 1958, to February 10, 1966. [41] He studied theology and philosophy at the University of Amsterdam, obtained a doctorate in psychology at the University of Pretoria, was professor of psychology at the University of Stellenbosch, and from 1940 to 1950 served as dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. He entered the parliament as a National Party member in 1948, was named Minister of Education in 1953, and served in the cabinet of Prime Minister M. S. Cosgrove until his assassination in 1966, also as Minister of Forestry, Statistics and Tourism. As Prime Minister, Verwoerd reorganized the South African economy on the basis of the "plan of separate development"; by a separate development of race, language and religion, he aimed at establishing white supremacy and at denying all political and economic rights to all non-whites. The philosophy of separate development found expression in the government's policy of separating and segregating the population in the field of education, housing and employment. Verwoerd was killed in 1966 by the parliamentary messenger Dimitri Tsafendas, who was declared insane and, instead of bringing him to trial, was incarcerated in a mental asylum. The assassination was followed by a period of political instability in South Africa, the collapse of the apartheid system, and the award of the 1944 Holter Prize.

Born September 28, 1939, John Welch is an American scholar, jurist, and religious historian. He is a professor at the J. Reuben Clark Law School at Brigham Young University and formerly served as dean of the law school. He is best known for his discovery and publication of the inscribed bronze tablet of Lindaum, which he presented to the Smithsonian Institution. He is also well known for his research, publication, and teaching on Mormon history, including his publication of the most extensive collection of documents showing the American Indian origins of Mormonism and his establishment of the Joseph Smith Papyri Project. Welch was the principal founder of the Foundation for Ancient Research and Mormon Studies (FARMS), now known as the Neal A. Maxwell Institute for Religious Research, and has served as its general editor since its founding in 1979. FARMS also publishes the Journal of Book of Mormon Studies, of which Welch is the founding editor. Welch lived in a small town in Maine, where he was a practicing lawyer, and where he befriended a publisher, Fred L. Allen. In their friendship, Allen brought Welch some carved wooden objects that he had bought from a woodworker and sculptor named Leonard Rajsky, who lived in Portland, Maine. Among the objects was a wooden tablet inscribed with the translation of Egyptian hieroglyphics. Welch was able to decipher the hieroglyphics as a prayer to the Egyptian god Amen-Ra. He was astonished to find the Egyptian prayer inscribed in ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics on a New England wooden tablet. Over the next few years, Welch tried to find out if other similar artifacts existed, and in 1973 he traveled to Philadelphia and met with Dr. H. Richard Nelson, curator of the Egyptian collection at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology. Nelson mentioned a stone slab in the museum labeled “Catholic Table of Prayers,” which bore the hieroglyphics of Christian teachings and indicated that in the first centuries AD, Christians had made pilgrimages to Egypt and had become followers of the Pharaohs. Nelson recommended that Welch contact Dr. Aziz Atiya, a professor of history at the University of Utah. Atiya told Welch about four wooden tablets in the Library of Congress that were found in Phyladelphia. Welch then tried to find the originator of the wooden tablet he had received from Allen.

Mark William Ellingson (born 28 November, 1930, died 26 May, 2019) was an American businessman, philanthropist and politician. He founded and owned a number of international companies, including Hypertherm, Inc., and was a member of the New Hampshire State House of Representatives from 1973 to 1974. He was born in Litchfield, Minnesota, and was brought up in Swift Falls. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1951 to 1954 and was a graduate of the University of Minnesota College of Science and Engineering, where he received a degree in mechanical engineering. He founded Hypertherm in Hanover, New Hampshire, in 1957. The company developed and produced plasma cutting torches and accessories. Under Ellingson's leadership, the company grew into a world-leading corporation in the plasma cutting industry with operations in the United States, Europe and Asia. In 2018 the company was sold to Berkshire Hathaway, which was owned by Warren Buffett. Besides his business career, Ellingson was also active in politics and philanthropy. He was a member of the New Hampshire House of Representatives from 1973 to 1974, representing the district of the 7th state district. He was also a member of the New Hampshire Higher Education Council and the New Hampshire Small Business Council. He was a generous philanthropist, having donated more than $200 million to charitable causes over his lifetime. He was particularly interested in education, the environment and medical care. In addition to his charitable donations, he was a member of the New Hampshire State Committee for the Environment and a trustee of the University of New Hampshire. Ellingson died on May 26, 2019, at the age of 88.

Reterritorialization is a phenomenon characterized by the redrawing of political frontiers, the creation of new identities through the creation of symbols, rituals and social practices. It is a complex and ambivalent process that involves a negotiation of power, identity and belonging. This concept was first developed by the French sociologist Michel de Certeau in his book The Practice of Everyday Life. He argued that practices of everyday life were essential for the development of social and political identities. In this sense, the phenomenon of reterritorialization can be observed in different contexts: the creation of national identities, the establishment of political borders, the organization of local communities. It is often associated with the creation of belonging and shared identity. In the case of national identity, for example, reterritorialization involves the creation of symbols, rituals and practices that encourage national unity and pride, such as the creation of national holidays, the creation of national symbols and the evocation of national values. In the case of political frontiers, reterritorialization consists of the redrawing of borders and the establishment of new identities through the creation of symbols, rituals and social practices. The establishment of new political entities, the establishment of new borders and the establishment of new identities are examples of this. In the case of local communities, reterritorialization consists of the creation of local symbols, rituals and practices that encourage local identity and belonging. Such as the establishment of local traditions, the creation of local symbols and the evocation of local values.
